Notorious, directed by George Tillman Jr. with a sentimental touch, seems torn.
Surprisingly winning.

Chandni has martial- arts montages and Bollywood song-and-dance numbers. As tacky as the latter are, they're the sweet -- and only? -- draw of the movie. They also give this slight comedy-adventure its epic and unearned length.
As Janice, Christine Lahti is the pivot between father and son. The scenes between Janice and Joe Jr. are sweet, harrowing, movie-altering.
Credit director Christine Jeffs and writer Megan Holley with revealing the sisters' pained back story ever so gently.
You see, it's all a bit too interlocking, a cable series jammed into a couple of hours.
One of the refreshing traits of this action-nudging documentary is Tickell's willingness to wrestle his own biases.
Just as in Burn After Reading, the craftsman's pursuit of character, warts and vulnerability intact, is adamant. He makes it hard to pass up this Buck.
Davies has carried out the duty of expansive memoirs. Instead of high-tailing it away from the rigors of reminiscence, he pushes headlong through them.
As willfully chock-full of the familiar as the animated feature is, it's also a hoot.
It's comfy. It's kitschy. There are lovely enticements but also much that is simply put and beautifully, beguilingly silly.
Peralta is a compassionate filmmaker.
movie_title: Crips and Bloods: Made in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It proves Mottola has a sweet sensibility for intimate grins, as well as broad yuks.
Meet mall cop Paul Blart's evil, unfunny twin.

Rafferty uses interviews with the former players, most now in their 60s and nearly all of them touchingly philosophical, to reveal the cultural issues buffeting their campuses, but not necessarily their locker rooms.
Rich details make the immigration thriller Sin Nombre vivid and haunting.

This conspiracy thriller, starring Russell Crowe as an investigative newspaper reporter and Helen Mirren as his fire/ice editor, comes at us like the proverbial bat out of hell and keeps up a brisk rhythm built for intelligence.
Director Miranda shows real skill here.
If you're looking for the performance that might one day be characterized as Efron's embarrassing breakout role, this is a good bet.
At times, Gilroy's leaps verge on gimmick. But the shuffled deck of place and time is intrinsic to the three-card monte rhythms. He keeps us guessing, even as we know he's gaming us.
Spike Jonze, we salute you.
As sweet as it is tart.

Unlike the slew of Michael Bay- produced slasher remakes, this is not an idea-free flick. And Craven (shepherding producer on this remake) believes in character. More, he believes, in engaging what the word "horror" means.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Taken is an exploitation thriller, the sort of studio pic that seizes the worst the world has to offer (the sex-slave outrages that The New York Times' Nicholas Kristof exposed so brilliantly) to bolster its rote rhythms.
The writer-director and his gifted animators impress with stop-motion detail. Yet Coraline is short on delight
He's Just Not That Into You has a likable cast going for it. Yet it suffers from its own relationship myopia.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is powerful because this work of art also provides such a cautionary tale about the psychic burdens young soldiers carry deep inside them decades after they've laid down their weapons.
Writer-director Lurie makes dramas that whole-headedly engage ethical quandaries yet dodge easy judgments.
It was hard to shake the worry that a fizzy comedy about debt would be about as wrong for our current woes as uncorking a bottle of champagne. Confessions is definitely slight.

The International is a sleek, engaging example of a peculiar form of escapist entertainment, a favorite, in fact: It's a thriller that eases us away from our present worries without fully erasing a resonance with life beyond the multiplex.
This film is so last-century.
Emotions run deep but are never overdone.
It's the sort of brooding turn that makes us mourn Phoenix's threatened retreat from acting.
These kids aren't always all right. But they are consistently riveting.
Watchmen is a two-hour, 42 minute ride through a dystopian scape with appropriately twisting and conflicted story lines.
Wendy and Lucy is quiet, deliberate filmmaking. See it knowing you will witness an idiosyncratic take on storytelling by a fundamentally independent filmmaker.
Scott Walker: 30 Century Man (which takes its title from a Walker-penned song) makes a fascinating case that in the years that followed, Walker became the music equivalent of a 'poet's poet.'

Although Race to Witch Mountain is about space travelers, little soars here. The film is so by-the-book (and we don't mean Key's 1968 novel) that it's hard to recount it without reverting to blahblahblah.
The film's multiple strands might reflect a trend in multiple story lines. And it works to persuasively argue just how pervasive the corruption is in this community.
Tautou's sophisticated portrayal won't allow viewers to dismiss Coco as kept. Coco's talents are too pronounced, her approach to intimacy, to life, too aware for that.
What next: The Banana Splits movie?
Beeswax reminds viewers that in talkative films much can go unspoken. For writer-director Andrew Bujalski these betwixt-between, hem-haw spaces are the places to be.
The Social Network shares creative DNA with a handful of classic, zeitgeist-savvy films like Network and All the President's Men, as well as more recent fare such as The Insider and Michael Clayton.
It's called Let Me In. That demanding title says something about how the gentle poetry of the original gets lost a bit in Reeves' translation.
The movie's heart and story, both bleeding and mending, and its quartet of characters are hard to abandon -- and easy to care about.

Secretariat earns its best accolades for asking even larger questions as it highlights the story not just of a terrific horse but of his greatest champion, owner Penny Chenery, portrayed with grace, edge and a growing sense of self by Diane Lane.
Yes, there are some twists, a nice comedic turn or two, but the inevitable hook-up of dueling opposites is never anything but inevitable.
This is a strange failing for the tag team who has handled the wounded so well in previous outings.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At the end of this exquisitely poignant film, it's clear we humans are going to need a refreshed emotional skill set if we're to make sense of the real relationships we forge in our virtual worlds.
Red has ka-booms, rat-a-tat-tats and a wildly extended first date. It's edgy and fantastically gooey -- and flaunts it.
The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest is too akin to the tidying up of a television-series finale - albeit a very classy franchise with fine characters and able performances.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The story's the thing. And this one is as subtly deep as it is ridiculously fun.
Director Tyler Perry's For Colored Girls is a bold example of an artist's reach exceeding his grasp. And it's hard not to applaud his determination and grade for ambition.
In his impressive follow-up to Slumdog Millionaire, the Academy Award-winning director honors the lure of solitude while at the same time celebrating the beautiful necessity of other people.
This isn't groundbreaking fare, mind you. But Unstoppable muscles through its story of peril with crafted intensity and a few well-placed grins.
The Fighter is so muscularly and tenderly good because it trains its eye on the matches that take place between kin.
The film is a deeply compassionate, decidedly secular and somewhat plodding meditation on what matters now and what lies beyond this life.
The story of Jake, Winnie and Gordon makes us wonder if there is any other bedtime story so lulling, so disarming, as moviedom's falsely wrought "happily ever after."

Bar-Lev's documentary's greatest service isn't in recounting the Army's back-pedaling so much as underscoring how communal needs and family grief don't perfectly align. And that political usefulness may attempt to trump all other rites.
Ben Affleck's follow-up to his gritty directorial debut, Gone Baby Gone, proves the actor/director/co-writer is here, baby, here to stay.

Cholodenko and cowriter Stuart Blumberg have crafted a loving work about family that will resonate as true for those who find their experience reflected on the big screen and will be revelatory to others.
Thought the recently swapped Russian spy Anna Chapman was foxy? Hah.
The number of interviewees makes the film a signpost survey, more meaningful to film- study newbies than veterans.
Ramona and Beezus has enough charm to forgive it an unnecessary foray onto romantic-comedy turf.
The movie has a slew of goofball moments that don't add up to a consistently hilarious outing.
The news is ugly. The film is often gorgeous and wields a cumulative power to humanize potential devastation.
At times, there's an "everything but the kitchen sink" quality to the joke grab. But it works.
In hewing closely to the rhythms of war, Junger and Hetherington forgo different considerations about war.

It may come as a bit of a shock to some that the most interesting turns in the woman-on-a-quest sojourn don't belong to Roberts, luminous though she is. Those are owned by a number of misty-eyed if masculine menfolk.
Sylvester Stallone's gun-emptying, blade-tossing, clandestine action flick "The Expendables" is great fun. Sure, this declaration comes with caveats, but do you really need to hear them?
The comedy itself suffers from awkward scheduling. Though this isn't its only wrinkle.
Dano and Kline are very fine performers. So why is this comedy such a chore? The answer appears to be whimsy overload.
If you're expecting a star-propelled thriller with the usual bob, weave and one-two punch, this isn't your ticket.
Rodriguez plans "Machete" sequels. Here's hoping the next is sharper and cuts closer to the bone.
A gem of a turn by Emma Stone as high school student Olive Penderghast makes this tale of a girl, gossip and independence a smart and self-aware hoot in the tradition of the teen flicks of the 1980s.
TRON: Legacy proves once again that movies can be incubators for exciting technological and F/X advances... while leaving our need for narrative unsatisfied.

How Do You Know isn't Brooks' best. Witherspoon is too uneasy in her role. But thanks to Rudd, plus Kathryn Hahn as... George's loyal secretary and Nicholson as his father, it delivers a number of delights.
It's one of the loveliest lowest-budget features to come down the pike.
Not quite a must-see, The Voyage of the Dawn Treader is nonetheless a sturdy outing with many of the charms that have become franchise trademarks.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The latest sandals-and-swords outing, "The Eagle" has landed . . . with a thud.
When this mix of hopeful and edgy works, you get something like "Little Miss Sunshine." And when it doesn't, you get a cocktail with a bad smell, one part sunny to two parts vulgar.
Iñárritu has a delicate yet searing sense of intimacy, which cinematographer Rodrigo Prieto captures with hand-held determination.
"Something about Mary" seems a lifetime ago.
Brad Anderson's supernatural thriller is stacked to keep us guessing. Initially, this makes it watchably atmospheric. But the inconclusive hints lead to the sense that he's withholding too much.
Yes, [there are] enough nods to other sources to make Rango a bobblehead. But the movie, and much of John Logan's writing, is still pretty durn clever.

Now is the time to bestow on yourself the gift of one of the most, well, poetic films of 2010. And by "poetic," we mean rich with soulful pauses that are at once visual and aural and deeply observant of the dance of routine and quiet surprise.
Wrenching and wondrous, Dereck and Beverly Joubert's documentary The Last Lions is not a tale for the faint-hearted.
The Lincoln Lawyer is not a feat of genre-breaking design. But it is a well-oiled machine.
In the end - as well as the middle and maybe even at the outset - Paul is more often a close encounter of the middling kind.
Clayton Robey's documentary starts off wobbly before becoming a bracing cocktail of cultural, creative and personal histories.
Duncan Jones' swiftly paced and engaging sci-fi thriller is a Groundhog Day for a post- 9/11 world.
Tom McCarthy's third feature proves something incontestable: The writer-director has a way with American characters.
A wounded and hopeful take on generation gaps and the wider, nearly unbridgeable chasms created by neurological disaster.
"Hanna" plays out as a visceral fairy tale about a naif discovering a world both fascinating and dangerous.
This parable of the welcome-unwelcome guest is less a key to the ensuing domestic drama than a teasing reminder of the traditional roots of the brothers' singular skill with humor and violence.
Even 50 years later, it's easy feel how vivid a game-changer Breathless must have been when it arrived.
Despite its obvious angling to become a franchise, this Green Hornet offers little that's worth committing to even the "cult flick" chamber of your brain.
What a challenge it must be to mine our ordinary lives in ways that reveal and revel in the quietly meaningful. It is a challenge British writer-director Mike Leigh meets in Another Year.
At times, Black Swan verges on laughably old school. Still, what a brazen, bold riff on the cost - physical, emotional - of art.
Monsters is part immigration parable, part war allegory with a dose of It Happened One Night and The African Queen tossed in.
Vision is shot through with issues of power - personal, political, spiritual. Which makes it a terrifically resonant work.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: But in Love & Other Drugs, [Zwick] and Herskovitz find a groove that delivers wry writing and smart cultural observation.
Four Lions is more interesting than riotous. Consider it an example - a well-paced, clever and understated compassionate example - of a filmmaker wrestling with fear.
This True Grit makes the original almost unwatchable except as a curio.
It is an intelligent, winning drama fit for a king -- and the rest of us. And this year, there were far too few of those coming from Hollywood.
Think of the film as Gray's final monologue.
It's a nice breather indeed.

The writer-director of "Lost in Translation" and "Marie Antoinette" has made the malaise of the privileged her special turf. Ennui is her milieu. And Coppola has a talent for revealing its existential and cultural dimensions.
It's a sugar rush of candy-colored images, a beautifully drawn tale of family tradition and a bracing brain tonic about the Internet's charms and vulnerabilities.
Spacey has fun doing Abramoff doing Al Pacino, President Ronald Reagan and Sylvester Stallone. But the typically strong Spacey isn't the only actor doing commanding work here.
Blue Valentine comes on like a bittersweet cautionary tale.
Rabbit Hole, directed with grace and surprising humor by John Cameron Mitchell, is a delicate tale that shares a great deal of the hurt of Robert Redford's Ordinary People.
"The Company Men" is a worthwhile outing that takes despair - but also resilience - seriously.

It's not that the leads aren't affable. They are. It's not that they aren't nice to look at. They are. (Although the cinematography makes them look sort of blotchy.) It's just hard to care if they hook up after they, well, hook up.
Inception is a boldly constructed wonder with plenty of -- as one character describes it -- "paradoxical architecture."

The film is not just a wrenching history lesson about how easily riven a nation can become. It is also a moving tale about the struggle of Rwandans to stitch their country back together, to find a way to forgive as well as ask forgiveness.
Directed by Daniel Alfredson and adapted by Jonas Frykberg, it's more gripping than Tattoo.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's all knotted together, then unraveled with brio, by Holmes and Watson. There are fisticuffs galore, fiery combustion aplenty, and, yes, my dear reader, clever deduction.
In this beautifully tailored drama, content and style have as vital a relationship as George and Jim did. The one would be lost without the other.
It teases with magnificently tantalizing moments that don't quite add up to one grand insight. Which, come to think of it, is an epiphany of its own peculiar sort.

Rain Li's crisp cinematography gives the entwined stories different but complementary visual styles. Paul Zucker's editing supports each genre then poses fresh questions by leaping from one to the other.
The movie is often wise.
A stylish, gritty fantasy feature that wrestles with the agonies, joys and eternal wrinkles of faith and evil and the dangerous minuet they do.
Nine is, if not a grand work, terrifically tasty eye and ear candy. Two numbers -- from somewhat unexpected quarters -- are worth the price of admission alone.
Into Temptation doesn't break ground as a story, even one about redemption. Even so, Coyle's understanding of the pastoral work of the parish priest is refreshing.
Tthe script is clunky, the acting strained. Too bad. Underlying the life-and-death thriller are notions about the ways coupledom changes and challenges friendships.
Kolja Brandt's cinematography is stunning, but can't rescue the end from some wince-inducing "Ain't no mountain high enough" heroics.
Charmingly cast and phenomenally so-so.
This tale of conspiracy and corruption, directed with adrenalized pleasure by Patrick Alessandrin and written by a reinvigorated Luc Besson, has a brain.
What is real? What is delusion? What is montrous? What is decent? Shutter Island may not shatter the heart but these are gnawing achievements for a movie about madness and paranoia.
Cop Out is a little too well-shot to be full-on cheesy and too much a redux to be, well, as fresh as Beverly Hills Cop or Lethal Weapon.
The marvelously handsome wrestler-turned-actor -- proving once again better than the material he takes -- dons tights and a baby-blue satin tunic in the slight family comedy Tooth Fairy.
Simply put, It's Complicated is a hoot.
Cameron and his legion of CGI experts and skilled craftspeople have delivered a lovely, misty, dangerous world.
Yes, comedies thrive on broad strokes. But selling Americans lame images of one another as if we haven't traversed the country (if not in actuality, via television and film) is dispiriting.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Little, however, can save The Killer Inside Me from its worst impulses, its reveling in brute violence that makes it hard to watch and nearly impossible to admire, even though it's carefully crafted.
The film is gentle with its judgments. Or most of them.
The movie is as conventional a biopic as Earhart was an unconventional woman.
Full of sweetly sardonic observations, the docu-comedy is one of the funniest movies of the year.
Does this entertainment achieve a timelessness beyond its exquisite source material? Not even. Yet there's pleasure to be had and relief in feeling the filmmakers didn't Scrooge it up either.
Von Trier and cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle use sumptuous black-and-white photography and saturated color. Few movies are as beautifully wrought as this.
It seems too much a privilege to be chuckling in the theater about psychic warfare while the unfunny business of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan continues.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: We never learn why Leigh Anne is so fearless, but Bullock is the force here. McGraw is an amiable anchor to her bull-by-the-horns portrayal.
Mo'Nique plunges headfirst into a moral abyss that makes her frightening.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers hew to Dahl's intent and add fine turns of their own.
This is a willfully, skillfully crafted film with insufficient heart to the task it undertakes. It never fully connects us to love amid its ruins.
Brothers never fully earns the right to exploit Sam's crucible in Afghanistan and the angry anguish it brings about.
The visual artistry of the song-and-dance numbers captivates.
From taxi to touchdown, Reitman knows how to get us to the next destination.
Eastwood makes moving pictures that seldom collapse under the burden of sentiment. He has a muscular understanding of how kernels of wisdom needn't become caramel corn.
The film swims in an anguish not solely the result of Mia's coming of age -- and yet, it surfaces for air in ways compelling and uncompromising.
Red Riding Trilogy, with its remarkable performances, its brilliantly constructed puzzle, its dispiriting cycles of violence, isn't an easy ride. But it is an exhilarating one.
This Is It isn't quite extraordinary as non-fiction film goes. Perhaps it's something better: a work of generosity.
Damon's the anchor, a fine one at that, but even he can't seem to hold the filmmakers' attention for long.

It's not a classic, but it's sturdy enough, thanks to Gyllenhaal and a sly and grousing turn by Alfred Molina as Sheikh Amar, a scoundrel with a heart of gold -- or at least, a ticker very interested in riches.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A veering, careening joy ride of excess and heart.
What makes Splice morally compelling isn't the bioethics quandaries it raises so much as the way it delves into parenthood.
What Convention sets out to do, it does with understated candor.
Consider the oft-amusing, terribly clever G-rated sequel Toy Story 3 as the brightest student in the class delivering a very fine B paper.
Were James Brown still with us, he'd have to at least share his "hardest working man in showbiz" honors with Rivers.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Directed with zest by Mike Mitchell (from a script by Josh Klausner and Darren Lemke) and shot in 3D, this final Shrek sequel has plenty of verve.
Give in to the ridiculousness, and Knight and Day is frisky fun.
It's a crude and decent-hearted outing.
While the new Eclipse remains foremost a flick for devotees, it has sturdier pleasures and takes on its emotional ambitions with renewed dedication.
Delightfully demented and unique.
Provocative and disturbing.

Cinematographer Yorick Le Saux's elegant images of buildings -- stony exteriors, lux interiors -- and weather-worn statuary suggest centuries-old tradition but also invite a meditative or appreciative silence.

The finale manages to be tasteful and exploitative at the same time. It touts forgiveness while being mildly infuriating. Such is the danger of borrowing from the enormous to merely entertain. If that.
Jennifer Lawrence gives a stirring turn in a gift-of-a-lifetime role.

So many stories come packaged in hyped genres that we can forget how much character can hold sway. Watts, Bening and Washington -- along with a fine ensemble and a humane director -- make sure we remember.

In a marketplace mad for 3D, it's good to see a dramatic adventure built for young audiences (and the rest of us) that achieves its depth the old-fashioned way, with characters struggling and maturing.
Superhero Stark remains intriguing.
Audiard never overplays the new experiences facing Malik, be they violent or touching. Yet his tender regard for our complicated hero shines through.
[A] lyrical, loving documentary.
One of the pleasures in this wise, emotionally bold PG ride is there's nary a wink, nudge or nod to popular culture.
Babies begins to gain telling traction as the small triumphs start to come faster toward the sixth-month mark. Things begin to look up once the infants begin to, well, look up.
A stylish, lean and, well, familiar outing.
The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo grapples with far more than "whodunit." And it does a handy job of answering that question, too.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay, by Josh Klausner, proves that the easy laugh isn't always the best.
This expertly restored black-and-white work is a thing of wonder.
It doesn't soar (though Pegasus the winged horse is captivating).
Nicolas Cage is a hoot, a hollar and a fright as Damon Mac ready, a.k.a. Big Daddy. How can he be otherwise? He's a good cop gone mad.
[Demi Moore is] She's one reason to see writer-director's Derrick Borte's zeitgeist fable The Joneses. Though she's not the only one.
The Square is a morality noir in which there's very little onscreen morality.
Bong is a talent to heed.
There is plenty of good-guys-vs.-rotten-apple tension here.

With its clunky chalkboard chapters and a parade of static talking heads too often repeating the filmmaker's underlying theme of political corruption and union myopia, it's a C theatrical experience. Maybe a C+ for right intentions.
Excess is abundant in photographer and music-video director Floria Sigismondi's energetic debut.
Ten minutes into it, you won't need superhuman senses to realize it won't be a great movie.
Happily, Carrey is back with his trademark facial expressions and outrageous physical comedy.
Once word gets out about how painful and laughably bad this film is, it will tank faster than you can say 'Bennifer.'
Lane does a superb job. Kudos also go to director Wells for delivering a delightful, clever script.
It's entertaining, but if you can't stomach brutal violence and gunfire, it's best to skip this one.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Lost in France is both a touching oral history of beloved indie record label Chemikal Underground and a thought-provoking look at how the performance and production of independent music has radically shifted over the past two decades.
Tcheng gets under Simons' skin - we see the designer's methods of work, insecurities, vulnerabilities and his ability to cut through the noise.
For those of us in the reading and writing business-for anyone, really, who loves the written word-the movie has a powerful resonance. It reminds us that literacy can't be taken for granted.

The imposition of a fairytale quest structure turns the surrealist wanderings (and wonderings) of a free-associating dreamer into a brusque crash-zoom, as Alice hurtles towards her appointment on the good-versus-evil battlefield.
Is this a film about art, or about film as art? That's the question asked by Sophie Fiennes' ravishing, hypnotic record of the work of Anselm Kiefer.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Young Adult is much funnier and infinitely more savage than Cody's earlier collaboration with director Jason Reitman, the cute but rather cosy Juno.
It proves again that films made for grown-ups can be more nimble-footed and fresh-faced than anything aimed at the youth market.
Albert Maysles's last film is a typically deft exercise in subtle observation.
Mickle and co-writer Nick Damici give themselves plenty of time to tease out their themes and ladle on the tension.
Bolstered by an atmospheric score by Nils Frahm and masterful performances by its young leads... the result is a lively and engrossing exercise in creative swagger.

Underlying it all is a strongly feminist message about power, money and male fear of what might happen if a woman should gain possession of both - agreeably subversive stuff to find in a crowd-pleasing period drama.

The film finally adds up to more than the sum of its well-wrought parts, offering a quietly profound insight into this young woman's attempt to navigate a world that is both familiar and brutally alien.
The film is uproariously funny but painfully close to the bone in a world where once again the lunatics have taken over the asylum.
Tangerine takes you by the scruff of your neck into a parallel world where tattered reality is shot through with neon flashes of colour, clarity and pure emotional honesty.
First film by gifted scripter-helmer Celine Sciamma nails the aching doubts and offhanded cruelty of 15- and 16-year-old girls.
Feature debut by scripter-helmer Nic Bettauer is a small, affecting road movie peopled with sharp vignettes.
Speculative pic on how Gaul's answer to Shakespeare found inspiration in an involuntary gig giving a nobleman acting lessons is sumptuous, touching and often laugh-out-loud funny.
Portrait of career criminals going about their menacing business is visceral without being interesting.
Wonderfully engaging.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An achingly sincere but protracted effort.
A story of initiation, friendship, teamwork and sacrifice set on the vast ochre savannah of Kenya, Masai: The Rain Warriors builds slowly -- very slowly -- to a powerful and touching finale.
Talky, cynical tale of ruthless office politics tested in the great outdoors is far more energetic than most mainstream French pics.
Intrigues by virtue of its cast and premise but -- at least for native English-speakers -- is marbled with conceptual clunkiness verging, in places, on laughable.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Situational humor is structurally sound, and yet the aggregate result of all this Sturm und Drang is more distancing than involving.
This moody, more-bitter-than-sweet ode to anxiety is intense adult fare reinforced by effective no frills lensing.
The Moustache provides a feast of sustained tension.
Visual bravado and narrative teasing lead nowhere in particular, which is frustrating in the presence of so much raw talent.
Consistently engaging account of decent folks scraping by in a former steel town builds suspense with a keen eye and a sharp ear for the pride of workers who no longer have work.
Despite a smattering of images that evoke pointillist or impressionist paintings -- or maybe pixilated Navajo rugs -- the proverbial actor reading from a telephone book would be more entertaining.
The intense feelings, reckless experimentation and sheer obliviousness of adolescence are convincingly portrayed in slightly overlong On Fire.
Maestro of pulse-quickening simulated sex Jean-Claude Brisseau offers a frequently funny, authentically arousing and seemingly autobiographical tale.
A sharp, efficient package.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A tight little emotional thriller about a music lover who becomes a musician-hater.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The cinematic equivalent of sipping homemade lemonade on a balmy afternoon.
movie_title: Najac Calling Over to You, Earth (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Far from inundating viewers with a litany of facts, Jan Kounen has his lilting camera drift through the colorful streets of India, recording Amma from a you-are-there vantage.
Both pertinent and discomfiting, this sober, well-cast drama remains quietly riveting, despite its 140-minute running time.
Exploring unresolved loss with docu-like veracity, this intimate, disturbing tale will prove more frustrating than enlightening for many viewers, despite its conversation-sparking premise.
Awash in extreme close-ups, elliptical run-up to the heist is majestically tedious and denouement predictable.
Pic is deft, entertaining and, in its reverence for name-dropping scholarship and the paths by which the chosen few make a name for themselves, thoroughly Parisian.
Uproarious romp, grounded in believable if gleefully implausible human behavior, is a model of comic timing.
Every variation on "disgusting" you can think of -- and many you can't -- is here. It's a veritable "Cluckwork Orange," but without the sentimentality.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A naive fairy tale splattered with blood.
Sounding intriguing enough in concept, Death misses the mark onscreen in a way adaptations of deceptively cinematic novels often do.
...the wrenching tale has something for anyone who likes their melodrama spiked with palpable tension and genuine suspense.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Adapting a book by semi-notorious novelist and critic Jules Barbey d'Aurevilly (1808-89), Breillat freely stamps her strong and singular feminine insights on a man's material.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Moral ambiguity is the real star of Ben Affleck's helming debut, Gone Baby Gone, an involving Boston-set tale of mixed motives, selflessness and perfidy in the wake of a 4-year-old girl's disappearance.

Sure to inspire debate in France and Germany and of obvious interest to anyone who follows the roots of modern international terrorism, doc probes gray areas in the colorful life of its controversial, limelight-courting subject.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Lensed with skill to no particular end.
Thesps are clearly having a field day.
In its embrace of communal life on a shoestring, its contempt for bureaucracy and authority, pic shares many points with Otar Iosseliani's recent Gardens in Autumn.
Remains in conventional (if enjoyable) movie territory from start to finish.
An earnest, frequently funny comedy about stateless persons and the looming cliches that make Muslims and Jews so wary of each other. Completely accessible and non-threatening.
A message-based actioner that's fast, dumb fun.
Impressively mounted and involving pic should be greeted with applause.
Frequently inventive and playful pic conveys exactly how it feels to kick oneself for words spoken in anger and be unable to make amends because a cruel universe won't cooperate.

Third installment in Jacques Nolot's trilogy on the pragmatic side of gay life finds the straight-shooting poet of matter-of-fact sexual transactions in fine narrative form, exhibiting his aging body and mindset without a trace of vanity.
A straightforward docu with a slightly mystical heart, Back to Normandy plays like a meticulous personal project on which we are permitted to eavesdrop.
Any stragglers still unconvinced that animation can be an exciting medium for both adults and kids will run out of arguments in the face of Persepolis.
Thinking man's horror story should have a tasty future.

Script's veneer of invention doesn't always lift characters or situations above cringe-making cliche. But well-cast thesps imbue pic's social experiment with a fair quotient of believability, no matter how extreme the situations.
[The] filmmakers seem so reluctant to spell things out that the viewer is likely to remain indifferent to any or all of the ably-lensed personal crises coming to a head.
Deconstructs time and space with Einstein-caliber dexterity in the service of a delectably disturbing tale of revenge.
As the overlong pic wears on, it's hard to care whether the puzzle pieces of the protags' lives fall into place or not.

Sometimes funny, sometimes wrenching and persistently bittersweet, tale is a fascinating account of strength and solidarity, bolstered by vintage photos, edifying newsreels and winningly frank interviews.
Once story is safely out of the present-day prologue and into the extended flashback of pic proper, all is well and thoroughly enjoyable.
Told with a blend of visual mastery and emotional intimacy, ambitious venture sustains a special melding of romance and pragmatism that should engage discerning audiences.
Consistently engaging, non-judgmental and cumulatively powerful two-hander marks a noteworthy feature debut for Israeli helmer Keren Yedaya.
Failing to invest famous characters with the depth to break free of a made-for-TV feel, earnest misfire does make one want to read up on the real Modigliani.

Breillat is militantly in favor of personal and intellectual freedom -- and that aspect of her mission as an artist is laudable. But it's the way she expresses it on film that lends itself to giggles and guffaws.
Pic's ace in the hole is its extremely authentic feel when it comes to the landscape of Afghanistan and the people and perils one might encounter there.
Valiant attempt to innovate in the well-trod realm of Boy Meets Girl doesn't quite coalesce despite a thoughtful and distinctive visual approach.
Gives Euro-style ambient guilt over money a sensitive and bittersweet (if slightly overlong) treatment that's worth a detour.
Shines thanks to splendid visual execution and sterling perfs from leads Sandrine Bonnaire and Fabrice Luchini.
Valiant attempt to create a modern fairytale ends up being frustratingly creepy instead of haunting and memorable.
[Brown Bunny] sports the narrative complexity of War and Peace compared with Twentynine Palms.
A rousing, well-crafted romp packed with ingenuity, duplicity, close calls and heroic gestures, Bon Voyage is true to its title.
Despite bracingly peculiar premise and astonishingly fine perf from Gary Oldman, pic is an honorable failure.
[Sports] admirable energy, full-bodied characterizations and narrative urgency.
Feisty fun from start to finish.
Cage makes an unusual but pleasantly haunting debut behind the camera.
Lavish and florid, the corny venture falls into so-bad- it's-good territory.
Consistently silly, occasionally funny but mostly forced.
A pleasingly low-budget demeanor.
Weaves a simple premise into comedy gold.
movie_title: The Dinner Game (Le Dîner de cons) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Dramatically dense, neatly thesped and visually involving.
Uneven but quite pleasant.
Auds craving for a mix of full-bore, Droog-style ultraviolence and shameless sentimentality made palatable by name thesps will find what they want in Jet Li showcase [Unleashed].
A gem of comic melancholy.

Sparkling production design, a jubilantly retroretro score and a genuine flair for using the film and TV vocabulary of the '60s to revisit colonial arrogance put pic in the same conceptual ballpark as Austin Powers.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyable as a sardonic glimpse of unspoken codes at the intersection of politics and business.
A captivating docudocu profiling the some strange, some adorable -- but all endangered -- denizens of the North Pole.
Enjoyably peppy if not particularly memorable.
Choreography may please dance mavens but score is rarely memorable and enchantment only intermittent.
The message is powerful with storytelling to match.
A riveting pageant of human behavior on both sides of the law unfolds with humor, poignancy and a measure of inherent majesty.
movie_title: The 10th District Court: Moments of Trial (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Centered on people of limited means, pic intelligently explores the ways in which the demands of a tightly knit religious community can be stifling or liberating depending on one's own temperament.
[The] first Turkish docu ever made on 35mm plays beautifully on the bigscreen where war buffs, historians and students of human nature will enjoy it.
For those who buy into Blier's style, touching -- and funny -- human truths come shining through.
movie_title: Combien tu m'aimes? (How Much Do You Love Me?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fans the flames of passion, undoused by time or clunky exposition.
Rock solid visual assurance carries the day in this tale of few words.
A treat for grown up audiences with an ear for sardonic dialogue.
A topnotch central perf by the attractive and convincing Fejria Deliba combines with well-observed details that bring the tricky assimilation of a generation of immigrants to life.
Deftly juggles gore and suspense.

Offers the kind of eye-poppingly intimate footage of various critters evolving from the fetal stage or eating, strolling, fighting and courting that can only be obtained via infinite patience with special equipment in exotic locations.
Hypnotically banal in content but strangely riveting in execution, whatever the opposite of an action picture is, this is it.
There's very little wit, charm or even energy on display.
Elegantly written, well-thesped comedy is too hermetic and bittersweet to be laugh-out-loud funny, but sustains a fairly successful ratio of uncomfortable situations to amusing solutions.
An eye-opener about the true dimensions -- both physical and mental -- of the barrier being built to divide Palestinian territories from Israel.
It integrates ordinary pleasures, anxiety, joy, doubt and loneliness into a slightly melancholy portrait that's deceptively simple but never dull.
An entertaining ensembler marbled with wit and heartache.
Another deft, deeply affecting variation on Krzysztof Kieslowski's recurring theme that people are interconnected in ways they can barely fathom.
Told primarily via body language and facial expressions with a minimum of dialogue, beautifully observed, emotionally intense tale is an ambitious and rewarding outing for Frederic Fonteyne.
A gently subversive outing full of nicely limned characters.
Mirica makes a very assured feature debut, juggling an accretion of sinister clues and slow-burn allegiances at a low-key pace kept humming thanks to attention-getting widescreen panache.
This is a crowd-pleasing bittersweet comedy in which tragic circumstances are attenuated by moral support from unusual quarters.
In Bed with Victoria (Victoria) has its moments but too often falls short of the "oomph" that renders a comedy special.
Nobody in Jiale's extended family is happy for long but neither are they miserable. The film achieves a quietly impressive balance as human behaviour swings from serious to funny and back again.
An unflinching look at deteriorating working -- and non-working -- conditions for the common man and woman in contemporary France.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Messina is a young talent to watch.
Despite its running time, the film's suspense lasts until the final frames. The musical score -- both on-and-off key -- is splendid.
What's on screen is, for the most part, both suspenseful and entertaining if comfortably familiar.
A sustained visual tour-de-force that's the opposite of a popcorn movie.
Sustains a tone that acknowledges that life is a blend of good news and bad but that kindness and compassion can cut through a great deal of soul-crushing adversity.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jean-Jacques Annaud adds another visually bold adventure tale to his filmography with Wolf Totem.
A Frencher-than-French tale of deeply-anchored yet partially thwarted romance, Arnaud Desplechin's My Golden Days is touching, involving and very well acted.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Alexandre Arcady's film is wrenching and politically astute.
Audiences who like twisty narratives laced with wrenching revelations should be pleased with this satisfyingly downbeat thriller.
Touching and entertaining in equal measure.

Bittersweet comedy's perfectly chosen multigenerational cast ably demonstrates that if money can't buy love, it sure can purchase lots of obsequious service from four-star hotel staffers and costly goodies from laughably pricey boutiques.
Assembled with flair, Magician: The Astonishing Life And Work Of Orson Welles is a lively and entertaining documentary that positively swings with informative forward momentum.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Chazelle finds the cinematic equivalent of the white hat/black hat showdown in a classic Western but imbues it with equal parts physicality and intellectual grit.
It's said that one must suffer to be beautiful. Thrilling in places, self-indulgent in others, Saint Laurent strongly suggests that one must suffer to make others beautiful.
Just about everybody in The Immigrant may have misplaced their copy of the Declaration of Human Rights, but a perfectly sung operatic note needs no administrative documents to work its magic.
First-time director Jeanne Herry delivers a sardonic comedy propelled by spot-on performances in Elle l'adore.
A rewarding take on coupledom told with satisfying visual flair.

With unpretentious poetry to spare, Dutch illustrator and animator Michael Dudok de Wit winningly expands to feature length the verve that has been evident in his award-winning short films for two decades.
Suspenseful and unsettling from first frame to last ...
Always watchable but not transcendent, Cedric Kahn's character study builds its portrait via landscape, work, prayer and friendship.
A fearless, powerhouse performance by Laetitia Dosch infuses every frame of Montparnasse Bienvenue (Jeune Femme).
More often irritating than involving although it is fetchingly shot and features a few strikingly original elements. Chalk this up as a benevolent misfire in an honorable filmography.
A complex and involving compound portrait of the upheaval caused by creeping theocracy and ingrained attitudes.
Wielding an entertainingly sharp narrative scalpel throughout incident-rich Number One, (Numero Une) Tonie Marshall posits that women getting promoted solely on merit is a quaint notion.
A cascade of clichés made palatable and cumulatively touching by a very fine cast.
Should be shown on screens large and small wherever quality docs find a home.
Marlina The Murderer In Four Acts weaves basic elements into a tale worth telling splendidly accompanied by a sit-up-and-take-notice musical score.
movie_title: Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a crowd-pleasing winner that's educational, touching and hilarious. An infectious live-for-today energy permeates every frame.
A strange and forthright cinematic object with considerable rough-hewn charm.
movie_title: Jeannette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc (Jeannette l'enfance de Jeanne d'Arc) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A lot happens in just 75 minutes of screen time, offering viewers emotional fallout that lingers much longer.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally satisfying, cinematically deft look at interwoven fates.
Even though there's an enormous amount to look at and digest, little of this film is truly memorable or thought-provoking.
Suggesting that there's anything wrong with what's on screen would be akin to criticising a bunch of kids having a great time at a playground.
A relativity unusual topic - how to relate to one's own body and to other people after battling and beating cancer - is explored in a leisurely and ultimately touching manner in De Plus Belle.
The final result is seamlessly convincing.
A bittersweet delight written to order for two consummate performers who inhabit their diametrically opposed characters with satisfying élan.
The style is minimalist and meandering but does eventually add up to an unsettling portrait of three generations connected by blood if not affection.
A battle sequence is never far away and motivations remain credible within the parameters of popcorn-movie silliness, played straight.
Bertrand Bonello's Paris-set Nocturama does a riveting job of observing a group of young people who think it's a good idea to do what should be unthinkable.

This increasingly unsettling tale sets the bar as high as electrified prison walls and would probably veer towards silliness were it not for the very fine work by its two leads Adele Exarchopoulos and Guillaume Gallienne.

Yves Saint Laurent does an effective job of condensing two decades in the life of the justly celebrated clothing designer into a series of pithy vignettes carried along by genuine emotion and a superb central performance.
If you see only one black and white film disguised as a road movie this year or next, make it Nebraska.
A solid, consistently compelling look at the big questions of life laced into the framework of a transformative meeting of the minds under dicey circumstances.

This over-eager approach will grow tiresome for many viewers but, in its defense, an overload of hand-made creativity feels a lot healthier than watching endless CGI or CGI + 3D assault one's retinas.
Despite an abrupt narrative approach, formative episodes in Mesrine's larger-than-life reign flow together well enough to yield a frequently gripping whole.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The spiritual, historical and practical complications of being Jewish get a funny and touching workout.
The screenwriters have taken liberties with chronology that may upset fashion purists but the broad outline of alliances, influences, lucky breaks and tragedy rings true.

John Glen's take on the Genovese explorer adds up to perfectly serviceable commercial entertainment -- there are a few moments where Kirk Douglas or Charlton Heston would have felt right at home.
A dialogue-free bug saga carried along by brilliant sound effects, an epic score and delightful animation in the service of an incredibly basic yet endlessly inventive story.
movie_title: Minuscule: Valley of the Lost Ants (Minuscule - La vallée des fourmis perdues) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Kate Winslet continues an uninterrupted line of fine performances with the modest yet affecting Hideous Kinky.
The franchise is still kicking -- but not very high.
Boasts a riveting central performance by a carefully controlled, lovingly lit Juliette Binoche.
Chock full of engaging narrative developments, with splendid sets, an appealing original score and gung-ho performances, there's still something perplexingly peculiar about the whole shiny package.
This occasionally lavish, often clunky venture is consistently watchable if not terribly memorable or distinctive.
While not a classic, this is a pleasantly disturbing, nominally voyeuristic romp in the territory Chabrol knows best.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Arnaud Desplechin's A Christmas Tale is an intricate, accomplished patchwork of sometimes nutty but always believable human behaviour.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Catchy entertainment for kids and adults...
A full-bodied, funny and gloriously unpretentious ode to family, friendship and the meaning of life.

It's a testament to the production design that one quickly gets caught up in the story without ever completely losing the "ooh-ahh" factor. Ominous, wall-to-wall music bolsters the appropriately uneasy mood, and the bittersweet conclusion is satisfying.
A winning blend of dark and bittersweet, aimed more at adults than kiddies, but suitable for all ages.
Incident-packed tale is marbled with black humor but Israeli gumption triumphs by default.
:ags in the middle, growing more interesting -- if hardly more original -- only as the situation deteriorates.

Is The Intouchables an enjoyable movie if you overlook a few potentially queasy-making scenes? Absolutely. Is it great filmmaking in the neighbourhood of art? Nope.

A delightful melding of visual style and narrative pirouettes.
The theme of reconciliation - between man and woman, father and son, brother and sister, man and animal - feels kind of perfunctory and over-reaching.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

A visually splendid and emotionally satisfying animated adventure for all ages,
An action-packed distraction for popcorn munchers who found the dialogue and plot points in Transformers: Dark Of The Moon too subtle.

Colorful performances!
A powerful and disturbing movie!
The casting is great. Hopkins, Banderas and Zeta-Jones all look the part and breathe life and passion into their roles.

movie_review_blurb: He makes a few misguided choices, but the intentions are admirable and the film ultimately wins audience sentiment.

Imaginatively plotted destruction abounds.
Its allure lies not only in its exotic creatures, but also in its depiction of human kindness.

movie_review_blurb: It's all very juvenile, yet there's a level of imagination one wouldn't expect from such fluff. It's the sort of visionary immaturity that bridges generations.

The film resides in the realm of mediocrity, dreadful in spots, enjoyable on occasion, and disposable throughout.
The talk is engaging and the action riveting.

Just an ordinary tale of rich people in crisis.

Pointless without pause.

A humane portrait of a troubled household and, by extension, a troubled country.

Cry_Wolf is not_scary.

The debut film from performance art crossover Miranda July delivers an unlikely blend of irreverence and optimism. For all its dark humor and fringe qualities, the movie never descends into easy misanthropy.
