There are bound to be pictures bigger, dumber and more punishing than this one released during the summer, but at least the warm weather also will bring a wider range of alternatives.
It's a mutant piece of entertainment that's bound to leave fans feeling betrayed and everyone else befuddled.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Viewers may be left feeling as frustrated as the characters, but the blurred storyline is also what makes the movie unique and memorable.
Silly, mindless and derivative, but Duvall brings some bite to the proceedings and Ferrell is dependably amusing.
In a way, the movie title refers not only to the characters, but also the audience. Enduring this harrowingly derivative tale, viewers will wonder where the filmmakers' minds were.
Even though the dramatic aspect doesn't quite click, it's a watchable experiment.

For many, the Sith finale will redeem all three prequels. Others will wonder why Lucas wasted so many dollars, years and pixels on a story that could have been told in one film, or better yet, not at all.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's a case in which the director should have put his ego and personal issues aside to create a more conventional life story.
This doesn't signify progress for the computer-animated medium. If anything, it's regression.
A sports memoir fringed with punk rock clamor.
House of D is intensely incompetent.
Engrossing from its first shot to its final fade.
The funny stuff is too scattered to forgive the buffoonish storyline.

Audiences may wonder why a picture with Robert De Niro, Kathy Bates and Harvey Keitel would be so bereft of hype. After you've endured the film, all 120 airless minutes, you'll understand the rationale behind the quiet release.
movie_title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Heights is just as contrived as the entertainment it mocks.
Herbie moves along swiftly enough, but it suffers from a poor sense of direction and certainly can't keep pace with the original.
Rize isn't a revolution. It's a fashion shoot.
In George A. Romero's Land of the Dead, it's depressingly evident that the horror pioneer has been surpassed by his imitators.
A mess of pretense, too hip and cool to concern itself with emotional logic or narrative cohesion.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Like its heroine, Caterina in the Big City is delightfully unclassifiable, a modest, unassuming movie, but a rule-breaker nonetheless.
Modigliani is slow, shamefully cliched and disjointed as a cubist portrait.
The movie is devoid of subtext because every idea is expressed with bold punctuation.
Even though Murderball founders in the sports department, it's a champ as a character-driven piece of entertainment.
The comic book adventure is a fun, escapist change of pace from all the politically weighted popcorn fare on the scene this season.
The story crash-lands in contrivance, losing its way in the third act.
A ripped-from-the- headlines story rendered with wit, imagination and no small amount of moxie.
It's a game of cinematic Survivor that takes on broader meaning, exploring film as a mode of self-expression and the latent insecurity that drives artists to deliver works of greatness.
It's a dead man's party driven by inspired sight gags, witty repartee and likable, dare we say, cuddly characters.
Like last year's Seabiscuit, the movie spends too much time harping on ancillary bustle, and not enough watching the title character put his hoofs to work.
Gondry still lags behind Jonze in rendering cohesive stories and human connection from Kaufman's adventures in self-analysis.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: More an interesting experiment than an engaging piece of entertainment.
Visceral thrills and mordant humor are on this film's agenda, and it serves up both in style.

Just as the central criminal steals the identity of his victims, Taking Lives lifts traits and style from other movies. Both do so relatively successfully, until they bungle the job in the final half-hour.
Slightly more digestible than its predecessor.
Offers a couple of well-filmed showdowns and lots of pretty landscapes, but you need more than scenic views and stylish action to chronicle a life, especially one as controversial as Kelly's.
An unsettling look at Third World politics in the guise of a love story.
Even though the film runs a mere 77 minutes -- brief even by family fare standards -- it's still too large a dose of Barr.
A lunatic whirl of a film that will leave audiences as giddy and punch drunk as the Shaolin team's opponents.
It makes for a satisfyingly excruciating experience.
The movie never rises above mediocrity and at times, devolves into amateurish histrionics.
The picture feels fresh and audacious thanks to its smart script and sassy cast.
Comes off like a stodgy lecture rather than a rousing saga.
At the bottom of it all lies nothing more than a by-the-numbers Hollywood thriller.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: For those who can stomach two hours of brain-dead brutality, the film has more laughs than most comedies.
The story comes up hollow in the end.
The narrative momentum may sputter, but the vivid performances keep the film from dragging.
Frothier than the sweetest drink at Starbuck's and deft in the slapstick department, the actress turns a generic female version of Big into a raucously charming teen fairy tale.
A transcendent, masterfully told story.
This is one film that should be stamped, 'Return to sender.'
One of the lamest comedies in recent memory.
The experience of watching the film is best described as deadening.
It lacks the wit and depth to make it anything more than a mediocre tale of Hollywood malcontents.
It's not an easy film to watch, but it is a memorable one.
One the best '70s tube lampoons since 1995's The Brady Bunch Movie.
A chill-deficient suspense flick that shares too much common ominous ground with [Judd's] past thrillers.
The salsa routines are fittingly sultry, but not nearly torrid enough to redeem the leaden dialogue and labored emoting that surround them.
It is a modest meditation on human nature that lingers, sweetly, in memory.
Yet another pandering, half-baked romantic comedy.
A resounding success in the laugh department, but it tries to warm hearts as well, and eventually collapses under the weight of its own sugarplum schmaltz.
You'll find yourself warming to Bad Santa in spite of its blemishes, simply because it's different than any holiday tale that's come before, or is likely to assail multiplexes again.
Disney's latest cinematic spin-off of a theme park attraction is a vortex of boredom. The mansion itself looks great, but what happens inside is woefully uninspired.
Ever since Mary, the Farrellys have struggled to find a more mature comedic voice. Stuck on You finds them hitting their stride, adding sentiment without compromising their quirkiness.
Nothing more than a cynical attempt to dress a blah story in bling-bling fashion.
The humor lacks bite, and the drama is forced.
The cartoonish chaos will engage little ones, while Tom's struggle to balance career and home time should keep parents' eyes on the screen.
Continues in the hackneyed tradition of other made-for-IMAX dramas, with storytelling that doesn't measure up to the scope of the screen.
Even if she skirts the big questions, Wuornos is a riveting presence -- affable and articulate one minute, twitchy and petulant the next.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A vapid attempt to ride the high-octane coattails of Fast and Furious.
The lead character in Crimson Gold is so detached, the audience never becomes emotionally involved in the world Panahi depicts.

The lead performers have collected prizes at international festivals, and deservedly so. They play their roles with such courage and compassion that one sees the souls of the characters rather than their afflictions.
The twists and tendrils don't withstand close or even not-so-close scrutiny.
Void offers some remarkable scenery and no small amount of drama.
Strains to be a hip splice of Ocean's Eleven and The Breakfast Club, but plays more like a never-ending civics lecture, trying to mask its pervasive lameness in visual zip and savvy reference points.
The movie is as pleasant as a sea breeze, but it slacks in the substance department.
May be glutted with despair but it has the levity of an involving story and mordant humor.
It isn't a bad hair day, just a limp, uninspired one.
A suspenseful, emotional experience even for those who don't study the sports pages.
50 First Dates is reasonably good fluff, balancing lovey sentiment and low-brow laughs, though it will likely evaporate from memory as quickly as Lucy forgets her meetings with Henry.
It may have some glaring flaws, but it is certainly one of the more interesting romances to hit the big screen in recent years.
Eurotrip doesn't try to reinvent the sex comedy wheel. It simply wants to shock you into hysterics, and more often than not, it sublimely succeeds.
It's a pubescent fantasia without soul or purpose beyond positioning star Lindsay Lohan as the successor to Hilary Duff's throne.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A nice, if not consistently funny, place to visit.
It has the potential to build a word-of-mouth audience through its sweet nature and lack of pretense, two qualities that are a rarity in both multiplexes and arthouses.
The film may not break the romantic comedy mold, but at least it offers some engaging chiseling.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting travelogue / character study filled with mythic landscapes and poignant encounters of near-molecular intimacy.
For all the labyrinthine liaisons, the plot is as predictable as a rainforest weather forecast. There are, however, enough bright ideas and zippy lines to keep things on the fresh side.
A touch of ambiguity never hurts, but too few dots connect in this story, and we're left with a portrait that only can be admired from a distance.
A wild, lobe-bending ride.
All Little Black Book offers is a pileup of sitcom scenarios overlaid with annoyingly glib narration, à la Sex and the City.
It's that rare thing, an intelligent date movie, a celluloid romance with enough substance to fill a thesis paper.
It is less a character study than an action pageant, cycling through the exploits of its anti-hero with an emphasis on flash and adrenaline.
Though the picture is often trite and occasionally exasperating, the leading ladies give it a spoonful of sugar and a hint of enchantment.
A feature-length sales pitch aimed at kids.
Some tales center on man vs. nature, others on man vs. man. Without a Paddle falls within a third category: man vs. poorly conceived script.
Has a level of moral and psychological intricacy that is rare in high school fables.
For all its zoomy camera work and outrageous mishaps, the film is as stale as a forgotten pack of Pall Malls.
The shtick is as stale and over-processed as expired Froot Loops, with references that were dated even when the original was released.
Coiled in cliché it may be, but the film offers a reasonably good time for audiences, and it boasts a few cast members with promise, both human and primate.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a black hole of failed ambition that mystifies on every level and offers zero payoff.
The lack of a streamlined narrative and reliance on manipulative devices turn a story of stark significance into a middling melodrama.
Instead of a sly critique of hypocrisy and pretense in all social classes, the film is a stodgy, unremarkable costume drama with all the bite of a poodle.
A piece of entertainment as tired and throwaway as a discount Harlequin paperback, but it comes sheathed in the flashiest of book covers.
Emotion and aesthetics get equal play in this adaptation of a novel by Georges Simenon, creating high-tension entertainment of the highest order.
A vigilante fable so boorish, brainless and mean-spirited, everyone involved should be locked up for assault.
The story moves briskly, the action is pulse-charging, and the laughs are many.
When Will I be Loved isn't a great leap forward for Toback, but it certainly is a step up from the noxious delirium of his last effort, Harvard Man.
Though there is the novelty of racket action, all the film really amounts to is same story, different sport.
Comes up a few laughs short of being something worth leaving the house for.
For all the hot sex and fevered politics, the movie is remarkably blah, a generic rush of attractive actors in compromising positions.
The film is marred by poorly constructed supporting characters and disorienting subplots that burst in out of nowhere.
A shapeless mass of crude sight gags barely worthy of the new release shelf, let alone theatrical distribution.
Praiseworthy for its concepts and aesthetics, yet it is too theory-heavy and action-shy, clumped with philosophical tangents and scholarly reference points.
The hallucinatory shock opera builds to a climax that will widen even the most jaded eyes.

There is no doubt that Shyamalan is a gifted director who knows how to push audience buttons, but heavy-handed horror shows like this one make the man behind the camera seems less an artist than a huckster.
While Harold & Kumar isn't quite a low-brow revelation on the scale of Clerks, it is one of film history's more inspired examples of off-color Jerseyana.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It seems as if She Hate Me is two different stories spliced together, with cross-purposed tones and topics.
The sequel doesn't feel like recycled pixie dust thanks to lovably loony new characters and a story crammed with enough pop-culture references to make Quentin Tarantino cry uncle.
A film made with intelligence and craftsmanship.
movie_title: Springtime in a Small Town (Xiao cheng zhi chun) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Like the best documentaries, Control Room spurs questions rather than promoting an agenda.
Movies like Soul Plane give bad taste a bad name.
The actors swim well, but emote poorly.
A banal high school comedy in the guise of a scathing religious satire.
It has the cute quotient, but it does more than spur cries of 'Awww.' The film is a healthy dose of cultural enrichment.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A static-filled space opera that is less thrill-a-minute than thrill-an-hour.
While these kinds of stories often drown in their own eccentricity, the cast keeps the film afloat.
A journey worth taking.
A surprisingly entertaining documentary that captures the triumph, the heartbreak and the consonants of the competitive Scrabble circuit.
While it doesn't have enough heart to put it in league with the all-time great sports comedies, the film certainly ranks among the more quotable ones.
[Babenco] tries to create the illusion of substance by crowding the film with plotlines, but all it really amounts to is lack of focus and purpose.
Essentially, it is a love story, but it's one that both cynics and romantics can embrace.
Even those sympathetic to the picture's cause will recognize it as a case of shoddy journalism, not so much due to its partisan mind-set but because it lacks clarity and revelation.
Even though they go preachy in the end, these chicks with quips deliver scattered bouts of hilarity.

Two Brothers isn't a sequel to the 1988 nature hit The Bear, yet it feels like one. It suffers from the lack of inspiration that plagues many second chapters, and it attempts to broaden the original concept to diminished effect.
Much like an awkward but well-intentioned suitor, the movie inspires affection despite its overwrought script and occasionally clunky staging.
[Raimi pulls] off the amazing feat of one-upping the original.
The film ultimately depicts thirtysomething melancholy just as effectively as its predecessor portrayed Gen-X romanticism.
The celluloid equivalent of a throwaway summer pop anthem, the sort of catchy-yet-agitating tune that has you humming in spite of yourself.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even those who've never waxed a board will be engaged and amazed.
The deft understatement of the actors and the resistance of cinematic artifice make the tale all the more devastating.
It is at once too fast, too slow and rarely engaging on a gut level.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A clawless cross-breed of comic book movie cliches.
While the movie has a higher IQ than the average summer action blitz, it underperforms as a thrill-dispenser.
It is, simply, a slice of life, one that transcends questions of right or wrong, moral or immoral.
The Greatest Game Ever Played may not be quite as superlative as its title, but it spins an engaging tale of sports triumph.
While a title card at the beginning of the picture says the story is inspired by true events, it really should read, 'Inspired by another film.'
If you're planning to go out for dinner and a movie, Waiting... should be your last choice at the multiplex.
You would expect heady fun from Guest and company as they parody themselves, but the movie is considerably weaker than past efforts.
Although some jokes and songs are recycled from the band's back catalog, the movie contains plenty of new material, a mix of killer tunes, monster laughs and savvy references.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A holiday farce that pairs a colorful cast with a generic filmmaker.
While Mel Gibson's epic was a divisive film, it had a visceral impact the new movie lacks.
It's hard to fathom why this didn't go straight to video, or maybe even YouTube.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is the storytelling murky, so is the picture quality. Video technology may have enabled the director to experiment with long takes and extreme close-ups, but it also yields a movie that's dull on several levels.
The movie, which runs two hours-plus, has its highs and lulls, but the charismatic cast offsets flawed storytelling.
There's some amusing mischief as the underage passengers outsmart the grownups, but the picture also features mean-spirited stereotypes that kill the festive mood. Talk about holiday blahs.
The movie doesn't leave you pondering the mysteries of a lost civilization. It leaves you pondering the psychopathology of the director.
The jokes are crude and repetitious.
It fails to strike an emotional chord, however, with a meandering narrative and heroes who spout rhetoric like pundits.
A big surprise, a comedy detailing the angst of first love with rare candor.
Cooper's performance is fine. The script, however, is filled with dead-end tangents and unanswered questions.
It's not quite a thrill ride but it isn't a total embarrassment for Cage. It's certainly no worse than Wicker Man, which depicted the actor chasing hippie chicks in a bear suit.
A formulaic, unfunny farce that will leave you nostalgic for Police Academy.
Pages turn, knives plunge, rain patters and the camera rarely holds steady. No amount of quick cuts and twitchy shots, however, can compensate for the lack of narrative momentum.
Explores dark themes without taking itself too seriously, offering wit to offset the angst.
It's a joyless cross-country romp in which the heroes confront crazy animals, lascivious hicks and rest-stop bathroom horrors.

There's elegance in the cinematography and pathos in some of the performances, but the script lacks structure. The movie shuttles between life events, more a snapshot collection of episodes than a cohesive character study.
Rock is so fixed on crude jokes, he neglects to create realistic characters and a story that's compelling to follow.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The picture grows pretentious in parts and the ending is anticlimactic.

There are lots of things in the script that ring false, but the acting is honest, witty and soulful. Sandler's performance is perfectly believable while the weak link, surprisingly enough, is the writing.

There are endless scenes in which the turtles sit around discussing their feelings. All the talk of anger management and sibling rivalry is sure to test the attention spans of viewers in every age group.
The dialogue and plot may be cliché, but Howard's slow-burn portrayal redeems the weak writing.

The movie draws upon so many influences -- stylized Hitchcock suspense, surreal Asian horror and the Gothic romance of Britain's Hammer Studios -- it's easier to follow the reference points than the plot.
The production numbers are delightful, but the musical fun is marooned in clichéd storytelling.
The Return is routine in its depiction of a waifish young woman surrounded by men with predatory qualities. It's sad to see Buffy so disempowered.
It works on an aesthetic level but it's uneven as a drama.

In a way, the movie itself is an example of that philosophy put into practice. [Director] Adams clearly did a lot of soul-searching as she wrote the story. Her introspective script provides another actress with a great role and a new start.
For a movie centered on a game without rules, Crossover is pretty formulaic.
All in all, it's a disappointing follow-up to Jaa's 2003 breakthrough, Ong-Bak: The Thai Warrior. He reteams with co-star Phetthai Wongkhamlao and director Prachya Pinkaew to diminishing returns.
... as chilling as a steam shower.
It's an edifying, upsetting film that offers a different perspective on the situation in the Middle East.
The Last Kiss is interminably bleak. It doesn't win laughs or offer catharsis. The film only lowers your spirits and never seems to end.
More a mediocrity than a shipwreck.
Imagine a naive, simplistic documentary about the most complex, cynical member of the Beatles.
While the comedy is corny and the storytelling inconsistent, the cast makes it a keeper.
A pretentious biopic about a Chinese sports legend.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The audience has layers of plot twists to sift through, with no great reward at the end for the investment.
Surrounding the flashy heroics, however, is a lot of stilted drama. Unresolved subplots make the movie longer than it needs to be.
The genius of the movie lies in Mirren's work. She captures the complexities of a woman who's often seen as unknowable. Ultimately, it's a tribute to the regal leader rooted in reverence and empathy.
Two actors with unique personas, Ferrell and Heder make a good combo, delivering winningly funny wordplay and skate moves.

It's sad to see actors like Walters and Linney mired in such undignified, one-note roles. The movie is an object lesson in the lack of good parts around for actresses, even on the indie front. Class dismissed.
It isn't a bad movie, just a redundant one.
A love story and an elegy, Sweet Land is a meaningful film that makes its points with subtlety.
The clichés undermine the power of the story.
The film is more a sideshow than a satire, and while it has a certain morbid allure, it doesn't succeed in replicating the charm of the novel.
It's not the kind of documentary that leaves you feeling like you've only heard one side of the debate, that certain unsettling truths have been tactically avoided.
movie_title: Exit: The Right to Die (Exit: Le Droit de Mourir) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Capturing the women in concert, backstage and at home with their families, the movie is compelling and insightful, if a bit self-serving, promoting a group whose popularity is waning.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The interviews with loved ones keep the tragedies in context and help us process what we see. The true substance of The Bridge lies in their words, rather than the shots of the people they've lost.
The biblical themes are reflected in the film's multilingual dialogue, broad geographic scope and, you could add, its failed ambitions.
Do you want to play a game? How about a really long, convoluted game that leads nowhere? The scariest thing about Saw III is how it seems like it's never going to end.
Tim Allen seems bored with his own franchise. At times, he looks downright morose, cranky enough to kick an elf.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Crude, confrontational and stunningly sick, it's a movie made in the fringe tradition of Pink Flamingos, featuring a performer who seems to be willing to do anything for the camera.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It seems like the screenwriter may have suffered a shortage of ideas and remedied the problem by watching Charlie Kaufman films.
It basically repeats the events of the first film with some roles reversed and perversions intensified. For all its visual audacity, The Grudge 2 is quite predictable in its pattern of behavior.
Unhealthy eating is paired with a wholesome message, as the story encourages youngsters to be themselves, keep their word and accept kids who are different.
A witty, inventive CG adventure that proves there are still new ideas to explore in the digital animation realm.
A surprisingly competent film, Disturbia lives up to its title. It's rare to find a decent film turn up in the dead of April, traditionally Hollywood's dump month for shelved oddities.
Buscemi creates an intriguing, if contrived, drama about the battle of the sexes.
More a reinvention than a retread, Hairspray is a pleasant surprise, a breath of fresh, whimsical air in a season that's been dominated by franchise entertainment.
The picture delivers 90 minutes of gay caricatures, along with a barrage of fat jokes, and culminates by lecturing the audience about how wrong it is to mock those who are different.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A period piece enlivened with slapstick and mischievous wit.
It's sad to see the once-promising actress killing her career, between her self-destructive behavior behind the scenes and her poor judgment selecting scripts.
Director Leon Ichaso (Piero) uses every trick in the hack biopic book, including flashback stock footage and montages of newspaper headlines flying toward the camera.
It's more a frivolous spoof than a pointed satire.
A pointless sequel in a franchise that's been underwhelming from the start.
The thing the film lacks -- besides originality -- is a character arc that keeps the audience interested.
On the fright scale, this pack of werewolves ranks below a basket of puppies.
...there are some classic scenes and the cast is hilarious.
Even though the film clocks under two hours, it seems longer than a Lord of the Rings marathon played on slow motion.
For a silly kids movie about an accident-prone man on a trip to the beach, Mr. Bean's Holiday is actually quite mean-spirited and pretentious.
A misguided film that veers between extremes in sentimentality and misanthropy.
Illegal Tender isn't quite the mess you expect this time of year, a film that achieves a certain level of originality by reversing gender roles.
The film is best appreciated as a meditation on celebrity psychology.
Something of a surprise, Balls of Fury serves up sports thrills and a good amount of laughter...
If only the world were a more peaceful place, we wouldn't have to sit through movies like Death Sentence.
The shtick grows a bit repetitive, so by the end of the story you may be checking the time rather than rooting for Randy.
Revamping the influential 1978 shocker Halloween for a new generation of viewers, director Rob Zombie offers a film with more sex, more violence, no humor and zero scares.
Better suited to 10 minutes of television than 90 minutes of cinema.
The director seems to be welcoming controversy, however, pushing buttons to evoke strong responses and stimulate discussion.

Part fairy tale, part college comedy, totally unoriginal and a tad offensive, Sydney White stars Amanda Bynes as a new student who starts a rebellion against the school's oppressive Greek establishment.
[Pettis] overplays cute to the point where you wish the Rock would practice one of his wrestling moves on her and ship her off to Kid Nation.

The filmmaker tries to keep the energy up and the audience engaged by incorporating stylistic touches from the Michael Bay 101 crib sheet, whirling the camera around characters in crisis and lacing scenes with hack guitar rock.
It's not exactly light summer entertainment. With its emphasis on paranoia and perversion, Joshua is closer in spirit to fringe films like Eraserhead than mainstream horror movies like The Omen.
A dizzying summer adventure, Transformers is a film to worship for its set pieces and chastise for its inscrutable storytelling.
Great cast, mediocre writing.
There's no point in whining that Die Hard is mindless. That's like complaining about the sound of people eating popcorn in the theater.
Layered with improbable plot twists and hypocritical commentary, the movie is lurid and outdated when it wants to be hip and provocative.
It's one thing to catch Aqua Teen in 15-minute increments on TV, but sitting through a feature-length onslaught is an endurance test even for devoted viewers.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The cars in the film are treated with more respect than the women.
French art films aren't generally known for their feel-good endings, but a total lack of resolution can be just as cloying as happily ever after.
Hot Fuzz runs a bit long for a cop spoof, but it is also one of the funniest law enforcement comedies this side of The Naked Gun.

When it isn't depicting brutal deaths, the film condemns audiences for flocking to see lurid entertainment. If director Scott Wiper is trying to make a statement, it gets lost in a mirror maze of hypocrisy and self-loathing.
Laugh proof and choreographically blah.
Civic Duty sends you home depressed, but at least it makes you think. It's a breed of film that's rare to find on the summer movie slate.
It's a weak hand from the filmmaker; not a colossal failure, just a dreary mediocrity.
Heartfelt and intelligent, with a pinch of whimsy.
The Ex is shrill when it means to be irreverent. It's frustrating to see the lead performers squandering their collective talent in a movie that fails to match the fun and pathos of their TV work.
The best scenes in Barbershop featured incisive discussions of current events. Here, the closest brush with topicality is a reference to Eddie Griffin.
So over-the-top, it makes 300 look like a study in minimalism.
Wendell Baker isn't perfect. The slacker humor grows cloying at times. Still, there's an undeniable charm to the Texas tale as it celebrates nonconformity and redemption.

The irony is thick, and the deaths are brutal, as horror and humor are spliced with social commentary. The British film sends up scary movies while building characters whose fates matter to the audience.
Even longer and less coherent [than Dead Man's Chest]. Consider it a companion piece to the similarly indulgent Spider-Man 3.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Elegantly capturing the alchemy of songwriting -- not to mention the alchemy of fleeting romance -- it's a one-of-a-kind movie to enthrall musicians and listeners alike.
Bug is a twisted, visceral film with an uncompromising sense of nihilism.
The jaunty sports story contains colorful characters, witty wisecracks and kinetic surf scenes. It's refreshing to see an animated family film that doesn't look like it was made on autopilot.
It's something of an accomplishment to stage deaths so disgusting, the main reaction is nervous laughter.
It's a playful, surrealistic antidote to standard genre entertainment.
Compared with its predecessor, the new movie contains less silliness to offend purists. At the same time, there isn't much to thrill anyone, either.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fido does offer a good number of laughs, along with a healthy serving of gore to satisfy horror fans.
The highlights of Evan Almighty aren't the supernatural moments but the scenes in which Carell grows comically flustered with his situation.
There's ghoulish fun and Hichcockian suspense until the film hits a narrative wall around the 60-minute mark.
Why give Moore a free pass just because you support his ideologies? In the end, the real loyalty we owe is to truth.
Once you get beyond the surface clichés, there's truth and sincerity in the dialogue and performances.
It's amusing on occasion, but also garbled, repetitious and potentially offensive.
Watching Norbit is like watching a train wreck with eye clamps on.
The OutKast epic Idlewild is an amazingly misguided film, a muddled attempt to create an old school Hollywood musical showcasing the unique hip-hop duo.

A charming, accessible movie that spotlights Moreau's talent against a fanciful cinematic backdrop.

movie_review_blurb: There have been so many protest pictures on the scene since the Iraq war began -- from Michael Moore, Robert Greenwald and other provocateurs -- that Why We Fight leaves you with a mild sense of deja vu rather than a fresh sense of outrage.
As far as gratuitous follow-ups go, it is neither evolution nor devolution. A more appropriate title is Underworld: Stagnation.
Nanny McPhee isn't a bad film, just a disappointing one.
The film is part boxing saga, part military recruiting ad and 100 percent cliché.
Deadly slow and repetitious.
Big Momma may be larger than life, but the shtick is older than old.

This indie death-feast, directed by Jeremy Haft and penned by Jeffrey Reddick (co-writer of Final Destination), was initially slated to debut on video. Watching it, you'll wonder why the distributor changed its plans.
Dial M for mediocre.
The film has its stumbling points, but it offers a sufficient amount of laughter.
The plot has more holes in it than the victims, but the shocks make up for the flaws. Don't think, just watch, and expect a wild ride.
Watching the canines scamper across glaciers is far more entertaining than watching Walker wander around depressed. The movie should be more March of the Huskies and less Dude, Where's My Sled?
Night Watch is narratively confused if visually robust. The picture doesn't work as a standalone story but it sets the stage for a potentially interesting second chapter.
It is ultimately an exercise in redundancy, since there's little point in creating a comedy that sends up other comedies. The end result is more a knockoff than a parody.
Tsotsi gets its message across without pandering to the audience. It has a keen sense of subtlety that's often lacking in social awareness cinema.
Goodwilled? Sure. Good filmmaking? Lord no.
A small film with a big cast, Little Fish is notable for its performances.

The music is angry and the jokes are raw but, ultimately, Block Party conveys a positive message to audiences. Instead of competition, we see collaboration between the artists and unity in the diverse crowd.

It tells an evocative story that withstands the sentimentality of the film-making.
Her sword is red, her eyes are blue and her movie is horrible.
The hard-boiled prose is translated into a schmaltzy movie with too much sap and not enough grit.
She's the Man is a bit of a mess.
It's not very Christian for Harvey to ask his fans to pay multiplex ticket prices for a shoddy film that is barely feature length.
movie_title: Don't Trip...He Ain't Through with Me Yet (2006)

The improbable Jackson-Sheridan collaboration yields an immensely entertaining film.

The picture climaxes with the crashing of a blimp, an image that encapsulates the Hindenburg scale of its failure.
The picture is so garish and creatively lazy at times, it almost becomes the very sort of vapid spectacle it parodies.

movie_review_blurb: With its lurching blend of scatology, sentimentality and sci-fi, the movie is a mess. It's also sexist, bigoted and misanthropic. Of course, those qualities used to be part of the star's charm.

Aesthetically interesting as it is, the film leaves you feeling somewhat blank and detached, sort of like the main character.

movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watching [Wilson] mug wildly in another uneven film short on plot, the audience may start to wish he would go away for awhile and stop turning up in such repetitive comedies.

A low-profile indie that's worth seeking out for Maria Bello's performance.

... the movie preaches to the choir rather than winning over new converts.

movie_review_blurb: This is not an easy movie. It tackles big stuff- the biggest, really... But it breathes, nonetheless, and encourages us to do so too even in the wake of the grief it inspires us to recall in our lives.

movie_review_blurb: In Melancholia, von Trier has created a mission statement of a masterpiece, one that reminds us that nihilism itself can serve as a legitimate form of creation, a means as well as The End.

movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Children and adults who've come to expect fireworks over clever coziness may take a while to settle into this dyslexic fairy tale, but it's eminently worth the effort.

No one makes sense in Reza's world of glittering mockery.

Shakespeare on a trip wire.

Michelle Williams plays Monroe, and she's a wonder.
For kids, blessedly unironic by nature until wised up by nurture, the movie is just shiny, funny, and filled with songs...
Yes, I know, Twilight fans love The Twilight Saga. But they (you?) deserve something better to love.
Ellen Barkin - playing the estranged mother of the groom - does a big heap of acting as one of the more histrionic members of the clan.
A beautiful, matter-of-fact French drama about a young girl who wants to be a boy - and for one singular summer around her 10th birthday passes as one...
Miller makes nice, subtle points about interdependence on earth. Meanwhile, the earthmates in Happy Feet Two continue to dance, sing, and, yes, charm.

A haunting, piquant melodrama about childhood dreams and yearnings, enhanced with a pleasant survey course in early film history.
Quote not available.
Tartakovsky's zippy, boing-boing touch shines through in the purely physical antics of the monster mob; words aren't necessary as the freaks bounce around the place with nutso energy.

Perhaps playwright Tennessee Williams' unproduced 1980 screenplay was unproduced -- until now -- for a reason.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another outstanding little movie in the exciting Romanian New Wave.

Each episode (originally made for British TV) works by itself, but there's a real payoff in following all three.
A well-made, sleekly retaliatory, pleasurably paranoid tale...
A quietly stunning saga that won the Grand Prix last year at Cannes and is a worthy Oscar nominee for Best Foreign Language Film...

[A] graceless piece of tragedy porn...

The warmth comes through, even if the storytelling is simplistic and clichéd.

Terribly shot and crudely assembled.

movie_review_blurb: Mezzogiorno plays Dalser with the kind of fervent intensity once seen in silent films...
The movie bubbles with intellectual curiosity and narrative ambition. And for that I dig it, even if Leaves of Grass has the habit of swerving and sometimes lurching from tone to tone.
As is so often the case since his Monty Python days, Gilliam is best at visual games and weakest at storytelling.

A jaunty and forthright production with a lively look reflecting the book's illustrated pages [that] does a great job of being in two places at once: In the head and gangly bodies of kids, and in the hearts of those of us who have survived grades 6-8.

Another must-see marvel of horror, comedy, and impeccable filmmaking by the Korean director Bong Joon-ho...

movie_review_blurb: Green Zone is a strangely dated, foolishly grandiose, simplistically angry fictional war-zone thriller about how one patriot blows the lid off America's missteps in Iraq.
A movie with all the hyperventilating hysteria of a 1960s teen-tragedy pop song and all the disposability, too.

I wish the screenwriters had been 2010-minded enough to leave out the crappy gay jokes. Then again, as directed by Cusack's longtime pal and collaborator Steve Pink, and performed with manic energy by this guys-among-guys cast, the movie bops and honks.
Hugh Grant and Sarah Jessica Parker ply their cute trademarks (his befuddled British grimace, her la-di-da New York sass) like grim, incompatible partners in a Hollywood business deal.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's Complicated is middle-aged porn, the specialty of Meyers,   who also set ladies and interior   decorators drooling over homes and gardens in 2006's The Holiday.
In Jackson's simplified, sweetened, and  CGI-besotted telling, The Lovely Bones is a sad-but-hopeful, dramatic-but-gentle fairy tale intentionally made less upsetting for teens.
Don't bother to take notes, because subplots go nowhere, and characters -- many played   by well-known actors -- barely get screen time.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Amelia is a frustratingly old-school, Hollywood-style, inspirational biopic about Amelia Earhart that doesn't trust a viewer's independent assessment of the famous woman pictured on the screen.

Adam Goldberg glowers effectively as a serious composer of maddeningly difficult music; the wonderful Marley Shelton glows with hilariously cool composure as a gallery owner who exhibits unendurable art pieces.

Profoundly beautiful and affecting, Where the Wild Things Are is a breath- taking act of artistic transubstantiation.
Jess Weixler (Teeth) is particularly lovely as Vandy, even when the mild young woman has to endure her beloved's screaming criticism of her sandwich-making methods.
The audience may have bought the act in Napoleon Dynamite. But this time, the act bombs.
Catalina Saavedra conjures a performance of such unflinching intensity and naked bravery in The Maid that at times it's painful to watch.
The great cast includes Timothy Spall as the assistant manager, Colm Meaney as Clough's nemesis, and Jim Broadbent as a sports exec who'd make George Steinbrenner nervous.
Anthony Campos (who was 24 when he made this jolting pic) captures the numbing psychic scramble that just might cause the YouTube generation to go morally haywire. Or become filmmakers.
Zombieland takes full advantage of both possibilities of the species as well as the current boom in zombiephilia.

The truth? Ricky Gervais' jolting philosophical comedy The Invention of Lying is seriously subversive. What other rom-com would spend so much time making a convincing case that belief in an afterlife is a harmless load of bollocks?

Whip It suggests what might have happened if Juno had gone to a high school as poky as Napoleon Dynamite's and decided that although her mother wanted her to be a beauty queen like Little Miss Sunshine, she'd rather just strap on roller skates.
There's fun robot stuff, some good philosophical ideas, and a brief, nutty Willis-Ving Rhames reunion 15 years after Pulp Fiction.
These tales are as highly designed as fashion layouts. But they're as relaxing to thumb through as those NYT Magazine trend pieces...
Although The Greatest is a histrionic mess, at least it looks clean.
Writer-director Ti West's crisp, economical, satisfying little horror pic reclaims the pleasures of the kind of old-school formula that the jokey Scream franchise deconstructed into satire.

Bridges' guileless performance makes this piquant little indie tale of country music, redemption, and the love of a pretty younger woman such a sad-song charmer.
Buschel makes striking use of the Mike Hammer/Philip Marlowe tradition to tell a story of disorientation and loss in a post-9/11 world where the Twin Towers can go missing too.
Written and directed by British director Kirk Jones with guidance, apparently, from Dr. Phil...

Based on the equally entertaining, erudite novel by Jay Parini and adapted and directed by Michael Hoffman, the movie is at once a hot marital showdown and a cool political debate, a domestic War and Peace.
There's a lot of yelling, cracking wise, and cooing in this creepy rom-com.
What might have been a so-so TV sitcom misses its appropriate medium by compacting all the characters' generic gotta-grow-up problems into one disposable film.
Writer-director Karin Albou (who plays the mother of the Jewish bride) has a sensuous, intimate filmmaking style that overrides The Wedding Song's more precariously loaded plot parallels.
movie_title: Le Chant des Mariées (The Wedding Song) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A rapturous (if occasionally disorienting) dance film precisely choreographed with seeming artlessness.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie includes an interminable scene of the men taking the wrong medications for their various boomer ailments, with weirdly horrible comedic side effects.
Weitz goes for an appealing, slightly old-fashioned look, one in which the near- constant rain nicely mirrors Bella's internal weather conditions.
A vibrant, mature love letter to the making of movies, the meaning of movies, and the dark-eyed muse Penélope Cruz...
There's plenty of vivid action to fill two and a half hours in John Woo's Chinese historical war epic Red Cliff, a rewarding change of terrain and era for the inventive Hong Kong director.

Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Lynn Collins are so interesting that it's easy to put up with the decision-making dithering that goes along with the title.
This A-level, G-rated entertainment is a fresh twist on the classic fairy tale.

Carell and Fey project an intellectual sharpness and an understanding of what's important in life - and what's ridiculous - that are the hallmarks of endearingly sane adults capable of sustaining both a hot career and a warm marriage-with-children.

movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The close-to-the-ground style compensates for the tenuous narrative structure by capturing the energy and variety of Tehran's music scene in all its bravery.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This former violist can vouch that Laurent does a bravura job of fake fiddle playing, and Guskov's baton work as a conductor is exemplary.
What feels enjoyably outré in the 1998 coming-of-age novel by Jonathan Ames feels oppressively outré in this deadened, literal adaptation.
Just another cost-of-war movie, you say? Yes, and that's exactly the point.
[A] smart, low-key, melancholy dramatization based on a little-known real moment in espionage, circa 1981...
This proud graduate of the School of Cleary Classics wishes that, like the young heroine herself, Ramona and Beezus dared more often to color outside the lines.
In a staring contest with his audience, Solondz never blinks. He picks and picks at the themes that consume him, and he doesn't care who stays and who leaves. Me, I'm rapt.
A bland, summer-sloppy comedy that never risks actually swimming with schmucks and letting characters bruise themselves on outcroppings of mean fun.
When it comes to crazy, violent, semidelirious, testosterone-laden, proto-Viking tales about a mute visionary one-eyed warrior who breaks skulls, Valhalla Rising is pretty great.

Your average winter cold follows a less predictable course.

A superior lyrical ragamuffin Irish drama about neighbor kids in a dingy outpost of Dublin who run away from their crummy home situations at Christmas and spend a picaresque night on city streets.

Perhaps it's inevitable that this cranked-up drama wants it both ways.
Hoffman is stymied by the difficult task of transforming stage material into a movie; Jack Goes Boating's camera just sits there while actors act.

The movie goes right to the heart in focusing on the fates of some irresistibly real kids and the loving, frustrated parents and grandparents who care for them.

movie_review_blurb: Disturbing, visceral, personal...
Does it matter that this self-centered experiment intrudes on the lives of others? IMHO: yes. In Catfish, the camera's-rolling readiness to trawl for drama leaves a slimy aftertaste.
This is essential viewing for understanding our world.

A rich, dark, pulpy mess of entanglements that fulfills all the requirements of the genre, and is told with an ease and gusto that make the pulp tasty.

Ignore the story of Paper Heart ... Concentrate instead on the delightful performances.

Part punk-drab British art-house portrait of underclass despair, part bloody vigilante pic, Harry Brown is shakily held together by industrial-strength sound design and the expertly employed theatrics of Michael Caine in the title role.

David Duchovny and Demi Moore are well accessorized as display-model husband and wife. But this cautionary tale might be easier to swallow if all that stuff didn't look like it came from a Sky Mall catalog.
The performances are tender, the script elegant, the cinematography (especially during a virtuoso chase scene in a soccer stadium) artful.

At least they're not Katherine Heigl and Ashton Kutcher in Killers.

Don't tell me I'm making too much out of nothing, because the steady drip-drip-drip of nothings like this are killing us all.
As Carrie might type on her laptop while giving one of her girly little shrugs, When did Sex and the City become so long and mean so little?
As sword-and-sandal fantasy movies based on videogames and starring a buffed-up Jake Gyllenhaal go, Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time goes pretty well.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Jaoui neatly, gently, firmly slips political commentary into Let It Rain's articulate mayhem.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a good bet any cocky contestant on Top Chef would keel over from the rigors of the challenge, the rituals of which are treated with fervent concentration by these meticulous artistes with their piping bags and spun-sugar sculptures.
With those piercing eyes, Owen makes a lovely, soulful Joe, of course. But it's not the nice papa we want to understand here, it's the unapologetically naughty one.
Newcomer Jessica Haines is transparent and heartbreaking as the prof's unorthodox daughter, a victim of violence as the old ways crumble.
It's a great day in America when the complicated looks so easy, and when we expect smart storytelling as a rule, not the exception.
The story is as impersonal as it is labored.
[Director] Koury doesn't make any points in We Are Wizards, particularly, but he stylishly shares the love.

More than a million people have been displaced in central China in the cause of generating electrical power to meet the needs of the future; Jia's flowing river of a picture washes over a few of them as they adjust to life's currents in the present.
Missing the 'e' in epic, the filmmaker has produced a labored pic, weighed down by the very artifice that is traditionally his specialty.
Makes good on its formula with no pretensions.
Frost/Nixon surges with an energy and visual verve that improve the play and enhance the themes of dramatist Peter Morgan's script.
Doubt, fussily overdirected by its author, John Patrick Shanley, dulls the play's own sharp inquiries into the dangerous power of those who profess certainty with God on their side.
A tough, authentic street drama born, bred, and shot in the   no-spin zone of working-class South Boston.
Toni Collette gives it the old Little Miss Sunshine try in The Black Balloon as an edge-of-kooky, very pregnant mama presiding over a chaotic household.

A movie at once understated and radical, deceptively unremarkable in presentation and ballsy in its earnestness. Don't let the star's overly familiar squint fool you: This is subtle, perceptive stuff.
Everything is admirable, worthy, and muffled in a blanket of Britishness in this well-bred production, which reunites director Stephen Daldry with screenwriter David Hare six years after The Hours.
The troubles are broad, the plot twists giant, and the performances cheery in this carol to ethnic pride in Chicago's traditionally Latino Humboldt Park.
Writer-director Salvatore Stabile has a good eye for the details of hard-luck ordinariness, and he sketches believable family bonds with a minimum of flourish.
An unintentionally ludicrous drama of repentance as an extreme sport.
An extravagantly ambitious movie that's easy to admire but a challenge to love.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Extraordinary and painfully timely.
File this 'therapeutic' movie, well made and creepy, on the dysfunction-as-art shelf  next to Capturing the Friedmans.

For those of us dwelling outside the Jonas demo, the small charms in the 'candid' moments have little to do with the boys' talents as actors, and a lot to do with the revered icons whose cheeky behavior they're imitating.
The great Polish director Andrzej Wajda musters the power of classical filmmaking and personal emotional investment  to dramatize a stunning atrocity long covered up.

Don't look for resolution, romanticism, or comic relief in this underworld tour, shot   with a fast, you-are-there look and no pity; you won't find picaresque goodfellas or Sopranos-style ziti eaters here. Instead, there's the power of damning truth
The star of the pic may well be NYC's Guggenheim Museum and Istanbul's Grand Bazaar, both of which figure in cool action chase sequences that pay handsome dividends.
A weightless, style-driven thriller set in a photogenically chaotic Hong Kong.

Out of the most ordinary ingredients -- an ailing mother, estranged adult siblings, a good meal ruined by bad behavior -- the endlessly inventive French filmmaker Arnaud Desplechin has made the old look fresh in A Christmas Tale.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Real-life fanboys know that the release of this mildly cute, mildly drooly, majorly too late spoof/homage has been delayed for more than two years.
The infectious charm and sunny goodwill of Four Weddings and a Funeral can so immediately buoy a soul ravaged by winter weather and winter movies.
How much do I want to believe in America 2.0 as a place where a Suit might help factory workers survive hard times?
A short, beautiful, characteristically sublime memory piece by the great British auteur Terence Davies.
The Class -- winner of the Palme d'Or at the 2008 Cannes Film Festival -- is in a class by itself.

The story is a whirl, a jumble, an effusion -- sometimes flowing smoothly, other times jerking along as if the filmmaker has been given advice he resents regarding pacing and the balance of sweetness and danger.
I wish The Secret of the Grain had another title, something that conveys the vibrancy teeming in this great drama of daily life -- something less grainy.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This thrilling stop-motion animated adventure is a high point in [Henry] Selick's career of creating handcrafted wonderlands of beauty blended with deep, disconcerting creepiness.

As the reigning inhabitant, Redgrave adopts the swanning gestures of Maggie Smith in this mild adaptation of a Maeve Binchy story. Other drama queens enjoying the opportunity to screech include Imelda Staunton, Brenda Fricker, and Joss Ackland.
The clever, stylish perception-teaser of a comic drama JCVD -- a reality-twisting cousin to Being John Malkovich -- showcases a Van Damme who's sly like a fox about his own image.
As a Holocaust-for-kids fable, The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is an appalling, jaw-dropping movie that will cause serious nightmares.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: So hysterical in its terrorist subplot and its seizure-inducing action sequences that a pummeled viewer can be excused for texting WTF? to a friend in the middle of the chaos.
The secret uncovered by an adolescent in 1950s Paris is strikingly specific, yet echoes with the history of millions.
Under the circumstances, Fanning is remarkably collected and even dignified. As for the rest of the gang, they ought to be returned to sender.
Ghost Town is diverting enough, but it's also the kind of high-concept studio concoction Ricky Gervais might have ridiculed in his great backstage-showbiz sitcom Extras.

[The filmmakers] have accomplished their goal of making the unorthodox life of the late-18th-century noblewoman Georgiana Spencer, Duchess of Devonshire, relevant to a 21st-century audience of moviegoers.

The whole idea of foundation -- as it applies to family, history, and an actual, stately American house -- receives a thoughtful inspection in Moving Midway, the graceful nonfiction film from Godfrey Cheshire.
Even keepers of the Sparks flame are likely to have their spirits dampened by the wind-rattled, Diane Lane and Richard Gereencrusted adaptation of Nights in Rodanthe.
Once more in Burn After Reading [the Coens] goof around, in their arch, bemused way, with conventions of genre -- a little screwball here, some spy spoof there.

Interest in Playa lies in the fact that director Jessica Yu is a documentarian with a daring taste in subjects. Yet in her first non-doc feature, she plays it safe; even the championship showdown feels polite.
The story sometimes moves at a crawl, but always the filmmaker follows the pair with unobtrusive attentiveness to conflicting cultural and generational pulls.
Essential, unique viewing: a stunning experience of the hurricane and its aftermath, rooted in immediate personal response and emotions that encapsulate the full national catastrophe.
[Faris] gives an A performance in the kind of farce from which she's more than ready to graduate.

The wait isn't worth it in this fearmongering, opportunistic political/spy thriller, a slippery entertainment that's all feints and few punches thrown at a fight card of indistinguishable terrorists, Muslim and otherwise.

Let Death Race serve as a warning, or maybe an inspiration, to any TV producer who says she'd kill for high ratings: Why not stage a pay-per-view car race in which prisoners compete to stay alive on the course?
The resonant, beautifully naturalistic drama The Pool is a return to the familiar subject of haves and have-nots for director Chris Smith.
Truly lovely performances by Adams and Blunt pierce the thoroughly artificial climate.
As the players enact the fall and rebirth of civilization, Meirelles suggests that even a society gone to hell looks better with a little music-video-like pizzazz.
The marvelous, magical boy-meets-girl-in-the-city-that-never-sleeps romantic comedy Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist is a revolutionary movie disguised as a familiar story.
I mean it as a cockeyed compliment to the reborn Bond franchise, then, when I say that Quantum of Solace is an unnecessarily cramped arena for such an interesting cat.
Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa is pretty tame, but it knows how to keep its own turf tidy.
A nifty horror movie that doesn't claim to be anything other than a zippy exercise in creature-feature entertainment.

The story is a luxurious mess of woes. But dramatic resolution is almost beside the point when Scott Thomas and the precise, birdlike Zylberstein engage in such attractive flights of performance in service to sisterly love.

The facts are so awful that Dear Zachary can be forgiven much of its antsiness -- as a memorial, as a condolence to Bagby's parents (who became activists for judicial reform in their late son's honor), and as a howl of grief.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Of course, what Zack and Miri actually make -- and what Rogen and Banks power their way through with a cherubic energy above and beyond the call of duty for a premise so inconsequential and puerile -- is another Kevin Smith comedy.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A spare, controlled study in communication gaps and a piercing sketch of suburban American loneliness.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The moments Stone and Weiser select to sketch Bush's character are more of a jumble than a natural progression.
For the love of all things sensual and mysterious, see this one on a big screen.
It's hardly the most gracefully made indie on the block -- more like a whole season of a sitcom crammed into one feature.
The sunshiny primary-school teacher nicknamed Poppy (Sally Hawkins) in Mike Leigh's exuberant comedy Happy-Go-Lucky is the kind of relentless optimist one might worry about in real life.
Only you can decide whether you're in the mood to wade through the smear of stink jokes and political ravings.
The product is concept, not execution, and the delivery techniques bear standard Hollywood patents.

How to Lose Friends & Alienate People chronicles the short-but-sour New York career of the British journalist, who arrived for a stint at Vanity Fair at the invitation of its flamboyantly coiffed editor, Graydon Carter.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: These politicians may be teens, but they grapple with constituencies, campaign strategies, and demands on their time with a spirit and seriousness of purpose suitable for the highest office in the land.
Duplicity doesn't have depth -- but it does have Julia Roberts, in full Hollywood movie-star mode. And for filmgoers with scaled-back expectations, that news may be enough.

For your art-house pleasure and discomfort, here's one of the most talked-about film-festival triumphs of 2008, a disturbingly avid re-creation of the last six weeks in the life and slow, self-imposed wasting of Irish hunger striker Bobby Sands.

Known for distinctive horror movies like Cure and Pulse, inventive Japanese filmmaker Kiyoshi Kurosawa finds just the right melancholy tone to suit a new and all too familiar kind of horror: economic downsizing.
Austrian actor Christoph Waltz   triumphs, heroically, over Tarantino's brash, cine-drunk tall tale.
District 9 proves that there's intelligent alien life in the movie universe this summer.
The inventiveness of Barthes' story is matched by a sense of visual fluidity that's especially striking in a first feature.
This diverting riff is as much a spoof of film-school self-seriousness as it is a sincere art project, enhanced by Yi's great, homemade puppets.

Who's been murdering newlyweds, turning a beachy paradise into a tropical hell shared by three pretty couples? You'll probably guess, but that doesn't take away from the slicked-up genre charms of this A Perfect Getaway.

From the outstanding Belgian filmmakers Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne (Rosetta), here's another closely observed, sociologically astute, and amazingly naturalistic drama about moral compromise as a by-product of economic need.
The comedy concept is solid... It's the execution that's out of alignment in The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A gaudy, daring, operatic, and bloody funny provocation of a melodrama from Park Chan-wook.
Larrain's (literally) dark, edgy movie is a precise artistic commentary on Augusto Pinochet's miserable regime, which was  under way while Travolta gyrated.

Consider the movie an offspring of the great 1980s BBC screwball political comedy series Yes Minister. And consider it a welcome oasis of script literacy in a summer of Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen.
The filmmakers have found a way to refresh our eyes and enhance our appreciation for this rich, amazing creation.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A charmless rom-com about an exhaustingly vivacious florist.
Writer-director Lynn Shelton sweetly, mischievously tracks Ben and Andrew as they jaw, shoot hoops, roughhouse, and hug it out.

The story is timeless; this could have taken place when [screenwriter] Doyle graduated in '76 -- or any year, really, since the effects of high school linger throughout adult life and nerds are forever.

In his long, sobering story without a punchline, Judd Apatow confounds three crowds: traditional Sandler fans expecting goofy sweetness, Virgin/Knocked Up boosters hoping for raunchy fun, and connoisseurs of movies that know how to kill.

A reasonable person might well add the issue to the agenda after enduring this at times unbearably violent agitprop drama, based on the true story of an Iranian woman stoned to death after being falsely accused by her husband of adultery.
There's enough of a strong filmmaking backbeat in Bandslam to carry the movie's light tune.
Can we wish for a fresher subplot than that of pleasure-deadened grown-ups who live their lives in a stupor of consumerism?
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The scenery (prettily captured by There Will Be Blood cinematographer Robert Elswit) is littered with heavy symbolism (fire! rain! dead birds!); the performances are merely heavy.
Other stuff happens too, all of it strained and dull.
[Damon] -- who has quietly and steadily turned into a great Everyman actor -- is in nimble control as he reveals his character's deep crazies.

Campion's big-sisterly encouragement of Cornish's lovely, openhearted performance -- and Whishaw's well-matched response -- results in a character instantly, intimately recognizable to anyone remembering her own first love.
After a summer of phony, pasty rom-coms, do this: See a movie where old-fashioned notions of love, faith, strength, and the possibility of redemption are taken seriously.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Whiteout is a conventionally jam-packed, dutifully ludicrous action thriller.
Don't tell Walt Disney, but Hayao Miyazaki  really holds the keys to the magic kingdom.
The Other Man is self-conscious, overproduced, overacted Euro-marital hoo-ha.
Oops, sorry, we're not supposed to think of Mary as mentally ill, psychologically unbalanced, or any of those painful things, just full of gumption and sunny determination.
The good humor, generosity, and love Dabis bestows on her characters in this assured first feature are uniquely hers -- the mark of a talent to watch
Jim Sturgess makes a believable cocky lad who signs on for the con; an oddly bewigged Ben Kingsley is fussier and too actorly as his handler.

It's an original movie idea that feels written for the stage, all the more so since so much of our attention is diverted to admiring how the actors act, in roles with a high degree of technical  difficulty.
Renée Zellweger plays to her strengths as an unsinkable Southern belle in the safe and breezy 1950s period piece My One and Only.

Alexis Bledel plays a Ms. Sunshine who's fresh out of college and unable to find work, and thus -- conveniently for the uninspired makers of this dismayingly conservative dramedy -- she's temporarily bunking back home
The expanded cast of creatures looks great, dressed and animated in the homespun style Acker calls ''stitchpunk.''

Coco Before Chanel examines the influences that made Chanel so different - and so irreplaceable - the way an observant fashion student might deconstruct an haute couture garment to understand how it's built.

With its measured, team-produced screenplay by Mann, Ronan Bennett, and Ann Biderman, Public Enemies makes heavy business of the notion that Hoover ushered in an era of ethically elastic law-enforcement procedures still recognizable today.
Cheery, silly, splattery, and respectful of its elders, this bloody/cheesy subtitled Scandinavian lark is written and directed  by Tommy Wirkola, who has a nice touch with severed limbs.
You need know nothing about Italian politics to completely enjoy the fantastical, Fellini-fied, tragi-comic, biographical fun-for-all Il Divo.
An artlessly powerful performance by newcomer Nicole Behaire anchors American Violet, an instructive, sturdily built drama based on a true story worth teaching.
Spectacularly photographed, gracefully edited, and effectively matter-of-fact in demonstrating the effects of of climate change.

The term isn't generally applied to the subject of a nonfiction film, but 'starring' is the right description for Mike Tyson's participation in James Toback's provocatively sympathetic, impressionistic documentary portrait, Tyson.
A slack do-over fantasy in which Zac Efron, as a basketball star, looks baffled as to why he hasn't been asked to sing and dance.
There's no room for mush in filmmaker Sergey Dvortsevoy's triumphant, intimate drama, not when the necessities of daily life are so elemental, and so tenderly observed.
Set during a joyless Chicago Christmas (hence the carol-like title), this Debbie Downer of a drama is a bitter slog.
[An] overworked if heartfelt indie.
[An] enticing, weightless divertissement, a distant Gallic cousin to Woody Allen's talky comedies of romantic fumbling.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: That warm tone, along with the picture's bright, saturated, anti-CGI look, is a welcome respite from jokes, irony, and the postmodern malaise of know-it-all-ness.
In the jammed landscape of mass-market new releases, it offers an attractive getaway route from self-importance, snark, and chatty comedies about male bonding. Here, stick shifts do the talking.

Matt Tyrnauer's sharp-eyed documentary Valentino: The Last Emperor follows the luxury-loving pooh-bah and his indispensable, since-forever lover and business partner, Giancarlo Giammetti, through a season of magical dresses and minor diva snits.

Shelf mold encrusts this misshapen adaptation of Spinning Into Butter, and Rebecca Gilman's 1999 play about racism and toxic political correctness at a small Vermont college  is lumpy enough as it is.
Monsters vs. Aliens sacrifices soul and edge for safety and bland blue goo.
A crazy mosaic of Americana with tiles scattered and missing. Need I observe and report that the view isn't for every taste? It sure is for mine.
Their message in My Sister's Keeper? Cancer sucks, but there's always the balm of beach scenes and an emo soundtrack.

Earthlings who have fled their unsustainable environment are the belligerent, culturally insensitive visitors, and aliens with big, moist eyes out of a sad-clown painting are the home team in this gentle, dreamy animated sci-fi tale.
Rudo y Cursi is a sly miniaturist pleasure on its own terms, a piquant fable about the bouncing ups and downs of success, failure, competition, and comradeship.
Using the droll, wise stories of Etgar Keret as her guide, Israeli filmmaker Tatia Rosenthal concocts an artful film that   expresses deep thoughts, lightly.
An intense, action-driven war pic, a muscular, efficient standout that   simultaneously conveys the feeling of combat from within as well as what it looks like on the ground.
The fact that Allen wrote the script in the '70s explains something about why his newest movie feels so old.
The chemical energy between Bullock and Reynolds is fresh and irresistible.

An open-hydrant whoooosh of an action thriller about a hijacked NYC subway train with passengers held as hostages -- a caffeinated update of a 1974 city-on-fire cult classic that cracked wise with a cynical, now nostalgia-inducing, graffiti-era veracity.

Heroes and villains clash, then rise up to clash again, just because that's what X-Men do. The truth is, it doesn't matter Y.

Spirit, animal, and human worlds coexist in dreamy harmony in this remarkable drama, winner of the 2010 Cannes Palme d'Or.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [A] marvelous documentary.

Having sampled London and Barcelona in recent films, Woody Allen continues his grand tour of European cities with Midnight in Paris, an ingratiating, tourist-oriented exercise in nostalgia for a city that doesn't exist.

The film deftly pokes fun at the foibles of earthlings -- especially their warring religions -- with warmth and compassion, and shines a light on the contradictions of India's strict but unwritten social rules.
When Dhoom 3 is going at full tilt, as in an autorickshaw chase over corrugated tin village rooftops, it's an exhilarating ride.

The film grabs on tight and doesn't let go.
Out-of-date animation throws up a roadblock for this Indian animated 3D family film.
Quirky deaf man gets entangled in love triangle in poignant Bollywood romantic comedy.
Salman Khan dazzles in rollicking -- and romantic -- Indian action thriller.
The most controversial Hindi film of the year is also the worst.

Batra falls into a formulaic trap on several occasions. But the way he depicts the growing closeness between Rahul and Riana is sincere, and the way their relationship ends up is definitely a stretch for a Hindi film.
It's no surprise that Ready, a wafer-thin romantic comedy from Anees Bazmee, a filmmaker known for dumb-and-dumber knucklehead comedies, fails to make a mark artistically.
More than just a sip of fizzy fun, this 3-hour comedy is Jeroboam-sized.
A hybrid of fact and fiction, this Delhi-based thriller packs a punch no matter the label.
Despite its flaws, 3 Idiots conveys a powerful message about how valuable your friends can be when they push you toward reaching your own highest potential.
Roshan anchors the film with a solid, believable performance and a palpable chemistry with his co-star that will remind audiences just how hot a good Bollywood romance can be.
Its adult and hard-hitting subject matter probably won't bring in masala-loving family crowds, but it offers a lesson with long-lasting emotional and moral impact for thinking audiences.

Bollywood comedy about an unlikely friendship is full of unexpected pleasures.

Sexy, filthy and thoroughly entertaining comedy marks a welcome shift in contemporary Indian cinema.

Despite its intriguing and relevant premise, Ungli suffers from a too-tame and by-the-numbers directorial approach. This stuff is supposed to have viewers raging for revolution on the way to the parking lot; it isn't supposed to be boring.
The movie is devoid of that one secret ingredient that makes audiences love superhero films: It just isn't cool.

Padmaavat's sumptuous palace interiors and classically inspired music lend elegance to the film without overpowering it - a welcome shift in tone from the director of the lavish but uneven Devdas and Saawariya.

[Guzaarish] is restrained and powerful.
This is no arty festival film - where Gulaab Gang succeeds is in its total embrace of the Bollywood style, with all its music and deliberate artifice.
Rockstar is that rare popular film that captures the precise moment when music draws a man into the realm of the divine.
Hrithik Roshan is believable as a brilliant international jewel thief -- but a slack Katrina Kaif lends little to the proceedings.

Sixty-five-year-old Amitabh Bachchan, India's vibrant and virile living legend, is riveting in nearly every film he does. But even a true fan's ardor is tested by the tedious political thriller, Sarkar Raj.

This big-budget summer release starts off awkwardly with a half-hearted music number, but once it kicks into gear, the film's engaging performances and ever-spiraling hysteria make its two-and-a-half-hour running time fly by.
Dark, if satisfying.

[Director Sharma] pads out the songless film with well-executed but overlong action pieces that become even more frustrating when you consider the ways time could have been better spent exploring Aryan's fascinating backstory.

Viewers willing to embrace its skillful and emotionally real depiction of a man making impossible choices -- and especially fans of Akshay Kumar ready to see him excel in a physically and emotionally challenging role -- will be well rewarded.

The main problem with the film is in the casting of its stars.
Farhan Akhtar's intelligent performance is a highlight of the film.
Even its formulaic elements are as comforting as a hot, steaming cup of masala tea.
The overly long Don 2 falls short on two key points -- the screenplay and Khan's performance.

Shankar has been working on getting this film made for the past decade, and he clearly is so thrilled to get Robot into theaters that his enthusiasm is infectious. Filmgoers with a taste for the absurd will be richly rewarded.

Just play Grand Theft Auto 5 instead.

Even if TFA is mostly fan service, I'll take it.

Should make horror fans quite content.
