The film has magnificent performances and cinematography to match; moreover, it is quiet and it is civilized, desirable qualities that are rarely available on the big screen.
Aside from some wacky, hand-held wavering goings-on with the camera, Mondovino is really interesting to look at, amusing, smart and already causing a huge furor in the wine world.

A movie that pre-teen and adolescent girls will embrace. (Pre-teen and adolescent girls will also embrace Chad, Jesse, Lindsay, Hilary, fake tans, designer cellphones, junior prom and Uggs, so proceed with caution.)
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: We're not sure why one is supposed to care.
If it's spectacle you're after, it's spectacle you'll get.
This film is either a profound investigation of recent Italian history and a loving look at the national psyche -- warts, poetry and all -- or else it's a really superb soap opera.
movie_title: The Best of Youth (La meglio gioventù) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Robots is often dazzling to look at and has the requisite items for a ripping tale of good versus evil, but for this viewer, it just wasn't that easy to warm up to metalheads.
It's a full-on adrenaline feature.
It's a fascinating story, and mostly because Garry Kasparov is a fascinating subject.
movie_title: Game Over: Kasparov and the Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It ain't War & Peace, but there are some pleasant comedic moments here.
A dreadful movie, and if you've seen the advertisements you've already seen the laughs -- all three of them -- it has to offer.
It's a tiny-budget indie film with an interesting sci-fi story premise. Too bad the mystery overwhelms the humanity, so it doesn't quite work.
A beautifully paced story.
The film purports to tell a heist story, but it is utterly lacking in logic, tension or intrigue. And it ends in a way that resets the bar for ludicrous.
While visually impressive -- the film won the Silver Bear for best director at the 2003 Berlin Film Festival -- Son Frere is draining to look at.
Tautou anchors the film with her calm gaze and endless faith, and her performance is mesmerizing.
Thanks to an ensemble cast that includes Robert De Niro, Barbra Streisand and Dustin Hoffman, Meet The Fockers is much more fun than anticipated.
There are no bodily function jokes in Fat Albert, and not one disbelieving or stupid parental figure. As family fare goes, that alone may be worth the price of admission.
An exercise in intrigue and tension, and the slow, constant build-up of dread has a certain Hitchcock flair.
This is a story too big to even begin to comprehend, much less turn into a movie; still, by keeping the focus small, the filmmakers manage big impact.
White Noise works because Michael Keaton makes you believe in what he's going through.
Tarnation is visually inventive, even dazzling at times, and the music is terrific, but the subject matter is hugely depressing and weirdly narcissistic.
A magical film about many forms of love and about the energy of life.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Brisk, smart, funny, tragic and sometimes downright thrilling.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Jugnot is earnest and believable in the role of the new teacher -- that lived-in face of his always helps -- and the children in the cast all manage very good performances.
You wonder if the filmmakers intended you to utterly despise everyone in the story. Probably not.
Pooh's Heffalump Movie is just the thing for really little kids and their parents.
A treat to look at.
A documentary full of hope. That, in our humble opinion, is worth the price of admission.

While the film tries to tell a good story and illuminate various issues for the handicapped at the same time, the third act slides into the maudlin, and that would be the extra-strength Irish maudlin at that, with its hint o' blithering blarney.
A rollicking good time at the movies.
Be Cool hopes to be an equal-opportunity insult package, but where there might be edge or wit or fresh observation, there's just dumb shock value.
An inspirational tale about the workers who have decided to take back their lives and their livelihood.
A marvellous tale about sex, love, age and family.
Erotic, violent and bursting with colour.
The whole thing is charming to look at, wise and funny -- but, alas, slim. Slight.
You can sum up the worthy aspects of this one in two words -- Mike Myers.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Features serious over-acting, lousy effects, appalling dialogue, misplaced and ill-advised romantic interludes, a complete lack of tension, nothing to link the story set in the past with the section set in the present and very bad wigs.
Anyone hungerin' to get back in the saddle for a good ol' epic western will find The Missing highly satisfying.
See it for the beauty of the first hour, but after that, well -- don't say you weren't warned.
The film has plenty of wicked social jokes you needn't be Danish to get.
A tired remake of the usual dance movies.
Visually, it's a charming movie, but for a film that celebrates storytelling it's a bit of a jumble. Sadly, this Big Fish is a flounder.
A delightful spoof of everything pretentious in Hollywood.
It involves stereotypical characters, amateurish filmmaking and a really shopworn story.
Meyers has written a killer story about grown-ups, risk-taking, passion and vulnerability and more or less disguised it all as a romantic comedy.

Tupac: Resurrection does not shy away from the violence or controversy in the rapper's life, but this film is a love letter, no question. Shakur comes across as smart, energetic and deeply philosophical.
Calendar Girls is The Full Monty for women, with the same regular-folk approach to storytelling and the same entertaining and endearing qualities.
This is one strange outing. We mean that in the nicest way.
This is mediocre TV fare, somehow extended from the permitted 30-minute slot to feature film length.
Monster is a very disturbing film, but an exhilarating movie-going experience.
This is a funny (albeit violent) film about the transformative power of love.
This is very rich fare.
Oddly paced and emotionally flat.
A clear-eyed and mostly affectionate look at the world of ballet.
Has lots of well-wrought tension, plenty of (sick) humour and wonderfully staged gory stuff.
Despite the small canvas, Gaz Bar Blues manages to take on the universe.
50 First Dates is not hideous. It's not horrible. It's not very good, either, but it won't make you want to go out and hurt someone from how bad it is, because it's not that bad.
Just why this sort of big-screen pap comes around and comes around again remains a mystery.
Makes adults laugh out loud and will keep kids occupied and amused.
Thanks to a brilliant script and spot-on performances, Pieces Of April turns out to be a perfect film about families and what makes them work.
A film that must be watched with a pair of cardboard glasses stuck across one's face. Oh, goodie. This may not be unmitigated joy for persons older than 8 or 9, tops. Just so you know.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: One of those movies that went horribly wrong, but for one financial or contractual reason or another, it had to go into movie theatres anyway.
The real horror deal.
An epic love story, a shorthand history of Japan and a visually magnificent study of the relationship between memory and identity.
Like everything else Allen has done in the last decade -- dull, self-indulgent and not funny. Enough, already.
Between an entirely attractive cast of characters and stupendous, awe-inspiring cinematography, Step Into Liquid is wonderful entertainment.
A keeper.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Rundown is big fun at the movies.
Has no bite whatsoever.
The characters are all strangely endearing, and the real pleasure of the movie is just watching them interact.
Out Of Time is a cop thriller with a great cast. Trouble is, you may feel as if you've seen it all before.
The mother-son relationship between Dukakis and McKellar is both believable and very moving.
Intelligent adult fare is hard to find on the big screen, but Clint Eastwood manages nicely with this tough ensemble piece.
Pretty to look at, really and truly funny, streaked with cynicism and chock full of talent.
The Station Agent is funny, respectful, and best of all, hopeful in nature.
Offers full, living meaning to the word 'gratuitous' as it applies to film violence and is an exercise in being grossed out.
Juicy Hollywood fare.
An entirely watchable drama despite a clumsy opening and closing.
It turns out to be a really manipulative, self-congratulatory film about a pack of people who learn to treat a handicapped black man like a human being. Goody for them.
The story is boring and tragic, but never so tragic that it stops being boring.
A brave film.
An odd and really wonderful mix of sadness and wonder.
It's hilarious.
Funny, exhilarating, and an amazing adventure to look at.
The real world in which these characters live is only hinted at, making their behaviour look mighty precious most of the time.
It's one of those movies that seems to have started out as one thing and ended up as quite another.
Clothes, friends, makeup, popularity, high school: All this, and Lindsay Lohan, too.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: My Architect works on so many levels -- and all of them so engaging -- it could make your head spin.
Quote not available.
A transporting sort of experience at the movies.
It isn't great by any stretch, but it could be just the escape for anyone hoping to avoid the big-budget blockbusters currently using up all the available oxygen.
Camp, overwrought, unsophisticated and big fun to watch.
A fascinating film about a country's 200- year fight for democracy and the contributions made by one extraordinary man.
Smart, hopeful, good-natured and essentially kind-hearted, eh?
Lefcoe gets her message across through a very strong script and terrific performances.
Funny and forgettable.
It's all weird. It's often humourous. It can be a tad precious but it's mostly very engaging.
Thanks to strong performances from Cole and Vint and some truly hilarious writing, 19 Months is a pleasure to look at and to laugh at.
A really putrid movie.
A terrific B-movie.
Fascinating.
It's really the feel-bad movie of the week. In a genius sort of way.
Absolutely wonderful to look at.
The effects are a wonder to behold.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A delightful film -- funny, sweet and touching.
A subtle and unexpected pleasure, all nuanced performance and character detail.
The film takes aim at so many contemporary targets and with such gusto that you fear each time you laugh you might be missing another wonderful line.
There are some fabulous laughs along the way, but not quite enough to disguise the fact that the movie seems to have been tinkered with.
For people who like this sort of thing, this is just the sort of thing they like.
Overwrought and self-indulgent.
When the 9-year-old in the next seat can anticipate every plot development and emotional response, you know you're in sitcom land.
The only thing missing is a story.
Generally smart and often very funny. And there is a pearl of wisdom or two in there among the laughs.
The events are simple. The emotions are hugely complex.
It's just bad storytelling.
It doesn't make a lot of sense, but there are some lovely dance numbers, and it isn't tough to look at the young and beautiful leads.
Okay, great performances, nice to look at -- but what this movie is missing is something to hold it together in the middle.
There are about three good laughs in Starsky & Hutch.
By keeping his focus small and personal, director Michael Winterbottom completely immerses a viewer in Jamal and Enayat's experience. It's quite devastating.
A speedy, gadget-filled adventure with the same overall innocence that will attract parents and children.
The ending is somewhat soggy, but until that point, Spartan is a graceful exercise in fear and loathing.
Very clever and very daffy, and it will remind you how delicious trash cinema can be.
The first hour is perfect. The rest is a mess.
The Technical Writer is a film that works because of the writing.
Father And Sons deals with a serious subject, but it's generally very funny, and the humour is more or less adult.
The film has an unfinished feel, and plays like a film 101 outing.
The performances are understated and touching, the humour mostly deadpan, the philosophical message subtle.
Quick and funny, and funny in the way that makes children laugh out loud with delight.
Wanders around in a state of creative lassitude and finally collapses in an ending that smells suspiciously of market-testing.
Simultaneously horrifying and transporting.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of those small features that sneaks up on you and stays with you long after you leave the theatre.
Talk about enchanting.
Did the writer lack opposable thumbs? Was this edited with a machete? Do the filmmakers hate women?
If you've seen the Griswolds go off on any of those National Lampoon holidays, you've sort of already experienced Johnson Family Vacation.
Connie And Carla has exactly the same appeal of My Big Fat Greek Wedding in terms of charm and innocent humour.
The film is busy and funny, but not in a laugh-out-loud kind of way.
A visually magnificent film in which the camera will help you remember just how the world looks to children.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Touching The Void is a real you-are-there experience, filmed with awe-inspiring shots of the mountains and deeply moving personal interviews.
There's an air of menace about even the most cheerful characters and a sense of dread in every undertaking -- it's quite wonderful, really.
Basic Instinct 2 is trashy and stupid, and not really in a fun sort of way.
Now you know why the moms or dads who must go to family movies are always holding reefer.
It's the sort of movie that shortens your life and makes you doubt the existence of God.
Blood Diamond works because of the performance from DiCaprio, which is stunning. Talk about rising about the material.
One needn't be a fan of fantasy-adventure to be thrilled by the winged lizard in Eragon.
We can accept football as a metaphor for picking yourself up and dusting yourself off and finding the courage to get on with life, but only if we've come to care about the people playing the game.
Stellar cast, plodding storytelling.
This is one of the best movies of the whole year. And likely one of the best of next year, too.
There's something missing at the heart of the film, some spark, and it may be nothing more than a lack of chemistry between Norton and Watts.
Pretentious twaddle that tells you nothing about Arbus. Robert Downey Jr. manages to be dignified even when covered in mountains of body hair. That's something.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If children will sit still for 'once upon a time' in a book, why does it all have to be dumbed down (and turned up) for the screen?
The movie is pretty to look at, but over-long and, in the end, self-conscious. What a disappointment.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bleak-ish, inebriated and quite exhilarating in the full-on Bukowski fashion.
Although the filmmaker, Nick Cassavetes, doesn't seem to be trying to provide the whys and wherefores of the case, he has created an unmistakable (if uneven) indictment of the lifestyle.
... Mount Pleasant is mostly well done and believable.
One of those rare movies that is so fantastically, fabulously bad, so bursting full of putrid dialogue and appalling scenes, that it becomes worth seeing as some sort of artifact of horribleness.
Partition is big and ambitious, but the storytelling gets too close to melodrama too often. The film is clunky, the acting fairly wooden; Neve Campbell seems to struggle with her English accent.
This is a heartbreaker. The little boy, Kolya Spiridonov, loves the camera, and the camera loves him. Interesting way to illustrate contemporary social problems in Russia.
Why do movies like this always have such unsatisfactory endings? Who pays to watch this stuff, anyway? You? Hope not.
You wouldn't call this a recommendation, exactly, but the new Eddie Murphy movie is not nearly as horrible as it looks.

According to anyone you care to ask, Factory Girl has been cut and recut a couple of times and may not even be the movie that filmmaker George Hickenlooper intended to make. This sounds reasonable, as nobody sets out to make a movie this banal.
Breach, not unlike The Good Shepherd, is a flat film. All the action plays out in the same grey fashion, with few emotional ups or downs, little tension and no real surprises.
At times, it wobbles too close to melodrama, but the performances are strong and the history upon which the story is based is so devastating that the film packs a wallop despite its faults.

In the way it celebrates can-do spirit and the rugged individual and the power of dreams and all that, The Astronaut Farmer seems to be a nostalgia outing about another time and place and a celebration of the people who lived in that America.

This is an earnest and rather sweet film, and one that will vanish from your mind as soon as the final credits roll. You could bring the children, who might like to know a little bit about the woman who created Peter Rabbit.
The movie is often beautiful to look at, but weak storytelling overwhelms attractive pictures.
You can see the good intentions, but this is a problematic film, with the usual low-budget drawbacks plus horrifying assault scenes.
Deja Vu gets mighty close to goofy from time to time, but Washington pulls it all back together -- sometimes, it seems, just by being there.
Garcia's storytelling lacks highs and lows and has far too much going on. And on.
A couple of good laughs, but mostly a big mess.
All The King's Men has a big cast and a big story and a big, important message, but it all comes across as overwrought and overstuffed.
The characters are stereotypes and the action is mostly sitcom-ish, and the film seems to invite an audience to laugh at the characters rather than with them.
Slow and pretty and essentially unsatisfying.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Science Of Sleep is a collection of lovely little moments and inspired effects with not much holding them together.
The first hour of The Guardian gives every indication that some sort of contemporary Greek tragedy is about to be played out. And then the film goes right off the rails.
Keeping Mum can't decide if it's a black comedy or a touching emotional journey; trying to be both at once just doesn't work.
The film is such humourless drivel it's depressing just to write about it.
A fascinating look at a violent and disturbing chapter in Africa's history.
The story is idiotic, the dialogue moronic and the characters are cardboard cutouts. Stupid cardboard cutouts.
Q: Did we need two Truman Capote movies? A: Yes. Actually, we probably need more.
This is one of those films that sneaks up on you and offers some wonderful surprises in storytelling and performance -- and the performances are truly astounding, particularly from Winslet and Haley.
...A huge disappointment. This is a truly astounding waste of time, money and talent.
The film, which reduced a roomful of jaded film critics to tears, could literally make you sick.
Catch A Fire is an interesting combo of biopic and political thriller.
The characters are all two-dimensional, or maybe one, except Martin Short as Jack Frost.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Flushed Away has a pleasant moral about friendship, community and working together, and it's amusing as all get-out to children. Too bad the movie won't appeal as much to accompanying adults.
A charming film that gets nudged toward greatness by Julie Walters.
The movie plays like a Film 101 final project, and the writer/director, Benjamin Paquette, is not quite ready for prime time.
movie_title: Year in the Death of Jack Richards (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Don't read any of the reviews beforehand, including this one. Just go. The less you know about the film going in, the more fun it is to watch -- no hype, no expectations high or low, no preconceptions.
This is the sort of film that packs a wallop, emotionally.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty of singing and haircutting and pretty landscape and annoying crap to fill in the blanks between confrontations.
Days Of Glory is an extraordinary document, part war film, part love story, part history lesson.
The movie has exactly four laughs.
Black Snake Moan is a weird little story held together by two gobsmacking performances.

If you'd like a look at Paris in all its splendour, look no further than Angel-A. Just be sure that in order to see Paris in all its splendour you don't mind sitting through a silly little comedy with a dopey ending.
Day Watch is fast and furious and larded with bizarre laughs, and given its ending, we really can't wait to see what happens in Dusk Watch, the third installment.

The film is interesting to look at for the ways in which the different stories are edited together, but the technical element isn't enough to keep you fully engaged, and eventually it all becomes a bit dreary.
Anyone tired of taking their children to summer blockbusters (or Big Tired Crap Part III as they're referred to 'round here) will be happy to have a look at Nancy Drew.

A completely engaging film. It's all about performance, and Timothy Spall is riveting as the earnest hangman. If you're desperate for a movie that has nothing to do with sequels or product placement, look no further.
As pure character study, it's a keeper.
Bruce Springsteen has even given the film his own rare seal of approval by providing a song for the soundtrack -- something he almost never does. See that? Even the Boss likes Gracie.
It's odd, endearing and weirdly funny for an hour, and after that it's a bit of a self-conscious mess.
First Snow is an auspicious directorial debut for Mark Fergus. It will be interesting to see what he does next.
As spectacle goes, this is, ah, spectacular.
If it ran five minutes longer it would cross the line from amusing to annoying. But it doesn't.
It's all terribly Great Gatsby, and fun to watch.
The film is charming and often funny, but under all that sweetness are some very sharp observations about contemporary life.
The Boss of it All is indeed a comedy and often a very funny one -- at its best a bit like The Office, and at its worst like a deranged Danish version of the 1960s Carry On farces.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While the film has far more emotional life than the genre usually offers, it doesn't lack for action, and it's a thinking-man's sort of action, at that.
Sharp dialogue and good performances keep it interesting. The film suggests a level of talent in Sienna Miller that she rarely gets a chance to show.
Manufacturing Dissent seems disingenuous at times and just plain stupid at others.
No Reservations doesn't ring entirely true, which isn't too surprising for the genre, but it is a cut above most offerings of its sort.
Too bad the storytelling, which is somewhat disjointed, isn't as good as the rest of the deal -- but Don Cheadle is so good at what he does you probably won't even notice.
The story is touching, the dialogue clever, the cast is great and the period detail is impressive.
It's mostly a light and funny comedy of manners, and sexual manners at that. The neat trick is that under the laughs are some dark little truths about men and women.
Marci X is silly, crude, juvenile and often very, very funny.
Red Road is an atmospheric little thriller made up of equal parts paranoia, loneliness and anxiety.
Severance is a bit of British fear-mongering that pulls you in with a nifty mix of black humour and white-knuckle scares.
Mr. Brooks has a crisp, clever script, lacings of black humour, heart-racing pacing and convincing performances.
This is an unusual and completely engaging movie.
A delight to look at, and full of both beautiful music and beautiful silences.
The movie could have used some energy overall and possibly an ending that makes sense.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Namesake is an understated picture that draws a viewer completely into the world it presents.
The film is pretty, predictable and far too long ...

The film has plenty of unsettling atmosphere, tension and general graveyard oogie-boogie, but you can't care about the characters or their incomprehensible predicament, so those chills and thrills never go all the way to gripping. They stop at griping.
Irresistible.
Meet The Robinsons is a 3D outing so technically dazzling that you'll hear people say "Wow!" out loud in the theatre during the first few minutes. The problem? The remaining 98 minutes.
Despite a clunky start (and pedestrian filmmaking) the story has enough humour and heroics to amuse viewers of any age.
A film about secrets and lies, not to mention overacting and poor casting choices.
It's not our idea of a good time, but we'll bet that plenty of adolescent boys will be doing their best to look 18 years old this weekend.
Kasdan displays a whimsical sense of humour that translates nicely to the screen. It will be interesting to see what he does next.
Outside of some lovely encounters between Jessica and her beloved grandmother, the film seems mostly obvious and two-dimensional. And with subtitles.
It's a pretty terrible movie, a jumble of bad edits and confused storytelling, but it's so tough to get a movie made in Canada that we don't want to dwell on just how putrid Crossing really is.

The film has gross scenes of rape and torture and killing. It also has a stern lecture on the violence peddled by those who create entertainment (seriously), so you won't know whether to laugh or cry. So just don't go.
A fast-paced war thriller distinguished by its own ambiguous morality.
How will he get someone to find his body and save him from dying? And soon. So this boring movie can end. Please. Could you hurry? Anyone?
You can bet on a happy ending in Lucky You, a mildly entertaining spin through the world of professional card players in Vegas.
Fairly dull. Better to spend your money on that other Flying Scotsman -- Obree's autobiography.
It's all good. Actually, it's way better than good. This is a film for anyone who's almost given up on the movies.
Georgia Rule veers back and forth awkwardly between humour and drama, getting both wrong. The various family secrets and plot twisties in the tale are painfully, psych 101 obvious.
Waitress is a pastel-coloured fairytale about love and pie-baking. And fresh choices.
A slow, complex tale about how people live together, and about the rituals and relationships that constitute community.
The movie just puts its big ol' metaphor in your face and hope the actors can drag you along with them. Almost works, too, but in the last 20 minutes, Bug goes right off the rails. Pity.

In a way, this film moves the Adam Sandler 'idiot' persona and the Adam Sandler Punch Drunk Love persona closer together; anyway, fans will like Click, no doubt, and even non-fans will be entertained.
The soundtrack is brilliant, the cinematography strange and wonderful and the performances are creepy good.
This is an odd and endearing look at the minds behind those tricky puzzles as well as the minds on the receiving end of all that Down and Across.
There doesn't seem to be much point to A Prairie Home Companion, but it's smart and charming and the music is lovely. Maybe that's the point.

The story is a strange mix of action/adventure, character development and comedy. Here is the sort of wonderful writing that will have you laughing out loud at gunplay and rooting for an utterly amoral broker of death.
Given the graphic sex scenes, it is surprisingly dull. The music isn't great, either, now that we think about it.
An uneven but charming directorial debut from actor Liev Schreiber.
A straight-up case of really bad filmmaking, all mangled punchlines and sitcom setups and all of it too long in the telling.
Waiting... is rude, crude, childish and stupid, which is pretty much everything you want in a gross-out humour movie.
This is a film with a dramatic heart and plenty to say about family.
This is an engaging film about a real family and about optimism in the midst of hardship, but it's also a fascinating historical document.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Only Levy gets out of this one looking good.
The story is cluttered with bears, abusive boyfriends, tragic loss and plenty of other extraneous detail.
A big disappointment.
Lots of talent, all of it pretty well wasted here.
It's an interesting story, no question, but it's good where it could have been great.

If there's a Harry Potter fan at your house, you're going to this movie regardless of what anybody says about it. Fortunately, what most people are saying about Harry Potter And The Goblet Of Fire is, 'wow!'
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A brutally honest look at how some men view fatherhood. Not too surprisingly, it's laugh out loud funny.
The film does not invite you to root for either side of the conflict, just to see these guys as human. It is almost impossible not to empathize with their intense personal struggle.
Not fabulous, but fairly interesting.
Delightfully seedy outing involves cold cash, hot women, cruel betrayal and Christmas Eve.
This is a stupid comedy and you'll probably be embarrassed by how much you laugh.
The director, Raja Gosnell, is the auteur responsible for the Scooby-Doo movies, Big Momma's House and Home Alone 3. Enough said.
There are several laugh-out-loud moments in the adult romantic comedy Cake, a film with the magical ability to -- poof! -- leave your head the second it leaves the screen.
This is a rare look inside the Orthodox community in Jerusalem and it's educational as well as entertaining.

It is particularly affecting to watch Heath Ledger's portrayal of a man struggling along the road of life with the wrong map, a man thunderstruck to discover that a secret sharer, a soul mate, could even be in the realm of the possible for him.
This is a lovely film; it's about a million times better than the other so-called children's or family movies out there.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Its bad writing is made worse by sloppy filmmaking -- and it's a shame, because you can see the potential here.
Undiscovered is a pack of romantic nonsense arranged to suit a pre-teen audience.
Depressing? Yeesh -- but also hopeful in its depiction of Stryker's determination.
Clever and fascinating, but it's ultimately a downer.
It's tough to argue with a movie that features close-ups of Labrador puppies. Still, the Japanese feature Quill is one of the strangest dog movies this viewer has ever encountered.
movie_title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Rebound is a good example of the mediocre product so readily available at the movies. It's just sort of nothing at all really, a pleasant and forgettable 90 minutes of ... whatever.
As coming-of-age stories go, My Summer Of Love is far more provocative and mysterious than most.
An energetic and endearing story about three generations of a Chinese immigrant family.
The film is very slow and prone to embarrassing attempts at humour: Beatrix smokes a joint and becomes fascinated by airplanes, for example. Ha, ha.
A hopeful undertaking, but you have to get through plenty of dark stuff before that becomes obvious.
There isn't much of a story to it, but the comic combo of Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn is outrageous.

The Bad News Bears is not risque at all, but it's often cute and has a handful of laughs, and that's about it. Not every film can be a winner, you know, but it still takes 12 to make a team and there's no 'i' in movie.

A riveting study of age, decline, the self-interest peculiar to humans and grotesque family dysfunctionality and -- let's quickly mention the riveting part again -- we sure wouldn't want to have to see it twice.

What Munga has to say in this feature directorial debut is delivered via a quick-paced, gritty crime story that is both entertaining and enlightening.
Jumbled or not, Page One: Inside The New York Times is a movie bound to appeal to anyone who cherishes his morning paper, or who obsessively watches news on TV or the Internet.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You won't be more than mildly interested, but Little White Lies has such a stellar cast that it's not a hardship to keep watching.
Parents tired of noise and frantic nonsense filling in for plot and character should find this movie a breath of fresh air.

Underwater shots of ocean vegetation and sea life are fantastic, the soundtrack (which involves nature sounds) is riveting and the general air of the thing is mysterious and mystical, at least to Ontario eyes.
There may be some two dozen other TV and film versions at your disposal, but this new Jane Eyre, from director Cary Fukunaga, is a must-see proposition.
The film is proof that a good story and a great cast can overcome a lot of obstacles.
The humour in A Matter of Size is somewhat puerile, but the film does cover important social issues in its own gentle way.
If you already know the work of filmmaker Tom McCarthy -- who made The Station Agent and The Visitor -- then you know you have a treat in store with this latest project.
You need have no political or historical investment in the movie whatsoever to find it completely fascinating.
Insidious is a haunted house story. In some ways it's smarter than most.
This indie film about a young couple with various commitment issues is written with a lot of snap, crackle and pop culture cool.
Born to Be Wild is a film you'll want to show your children. With any luck, it will eventually find its way into every elementary classroom.
An oddly charming stoner comedy set in medieval times.
It's an apocalyptic fable for the cool kids, and while most of the comedic elements work, the faux supernatural stuff is just dopey. That's probably the point. Never mind.
Bill Cunningham New York is a portrait of an extraordinary man who possesses such arcane knowledge as the difference between right and wrong.
The animals have names; call it anthropomorphism if you like, but the cat families and their gripping adventures are all the more real to child viewers for that bit of familiarity.
A trite, arch, frantic, condescending, vaguely racist and homophobic little bonbon of computer generated noise. It's more like an assault than a movie.
Even the Rain is black and white in its moral intent, but all manner of fascinating detail exists around the edges of the main story.
Let us begin by saying The Beaver is good enough to let you forget everything you think you know about Mel Gibson for 90 minutes.
Thrilling stories; mediocre movie. It happens.
This film has no teeth, and philosophy doesn't help you chew.

On its surface, the film marries gross-out comedy and romantic comedy and will make you laugh out loud. Right underneath that is a truly wonderful movie about female friendship that's quite unlike anything else out there.
Meet Monica Velour is an uncomfortable mix of humour and drama, a hybrid sex farce/coming of age story distinguished by an attractive weirdness.

Stripped of Hollywood embellishment, Meek's Cutoff examines issues of leadership, trust and 'the other' in ways that suggest it could be taken as a metaphor for the American way of thought, then or now. Well, maybe that's just us.
At $12.75 a movie ticket, you might be better off buying the comic book.
Could a movie save your life? Forks Over Knives is a documentary willing to try as it examines diet and degenerative disease.
Last Night is quiet and it moves slowly. It's also dense with conversation, so it won't appeal to everyone, but it's a worthwhile (albeit depressing) relationship drama.
Something about this feature never ignites.
It's going to take more than one film to offset the extreme suckage of this summer's movies, but the crime caper 2 Guns is a good start.
You have to give credit to Conan The Barbarian 3D for truth in advertising: Conan really is barbaric, and you get to see all that head-smashing and blood-letting in revolting 3D detail.
Caterpillar is brilliant but tough to look at; Wakamatsu isn't pulling any punches as he delivers his message. It's the Feel-Bad Movie of the Week, really.
The coolest element of the whole thing is probably the way the movie ties art (specifically those plays) and politics together.
It isn't great. But it gets close.

It is astounding to witness how Sophie unfolds without benefit of energy, plot or character development, but all this lethargy is booted forward by a soundtrack consisting of relentless and life-shortening pop songs.
Time really is money, people. Invest neither here.
Cell 211 is both gritty and gripping, and if the second half is not quite as electrifying as the first, much is forgiven because the story is so clever.
A slow, thoughtful meditation on the waxing and waning of a love affair.
Utterly stupid, not to mention rude, crude and irreverent in the extreme, A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas is exactly what the fans are hungering for.
The first thing you need to know about a four-hour-plus movie is that you'll probably wish it were longer.

The Mill and the Cross is visually transporting, a painterly undertaking in every sense of the word. It's a neat case of a contemporary art form conveying to an audience what the painting itself might have conveyed to its viewers hundreds of years ago.
The Descendants has a jaunty, energetic air about it. It's just the thing to lure you into the heart of a family tragedy.
Olsen is so good as a person coping with the aftermath of physical and psychological abuse that the movie has made her an 'overnight sensation'.
Compact comic Kevin Hart completed a wildly successful 90-city tour this year and he's got the movie to prove it.
movie_title: Kevin Hart: Laugh At My Pain (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The astonishing experience of watching Michelle Williams transform herself into Marilyn Monroe tends to block out everything else going on.
An epic crime drama from Rio de Janeiro with a thrilling pace and an over-the-top body count.
Shame is a brilliant drama; it may also be the most uncomfortable 100 minutes you spend in a movie theatre this year.
Tomboy is a charming film about childhood and identity.
There is no doubt an audience for this material among adolescent boys, but for almost everyone else, this is 82 deja vu minutes of your life you're not getting back.
The film is blackly funny, incisive and often moving, and the performances are spectacular.
A year in the wilderness with Werner Herzog as a guide is a unique film experience.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Artist is a witty little confection, bound to please but not necessarily to linger in the mind.

Dragonslayer is an amazing window into a particular part of the culture and how we live now. You'll think about Skreech -- his father's day gift for his son, his new job at a bowling alley -- for a long time after you leave the theatre.
It's fast and furious the whole way, and there's a lot to look at.
Your job is probably to accompany children to this film and they, the target audience, will probably like it very much.

Shebib, who would probably be the first to admit that Goin' Down the Road is a hard act to follow, tells the story in Down the Road Again with energy and humour and he gets terrific performances from his cast.
If you're in the market for a subversive indie comedy this week, consider The Untitled Work of Paul Shepard.
movie_title: The Untitled Work Of Paul Shepard (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A staid Frenchman has his life turned upside down by a handful of Spanish maids in The Women on the 6th Floor.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Chasing Madoff is an interesting story. Too bad it's such a mediocre movie.
It's slow, vaguely preachy and filled with characters who are impossible to like.
If you like your cops and robbers stories laced with Irish humour, you'll want to see The Guard, a film that blends crime and blarney in equal measure.
The mission is accomplished, more or less.
It plays like a Film 101 collection of no-budget, blood-spurting special effects; other than shock value, the film has little to offer.
The projection and anthropomorphic comments are truly fascinating.
Gainsbourg is a noble attempt and interesting enough to keep you watching, but it's bound to disappoint fans of the singer's and possibly will confuse any newcomer to the story.
Lautner seems perfectly capable of playing a three-dimensional character who can also, as it happens, kick butt, but you'd never know it from Abduction.
Limelight joins an ever-growing movie and book library about the glory days of New York club life.
If you know nothing about the tiles, the film might play like an urban mini-thriller. It's never entirely satisfying, however, and the filmmakers seem to run out of steam before their story is told.
movie_title: Resurrect Dead: The Mystery of the Toynbee Tiles (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are some laughs here, no question, but it seems to take every ounce of Faris' comic ability to keep the story moving forward.
It does appear to be the kind of movie people either love or hate. Either way, it gets under your skin.
Dream House is a psychological thriller with a real mystery at its core: What the heck happened here?
Weirdly, you can see how terrific Margaret should have been.
For American-Iranian filmmaker Maryam Keshavarz, Circumstance is a labour of love. It is also an accomplished first narrative feature.
The Interrupters is a film that offers an unflinching look at urban violence but also introduces a ray of hope.
This one is a noble failure.
If this sounds silly, it is, but it's also very funny. Both English and French Canadians get to be the butt of the jokes.
The film is fairly typical of the genre.
The Ides of March is a character study dressed up as a political thriller, and it's a terrific yarn.
If you're tired of gross-out humour and interested to see what three leading comics do with this mild-mannered material, The Big Year is well worth a look.
A terrific thriller about a man who is increasingly plagued by apocalyptic visions
Dead Dreams is a thriller with gross torture scenes where the thrills should be. Just thought we'd mention it.
A story that quietly captures both the general horror and the faint possibility of hope that distinguish teenage life.
Briskly paced, nicely noirish and populated by many actors you trust, The Lincoln Lawyer is a solid crime drama worth seeing.
Weird and creepy is pretty much what's on offer in The Canyons, but not so much of either that it gets interesting.
You can see what director Lee Daniels was after here, but the material overwhelms the storytelling.
You'd be forgiven for expecting it to be far more interesting than it is.

Wiig is at her best, Jones is a revelation, Chris Hemsworth is a wonderful surprise in the movie and Kate McKinnon steals the show. They're all weirdly endearing, too, and it has nothing to do with nostalgia.
Captain Fantastic is an engaging character study about compromise, humility, letting go and love of family. It's one of the best films you'll see all year.
This is a visually interesting meditation on human emotion, and it's too bad there isn't quite enough story to go around.

Bad Moms is full of bad language and worse behaviour, but bottom line, it's a valentine to moms everywhere. Despite what you've been seeing all summer on the big screen, real superheroes wear aprons, not capes.
From an historical viewpoint, the events depicted in Anthropoid are more than enough to hold a viewer's interest, but you never forget that you're watching a movie.
For sheer audacity, Sausage Party is impressive.
It's a credit to Streep and to filmmaker Stephen Frears (Dangerous Liaisons, The Queen) that you will laugh at the absurdity of Jenkins' situation - but never at the lady herself.
Jack Huston is impressive as Judah Ben-Hur. He brings a natural air of noblesse oblige to the role, not to mention the emotional nuance that Mr. Heston could never seem to muster.
It's a shame. The worst part is that you can see what War Dogs could have been.
Want to see things blow up good? Independence Day: Resurgence really delivers. However, if you like a bit of story to go with all those explosions -- forget it.
Hell or High Water is set up like a cops and robbers drama, but it plays out like a complicated western -- no black-hats-and-white-hats simplicity here. It's all moral shades of grey.
It's not a terrible movie, but it is a lacklustre feature debut for director Luke Scott.
It's a rousing good time at the movies.
Bridget Jones's Baby leaves two happy impressions: 1) Welcome back Bridget! 2) More Emma Thompson, please.
Despite some over-obvious symbols and heavy-handed soundtrack choices, The Birth of a Nation is a powerful bit of moviemaking about history and the ongoing issue of racial inequality.

There's a surreal quality to Two Lovers and a Bear that gets underlined by the appearance of the Ursus maritimus of the title; DeHaan has called the movie an adult fairy tale, and that's an apt description.
As courtroom dramas go, Denial is somewhat sedate.
Up for some brainless fun?

Mean Dreams is a coming-of-age drama that evolves into a crime thriller. There's too much going on here, and the story eventually falls apart under its own weight, but there's still a lot to like about this engaging film.
It's so good it may restore your faith in cinema.

Fans of Tom Hanks, of the books, or of the movies made from the books will likely find Inferno an acceptable amusement for the usual reasons of loyalty and familiarity. All others should consider themselves warned.
The Light Between Oceans is completely engaging and it's heartbreaking, though not so heartbreaking, Mr. Cianfrance seems to suggest, as the simple passage of time.
Faith and fighting -- two of Mel Gibson's biggest obsessions -- are at the heart of his excellent new movie, Hacksaw Ridge. It's a war movie about a pacifist.

The Shallows is brisk and engaging, and a great vehicle for Lively. The film has the sort of breathtaking cinematography that will inspire you to visit the ocean. And a story that may stop you from ever going into the water again.
It's not bad, Genius, but it could have been great, and that's the disappointment.
Helped by along by a great cast, a haunting soundtrack and terrific attention to period detail, The Witch is an auspicious feature debut for writer-director Robert Eggers.
Triple 9 races past in a blur of crime and action scenes, with plenty of violence and the odd spot of gallows humour to keep things interesting.

This tale of the quixotic British athlete who became the darling of the 1988 Winter Olympic Games is a tad sugary sweet, but thanks to the performances of Hugh Jackman and Taron Egerton, the end result is a family film that's highly entertaining.
A Perfect Day is a war story told on a small scale. It's all the more powerful for its subtlety.
The sequel swaps cunning for brutal violence and turns Banning into a one man killing machine.
You don't have to be a Scot to laugh yourself silly at The Legend of Barney Thomson, although canny viewers will no doubt catch more of the inside references.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As thrillers go, the thrill is gone fairly quickly. But give River points for appearing to ask hard questions about do-gooders in far-away places.
There are some decent laughs here (especially for a well choreographed sex scene) and even an amusing soundtrack, but there's just not enough story to go around.
For this viewer the whole thing ran out of steam halfway through. A general flat affect, mirrored in visuals and performance, eventually stopped being funny.

Watching battle organized at arm's length is a strange and surreal experience, steeped in dread. When Eye in the Sky eventually touches down to put a viewer right into the centre of the action, emotionally speaking, it's a jarring transition.
The Neon Demon is a cautionary tale about youth, beauty and Los Angeles, a vampiric study of modelling that is both terrifying and hilarious.

The movie has Andrea Martin, who returns as bossy Aunt Voula, sometimes dispensing her gonzo brand of sexual advice and sometimes confiding her list of bizarre medical curiosities. She alone may be worth the price of admission.
Around the time Davis starts smashing his house and its contents to smithereens, Demolition goes into story overdrive. And stops being interesting.
Everything changes over a single summer for the kids in Sleeping Giant, a superb coming-of-age story set in Northern Ontario.

Miles Ahead has its moments, but the movie is disjointed and, for the uninitiated, probably bewildering. You could say the narrative has the same creative flights of fancy as a Davis' jazz composition, but that would be a lie.

The best thing about Hello, My Name Is Doris is that nothing gets resolved in the expected movie fashion. The story will make you laugh, no question, but it will also make you deeply uncomfortable, and we mean that in the best way.
It's a credit to the chemistry and charisma of Key and Peele that the movie works at all.
This is a sunny little gem of a film.
Even when the story turns dark, much remains unsaid, unresolved and ambiguous. Four great performances bring the whole thing to life.
Love & Friendship is quick, clever and delightful, very funny and hugely entertaining.

Rockwell and Kendrick are great together, but the movie never quite marries the cute romance and the bloody killings. Most of the time the two leads appear to be on their own in a completely separate movie.
In the midst of blockbuster season, any viewer hungry for character-driven drama will appreciate the subtlety, intelligence and power of Into the Forest.
The movie has its flaws, but it is nonetheless an intriguing sci-fi entry and an engaging story about family.
Filmmaker Jeff Nichols (Mud; Take Shelter) has recreated the world lived in by Richard and Mildred Loving for a new feature film made with authenticity and laudable restraint.

Rules Don't Apply is hugely imperfect and, oddly, seems to be illustrating elements of Beatty's real life and personality through all the main characters. But there's no question that it's entertaining.
The reason to see Miss Sloane is Jessica Chastain, an actor apparently constitutionally incapable of giving a bad performance.
This should have been funnier. Rough Night is a comedy with a great female cast, but the women were given nothing to do.
Transformers: The Last Knight is an incomprehensible pile of scrap. Luckily, there's an upside -- you'll forget every single stupid frame of this thing the moment you walk out of the theatre.

Baby Driver is wild, violent, often very funny and hugely inventive. Wright puts you right in the driver's seat with Baby for spectacular car escapades, but the characters and conversations he creates are just as gripping.
Okja moves seamlessly between fairy tale, action caper and crime drama.
The Beguiled works at a slow simmer and within the hothouse atmosphere painstakingly created by the filmmaker.
Much is wrong with Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets, but just looking at this thing is such an astonishing trip that you'll hardly notice.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a wonder to experience (especially in Imax), but it's not perfect. For all the technical brilliance, there's something emotionally removed about the storytelling that keeps a viewer at arm's length throughout.

Although Stephen King fans may be disappointed that so much has had to be left out of the storytelling, they will be visually rewarded -- there are many sly references to other of King's works half-hidden throughout the scenery.
Detroit is an imperfect but entirely gripping drama.
It, on the page or the screen, is a complex mix of coming-of-age elements with ideas about childhood fears, memory and human nature - good and bad.
This is a good story, well told.
This is a movie that we experienced as thrilling for the first hour and annoying for the second; the annoying part was likely just our own longing for a recognizable narrative structure.
Ben Stiller plays the neurotic well, and he is excellent here as Brad; Austin Abrams is fantastic as the laid-back son with a clear-eyed vision of how the world works.

Under an entertaining story of two high-profile people who came to represent social upheaval on a tennis court, the Battle of the Sexes is also a timely reminder of the backsliding currently going on in America.

Though sanitized here, Seal's story is riveting; his life was as duplicitous as the country he sometimes represented. Cruise flying his drug-packed plane in American Made is like a weird extension of Cruise flying for glory in Top Gun back in the '80s.
For festive fun, A Bad Moms Christmas is right up there with coal in your stocking.
Lady Bird is a coming-of-age story distinguished by a great script and a perfect cast.
Kenneth Branagh's Murder on the Orient Express is an engaging bit of cinematic nostalgia.
Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a character study, even though the parts never stop moving -- it's wildly violent, brilliantly funny and deeply moving. And so smart.
Roman J. Israel, Esq. is one brilliant performance in search of a movie.

Black Panther is every bit as good as you were hoping. Actually -- it's better. A terrific screenplay from Ryan Coogler and Joe Robert Cole elevates this thing way beyond the usual boundaries of the Marvel Universe.

Red Sparrow isn't a good movie, and that's too bad, because you can see what it might have been. The story has intrigue built into it in a way that probably made perfect sense on the page; it just doesn't translate onto the big screen.
It's the daily daunting detail that keeps Stronger honest.

Writer/director Trey Edward Shults is a dab hand at creating an atmosphere of uncertainty and menace and does a fine job of showing how people disintegrate under duress. The performances are very convincing here.
Nothing quite comes together in this crazy mix of action, jokes, ancient curses and the undead, and even Tom Cruise's star power can't glue the thing together.

Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie was written by Nicholas Stoller, who includes funny stuff that will appeal to kids -- the name Professor Poopypants likely makes it unnecessary to explain further -- as well as humour aimed at adults.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Collateral Beauty is lacking in any real highs or lows and there's no energy to the proceedings.
There's so much potential. What a shame it's never realized.
Filmmaker J.A. Bayona keeps things visually interesting at all times in A Monster Calls. On a storytelling level, he doesn't pull his punches.
20th Century Women will likely mean more to anyone old enough to have experienced the '70s, but the movie's big draw is Bening.
Outdated and idiotic.
Gold is worth seeing. It's good -- but it should have been great.
A simple boy-meets-girl story gussied up with extraneous detail and stretched to an unconscionable two hours.
Very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, boring.

The Great Wall is a big, dull undertaking about 12th century soldiers fighting hideous monsters. It's some kind of sweeping historical fantasy/creature feature/cultural exercise/buddy picture mashup that never quite gets off the ground.
The screenplay is a masterpiece of subversion, laced with race-based fears and notions of stereotype that are played for laughs, but hit home.
Beauty and the Beast is energetic and hugely entertaining, both for children and the adults who accompany them.
Anyone who loved Trainspotting needs to see T2.
Violent, crude and really funny, Goon: Last of The Enforcers, works for the same reason the original Goon worked -- you will love the characters.
Low on ghost; big on shell -- Ghost in the Shell is eminently forgettable but often fantastic to look at.
The story has a few dubious turns and cliched bits, to be sure, but it all hangs together because the characters are fully three dimensional.
Unforgettable doesn't have quite enough story to go around.

Free Fire devotes itself to a whole hour of flying stuff -- bullets, barbs, quips, broken glass and other detritus, some of it human. It is complete, beautifully choreographed chaos, punctuated by unexpectedly funny lines.
It's a mess graced by a few terrific sequences, but a mess nonetheless.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Snatched is entertaining, no question, but in a pleasant, middle-of-the-road kind of way. And from this crowd, you expect more.
The film's close focus on one or two individuals makes the situation that much scarier, the fear that much more intense. And it makes the overall impact of The Wall that much more profound.

It's not the greatest show on earth, no, but it's a bloody, scary, energetic two hours at the movies -- proof positive that when the words Alien and Ridley Scott appear in the same sentence, it's cause for excitement.
We had zero hope for the fifth chapter in the waterlogged Pirates of The Caribbean franchise. And we were wrong. This thing is terrific.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pitt's oddly jokey performance as General Glen McMahon tends to overwhelm everything going on around him. That's too bad, because this anti-war satire has barbs a'plenty for pride, ignorance and the American can-do spirit.
To make a snowball fight seem like this much fun and then lay on a terrible lesson seems somewhat disingenuous.
The comedy is essentially sweet-natured; the conflict that will keep our lovebirds apart, so crucial to the genre, does not go down quite so well.
This is a movie that desperately wants to be a raunchy, politically incorrect, gross-out comedy. It gets as far as desperate.
Waaaaay too talky and overcomplicated.
Costner's performance really is powerful. What it all means remains a mystery.
The underside of the American Dream is on display in A Most Violent Year, a drama about an immigrant trying to make his way to the top.
Do you really want to expose your adolescent daughter to 100 minutes of the beautiful Lily Collins accepting second-best, over and over and over and over and over and over and over again?
There's an attractive air of menace hanging over the proceedings, but otherwise the movie feels stagey and stilted.
An uneasy mix of action and philosophy, with simplistic notions of good and evil and mother love proving to be a distraction from the main event.

The little-robot-who-could is a combination of Sharlto Copley's performance capture work and visual effects artistry, and the end result is remarkable.That may well be enough for Blomkamp fans, but anyone else can expect to be disappointed by Chappie.
The real-life kidnapping had all the elements of a thriller, so how it became such a mild-mannered movie is anybody's guess.
This is a brisk, frightening movie about recent history and it's well worth a look.
Anyone interested in spellbinding performances, however, should see Miss Julie.
Seymour: An Introduction is a delightful film experience about the transformative power of art.
The humour is puerile and idiotic, but you may laugh out loud in spite of yourself -- especially if you're familiar with the Carry On movies or the original Pink Panther.
October Gale is a quiet thriller set in the wilds of Georgian Bay. It's an uneven movie with some odd jolts in the story, but the performances -- especially from Patricia Clarkson -- are noteworthy.
There isn't much in the movie that you can't see on cable TV, where the action is bloodier and more energetic, but there's something old-fashioned about Last Knights that's appealing.
It takes a lot to bore your easily entertained correspondent but rest assured The Longest Ride has the goods.
For his directorial debut, Fogelman puts all the right people together, and what's more, gets a performance out of Pacino that's one of his best-ever comic turns.
This is chilling material, and Hill and Franco make sure the story packs a wallop.
You can't really call The Age of Adaline a movie. It's more like a series of pretty pictures held together by a remarkably idiotic story.
The movie is miscast and predictable, but it's not entirely without merit.
This futuristic take on age-old motivations, jealousy and betrayal among them, makes Ex Machina clever and engaging throughout.
Let's not belabour this. Preggoland is a misguided comedy about a thirtysomething woman who pretends to be pregnant on a whim.
Far from the Madding Crowd is pretty to look at, even if it is a sort of SparkNotes version of Thomas Hardy's novel.
The performances in Maggie are strong. The camera is often right up in the characters' faces, putting Schwarzenegger's lived-in, world-weary mug to good use and telegraphing Breslin's vulnerability.

The movie is a sweet-natured, easy-going bit of storytelling, and while Bill may be the central character, Queen and Country is really a movie about England. And it's a love letter to a particular time and place

Cake starts off like an edgy indie film and wraps up like one of the more serious episodes of Friends. Once Aniston's warts 'n' all performance has been highlighted, the movie seems to fizzle out, losing its momentum.
The well-written thriller is a masterpiece of tension, brought to life by strong performances, a clever plot and ... yeah, of course we're joking. It's a crap movie.
It's such a treat to see such an endearing slice o' life in the middle of this blockbuster season. There's not a single comic book character in sight.
Jobs is a dull movie about a snarky s.o.b.
It's too long, and the ending is curious, but the overall combo of serious themes and ridiculous situations is a joy to witness.
A briskly-paced, humorous and endearing journey that mixes concert footage and behind-the-scenes material on the boy band whose global reach is a testament to their fans and to social media.

Your kids might like 95 minutes worth of malicious cartoon food, terrible puns and a lesson in the importance of friendship. You'll be done at the 45 minute mark, moms and dads, but they didn't make this movie for you.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's no question that Lawrence accounts for the lion's share of the franchise's appeal, and a cliffhanger ending can only help build the frenzy of anticipation for Mockingjay Part I next year. Bring it on.
An experience that will let you imagine yourself to be in the middle of a chaotic video game.
For devotees of the much loved series, this long-awaited Veronica Mars feature film is a five-star proposition. For everyone else, Veronica Mars is a pleasant diversion.
Nymphomaniac is a cruel curiosity, and not much more.

Luckily, a terrific cast that includes Alan Arkin, Suraj Sharma, Bill Paxton, Pitobash Tripathy and Madhur Mittal holds this unwieldy thing together. (Bill Paxton, Jon Hamm or Lake Bell in the cast of any film is generally a good sign.)
Scary, campy and eventually quite moving, Maleficent is a frankly thrilling feminist fairy tale and completely engaging throughout.
Prepare to fall in love all over again as Schmidt and Jenko go to college.
Of Mice and Men at the end of the world -- that's the general turf of The Rover.
Even the most fervent fans of Cameron Diaz or Jason Segel will find little to like in Sex Tape, a tone deaf comedy about private life and public humiliation.
It comes to the screen as a clumsy tale, alas, but a strong cast that includes Oscar winner Susan Sarandon elevates matters somewhat.
It just gets sort of stupid. And the movie is too long. But these are minor quibbles.
Even those who have read Gillian Flynn's novel can expect to be surprised by the jolts and jumps in David Fincher's take on events.
When you are following in the footsteps of Kirk Cameron, nothing good can come from that.
Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is the sort of movie that ends up on a person's favourite-movies-of-all-time list. It's really that fresh.
Witherspoon et al have done justice to Strayed's story.
As you'd expect from a story that never leaves the confines of a car, Locke is intense and claustrophobic.

Near the end of the movie, Cave talks about living in the 'shimmering space' where imagination and reality intersect. He's talking about words and music, but he could be talking about 20,000 Days on Earth.
Filmmaker Laura Poitras paints a frankly terrifying picture of the loss of liberty involved in the widespread government gathering of the communication done by ordinary Joes on a daily basis.
Chris Rock's Top Five is very funny -- no surprise there -- but it's also unexpectedly romantic.
[A] good-natured documentary.
Amanda Seyfried is adept at showing the character's innocent side, but you'll leave the theatre not knowing much more about Lovelace than you knew going in.
Adult Beginners is a darkly funny indie film about family and second chances.
Even a not-so-great ending can't overturn everything that came before it.
Director Denis Villeneuve, aided and abetted by cinematographer Roger Deakins, fills Sicario with dread and a violence that happens to be stunning to look at.
The movie is both hysterically funny and heartbreaking, but Weitz somehow makes you laugh without making light of serious issues.

The Final Girls offers a lovely twist on the horror genre and some good laughs for movie fans of every stripe. Nice to see the more ludicrous elements of retro slasher fare get the mockery they deserve.
99 Homes is a movie about how we live now, a thriller for grown-ups about everyday life and the social pecking order. Not for the faint of heart, mind you.
[Freeheld] is sincere, to be sure, but unlikely to win any prizes. For starters, the most memorable character in this important story of a courageous woman is a man; that's a problem.
Room works as a film because of the completely engaging performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay.
Suffragette is easy to look at, populated by strong actors who move through a world furnished with lovely period detail, but it feels hollow at the centre.
Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse manages to be a very good comedy, a scary adventure, a tale of friendship and a coming of age story, all rolled into one.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kilo Two Bravo is one of the most intense anti-war films extant.
Spotlight is a mystery, a thriller and a human interest drama, but mostly it's a love letter to investigative journalism.

Only the impressive chemistry between Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway will keep you watching; we haven't even mentioned the painfully ageist sex jokes or the silly plot developments that unfold like sitcom padding.

The 33 is not a failure. It's a crowd-pleasing, sentimental, middle-of-the-road venture suitable for any audience. And that's a pity, because the subject matter cries out for a much more muscular treatment.
It's such a beautiful film.
Man Up has a couple of bits that don't quite work and the ending is just silly, but for the most part, Pegg and Bell carry this thing through sheer force of personality.
It's Julia Roberts who owns the movie. As the grieving Jess, a woman reduced to a shadow by the death of her daughter, Roberts is a revelation here.
It's not short of thrills, the biggest of which is Hardy's double performance.
Both Pattinson and DeHaan could have used more to do, but both actors put in performances that elevate the proceedings.
Carol is a complex human story about unspoken desire, social expectations and an authentic life.
Youth is imperfect and it meanders, but Caine and Keitel bring this thing to life with gusto.
It's a rare movie that can't be saved by Bruce Willis single-handedly killing all the bad guys. And yet, here it is: Extraction.
No question that the storytelling here is impressive; the story itself, however, is a bit thin.
A movie that will shatter you.
By the Sea [is] a strange, dream-like undertaking and ravishing to look at. What it all means is tougher to work out.
The Transporter Refueled is big, brainless fun and just the sort of amusement the back-to-school crowd might crave.
What we have here is a road trip about two guys talking. And it's riveting.
Experiencing Z for Zachariah is a bit like rummaging around in someone else's mind for 90 minutes, and we mean that in the best way.
Pitch Perfect 2 is sweet, predictable story, but it's shored up by some hilarious and absurd action on the sidelines.
The audience isn't invested in the characters or their fate. Bit of a problem.
No shortage of talent here. Pity they're all underused.
Bonello makes good use of mirrors and reflective surfaces throughout the film, all very fitting for a story about a boy as beautiful and as self-absorbed as Narcissus himself.
Sometimes confusing and often self-indulgent, Aloha is also kind of fabulous to watch. That's mostly thanks to a great cast.

Danner is probably the main reason to see the movie, and her screen presence is impressive; she's an actor who manages to bring gravitas to any role, and that includes her work in goofy things like Ben Stiller's Meet the Parents series.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: On her own, Melissa McCarthy is hilarious. So is Rose Byrne. Together, they're spectacularly funny.
Energetic storytelling and inspired visuals make this one an entertaining experience.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hagiography? Maybe a little, but for fans of the actor, it's a must-see.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What makes The Overnight work as well as it does is the cast. The performances here are truly fearless and engaging, with Schwartzman and Scott in particular in high gear.

By capturing a watershed period in her family life, Forbes also manages to offer a remarkably concise snapshot of the era and its social views on race, class, education, working women and mental illness. And the resilience of children.
What could be all-too-familiar here is mostly fresh and engaging, thanks to understated storytelling and a great cast.
We have seen the future of romantic comedy and its name is Amy Schumer. Thank the goddess.
Despite brilliant fight scenes and impressive performances, Southpaw is brought down by ham-handed storytelling.
Thanks to an intelligent script and the performances of Cobie Smulders, Gail Bean and Elizabeth McGovern, the minutiae of everyday life in this small, lovely film will capture your interest.
Provided you don't look too closely, Irrational Man is a film Woody Allen fans will love.
There's a lot to like about Ricki and the Flash, but seeing Meryl Streep perform the song Wooly Bully with a bar band is a particular highlight.
Shaun The Sheep is suitable entertainment for anyone who likes to laugh out loud.
This is a light and lovely confection that doesn't linger in the mind, but it will certainly leave you smiling.
Boulevard itself moves toward an obvious conclusion with no surprises along the way; it runs out of steam after about an hour.

Sometimes, [the film] wants to be light farce, all repartee and two-dimensional characters; other times it wants to be a contender, with deathbed scenes and motivating lectures on romantic poetry. At all times it's a tremendous waste of talent.
Take Dazed and Confused and mix it up a bit with James Bond, and you have a general idea of where American Ultra is headed.
If Cole's journey in We Are Your Friends is somewhat predictable, at least there are interesting things to look at along the way.
You couldn't call Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief entertaining, exactly, but it is absolutely riveting.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a lot of fun to watch, turning slowly as it does from the initial glee of discovery to the inevitable addiction issues and a transformation into a dark, suspense-fuelled drama.
It's all quite cute. Up to a point.
A wonderfully low-key but engaging movie about identity.
movie_title: The Year Dolly Parton Was My Mom (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As visually dazzling and colourful as an explosion in a Crayola factory.
A hugely entertaining movie -- surprisingly contemporary, always incisive and often very funny. And heartbreaking.
It's just so Disney. It could make you very cross.
It's a middling sort of experience at the movies.
Brick Lane is lovely to look at and the performances, particularly from Chatterjee and Kaushik, are delightful.
The movie has a handful of worthwhile scenes, but it's lacking in anything new or fresh.
I.O.U.S.A. manages to explain how and why the United States got into this kind of fiscal fiasco and make it entertaining -- no mean feat.
This is a film for followers of Wong Kar Wai and for fans of nostalgia.
The Other End of the Line isn't always convincing on the romance front. As a comedy about culture clash, however, The Other End of the Line works nicely.
movie_title: The Other End of the Line (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If big, stupid fun is high on your required viewing list, look no further than Role Models.
Satrapi's life story is exhilarating and heartbreaking; filtering political events through her youthful experience of them creates a very different, very human picture of Iran.
Engaging and intelligent.
The storytelling is wobbly at times, but the tale itself is so engaging you'll overlook all that. Well, most of it, anyway.
Quantum of Solace is a thrilling display of action, and it goes at a frenetic pace.
Growing Op has bad writing -- predictable and one-dimensional -- but after about 90 minutes, the story starts taking surprise turns that don't make a lot of sense.
Either there's a huge inside joke at work in Australia, or else the movie is just corny and weird. We liked watching it enough to vote for the first interpretation.
The film has the sort of quick pace, short-attention-span editing and music that add up to a teen audience. That's the nicest way we could think of to say that Nobel Son is sort of a stupid movie.
There's too much sugar sweetening this pat story.
Hynes is really effective as Keith, at ease with the rude, raw material that's drawn from his own past, and he manages to be charismatic even at his most down and dirty.
Little in the movie makes sense, the humour is forced and overall, it's sometimes boring.
Sadly, nobody has much to do.

The film boasts some of the more revolting special effects ever conceived. There isn't really any acting to speak of, although Jigsaw and Loony Bin Jim get to chew people and scenery; the dialogue is pretty much what you'd expect.
I've Loved You So Long is a love letter to family. It's an homage to the restorative power of love. It's a gift of forgiveness.
The movie, which has several non-professional actors in the cast, is sometimes clunky and the action is often predictable, but the character of Walt is solid gold.

The subject matter could be considered shocking and the film is difficult to watch at times; the director, Tom Kalin, isn't pulling his punches, but he refrains from giving any of the material the showy Hollywood treatment.
No amount of fiddling with funny glasses in the theatre will keep you from noticing a weak storyline.
Trouble is, it's never really funny or really scary, and a lot of it is hugely predictable.
Man On Wire is surprising and entertaining, an unexpected adventure story for the modern world.
Filmmaker Alex Aja is a dab hand with the gore, and it's only too bad you've already seen most of the movie's good stuff in the trailers and advertisements.
It should have been a lot funnier.
It all unfolds from the point of view of a fabulously selfish man, giving the film a special talent to annoy.
The film is slow and rather too long (and a bit preachy), but always intense, and its intentions are certainly clear.
Henry Poole Is Here is a movie that asks all the big questions and then, weirdly, wrecks itself by offering puny answers.

None of it is amusing, so there's probably enough suicide-inducing material here to make a send-up of The Happening redundant.
It's laugh-out-loud funny.
Still Life is a moody undertaking, with little action but plenty going on.
Abandon hope, all ye who enter here: Strange casting and a lousy script make The Women the sort of film that's pure torture to sit through.
Lakeview Terrace winds itself into a predictable tale, but the performances set this one apart from the genre pack.
Human desire hasn't changed much in 300 years, it would seem.
The trouble with I Served the King of England is that it's sometimes bizarre and clever and often visually wonderful, but you never forget that you're watching a movie. And it does go on.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Eagle Eye wants to be a little on the sci-fi side, but it's mostly just badly plotted and executed.
This is one of the most intelligent, satisfying, beautifully plotted adrenalin boosts you're ever likely to experience at the movies.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film manages to be both an homage to women and a heartbreaking cultural commentary, and it's intense.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The mood of the movie is flat, without highs or lows, and the special effects are only mildly exciting. Even kids will notice that.
Nostalgia for The Beatles and for their '60s scene would be the main reason to see All Together Now.

It's pleasant to look at. It's nice to see Latifah in a role that's closer to being worthy of her talent, and ditto Fanning, who moves gracefully from kiddie roles into dramatic lead. Both women put in very strong performances.
Happy-Go-Lucky is some sort of cinematic proof that beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
Righteous Kill is not a good movie, but it has some nifty violence and plenty of atmosphere.
The story is raw and often tough to watch, but Rourke is so good that you can't look away.
Waltz With Bashir is a strange and wonderful hybrid.
The movie is intense and stylized, and bristling with great performances.
