Chances are you'll see it much more clearly as an experiment that goes on too long.
For all that hard work and unrequited love, Tulpan is also very funny.
Two Lovers is a romantic drama for grown ups.
You can keep your 3-D, thanks. We'll take McQueen's ability to fill in all the dimensions.

Take a bow, Mother Nature.
n the end, however, Production Office feels too slender to be called a feature film -- it's like a terrific 15-minute comedy routine that somehow got stretched to the 90-minute mark.
Don't look for hot sex or boiled bunnies in Obsessed, a mild-mannered version of Fatal Attraction that seems to be hoping racial politics will fill in for a script.
It won't disappoint you. That's rare, don't you think?

It's also charming, despite the dark subject matter. You could say the same about Caine's performance.
Ideas are all tied together with magnificent visuals.
movie_title: Fierce Light: When Spirit Meets Action (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Part history, part character study and part journey of self-discovery, and it's entirely entertaining.
Every bit as over-long, talky and cumbersome as its title.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is quick and funny, and so are the visuals. This is the sort of film in which the landscape is littered with unexpected and unbelievable people and events.
The film, which is a huge hit in Mexico, is lightweight and often very funny, but there's a cruel edge to the laughs that left this viewer vaguely uncomfortable.
A gritty little drama that leaves you feeling like you might need a shower.
Mothers & Daughters isn't the greatest movie ever made, but it's got a handful of really terrific performances.
It starts off as a dark comedy about adult relationships and then just turns plain dark, moving from dull to creepy in a trice.
For the performances, the cinematography and the overall experience of this character-driven drama, you can put Goodbye Solo into the must-see category.
Lymelife is small and uneven, but it works.

As always, Dresen has turned his camera on ordinary people leading ordinary lives, but as the tiny details build into a complete, three-dimensional portrait, one is, finally, loath to leave their company.
The Pool is beautiful to look at, and, for what it conveys about human nature, to experience.
12 Rounds is too long, and about 80 minutes in you'll give up trying to make sense of the thing.
The performances and the passion fueling this film are astounding.
Some people really love goofy comedy, and for those people there's Paul Blart: Mall Cop. You can bring the kids.
Hoffman and Thompson together almost act their way out of the material, but even these major talents can't reboot the willing suspension of disbelief.

Not every routine in Rumba works and some of the comedy bits lean toward boring, but for the most part, each segment is brisk and visually delightful. The unusual elements of the movie certainly never wear thin.
Welcome to the Sticks is the most successful movie ever released in France, possibly because self-deprecating humour is so rare there.
Underworld: Rise of the Lycans is so dark at all times and so generally dull to boot that the biggest fight of all is the viewer's struggle to stay awake.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film has a breathtaking pace and non-stop action (and violence), and a carefully created air of paranoia and claustrophobia.
Scare-mongers will probably find The Uninvited too tame for their taste, but the storytelling should satisfy thriller fans.

The formula goes like this: Teens + sex = gruesome death at the hands of a loony in a hockey mask.
Trouble the Water is a truly gobsmacking document, but it's Kimberly Roberts who carries the film.
Extraordinary footage is the highlight of Saving Luna. It is truly mind-boggling to see and hear the Orca, an endearing creature whose playfulness is unexpected and surprisingly moving.
movie_title: Saving Luna: The True Story of a Lone Orca (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The idea may be dusty -- this is Wedding Crashers on the football field -- but the delivery is fresh.
Somehow, all this chaos is absurd and often very funny. When it's not heartbreaking.
movie_title: C'est Pas Moi, Je le Jure! (It's Not Me, I Swear!) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fear(s) of the Dark is an unusual little confection, bound to be interesting to most viewers and downright riveting to artists and illustrators.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Race To Witch Mountain is fast and furious and the action is bound to please children, who are the target audience.
If there's a target audience for Miss March, we suspect it would involve people aged around 14, who are male and perhaps stoned. All others: You were warned.

A worrisome document about the first world view of Third World countries, but what it says about contemporary art gives the movie a rich vein of humour.
movie_title: The Art Star and the Sudanese Twins (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is an odd little film that really sneaks up on you, packing a much bigger emotional punch than you'd anticipate.

It does have a mostly believable and engaging emotional life.
An intelligent, spare, mean-streets sort of story, This Is England features superb performances...
The book is translated into film as a series of chronological events, and they are flat events at that.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Barbet Schroeder's astonishing documentary is a glimpse into another world, and not one you would necessarily want to visit for too long.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Before The Devil Knows You're Dead plays around a bit with time and perception, and the story unfolds at a tremendous clip. The movie is not without its share of black humour, but it's an exercise in violence and adrenalin. And tragedy.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I'm Not There is funny, poignant, interesting and nostalgia-inducing, but above all it's a Todd Haynes movie, and that's a good thing.

How To Cook Your Life is slow and gentle, and it sneaks up on you. It ain't War & Peace, but it is the sort of film you'll think about long after you leave the theatre.
This is one of the best movies of 2007.
It's very earnest. And funny. And endearing.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film does not pull its punches, and though uneven, is compelling.

In the end, we were bored. In the end, it all seemed pretty trite.
This psychological thriller is a superb tale of haunting and secrets, and it's intelligent from start to finish.
You should know that the film's incomprehensible bits are complemented by much incomprehensible blather.

Performances, cinematography, writing, the amazing score from Radiohead's Jonny Greenwood -- we could go on. There Will Be Blood is odd, unsettling and completely engrossing, and just the thing to restore your faith in the movies.

Most of the material has never been made public before, so the movie is a must-see for Cobain fans. Even for non-fans, it is quite an astonishing document. Up to a point.

If you part ways with $12 for a ticket to see this thing -- that's before parking and popcorn -- you're barking mad.
Sometimes a movie is so richly, gloriously, flamboyantly stupid that it starts to become fun to watch.

The storytelling eventually gets bogged down in its own fancy footwork, leaving a viewer to wonder why everything was laid out in such a complex way.
This is one of the year's very best movies, provided you don't mind a sort of horrible depression hangover that keeps the film in your thoughts long after you've left the theatre.

We loved looking at the movie. The performances from Foster and Howard are absolutely terrific. What the hell any of it means escapes us.

This one is a typical time-waster for teenagers or others with disposable income and underdeveloped taste.
Even the special effects aren't very special.
There's no story, the dialogue will make you laugh out loud, the special effects are often cheesy, the acting is terrible and any scary bits are announced in advance through ham-handed movie making.

The filmmaking is a bit scrappy. Still, it's worth seeing.
Puffball is a surprisingly terrible movie.
The storytelling is clunky but the performances are decent, and Ludwig is both cute and talented.

Surprising, amusing and fascinating for the most part, and full of unexpected details -- such as the guys in Metallica describing how Japanese fans throw cute toothbrushes at them when they are on stage.

Werner Herzog takes his unique questions about the universe to Antarctica for Encounters at the End of the World, a collection of amazing pictures and meditations on life at the South Pole.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

A charming picture about filmmaking all dressed up as a comedy. Exaggerated and wonderfully silly, the movie concerns hilarious amateur movie-making -- but sneaks in a message about community and the transformative power of art.

movie_review_blurb: Everything in the movie (Whoville in particular) seems hyperactive, noisy and shrill -- and yet, for all the manufactured carry-on, there isn't enough story for a feature film.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: CJ7 is small and sweet.
The acting is better than adequate, and Rhona Mitra is very good as the jaded heroine. As loud, relentless, chaotic, brutally violent and gory B-movies go, this one is a keeper.

movie_review_blurb: Tyler Perry's Meet The Browns is another opportunity for Perry to hector his fans about leading good lives.
Paranoid Park will be catnip for Van Sant fans (the music and cinematography are complicated and chewy) but potentially tough sledding for everybody else.
After 20 minutes, you're welded to the characters emotionally. Their loss is your loss.
This one is a must-see for fans of the band and for anyone interested in the general phenom of rock 'n' roll.
The film works hard to be a dark, grown up, romantic comedy (plenty of sex, nudity, bad language and philosophy) and yet it winds up being every bit as childish as most other pictures in the genre.
The performances carry Smart People.
Bella is mostly harmless, feel-good fare, and not unlike a TV movie of the week in depth. And you could take your old granny with you to see it, without fear.
Do the math: X + Y = lousy.
One of those heartfelt but dubious films about the importance of family.
Much smarter than it needs to be and darker than you'd expect, The Hangover seems destined to be the big comedy of the summer.

It must be said that The Last House on the Left is really well done, with impressive performances, masterful creation of dread and tension, perfect pacing, intense storytelling, haunting cinematography, truly sickening sound effects, and all.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An edge-of-your seat documentary from Geoffrey Smith about a British physician who has done pro bono work in Ukraine for 15 years.
Will enchant the 'tween girl audience for whom it was created.
A sweet little film about loss and grieving.

This is a busy espionage feature with talking pets, so children may well like it. Although there's humour in the film aimed at the grown-ups who accompany those children, the movie is for the under-10 crowd.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever it all means, O'Horten is a bit of whimsy held together by the wonderful face of actor Bard Owe.
Understated storytelling and a general low-affect emotional atmosphere are the biggest contributors to a general sense of dread throughout.
It goes on a bit too long, but the final pay-off is well worth it.
Nanny McPhee turns up like magic when you need her.
For all the terrific throw-away lines, The Infidel plays like a TV show rather than a feature film, and a TV sitcom at that.
This is a slow, pretty, one-dimensional undertaking. The story is free of any real conflict or depth -- it's just kind of big and shiny, not unlike an expensive Hallmark greeting card.
It's heartbreaking.
A really difficult film to watch.
Z-z-z-z-z-z-z, we must say.
As for Reynolds' performance -- just be prepared to be pleasantly surprised. Amazed, even. In Buried he may finally have found a project as good as he is.
It's too mild-mannered for those who relish horror pictures and too gory and plotless and chatty for everyone else.
The drama and the comedy often don't fit together, but The Concert is so endlessly good-natured that you keep watching regardless.
Very much a rousing, indomitable-human-spirit kind of story, except that by some miracle, most of the saccharine was left out of the recipe. The end result is a movie everyone will enjoy.
All the short movies that make up Tales From the Golden Age employ the sort of black humour that suggests you'd better laugh, or you'll cry.
The performances from Landau and Burstyn are gobsmacking, and while there's nothing truly unexpected or surprising in the story, these two keep you watching regardless.
Whether you know a little or a lot (or even nothing) about John Lennon's background, Nowhere Boy is a keeper.

For its celebration of the universal yearning for answers to the big questions, Hereafter is an interesting film to look at. It gets more interesting when you factor in a couple of impressive special effects -- yes, in a Clint Eastwood movie.
A heartrending documentary about the eradication of Tibetan culture.
We should probably mention that all those hours and all those actors, languages and events notwithstanding, Carlos flies by at a brisk pace.
A gritty drama about bank robbing and the redemptive power of love.
The 3D is totally unnecessary.
Those who haven't read the novels may find the movies a bit jumpy, but they are still very much worth seeing.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Predators is brisk and busy, with plenty of other threats to contend with besides those monsters.
This movie is what's known as family entertainment, which means in this case that it's interesting and harmless.
It's familiar and engaging for anyone who's a parent, and should probably be required viewing for anyone who wants to be one.
It's a wonderful movie full of people you wish you knew in real life, and like most of Holofcener's movies, it's a remarkable combination of comedy and tragedy.
Writer/director Rodrigo Garcia is the son of famed Colombian novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez, so maybe the filmmaker comes by all the magic and coincidence in his stories naturally.
If you're on the lookout for something in the indomitable human spirit category, look no further than Mao's Last Dancer.
This new version from Ridley Scott is rich in history and adventure, a swashbuckling epic that attempts to explain the man behind the legend.
The Trotsky is an endearing comedy that at times flirts with greatness, and those times are courtesy of Jay Baruchel's performance.

Lower your expectations. Now keep lowering them. Think where the Naked Gun movies dredged. Now think lower. You're now ready to appreciate the free-wheeling idiocy that Forte and company bring to a project that embodies the question, "Why?"
Kites is, essentially, a love story. With exploding cars.
The performances are suitably bizarre. What it all means is something you can go away and argue about afterward.
We like whimsy as much as the next person, but 100 minutes of idle fancy may be more than most can take.
This is a small, perfectly delicious film. The actors are magical.
Those hoping for a summer celebration of wretched excess to rival The Hangover need wait no longer.
This tale of a philosophical Great Dane who speaks with Owen Wilson's voice is not entirely without merit. Well, actually, it is, but never mind.
Other than being an utterly miscast, ill-advised combo of rom-com and spy thriller distinguished by lousy writing and featuring two people with no screen chemistry, Killers is perfectly mediocre.
It's unlikely there will be a bigger disappointment this blockbuster season.
The movie celebrates a particular lifestyle and it's an homage to a dying tradition -- a slice of history that's fascinating to witness.

It's visually arresting. From scenes of Ree frying potatoes in bacon fat to discussions of deer stew and squirrel meat, the combination of poverty and insularity that defines this particular socio-economic group is quietly and carefully established.
Sadly, the movie doesn't reveal much on either the cultural/religious side or the crime side, but it's mildly entertaining as a coming-of-age story.
Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky is attractive as a bit of history and it's generally pretty to look at, but it's never engaging in a way that lets you forget you're watching a movie.
While the film is sometimes choppy, the content is never less than fascinating. In a horrifying kind of way.
movie_title: Pax Americana and the Weaponization of Space (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of the beautifully crafted TV show will be bitterly disappointed by this film version of the story.

Prince of Persia is a summer popcorn movie destined to leave your thoughts as soon as you leave the theatre, and its best quality is that it doesn't pretend to be anything else. And you can bring the kids.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The reason to see this film is (as always) Noomi Rapace, who has brought Lisbeth to life for fans of the Larsson trilogy. She and Annika Hallin, who plays her lawyer, are the main attractions here, gripping to watch.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Handsome Harry seems a bit obvious at times (and a little clunky at others) but the performances, particularly from Jamey Sheridan, will keep you watching.
On many levels, this is an utterly harrowing film.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Attenberg is spare emotionally and visually, and despite the tender humour of Marina's sexual indoctrination, the film is never completely engaging.

For fans of Tati and students of animation, The Illusionist probably represents some kind of nirvana. For everybody else, it's a chance to enter a magical, dream-like world created by the genius of these two artists.
What distinguishes Casino Jack, one version of lobbyist Jack Abramoff's story, is that it's often incomprehensible. That, we hasten to add, is not a good thing.
The overall effect is as elaborate and fascinating as one of Spector's musical productions from the '60s.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Mechanic is marked by relentless blood-letting and violence, with in-your-face crashes and explosions and all the other wild-eyed and utterly illogical activity that makes good action/adventure so exhilarating to watch.
The story shapes itself into a sophisticated psychological thriller where suspense is everything. Who will deal with the outsider?

The story is about increasing isolation, and as it progresses it's like watching someone engaged in survival training -- anything extraneous has to go, like emotion, for example, or human interaction.
The Roommate is a thriller with no thrills. Those hoping for compensation in the way of tasteful semi-naked scenes with the beautiful young cast can forget that, too.
Whether Bieber's wowing the fans at a concert or spontaneously hugging his grandfather, his enthusiasm and exuberance are impressive. And all that comes through loud and clear in Never Say Never.
Hear that funny swooshing noise? That's the sound of Jane Austen spinning in her grave over From Prada To Nada.
You'll forget the whole picture the minute you leave the theatre, but for the two hours you're sitting there in the dark, it's mildly, and pleasantly engaging.
Javier Bardem's performance in Biutiful is so arresting that it almost obscures the movie's many flaws. But not quite.
More than just a biopic of the famed troubadour, Phil Ochs: There But for Fortune is also a brief, brisk, brilliant history of social turmoil in America in the '60s.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I Am Number Four involves the sort of editing that turns some of the actions scenes into visual gibberish, but the hectic pace and angsty teen issues are bound to win this one a youth audience.
An intense little drama distinguished by an excellent ensemble cast.
Considering the movie is based on the real-life murder of these monks 15 years ago in Algeria during the civil war, it is a calming and spectacularly life-affirming picture.
Some days you want intellectually fulfilling or emotionally transporting at the movies and some days you just want stupid.
Alamar is a slow, beautiful meditation on nature, family and the relationship between father and son.
There are too many characters to care about and too many storylines to follow, but the high energy will carry you along and the performances are strong.
Soderbergh's creation doesn't fill in any blanks about Gray, and the film is not for the uninitiated, but even ardent fans will have trouble warming up to every detail.
Regardless of which aspects of the film catch your attention, you can prepare to be heartbroken by what you see.
Sweet Karma is an exploitation outing from top to bottom.
For all that Small Town Murder Songs hints at, there isn't enough delivery here.
The film's message about these worried individuals and the larger family of all humanity is a bit obvious at times, but the performances keep you watching.
Political filmmaker Patricio Guzman brings together the heavens and the earth in Nostalgia for the Light, a meditation on history, memory and the cosmos.
Oh, there's a dilemma all right -- your choices are clunky comedy or fumbled drama in this new Vince Vaughn vehicle.
A heartbreaking fable about life, legacy and the way men define themselves through their work.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has none of the awkwardness or clunky moments you might expect from a low-budget first feature.
Both Sean Penn and Naomi Watts offer believable performances here, and Watts is impressive in the truly tricky role of the complex Ms. Plame.
Morning Glory is a comedy that seems to be based entirely on Rachel McAdams' energy. Luckily, she's up to the task.
There's the indomitable human spirit -- and then there's Aron Ralston.
Unstoppable has all the requisite edge-of-your-seat events and moments of stark human drama (well, the lite brand, anyway), but the movie never fully engages your attention.

The film works like a sort of fast-forward of the city's past over the last 75 years, and in addition to the wealth of cultural and historical detail, there are things in the film that seem to welcome contemporary political interpretation.
movie_title: I Wish I Knew (Hai shang chuan qi) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A B-movie extravaganza, Skyline is a sort of sci-fi sampler of every alien invasion movie ever made.
Besides the specific political and historical elements, the film is a slow, quiet meditation on a very different way of life.
Given the pretty nudity and the hearts 'n' flowers finale, this one is strictly for teen fans of the actors to sneak into.
It's meandering, whimsical and definitely different.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: These guys are obsessed.
Made in Dagenham is a delightful British film about regular working stiffs in the 1960s. You'll hear the movie compared to The Full Monty.
It is intensely silly, but it grows on you.
The King's Speech is one of the best movies you'll see all year.
Sequels rarely outdo the original movie, and Voyage of the Dawn Treader is no exception. Still, it's a swashbuckling adventure story that kids will love, so what's not to like?
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Rabbit Hole has a great script and some terrific performances, but in a lot of ways it's a difficult project to warm up to.
If your general response to the festive season is bah, humbug, you'll want to see Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale.

It's all terribly Masterpiece Theatre, slow and beautiful, only with more seduction scenes. The music, the costumes and the breathtaking cinematography (courtesy of Vittorio Storaro) will keep you happily engaged.
Watching A-list actors behave like morons is not a bad way to offset the dreadful false cheer of the season.
This is a film about... um ... life and death, we'll guess, and it involves a minor drug dealer, his sister, their dead parents and some cronies in Japan.
Good thing note-perfect performances from all involved tend to offset those negative aspects.
Blue Valentine will break your heart.
Brendan Fraser: Human being or cartoon character?
It's like Starsky and Hutch in a head-on crash with The Monkees, and it's demented. But the joke fades fast.
A marvelous documentary about the guy all other men are said to envy.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It will be interesting -- and exciting -- to see what the Edgerton brothers come up with next.

The documentary covers 80 years of their lives, from a happy childhood right through to the present day, covering their personal and professional lives and offering a glimpse of their particular creative process.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film is spare, but intense.
It's a sort of anti-romance romantic comedy, and though uneven, it's a lot smarter than most films in the genre.
If you're interested in looking at creative carnage, The Final Destination has just want you want. And in 3D, too.
The idea of an ordinary guy busting his wife out of prison sounds fairly silly, but you'll still be at the edge of your seat for most of Pour Elle.
It's a veritable moral smorgasbord. Not.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If sci-fi is your thing, you could do worse.
Required viewing for guitar enthusiasts, and a pleasant diversion for everyone else.
The movie offers another memorable performance from Ellen Page, and it's an auspicious directing debut for Drew Barrymore.
The movie is trite but pretty, with great sets and period costumes, and as it's anchored on Chanel's lovers and their role in her story, it can only be described as a chick flick.
The performances, particularly from relative newcomer Alden Ehrenreich, will keep you engaged.
Couples Retreat is a comedy/drama mix, but it's mostly the comedy parts that work.
A more sophisticated slice-of-life than one usually gets on the big screen -- and for fans of Clarkson, it's a must-see.
Law Abiding Citizen could be the movie of the year, but only if you're a big fan of stupid.
Amelia isn't a terrible movie, but its greatest value will be as a history lesson rather than as entertainment.

R. J. Cutler's documentary appears to gloss over many pertinent details and the filmmaker has been accused of being too easy on Wintour, but The September Issue is incisive, detailed and somewhat cruel.
Full of complex emotion and crackling adventure, Astro Boy hits the big screen after 58 years in comics and TV.
Thanks to cinematographer Matyas Erdely, it's so beautiful to look at that the experience is more like walking through a gallery than watching a film.
Charles Bronson seems like a bit of a sweetheart, when he's not trying to gouge someone's eyes out.
Amreeka is a sweet-natured film about the experiences of a Palestinian woman and her teenage son when they emigrate to Illinois.
Defies expectation. This is an unpredictable landscape populated by fully three-dimensional characters, and it's entirely entertaining. This is the world as men live in it.
Inside Hana's Suitcase is not entirely without schmaltz, but it tells a deeply moving story without ever being maudlin or manipulative.
Looking for another reason to leave your car at home? Go see Crude.
High school... Vanessa Hudgens... kids making music. We know what you're thinking, but you're wrong.
It shows plenty of promise at the beginning, and even though that promise isn't kept, Giamatti's performance will keep your interest.
Adam is a low-key, charming movie, and often very funny.

The iconic ruins of Greece are photographed in a way that will likely inspire a lot of people to get on a plane; Vardalos looks luminous in every shot and manages to stay graceful while dealing with material that's beneath her.
This is a Dickensian tale about the transformative power of art.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Food, Inc. is 90 minutes of frankly riveting information about what we eat now.
Summer Hours is a slow, beautifully photographed film about what we value -- in the emotional and material realms.
A tiny perfect gem about the no-man's-land of adolescence.
The Baby Formula is proof that lesbian romantic comedies are every bit as dopey as the straight variety.
Sex, money and power are at the heart of the story in Cheri. What's not to like?
Remember how terrific the original Ice Age movie was? That was then. This is now. Alas.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Michael Mann movie is a Michael Mann movie, and fans will not be disappointed.
Empty Nest is light in tone and sometimes laugh-out-loud funny, and the humour is generally subtle and grown up.
This is a spectacular film about corruption in high places, specifically as that relates to the political life of Giulio Andreotti, seven times prime minister of Italy and a senator for life.
It seems to want to be an edgy story, but it's just depressing.
Most of it is inspired silliness.
Betrayal, heartbreak, disillusionment: Our young wizard has entered the adult world.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Seraphine is a fascinating story (and the film is beautiful to look at), but in the end, the movie leaves a lot of questions about the real-life Seraphine unanswered.
Plenty of fish in the sea? Time to learn a new adage.
A festival of carnage that's sometimes funny and sometimes waaay over the line.
The movie is crisp and quick and looks as if it were shot yesterday, but for all that, Soul Power is ultimately disappointing.
One of the big problems in Humpday for this viewer is the characters, none of whom really engages a viewer's imagination or emotion.
The storytelling intelligent, and the two leads are endlessly watchable. The casting is impeccable.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: G-Force is fast and funny and bound to appeal to kids.
Rocksteady: The Roots of Reggae uses archival footage from the 1960s and offers a brief recent history of the island.
The story is mostly riveting, in a chaotic kind of way.
There's something a little tired about Gentlemen Broncos.
It's brisk and witty and the cast makes it all such great entertainment that you could almost overlook the more or less absent story.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: C'est dommage.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What it might contribute to the topic of autism and change -- over and above the mysterious (but documented) healing power of hanging around horses -- appears to be hope.
A meditation on charity that is both exhilarating and hopeful.
Despite the subject matter, Prom Night In Mississippi is surprisingly buoyant with the hope and joy of these kids.
You will believe in their characters and their emotion, to the point where their love scenes might leave you feeling like a bit of a voyeur. We mean that in the best way.
It's a spy story with a weak start and a better action finish.
Hopkins, Del Toro and Blunt do the best they can with the material. Thanks in large part to their performances, the movie never slips into full-on cheese territory.
There's something ferocious and brave about Mia that makes her very winning.
On a practical level, the music is a helpful entry point into some of the most shameful chapters in American history.
Harrelson is a master at keeping his character real.
Contained in the simple story about one family's progress in the new China is a larger message about globalization and the rapid dismantling of an entire culture.

The film is quick and dirty, somewhat cliched at times and hugely violent, and it also has a dubious ending; on the other hand, some of the action sequences and all of Don Cheadle's scenes make the thing worth seeing.

A bright little confection that highlights the talents of both leads. The writing is sparkly and the story is sweet; the film feels a bit slight overall, but the performances are so engaging that you won't much mind.
movie_title: At Home, by Myself... with You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Cactus is the sort of film that grabs your attention from the beginning and holds on tight almost throughout, but vanishes from your mind the minute it's over.
You might want to pick up the book and skip the film.
It's a subversive little outing with a terrific soundtrack and a 'do-unto-others' moral, and it might appeal -- just a hunch -- to a young male audience.
A subtle social comedy with an upstairs/downstairs sort of flavour.

The movie doesn't always make sense, but it's very funny and seems to charm viewers wherever it plays. And the performances are terrific. Garcia is particularly good as a blue-collar guy with acting aspirations.
It's hilarious. It's also completely mindless, but as it cheerfully celebrates its own awesome idiocy rather than pretending to be something it's not, you can only love the thing.
As thrillers go, this one is lacking in edge-of-the-seat moments. It just never ignites.
An intense and intelligent war biopic about Norway's greatest Second World War saboteur.
The Eclipse examines grief and loss, and it's a fascinating, if not entirely satisfying movie. The experience of seeing it feels more like watching a play.
A Shine of Rainbows is a sweet tale about a little boy and the mother who teaches him to appreciate every nook and cranny of everyday life.

No matter how much you know about The Doors, it's always a trip to see and to hear them, and this documentary has all the music, concert footage and shots of band camaraderie to warm a rock fan's heart.
Aan engaging Jordanian film about friendship between generations -- and courage at any age.
It's great to see Denzel Washington back in the saddle again, but The Book of Eli is a bit of a mess.
Tooth Fairy has more than enough pratfalls and silly one-liners to amuse kids and their accompanying grown-ups.
This dark territory is so dark that it all gets fairly confusing, but Corpo, although macabre, remains interesting to look at.
The White Ribbon is a haunting period tale that suggests what the eventual consequences of living in an oppressive, paternalistic, rigid society might be.
Love and Savagery, though wonderful to look at, feels too slender to be called a feature film.
It has been interesting to watch the reactions to Precious, based on whether one sees the film as emotional, political or sociological. Above all, it's a good story, well told.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The best things about Fantastic Mr. Fox are the soundtrack, an extraordinary affair that involves, among others, the Beach Boys and Burl Ives, and the animation.
Director Walt Becker can't even pull off hits to the groin (you know they're coming in a movie like this) with as much panache as an episode of America's Funniest Home Videos.
A balletic collection of blood-spattered martial arts moves that's bound to delight fans of the genre.
This film is worth seeing for the performances from Mortensen and gifted adolescent actor Smit-McPhee.
Big Fan is wonderfully written, cliche-free and fully capable of surprising you.
Penn is the best thing about the movie.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has several good performances, but the storytelling is without emotional peaks and valleys; it's flat. It's also clumsy.
What's the international symbol for Emoting Ahead?
There isn't nearly enough time devoted to the relationships among the men at the beginning, which undermines what happens to them all later on.
With that foundation and such a stellar cast, it's tough to see how this American remake could be so lacklustre -- but it is.
The film has already won several awards at film festivals, and once you see it, you'll understand why people are clamoring to see Colin Firth win an Academy Award.
Bridges is so spectacularly good as Bad Blake, country artist, that he's the whole movie.
Whether you consider Ruppert prophetic or paranoid, hearing his sobering thoughts on the collapse of industrialized civilization is a thought-provoking experience. Thought-provoking and scary.
Unlike the current cinematic vampire milieu created for lovestruck teenagers, Daybreakers is fierce and scary and downright thrilling to look at.
If Leap Year works at all, it's because Amy Adams makes it work through sheer force of personality.
Those old enough to resist can expect to be impressed anyway by the on-screen energy levels of both Chan and Valletta. They make their work look like fun.
Meyers manages to offset most of the usual rom-com pitfalls just by passing the ball to Meryl Streep or Alec Baldwin.
Big River Man is strange and wonderful and quite an experience at the cinema.
The Young Victoria is slow and pretty and nobody has quite enough to do. Luckily, there's plenty to look at in the way of costumes and furniture and crown jewels and palace tchotchkes.
It's as if the film is a no-humour zone, and any attempt at a laugh gets sucked into a cinematic vacuum of mirthlessness.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Whichever way you choose to look at it, it's a trippy couple of hours at the theatre.
An insightful look into the remarkable rise of the tennis-playing Williams sisters.

Writer-director Karim Aïnouz is aiming for someplace deeper than he reaches in trying to convey Hermila's nadir -- but occasionally the film manages to evoke some of the truly aimless hubris of being 21.
It's no small feat to film a documentary like this with the right balance of reverence for the craft of air guitar and good, old-fashioned shooting at an easy target, but Lipsitz pulls it off.
The lure of Reynolds' and Bullock's nude scene together is sure to fill cinema seats (and raise a smile), but the other 106 minutes of The Proposal prove utterly forgettable.
Audrey Tautou, gives a near flawless performance as an ambitious, unorthodox young Chanel.
The sweet story gets overshadowed by strange directorial choices, though the cast support the story well.
movie_title: London mon amour (Mes amis, mes amours) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tired and cliche-ridden, saved only by the authentic scenery, with the movie allowed unprecedented access to sites in Greece such as The Acropolis.
Despite the obvious chemistry between the two leads, and comic moments inspired by classic romance stories, the film fails to deliver above the usual romantic slush.
A brooding drama about grief, which is greatly aided by the performances and its scenic locations.
Woody Allen's supposedly undiscovered masterpiece is a complete failure, featuring a one-note performance from the usually hilarious Larry David.
Gabourey Sidibe and Mo'Nique are utterly compelling, and hopefully their performances will be recognised come Oscar time.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly compelling documentary, though there are aspects to the fashion legend's story that are unfortunately neglected.
Cliched and predictable but goofy crowd-pleaser with a funny supporting cast.
The film ends on a high note, but you know that this could have, and should have, been a lot better.
A beautiful ode to an artisan and his culture.
Take a nap until something better comes along.
The people of Budrus, and their choice of peaceful protest, can only be admired.
Like the title song with its crazy lyrics, it's quirky, fun and yet slightly overlong.
The lack of respect for the body, the sheer bloody aftermath depresses me. Yes, they may handle the killing with verve and ironic tension, but this is a Coen brothers film too far.
The film is often very funny. The acting is first-class, especially Gosling, who never patronises his character.
Is it any good? Definitively, yes. A beautifully made, spectacularly designed family movie, it dares to ask serious questions about good and evil, free will and adolescent sexuality.
The Passionate Friends looks gorgeous and has a feverishly modern intensity.
The mystery is why some of Britain's finest character actors including Crook, Meaney, Antony Sher and Imelda Staunton got caught up in this mess.
Taymor creates an intense, singular vision of Ancient Rome, but ultimately the film feels as empty as Titus and Tamora's revenge.
Suffering from way too much narration and a plot slower than a Clydesdale, Running Free is more like Trotting Bored.

Those impatient with Anglophilia may grow restless, but the film often visually enchants, and it's chockablock with themes that transcend period: sexuality, class, religion, love, addiction and most of all, family.
A discomforting look at a transsexual actress's difficult life and isolating pursuit of fame.
Gripping anorexia docu; watch with your kids.
Tim Burton magic with just a touch of scariness.
Magnificent, spellbinding movie has a bit of edge.
Well-meaning movie will bore younger kids
Jet Li's final fight; teens OK.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeous martial arts movie for older kids.
Brilliant biography will engage preteens and up.
I'm not sure that the movie, in the end, was worth everything that went into making it.
Weirdly, in a cast of comedy greats like the above, Harington is the stand-out.
There are some fresh touches, most especially when the boundaries of reality are completely tossed aside.

Every cliché from sports movies, underdog stories and father-son dramas is trotted out and played with a straight face.

It's as stubbornly inscrutable as its subjects.

This is a strange, scatterbrained hybrid of disaster movie and theologically minded science fiction. It's like The Happening with math.

movie_review_blurb: It's four wacky holiday comedies in one movie, each trying to top the last.
If you're in the mood for a cynical, time-traveling Italian vacation, you couldn't do much better than this.
Boogie Man does not inspire pity for Atwater but sadness that a man of such talent wasted his life and learned his lesson too late.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The soundtrack is as good as you'd expect from a movie about music lovers, as artists like Vampire Weekend and Devendra Banhart provide the essential background for the characters' adventures.

Fly Me to the Moon is the first animated feature made specifically for the 3-D format. If this were not the case, it would have gone straight to DVD. Everything else about it is as lazy and dull as the latest cheap Pixar knockoff.
When Did You Last See Your Father? is based on a true story, but it still feels contrived.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a testament to how good casting can help a film and bad writing can hurt it even more.

It's hard to sympathize with characters who bear no resemblance to any existing member of the human species, although, as is typical with this kind of movie, the cast brings a commitment the material doesn't deserve.
Like the diamonds that motivate its characters, Flawless" has a pretty surface but not much else.
Narrated by Joan Allen, the film is a remarkably comprehensive look at the cultural destruction that accompanied the slaughter.

If Mystery Science Theater 3000 ever makes a comeback, I've got its first movie. A soulless blend of bad action, bad acting and worse writing, Never Back Down is tolerable only if merciless wisecrackers are offering commentary.

movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The supporting roles are all handled well by experienced actors, and they have good material to work with.

A moving, intimate story of loss and second chances.

An entertaining effort with "cult following" written all over it.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As Jordan drifts around, searching for a consistent tone, it becomes evident he isn't sure what kind of story he's telling.

Penn and Cho's stoner slapstick will doubtless please their obsessive fans.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: More than any other director, the extraordinarily gifted Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhang-ke has a talent for locating the future in the present day.
Director Chen Shi-Zheng is inconsistent from one scene to the next, alternating clichés with convincing, specific details. The film never quite earns its whopper of a finale.
The drama never merely titillates, instead developing a convincing dynamic among the three.
The film is shot through with keen observations and dry wit, and has a refreshing, easygoing sense of flow.

Boys Don't Cry director Kimberly Pearce attempts to anchor the Iraq War debate in the lives of a specific subset of soldiers and nearly pulls it off. But her promising premise runs into a rut of incompatible accents and melodramatic excess.
[This] lo-fi sci-fi debut is jam-packed with sly satirical gestures that more than compensate for its more-traditional shortcomings.

Even fans of Stephen Chow should probably skip his latest, kid-friendly flick. It's only sporadically funny, and often grating, and at some point you realize that you've been suckered into watching an extended advertisement for a toy.

movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly, this documentary honors Judge's memory, but one wishes for something greater.

movie_review_blurb: Reality TV has rarely cared much about truth -- and maybe this is the doc it deserves. The crass truthiness here is far more apt than any of the glossy satire in American Dreamz.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Joe Swanberg and Greta Gerwig nail the everyday rhythms of stuttering indecision.

Somber and exhaustive, the film manages to avoid exploitation while still conveying the harrowing ordeal of its subjects.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tomas Alfredson somehow takes a wild premise -- a ravenous 12-year-old bloodsucker who strikes up a romance with a bullied young boy in small-town Sweden -- and executes it with restraint and style.

it's Rapaport's mistake to spend so much time and energy unpacking something so much more obvious, and so much less interesting, than Tribe's music.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Still, Day's scene involving a mountain of cocaine is hyperspeed-hilarious, Farrell's unhinged, irrational fuming is marvelously cretinous, and Aniston's fully committed sex-addict sexpot act is wickedly absurd.
...by Pixar's outrageous standards of Oscar shoo-in virtuosity, this sequel is a disappointment at best.

Jim Carrey's farts-and-flippers comedy, which, though exceedingly dumb, is at least very smart about what appeals to 4- to 10-year-old kids, fans of Happy Feet, March of the Penguins, and YouTube animal videos.

An affecting, troubling, dazzling film.

Uncannily in tune with contemporary global events.

Mobsters is a bloody little fairy tale that makes good guys out of Lucky Luciano, Frank Costello, Bugsy Siegel and Meyer Lansky. According to the film, a largely plodding affair, they were just four kids who liked to kill people once in a while.
The problem is not so much the child. The problem is the movie, one which is, in its own way, amazing. Why was it made? Who made it? Do they have children? Would they want them to see this thing?
This is a very macho movie, and if the better film schools are looking for a contemporary film that very keenly exemplifies the marriage of sound and shoot, this is it.
It also lacks cuteness, which a movie of this sort needs. A film as predictable as this one is seriously in need of scenes that stand out, scenes that give the movie a little life, no pun intended.
