movie_review_blurb: Delves into one of the most chronically undercovered 9/11 stories -- the still-unknown number of U.S. citizens and foreign nationals detained without trial in the wake of the attacks.
The latest evidence that Hollywood has run the se rial-killer thriller into the ground through overuse.
The sort of vanity project that gives amateurs a bad name.
A solid documentary that examines the art's roots, from ad-libs by black preachers to 'toasts' delivered by Jamaican immigrants over instrumental tracks in the '70s South Bronx.
A clever and big- hearted gay screwball comedy.
Surprisingly smart, cool-looking, nicely paced and well-acted.
Handsome but coldly uninvolving and pretentious.
Quote not available.
A slight, silly musical fantasy with two left feet.
If ever a movie could be charged with imperiling the morals of a minor, it's probably Sleepover.
It all adds up to an acute character study -- but as a thriller, it's too cerebral to quicken the pulse.
Sequels don't get much better -- or smarter -- than the action-, drama-, romance- and comedy-packed Spider-Man 2.
Well worth the risk of diabetic shock for the sake of superb acting that transcends its teary milieu.
A bizarre and campily amusing 'tribute.'
A quietly persuasive and very timely documentary.
Contains little that is particularly new or compelling, save an emotional interview with Whitewater principal Susan McDougal.
An atmospheric but sluggish and needlessly confusing British contemporary film noir that may indeed leave some audience members struggling to stay awake.
This $110-million fiasco is the sort of movie that gives family entertainment a bad name.
A purr-fectly ridiculous and boring cat-astrophe.
A peculiarly bloodless variation on Jules and Jim suffused with the kind of pretentious gentility that some critics will mistake for seriousness.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Deb Ellis and Dennis Mueller's tight and deceptively low-key documentary lets the subject eloquently speak for himself.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: May not be subtle or disciplined, but it is funny as hell.
One of the better political documentaries flooding into theaters after Fahrenheit 9/11 and before the election.
The sort of incoherent mess that invariably goes straight to video.
Ross McElwee shows just how far subtlety can go with his latest charming effort.
Overlong and heavy-handed, semi-autobiographical dramedy.
Estes and his cinematographer, Sharone Meir, present a vision of paradise and innocence lost in this beautifully understated drama.
The acting is serviceable at best, the direction unfocused -- and the special effects and makeup cheesy-looking.
It all plays very much like an extremely drawn-out episode of Lassie updated with references to child, spousal and dog abuse.
A downright cat-astrophe.
One thing is certain: Nobody is going to be demanding a rematch.
A second-rate action picture that's content to use apartheid as a colorful background.
The diminutive actress [Morton] and the much taller Robbins make the season's most improbable screen couple since Tom Hanks and Catherine Zeta-Jones in The Terminal.
Collateral has such classy trappings, you're constantly expecting more -- but while there may be less here than meets the eye, this is solid stuff in the midst of Hollywood's dog days.
Does generate a fair amount of erotic tension and sly commentary on psychoanalysis.
The most gut-bustingly funny movie so far this year.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Village pours on creepy atmosphere, but this dud is too intent on delivering its liberal 'message' to actually deliver the kinds of scares it promises in the terrific trailer.
So terrifically entertaining, it would be a shame if it didn't inspire a companion piece on New York.
Director John Curran draws skillfully nuanced performances from the four leads, who have rarely been better.
A witty and wise midlife comedy.
The sort of lowbrow sports comedy best enjoyed on a 50-inch screen with a six-pack, a bucket of wings and a fast-forward button.
Quite silly and not especially scary.
This is a gifted director who actually has something to say and knows how to say it. We'll be hearing from him again.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An ugly, painfully derivative and sleep-inducing talking-animals cartoon laced with potty humor.
Inspired by a book by Steven Blush, Rachman deftly sketches the hardcore scene in a dozen cities and chronicles the growing violence that signaled its demise.
A lavish biopic that gives Li one of his juiciest roles but is relatively light on the action his fans have come to expect.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [It] isn't going to win any awards for Law, a frantically hamming Penn or anyone else involved.
The advertising slogan for The Haunted Mansion warns, 'Check your pulse at the door' -- pretty cheeky for a movie that flatlines for almost all of its 98 minutes.
Documents the Nixon administration's failed, almost comically inept attempt to deport the most political of The Beatles and his wife, Yoko Ono.
A strained, ultra-predictable and headache-inducing mockumentary.
... a middling remake of a mediocre Italian comedy pandering to the chick-flick crowd ...
Visually dazzling but ultimately disappointing.
There is a lot of preaching to the converted in Nick Doob and Chris Hedges' Al Franken: God Spoke, an adoring and fairly haphazard look behind the scenes with the comedian and liberal gadfly.
... a fascinating, sad, sometimes quite poetic window into a grueling way of life most of us know little about.
... a cinematic elegy for Father Mychal Judge ...
While This Film Is Not Yet Rated does not suggest an alternative to the ratings board, it does expose this Tinseltown sham to some well-deserved public ridicule.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Lassie is a dog movie even non-dog lovers will lap up.
... So Goes the Nation sticks to reporting. Unlike most political documentaries, it doesn't preach -- to the choir or to anyone else.
A blandly inoffensive 'After School Special'-type comedy based on a perennially popular children's book.
While it may not be the tour de force of Mitchell's directing debut (Hedwig and the Angry Inch), this risky project is still a lot of fun.
Mirren is the one to beat for the Best Actress Oscar -- and The Queen is one of the year's best movies. Don't miss it.
Director (Ramon) Salazar is no Pedro Almodóvar, try as he might.
The Bridge does not try to milk these tragedies, which are often shot from a great distance and tastefully edited.
A political thriller that thankfully sidesteps the offensive convention of exploring Africa's suffering through the eyes of a white protagonist.
Sharper and far more entertaining than most political documentaries.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Less than ideally focused but with terrific performances -- especially by the Oscar-baiting Annette Bening as a monster mom -- this is a compulsively watchable movie best enjoyed by forgetting that it's supposedly based on actual events...
Sweet Land is gorgeously shot and directed without a false note, but its chief virtue is the beautiful and little-known [Elizabeth] Reaser.
Sleeping Dogs Lie does collar big laughs for anyone who isn't skeeved out by the whole idea.
Flicka is a new version of the family classic about a teenager and a wild horse that's as misconceived as it is corny and predictable.

Eastwood storms Mt. Oscar again with Flags of Our Fathers, a stirring ode to American heroism during the battle of Iwo Jima - which also pointedly dissects how that heroism was cynically packaged for public consumption.
This superb documentary about the Catholic Church's worst pedophile scandal is in many ways far scarier than any fiction.
This lame teenage James Bond will leave audiences neither shaken nor stirred.
An overly adoring but still quite interesting profile of the writer.
Quote not available.
The film's leisurely pacing -- and Modine's overly laid-back work -- leave something to be desired.
Vanity productions don't come much worse than One Third.
Scorsese's sharpest film in a decade and the most entertaining major studio release this year.
Surviving Eden is the sort of hapless vanity project where even the outtakes at the end aren't funny.
A repugnant little indie black comedy, poorly acted in hideous-looking digital video, guaranteed to send audiences fleeing for the nearest shower.
It's basically a series of music videos -- a few quite good -- strung together over two long hours and loosely connected by a weak story line loaded with anachronisms.
Despite this seemingly surefire premise and cast of veteran comedians - there's even a cameo by Liza Minnelli as a masturbation coach -- The OH in Ohio just lies there, without a single laugh.
Think of the uncompromisingly mediocre comedy You, Me and Dupree as a referendum on whether audiences are tiring of Owen Wilson's beatific stoner dude character as rapidly as I am.
Shawn's Darryl comes off as terminally stupid, enduring many blows to the groin (there's even a montage of them) while lavishing affection on his dubious 'son.'

Excellent Cadavers uses archival footage to place the war in the context of the longtime alliance between the Mafia and crooked Italian politicians, but there's little, if anything, that will be new for those interested in the subject.
The documentary enters more dubious territory when it tries to present today's more consumer-friendly post-punkers (like the Strokes and Yeah Yeah Yeahs) as some sort of successors.
Unfortunately, there is... jarringly contemporary English dialogue... laced with F-bombs and humor straight out of a Monty Python movie.

No Hollywood scriptwriter would dare make up a tale as outrageously unlikely -- but, as it happens, true -- as the one so entertainingly told in the documentary Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos.
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A Scanner Darkly doesn't quite live up to the promise of its opening sequence, but it's still an audacious offering during a season of brain-dead blockbusters.
Despite some remarkable unembedded footage, Andrew Berends' is yet another disappointingly superficial, unfocused and one-sided documentary on the conflict in Iraq.
movie_title: The Blood of My Brother: A Story of Death in Iraq (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Laughless, pointless and downright creepy.
A beautifully crafted, emotionally resonant and heavily nostalgic Man of Steel guaranteed to appeal to several generations of Superman fans.
The Road to Guantanamo is a missed opportunity. This is a subject that deserves a more thoughtful documentary or docudrama, not a hastily thrown together amalgam of the two.
Rarely have I wanted to fast-forward through a movie as much as Click, a treacly and not-funny-enough Adam Sandler comedy about a man who uses a magical remote control to fast-forward through life.
All of the familiar urban stereotypes and clichés are out in force.
Not un-entertaining, but director George Bamer's debut feature may play better on video.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Chilly, pretentious and talky.
An act of spectacular (if unwitting) self-immolation.

The storytelling skill in Monster House isn't always up to its visuals. But as a roller-coaster summer entertainment, it's a heck of a lot more fun than Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest, not to mention a full hour shorter.
Not only will you want to shower after seeing this repellent movie -- the Rose-Mikey sex scenes are especially icky -- you'll feel sorry for the cast.
It's sort of reassuring that although Madge has seemingly given up starring in bad movies, her company is still financing terrible scripts.

As faux Woody Allen movies go, Trust the Man is one of the more diverting recent entries in the genre, with a top-drawer cast, well-chosen Manhattan locations and a sharper script than Allen himself has managed in a while.
The movie doesn't miss a cliché, ineptly lifting liberally from The Godfather and GoodFellas, among other classics.
This is the kind of thoughtful, poetic, lush and old-fashioned (in the best sense of the word) film that rarely gets made anymore -- one that immerses us in a bygone world for a couple of hours.
Most contemporary Japanese horror movies concentrate on mood and don't much bother with plot. But this brain-dead remake is full of yammering about suicide clusters, flu epidemics and hard drives.
Excruciating as it is well meaning, Doug Bollinger's Waltzing Anna is a vanity production that turns serious issues about the aging into a schmaltzy dramatic comedy.
[The film is] arguably as effective as Ambien at inducing sleep, but possible side effects include uncontrollable laughter.
Saw III is nasty, repulsive, disgusting -- and loaded with enough viscera to probably sell at least $30 million worth of tickets this weekend.
An expertly crafted, respectful piece of inspirational filmmaking.

Working on terrific sets with imaginative lighting effects and cinematography, Marshall creates a palpable sense of claustrophobia and danger well before murderous cave dwellers make their appearance quite a ways into the movie.
I wouldn't have thought it was possible to make a prison picture as utterly boring as Jailbait.
A lively and poignant comedy with lots of laughs and juicy roles for a roster of seasoned performers who should be seen more often.
An irresistible no-budget documentary.

This generic exercise in computer-generated animation may provide passable entertainment for very young children, but adults will be less than enchanted by its preachiness, talkiness and Communist Party-line political views.
Scoop, a half-baked amalgam of Manhattan Murder Mystery and Curse of the Jade Scorpion -- sadly demonstrates that Allen has lost much of his comic timing both as a director and an actor.
A smart, dark road comedy about a dysfunctional family that had them rolling in the aisles at this year's Sundance Film Festival.
This Sundance dud is a turgid gay soap opera with a limp twist, showcasing Robin Williams at his maudlin worst.
It has a charming protagonist in Will Shortz, the crossword editor of the New York Times.
Romantico is muy bueno.
Almodóvar milks this premise for all it's worth with witty dialogue, terrific performances -- and less-flamboyant-than-usual visuals that are still a red-accented treat for the eye.
While the film has impressive 18th-century trappings and vivid battle scenes, the plotting and acting are rudimentary.

Chris Rock, who famously mocked Jude Law's movie career at the Oscars, ought to watch out for his own after his second dud in a row as an actor-director, the screamingly unfunny romantic comedy I Think I Love My Wife.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As Premonition slowly creeps toward a ridiculous faith-based climax or two, you may feel compelled to take a nap yourself. When you awake, it may all seem like a bad dream -- but why is your wallet missing $11? Scary.
This gorgeously designed and photographed movie artfully depicts the immigrant experience in ways that transcend its setting.
Overall, TV veteran Stockman isn't terribly skillful at meshing comedy and drama.
This is the kind of movie that's best enjoyed as a stylized fantasy, much like Brewer's most obvious model, Elia Kazan's Southern-fried Tennessee Williams adaptation Baby Doll.
David Fincher's sprawling, lavishly produced Zodiac is, in my estimation, more than a good movie.

There isn't a remotely believable moment in the script here, and [writer/director] Kramer's leaden direction only helps strand a capable cast headed by Heather Graham in an hour and a half of virtual laugh-free tedium.

I was content to go along for the ride with this excellently cast labor of love -- which shows just how much you can accomplish with $12 million and more imagination than most big-studio re leases can muster these days.
Though it's being dumped in the wastelands in February, Breach is better than many of the pack of so-called prestige movies that were released at the end of last year.
Too bad director Lawrence tends to hit you over the head with the jokes in his script.
The skillfully acted and directed The Lives of Others is a timely warning about governments that seek to repress dissent.
The special effects look like they were executed on somebody's laptop.

There are touching interviews with a couple of former inmates, who were 'reeducated' for years after they were caught trying to help people attempting to escape to West Germany after the Berlin Wall went up.
Norbit is another crude, sloppy paycheck job for an actor who doesn't need the money -- and who proved in Dreamgirls that he is capable of far better.
After a slightly sluggish start, director Shaye directs with assurance, and the kids are delightful.
Nicely photographed but slow-moving, dull and utterly predictable.
Mike Binder's oddball film keeps retreating into fantasy -- as if to avoid precisely the kind of issues that have kept the studios from confronting the legacy of 9/11.
Covers very familiar indie territory, but debuting director Mark Fergus covers with style.
Next, which makes National Treasure look like a model of narrative logic, is almost beyond criticism.
[The filmmakers] insist, none too convincingly, that animals are capable of consenting to fulfilling their sexual needs. Wilburrrrr!!
Despite director Sam Raimi's near-desperate determination to top the earlier films and tie up loose ends, he does deliver a handsome product with some spectacular special-effects sequences.
Packs a lot of old-fashioned shocks into its taut 80-minute running time.
Fracture breaks no new ground, but with [Gosling and Hopkins] around, you'll never be bored.
A very low-key, well-acted dramedy.
A rather plodding movie.
This invaluable record contains a treasure trove of clips from Smith's hard-to-see and still striking films, plus comments that were culled from hours of interviews with this flamboyant pioneer.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing can quite top the climax, which arbitrarily assigns a culprit in a way that makes you question almost every single thing that's transpired up to that point. And no, that's not a good thing in this case.
Director D.J. Caruso relies entirely too much on clichéd shock cuts and keeps pulling back every time the flick seems to be settling into anything close to a creepy mood.
Quite a deal for $11 -- a veritable smorgasbord of decapitations, impalings, attempted rapes, car chases, explosions, good and bad acting and well-endowed women in very short shorts.
If you've seen the brilliantly edited trailer, you've seen just about every single laugh in the movie.
Not an easy movie to watch, and it's far from perfect -- but it does have an artsy integrity and a fascinatingly intense performance by Paul Giamatti.
[Director] Bier has lots [of] surprises up her sleeve to keep After the Wedding humming for two solid hours.
A delightful, quirk-filled riff on Back to the Future.
Great fun for the first 20 minutes but seems long at 86.
Writer-director Maggenti turns in some smart dialogue and keeps things moving swiftly.
Call it a hunch, but I don't think you're going to see a clip from the appalling romantic comedy Because I Said So at this spring's Diane Keaton tribute at Lincoln Center.
... moseys along very slowly ...
What is Inland Empire -- which Lynch is understandably distributing himself -- about? What is it trying to say? If you figure that out, let me know.
...Strictly remainder-bin material.
Even some of the many nuns at the screening I attended were shifting uncomfortably in their wimples.
Guest and his co-writer, Eugene Levy, aren't afraid to chew off the hand that feeds them.
Deja Vu starts out a lot like an expensive-looking episode of CSI before morphing into a solidly entertaining time-traveling romance.
The History Boys is essentially filmed theater, with minimal, and usually clumsy, attempts to take the action out of the classroom.

George Miller's Happy Feet may be the 10th animated film this year with talking critters -- but, trust me, you're probably going to want to see the best feature-length cartoon since The Incredibles, no matter what your age.
Bobby, which reportedly is going to receive a huge push for the Oscars, is one of the year's worst movies.

Though Jeff Lipsky's snoozefest, Flannel Pajamas, essentially consists of a couple talking nonstop for two hours, we never really understand what brought them together in the first place -- much less why they break up after two years together.
...Tin-eared script and tone-deaf direction sabotages a fortissimo performance by Ed Harris in the title role.
Rarely has a documentary been so pleased with itself -- with so little justification -- as Steve Anderson's repetitive and unenlightening F - - k.
Beautifully photographed by Tim Orr, Come Early Morning is the kind of small gem that's becoming increasingly rare in American films.
A Good Year may not be vintage stuff, but it goes down fairly smoothly.
[Babel] is, in short, one of the year's best movies.
Another week, another movie about a depressed transsexual hooker.

Complaining about the gooey and generic The Holiday is as useless as railing against fruitcake -- this is a slick, throwaway chick flick designed to provide nothing more than mindless diversion between bouts of shopping.
Forget your history lessons about what an advanced civilization the Mayans were. Here they're bloodthirsty savages.

[It] gets points for being the first movie to depict Iraq war veterans adjusting to civilian life. It loses points for being a painfully earnest and very thinly conceived update of The Best Years of Our Lives and Coming Home.
The film plays like a pastiche of Casablanca, The Third Man and Billy Wilder's "A Foreign Affair," though it is far more explicit about violence and sex than was ever dreamed of in films of the era.
Impersonal hackwork by someone who is bending over backwards to sell out and become the new Michael Bay.
At heart, The Italian is a Dickensian tale that paints a vivid portrait of post-Glasnost Russia en route to a four-handkerchief ending.
Far superior to the generic thrillers churned out by the big studios.

Mani Ratnam's often absorbing Guru is sort of a Bollywood Citizen Kane, a decades-spanning drama with a compelling Abhishek Bachchan as a ruthless Indian business tycoon who refuses to take no for an answer.
Irresponsible, uncommercial but surprisingly watchable.
All-too-tasteful film, which is apparently aimed at mothers and daughters with far too much time on their hands.
Suspenselessly directed by Robby Henson, Thr3e commits the eighth deadly sin -- boredom.
This is the finest and most thoughtful comedy released so far this century.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: 'I hate to tell you, but it gets worse,' one character promises midway through Happily N'Ever After. No kidding.
Flaws and all, Dreamgirls is certainly a lot more watchable than other recent adaptations of Broadway musicals like Rent, The Producers and The Phantom of the Opera.
Notes on a Scandal is a great cure for a holiday hangover. See it.
This unusual film holds interest for 2 1/2 hours and is so visually vivid you can practically smell many of the scenes.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sad to say, but Robert De Niro's The Good Shepherd, an ambitious and starry but lamentably interminable attempt to trace the beginnings of the Central Intelligence Agency, may well have you counting sheep.
The special effects are far more inspired than the comedy in Night at the Museum, which strands several generations of performers in a highly derivative script and hackneyed direction.

Despite a fierce lead performance by Naomi Watts, The Painted Veil is a quaintly bloodless, picture-postcard adaptation of W. Somerset Maugham's 1925 China-set novel -- more Merchant Ivory than David Lean.

Letters From Iwo Jima, Clint Eastwood's spare, poetic and remarkable companion piece to Flags of Our Fathers, is an engrossing and revealing look at that same World War II battle from the Japanese side.
Pan's Labyrinth represents a quantum leap in del Toro's storytelling, drawing on Alice in Wonderland, Pinocchio and many other inspirations to create something quite new and wonderful.
A cheesy, often unintentionally funny, direct-to-video-caliber knockoff of Aliens that couldn't be more shallow.
The sort of dopey movie best appreciated while wearing pajamas.
Sketchy, rambling, tune-filled -- and, at best, mildly entertaining.
Walk the Line is the only movie I've seen three times this year -- and I'd happily watch it again and again.

Murphy's tour de force as the eternally optimistic Patrick surely deserves an Oscar nomination. Thanks to Jordan's bravura storytelling, Breakfast on Pluto is one of very few movies this year truly worth remembering.
Charming if overlong.
The comedian and her director, Liam Lynch, have framed about an hour's worth of concert footage with bogus backstage scenes to pad this out to feature length.
Zathura is basically Jumanji in outer space -- and even without Robin Williams, this is still a singularly loud, charmless and overbearing family movie that could use a hit or two of Ritalin.
The charismatic rapper is so utterly inexpressive as an actor that he's constantly getting swallowed up in his own movie.
Audacious and extremely well-acted -- if flawed.
Fails to dig out the dramatic meat, despite a yeoman performance by Danny Aiello.
Highly entertaining.
movie_title: The Last Mogul (Life and Times of Lew Wasserman) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There's scarcely enough story here for a half-hour TV cartoon.
Knoxville tries hard and exudes a certain likability, but can't really handle big dramatic moments at this point in his career.
Wal-Mart's home office in Bentonville, Ark., can rest easy: Greenwald, as usual, is hysterically preaching to the choir.
movie_title: Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price (2005)

movie_review_blurb: New York Doll has a killer surprise ending that may leave even hard-core punkers reaching for the Kleenex.
[A] poorly acted, directed and written (but slick-looking) vanity project.
The sort of movie where all of the best jokes are in the trailer, but these days a romantic comedy with anything worth quoting at all is something of an accomplishment.
Americans might want to approach him first on the printed page rather than the hyperactive Zizek!

THERE'LL likely be more Z's in the audience than on the screen during The Legend of Zorro, a belated and belabored sequel to the delightful '98 hit that seems more like a cross between Wild Wild West and Spy Kids.
Taj Mahal on its own terms is lavishly satisfying.
movie_title: Taj Mahal: An Eternal Love Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Ice Harvest is a treat for everyone who hates holidays.
Speaking of corporate malfeasance, Fun with Dick & Jane cost a disgraceful $100 million -- approximately 33 times the price tag of the 1976 original.
Munich is essential viewing that should be rewarded for its bravery come Oscar time.
The Family Stone is a satisfying, big-hearted celebration of diversity that will brighten holiday moviegoing - - at least in the blue states.
Most great movies are lucky to have a handful of moments to remember; King Kong has at least two dozen.
Mrs. Henderson Presents is a classy crowd-pleaser with two stars who can pretty much count on Oscar nominations.
Overlong, poorly paced and woodenly acted.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hopkins' larger-than-life performance as the crusty and crafty Burt rivets your attention for two solid hours in this most entertaining labor of love.
The mesmerizingly awful The Kid & I is a historic first: a comedy about the making of a vanity production that is itself a vanity production.
Aeon Flux is by far the year's worst movie, a most dubious achievement.
An overlong and surprisingly dull documentary about snowboarding.
An uplifting documentary.
Seamless is pretty dry stuff that verges on an infomercial, despite cameo appearances by Sarah Jessica Parker and Mizrahi himself.

This painfully unfunny spoof promises to do for independent movies what Airplane! did for disaster movies, but mostly what My Big Fat Independent Movie does is demonstrate the ineptitude of its makers.
[A] terrific, long-overdue vehicle for Lady Olivier.
Largely laugh-free.
Hugely ambitious, excellently acted and very challenging.

Filmmaker Josh Stolberg claims to have been inspired by real-life events, but mostly he ineptly rips off other movies and wastes a cast that includes Rosanna Arquette, Adam Arkin and Elizabeth Perkins.
A smart, hilarious and affec tionate spoof of detective movies -- and Hollywood -- starring the inspired team of Robert Downey Jr. and Val Kilmer.
A valuable and frightening survey of contemporary anti-Semitism.
A painfully sincere indie drama.
Dorian Blues eschews the heavy sexual content (and most of the clichés) of so many gay films - - it also has a lot of heart.
By far the smartest American film released in 2005.
Separate Lies is a soufflé that begins promisingly but never quite rises.
The movie belongs entirely to Falk's memorable Sam.
Tim Burton's Corpse Bride is an instant classic.
Schreiber's film version of Everything Is Illuminated achieves the impossible -- it's even more annoying than Jonathan Safran Foer's gratingly precocious novel.
Six Lower Manhattan thirty somethings ponder the suicide of a mutual friend in Walking on the Sky, a tediously self-absorbed variation on The Big Chill and The Return of the Secaucus 7.

Solid performances can't save Melissa Painter's pretentious teen drama Steal Me, which plays like a cross between Dangerous Skin (without the gay sex) and Picnic (without the production values or credible situations).

The most frightening thing about The Exorcism of Emily Rose is how three Oscar-nominated actors were talked into working with Scott Dietrickson, writer-director of the direct-to-video Hellraiser: Inferno.
The Man is yet another screwed-up mess that will give audiences another excuse to shun the multiplexes this weekend.
A superficial and mostly unenlightening meditation on how the city has changed since 9/11, shot in dreary digital video.
Though Cho occasionally connects with her targets, more often than not she seems as intolerant and hate-filled as she accuses them of being -- and that's not funny.
This feeble Beverly Hills Cop knockoff will give audiences burned repeatedly by crummy movies this summer yet another reason to avoid multiplexes for the Labor Day weekend.

This aimless epic about a pair of charlatan brothers sinks under the weight of a problematic script, questionable star casting, hamfisted editing -- and penny-pinching by Gilliam's latest patrons, the Brothers Weinstein.
A History of Violence is solid entertainment value for the money, but those who think it's saying anything new or profound are kidding themselves.
Acting doesn't get much better than Philip Seymour Hoffman's acid-etched -- yet oddly poetic -- portrait of Truman Capote.
It's worth sticking with 40 Shades of Blue to catch two of the year's most richly detailed pieces of acting.
Alas, there is no treasure, buried or otherwise, but only fool's gold in the silly script.
In the end, the no-nonsense direction by Caro (the New Zealander who directed Whale Rider), the terrific actors and the pitiless visuals by the great Menges more than carry the day.
Another sorry chapter in Hollywood's infatuation with video games, Doom is basically a deadly dull rehash of Resident Evil, which in turn was a third-generation clone of Aliens.
There's no payoff as things drag along to a ludicrous ending that reeks of contempt for its audience.
Choppily edited and only sporadically funny.
Writer-director Kirkman takes the basic ingredients of a Lifetime movie and turns Loggerheads into something special indeed.
Egoyan's screenplay, based on a convoluted novel by Rupert Holmes, never achieves any kind of dramatic credibility.
An excruciatingly bad indie.
The White Countess is a worthy and classy conclusion to the Merchant Ivory cannon.
This documentary's director, Jacques Richard, includes insightful and often hilarious archival interviews with Langlois and dozens of associates.
movie_title: Henri Langlois: The Phantom of the Cinematheque (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully unfunny.
Schmaltzy, but reasonably entertaining.
The sophomorically crude comedy Waiting... confirms your worst suspicions about both the staff in chain restaurants -- and indie filmmakers desperate to be noticed.
Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit demands more than a single viewing to catch everything -- and audiences of all ages won't mind one bit.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A moderately charming comedy depicting a fumbling prepubescent first romance in a beautiful, fairy-tale version of the borough.

movie_review_blurb: Not exactly inspiring.
Extremely cool-looking in the manner of "Sin City,'' but clumsily staged, slackly acted and mind-numbingly dull...

Certainly grows on you, despite all of the twee touches.

Five delightful animated shorts...

Generates quite a few laughs on the way to a surprisingly satisfying climax.

Long on style and short on coherent storytelling...

This movie stubbornly refuses to take flight, or generate more than a few chuckles.

The stunning visuals surpass the high standards set by its predecessors, but storywise, it breaks no new ground.

All this hype, and for what? Three hours or so, set mostly in a single room where the unsavory guests and staff trade juvenile and racist insults, periodically murdering each other. I was hoping they'd get it over with already well before the intermission

Mostly it's up to Lawrence to wring all the drama and pathos she can out of a battle over patent rights that pushes Joy to the brink of bankruptcy. No surprise that her mettle cleans up all the messiness in Joy.
With not a wasted frame in its taut 80 minutes, this is deserving of your attention as one of the year's best movies even if it's being released in the middle of August.
Warner Bros. would have been better off sticking with the film's original March release date and selling it as a horror movie.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's warmest and most crowd-pleasing surprises.

Holds back a bit compared to its more melodramatic predecessor. But these are small complaints about a movie containing a trio of truly extraordinary and moving performances from Blanchett, Mara and Paulson that place it among the year's best.
Zemeckis and Gale have cannily chosen the time periods, which are funny as much for their similarities (political and materalistic) as their contrasts (music, fashions, language).
This disaster flick manages to stay afloat largely thanks to the yeoman efforts of Casey Affleck.

Kids will love "African Cats," which is full of "aw" moments. Their parents will appreciate that narrator Samuel L. Jackson keeps things from getting too schmaltzy in this true-life depiction of the circle of life.
Lots of luck figuring any of this out before dozing off.
[A] clunky, ugly and dull mash-up of a mystery about a missing housewife - and her daughter's sexual coming of age.
[A] highly entertaining documentary ...
Much longer on style and belligerence than actual substance.
Relentlessly gruesome, self-consciously shocking and pretty much pointless.
A family-friendly, Hallmark Channel-ready musical dramatic fable whose plot more closely resembles Spike Lee's "Red Hook Summer.''
[A] tiresome cavalcade of bickering - which feels like it lasts even longer than your typical Thanksgiving dinner.

Basically a kinder, gentler Vince Vaughn movie for people who don't like Vince Vaughn movies, "Delivery Man'' trades the abrasive comedian's trademark snark for schmaltz - an experiment that actually works better than you'd guess.
"Nebraska'' has enough good lines, scenes and performances to make it worth your while, as well as a sufficiently upbeat ending to qualify it as holiday entertainment.

Miyazaki offers a vivid, at times fantastical view of Japan between the wars, wracked by the Great Depression, a fearsome earthquake that leveled Tokyo in 1923, a tuberculosis epidemic and the rise of fascism.
Overall, it's engaging and serves its young audience well - a rare Holocaust movie that doesn't strain to become Oscar bait.
Thanks in no small part to Kline and Steenburgen, "Last Vegas'' has its moments. When they're not on-screen, beware of half-baked ham and hypoglycemic shock.
It's a remarkable story, vividly and urgently told by French-Canadian director Vallée from a pointed, schmaltz-free script by Craig Borten and Melissa Wallack.
Watts and Andrews have no chemistry together whatsoever. But in all fairness, probably no actor could convincingly play lines like "I love when you touch me there.''
A fine, touching tribute to John Waters' larger-than-life drag diva ...
Nearly every plot twist is telegraphed by reams of stilted dialogue provided by novelist Cormac McCarthy in his first original screenplay.
A brutally powerful and emotionally devastating film that takes great pains to rip any lingering vestiges of romanticism from America's most shameful institution.
"Saving Mr. Banks'' is ultimately much less about magic than making the sale, in more ways than one.
Based very loosely on an early short story by Leo Tolstoy, "Two Jacks" has a much less interesting second act ...
A space-holding, empty-headed epic filled with characters and places (digital and otherwise) that are hard to keep straight, much less care about.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Handsome, sporadically amusing and admittedly never boring - but also bloated, redundant, vulgar, shapeless and pointless ...
It's the wonderful performances by Bening and Harris that make this flawed, somewhat maudlin film worth seeing.
Anderson, who collaborated on the script (as in his previous films) with his college buddy Owen Wilson, gives everyone some of the best dialogue heard in a recent movie.

All the tedium of an endless trans-Atlantic flight gets packed into the 105 minutes of "Non-Stop,'' a preposterous "thriller'' providing Oscar winner-turned action star Liam Neeson with his latest paycheck job.
Though the performances aren't bad at all, everyone is playing one-note stereotypes in this cat-and-mouse game as Bondarchuk marks time for an impressively staged climax with lots of pyrotechnics.
A campy guilty pleasure that serves up a "Gladiator'' knockoff as an appetizer to the impressively flame-filled main course.

Shana Feste's endlessly lame "Endless Love'' remake turns the obsessive sexual heat way down from the infamous 1981 Brooke Shields vehicle - while also tossing out the tragedies of Scott Spencer's acclaimed source novel.
"Adult World" proceeds by fits and starts, but fans of Cusack won't want to miss his performance as the petulant poet, whose resistance is inevitably worn down by his persistent fan.
Clooney's low-key directorial effort is not quite an Oscar-caliber movie, though it's got a great cast, a worthy theme and plenty of things to reward adult moviegoers.
You probably don't want to see this gripping 3-D adaptation of an unusual and acclaimed 1999 off-Broadway production just before your next plane trip.

The primary exposure for animated shorts in this country is this annual compilation - which, as usual, is being shown along with separate programs of the Oscar-nominated live-action and documentary shorts.
Offers an admirable message of tolerance for teen audiences - too bad it's been absurdly saddled with an R rating, even though there's far less innuendo than in "Easy A.''
[A] stale, schmaltzy and testosterone-drenched comedy.
The small-town setting of a half-century ago is beautifully animated by director Peter Lepenotis and his team, and there are some nicely staged old-school action sequences.
Mostly, "Return to Nuke 'Em High'' is an occasionally hilarious series of parodies: "Carrie,'' "Soylent Green,'' "Glee,'' "Cat Ballou,'' you name it.

You could write "Walking With Dinosaurs'' off as harmless filler for the under-5 set, except that the only female dinosaur, Juniper, exists solely to moon over Patchi, who as a hatchling lost part of an ear to a winged predator.
Jonze seems to be heading for a far quirkier ending than the one he actually delivers, but he does tap into the zeitgeist with his unlikely romantic fable.
The results are distressingly anemic, pig blood and all.
The excellently acted, fact-inspired "Kill Your Darlings" is a consistently interesting origin story with impressive period details ...
Basically, the whole thing can be summed up as an epic midlife crisis.
The superficial script doesn't go nearly deep enough to begin explaining Lovelace.
A charmingly modest low-budget spin-off from Pixar's "Cars'' that provides more thrills and laughs for young children and their parents than many of its more elaborate brethren.
Superficial and hokey yet still oddly endearing ...
I'm a sucker for films with great surfing footage, let alone wacky '70s hairstyles. But this overlong, cliché-infested Aussie period drama tested my patience.
I've seen high school hygiene films that are steamier than this snoozer, notwithstanding the underwhelming "mainstream'' debut of popular porn star James Deen, who shouldn't give up his day job.
Somewhat less than the sum of its parts, Woody Allen's "Blue Jasmine'' showcases a brilliant, Oscar-worthy performance by Cate Blanchett as sort of a WASP version of Ruth Madoff.
"The Time Being'' looks sharp, but it's about as dramatically satisfying as watching paint dry.
"Still Mine'' eschews schmaltz, and is tremendously moving.
"Broken'' embraces the sort of unappealing British miserabilism perfected by "Ratcatcher" director Lynne Ramsay.
"The Conjuring'' depends more on its excellent cast and atmospheric direction than cheap gimmicks to raise hairs on the back of your neck. Which it does, quite frequently.
A fresh, fast and funny little fable about a freakishly fast garden snail who tries to enter the Indy 500.
[A] quietly devastating drama about a soft-spoken, bespectacled and devoted kindergarten teacher whose life is upended by a false accusation from one of his students.
If you've always wanted to see Robert De Niro forced to thread a steel rod through an open wound and then strung upside down by John Travolta, this is the movie for you.
The extinction of mankind has loomed again and again over Hollywood blockbusters the past couple of years, though never anywhere near as entertainingly as in "Pacific Rim.''
Worthwhile for its fine performances, including the best work that Greg Kinnear and Jennifer Connelly have done in quite a while.
"Zipper'' tells a story of a Coney Island that is still very much a work in progress, and where there seems to be no room for small-time operators like Eddie Miranda.
movie_title: ZIPPER: Coney Island's Last Wild Ride (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A star-filled, if heavy-handed, labor of love that certainly has its heart in the right place, and scores dramatically often enough to recommend it.
[Kutcher's] performance, like the movie, is all surface.
A taut procedural with atmospheric location work that traces Cage's clock-racing efforts to find evidence against Cusack ...
One of the year's best films.
Worth enduring only for a rare lead performance by Paul Giamatti, whose expert delineation of rage and frustration lends form to Morrison's otherwise shapeless script.
A visually enthralling popcorn movie with two big stars (Sandra Bullock and George Clooney) that will rivet vast crowds for every moment of its 90-minute running time with not a second wasted.
One of the most adventurous actors of his generation, Gordon-Levitt has a good sense of just how graphically he can depict Jon's addiction and maintain the sympathy of both men and women.
A film that seems headed toward one conclusion, then veers toward another over 2/₂ of the fastest-moving hours I've seen in a recent movie.
[Louis-Dreyfus] has wonderful chemistry with Gandolfini, whose Albert is warmly sympathetic, ruefully amusing, and ultimately hurt ...
It looks fantastic, sounds great, and the 3-D effects (reportedly labored over for 16 months by a thousand technicians) are both subtle and respectfully applied.
It largely consists of Franco musing about depictions of homosexual activity on film.
[A] familiarly snoozy romantic drama.
"Winnie Mandela'' really stumbles when it comes to depicting the couple's painful separation, which the film suggests resulted more from politics than Winnie's infidelity.
"Touchy Feely'' works better in its funnier moments, but Shelton - who pads things out with way too many scenic shots of Seattle - never pulls all these threads together into a satisfying whole.
[A] small-scale gem.

Mundane movies of events like the president's daughter's wedding and his groundbreaking trip to China are juxtaposed with Nixon's rants about his enemies and the "homosexuals" he believed were leading the US into decline.
Mostly it's another opportunity for this most self-referential of directors to dip once again into his well-worn bag of tricks.
A credulity-straining thriller featuring a few good paranoid moments - and, perhaps most important, Rebecca Hall running in high heels.
Cretton pulls off a tricky balancing act in "Short Term 12,'' which could easily have become a colossal downer if played to melodramatic excess.
Overall, the rambling "Jayne Mansfield's Car" is almost as big a wreck as its namesake.
It gets old fast.
A smart, funny and beautifully designed feature ...
This movie takes great pains to thank the fans who made this possible by including many characters from the series - a good deal for them, not necessarily so great for the rest of us.
Returns the erstwhile Tony Soprano to the world of crime, albeit at a lower rung and without the explosive temper.
"Maybe even Jack Nicholson couldn't do a better job than Murray playing this improbable hero - something that probably isn't going to be forgotten come Oscar time."

Think John Houseman in "The Paper Chase'' with a touch of Jack Webb's Marine drill sergeant in 'The D.I.,' and you'll get an idea of the extreme hazing and mind games from Simmons that push Teller toward the breaking point.
Just watching snarky Chicago lawyer Robert Downey Jr. spar with crotchety father Robert Duvall as he tries to defend the small-town Indiana jurist on a murder rap is worth the price of admission.
A dystopian blend of live-action and animation that acidly comments on some of Hollywood's touchiest issues before drifting off into an existential fog.
"Frontera" offers an unsparing look at the plight of illegal immigrants, even if the ending seems too patly convenient.
Dashing, handsome and self-deprecating, Kevin Kline was born to play Errol Flynn.

"Love is Strange'' is very well worth seeing for its two stars, who acutely convey the pain their characters feel over their separation as well as displaying their considerable comic chops to keep things from getting too grim.
Most of us have probably seen episodes of "Antiques Roadshow'' more exciting than this PG-13-rated, interminably boring "action'' fiasco.

The only truly lethal weapons in the criminally unfunny action comedy "Let's Be Cops'' are the lame script, putrid direction and pair of sitcom stars mugging nonstop in frantic pursuit of laughs that have fled over the state line.
Nowhere near as funny as you'd expect with its stellar cast.
The found-footage disaster flick "Into the Storm'' is "Twister'' for dummies, but by no means is that an insult. The new film is enormous fun if you're in the right mood.
A mouth-watering and charming - if overlong - romantic comedy-drama about an immigrant family opening an Indian restaurant in a most unlikely location: the South of France.
Keraudren's documentary fills in many fascinating details of Wojtowicz's life ...
One funk-tastic musical biopic.
As he demonstrated with 'Juno' and 'Up in the Air,' Reitman has an uncanny knack among contemporary directors for tapping into the zeitgeist in dramatically satisfying ways.

"Child of God'' is, like the source novel, loosely inspired by the notorious real-life cannibal murderer Ed Gein. So was Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho.'' Nobody left that classic bored - but they sure will be by Franco's film.

The most hilarious Woody Allen film in years is directed by Noah Baumbach, with Ben Stiller as basically an updated version of the idealistic documentary filmmaker the Woodman played in 'Crimes and Misdemeanors.'
Washington is a master at putting his own inimitable and stylish spin on even the most familiar situations.
Perhaps the most incisive and funniest Hollywood take on Broadway since Mel Brook's original "The Producers."
Von Sydow, Blair and Mercedes McCambridge (the originally uncredited actress who dubbed Regan's gross mutterings) are flat-out terrific.
Makes Howard Hawks' legendarily confusing 'The Big Sleep' look like a model of narrative coherence.
Glossy, empty and ultimately unsatisfying - if undeniably entertaining ...
"Hector and the Search for Happiness'' will most likely inspire audiences to search for the exit door.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Timothy Spall - best known to mainstream audiences as Wormtail in the Harry Potter series - delivers an Oscar-caliber tour de force reminiscent of Charles Laughton
Tobey Maguire does a great job
May not be anything like Witherspoon's answer to 'The Blind Side,' but definitely worth seeing.
Maybe the best thing Al Pacino has done has done this century
thoroughly engrossing
Ponderous, emotionally chilly Oscar bait.
Reese Witherspoon delivers her best performance since she won the Best Actress Oscar for 'Walk the Line' a decade ago.
Doesn't quite live up to its stellar cast, but there are still plenty of laughs.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The once-ubiquitous 'Full Monty' formula is alive, well and still irresistible
Eddie Redmayne knocks it straight out of the universe
If Billy Wilder's 'Ace in the Hole' and 'Network' had a mutant baby, it would probably look like Dan Gilroy's 'Nightcrawler'
Thirty years to the week after "When Harry Met Sally,'' Rob Reiner directs the excruciating, mawkish and interminable romantic dramedy "And So It Goes'' with shocking ineptitude.
Even for a farce, the situations stretch credulity far beyond the breaking point.

For all the Mr. Darcy-ish charm Woody's latest surrogate, Oscar winner Colin Firth, can still summon up, it's hard to believe Allen's current muse, played by Emma Stone, would put up with his insults for 10 minutes.
After 20 shaky opening minutes, first-time director Mark Schmidt finds his footing with this slightly overlong English-language Holocaust drama.
It's not a horrible premise for a movie, but the execution is exceedingly trite and sloppy.

The makers of "Heaven Is for Real'' should have had the faith to let audiences decide whether little Colton is telling the truth about his near-death experience without resorting to the digital equivalent of dry ice.

"Oculus'' eschews the buckets of gore common to R-rated horror movies and takes a relatively subtle, psychological approach - even if the somewhat disappointing ending leaves the door open for a sequel (or three).
Legendary hipster filmmaker Jim Jarmusch's wryly funny exercise in genre bending hits so many grace notes it ends up being his most satisfying film in years.

A rather shapeless film where what's happening onscreen is often less interesting than trying to figure out whether the participants recognize they're sharing the cab of a truck with a world-famous actress.
Deeply mediocre and ultra-predictable ...
Holy ship!
Those with a high tolerance for violence and gore - at one point, Rama battles assassins labeled "Baseball Bat Man'' and "Hammer Girl'' simultaneously - will eat up "The Raid 2.''
The always distinctive Raymond De Felitta ("City Island'') offers a hilarious mob comedy with virtually no violence, though it's based on a tabloid-ready true story that did not end at all happily.
Von Trier has made some wonderful movies ("Breaking the Waves,'' "Melancholia'') but this pretentious snoozer, like "Antichrist," isn't one of them.
Two sequels derived from Veronica Roth's novels have already been announced. Hopefully, they'll have more personality than this clunker.
It doesn't add up to much of anything exciting ...
A bickering middle-aged English couple return to Paris to celebrate their ill-fated 30th anniversary in this ruefully funny delight from director Roger Michell and screenwriter Hanif Kureishi.
Sobol encourages his excellent cast, which includes the iconic Terence Stamp as a federal informant and Jay Baruchel as the gang's weakest link, to steal scenes left and right.
Veteran screenwriter John Pogue, in his second directorial outing, tries repeatedly and mostly unsuccessfully to jolt his audience by amping up the abundant sound effects to ear-shattering levels.
Vanity, thy name is Kevin Spacey.
movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It has lots of smart things to say about social media, criticism and father-son relationships - while also appealing to fans of food porn and mildly raunchy buddy movies.
[An] eyeball-gougingly ugly, charm-free animated musical sequel, which is inexplicably opening in thousands of theaters instead of going direct to video.

A heady film experience packed with so many telling details about life in the United States over the past 12 years - and one that makes you care such much about the struggles and foibles of its imperfect characters.
"Deliver Us From Evil'' expertly serves shivers, buckets of gore - and pretty much every cliché of the genre.
Don't miss it - this is enormously fun visionary filmmaking, with a witty script and a great international cast.
Stars veteran Jean Reno as a longtime celebrity chef who may lose control of his Paris restaurant because the young new CEO thinks he's old toque.
Jersey Boys tells a familiar story, yes -- but rarely told this well and with this much heart and soul.
Offers some stunningly beautiful sequences and an engaging, if at times quite dark, story line.
Michael Tully's mild tribute to the 1980s - the decade that just won't go away.

The final product is very much Chow - with elaborately staged stunts, slapstick inspired by silent Hollywood, and a silliness that will appeal to kids (as well as some black humor that may take some explaining for younger audiences).
A Tom Cruise action flick with a strong female heroine and a sense of humor? "Edge of Tomorrow'' has both of those, plus a "Groundhog Day''-style gimmick that pays big dividends. Over and over.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: No film I've seen so far this year has provided the sheer moviegoing pleasure of "We Are the Best!''
A low-key, solidly acted indie charmer from director Megan Griffiths.
Manages to be excruciatingly unfunny despite the presence of Pierce Brosnan and Emma Thompson in the lead roles.

"X-Men: Days of Future Past'' blows a breath of fresh air through the musty Marvel universe, which increasingly is all about pandering to hard-core fans rather than trying to make good movies for everybody.
Writer-director Schwarz has a lot of fun with this nutty premise. And more important, the twisted dynamics of this particular family ring true.
Even in 3-D, these human characters are barely one-dimensional, but in the end that doesn't really matter very much.
Writer-director Aviva Kempner crafted this love letter to Greenberg by imaginatively weaving interviews with great footage from newsreels and feature films.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The frequently funny "The Grand Seduction'' is a thoroughly pleasant way to pass a couple of hours.
"Beautiful Darling" makes extensive use of photos, sketches and Darling's diaries belonging to Jeremiah Newton, a gay pal she lived with on and off until her death from cancer in 1974.
"The Perfect Family'' is Kathleen Turner's show. And when a series of crises forces Eileen to re-examine her values and beliefs, Turner rises magnificently to the occasion.
Nothing is quite what it initially seems in this twisty Italian thriller, the auspicious debut feature by Giuseppe Capotondi.

A low-budget triumph for director Courtney Hunt that won the grand jury prize at Sundance, Frozen River is a thriller set in upstate New York anchored by an unforgettable performance by veteran character actress Melissa Leo.
The direction of this autobiographical tale by Paul Weiland (whose lengthy rap sheet runs all the way from Leonard Part 6 to Made of Honor) is less than subtle.
This would-be civics lesson is such an appalling view of American democracy that it could be used as a recruiting film by al Qaeda.
[An] engrossing and exhilarating documentary Man on Wire, which uses vintage footage, interviews and re-creations.
Satire, you see, requires the sort of artistic discipline that is anathema to mumblecore filmmakers.
Ultra-slick and predictable.
The X-Files: I Want to Believe is atmospheric and moves briskly, but it's basically TV writ large.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Well-acted but familiar.
A good cast and disciplined direction add some distinction to Ric Roman Waugh's Felon, which is basically the old tale about an innocent man corrupted by a stay in prison.
An atmospheric, Hitchcockian thriller set aboard a famed train route, Brad Anderson's Transsiberian is a genuine sleeper that jump-starts an almost extinct genre.

A fun, crowd-pleasing alternative for an audience whose idea of entertainment runs more to infectious '70s pop ditties, spandex, sex-starved women of a certain age and bare-chested hunks than watching a caped sadist torturing criminals.

Despite a terrific lead performance by Ellen Burstyn, Kari Skogland's epic The Stone Angel is a lesson in the perils of trying to cram a hefty Canadian novel that spans decades into a movie running just under two hours.
Harold is a genuine oddity that's more watchable than it sounds.
There are some laughs here and there, but this is badly edited hack work.
Unusual for this genre, the script doesn't insult the audience's intelligence, and it mercifully soft-pedals its message about the virtues of reading.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sensitively directed by Sanaa Hamri, The Sister of the Traveling Pants 2 demonstrates that not only is sisterhood powerful, it can be awfully entertaining.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kabluey, which has no discernible political agenda, is wildly uneven and often seems like a short stretched to feature length. But it's also kind of oddly endearing.

Frequently hilarious, occasionally sweet and often graphically violent, Pineapple Express may not be the greatest stoner movie ever made, but it will do perfectly well until we get another hit of Harold and Kumar.
Tropic Thunder is all over the place, but it's hard to get too tough on a Hollywood satire that in the end loves Hollywood so much that it's just not going to take any prisoners.
Pieced together from Tim Burton and various other sources with more desperation than inspiration.
The clichés are thick as the kudzu in 1956 Alabama.
An often charming romantic drama that outstays its welcome at nearly two hours.
Towelhead is definitely not for all tastes, but it shows a bravery that's increasingly rare in American movies.

Al Pacino and Robert De Niro collect bloated paychecks with intent to bore in Righteous Kill, a slow-moving, ridiculous police thriller that would have been shipped straight to the remainder bin at Blockbuster if it starred anyone else.
A total disaster.
Jamie Bell has his best role since Billy Elliot in Mister Foe, a darkly comic tale of a twisted teen on the cusp of adulthood.
The film plays out pretty much exactly as you would expect -- which won't bother some people one iota.

Another Gay Movie was actually funny with some heart, but Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild is merely a crude series of sketches loosely revolving around an ersatz game show presided over by drag queens RuPaul and Lady Bunny.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: YPF caused a minor sensation at last year's Toronto Film Festival, but I guess the chance to see Canucks even partially disrobed is a selling point up there.
A solid, intelligent international thriller showcasing the underrated Don Cheadle in an intriguing and morally ambiguous role, Traitor is the best end-of-August movie I've seen in years.
I thought Spike Lee's When the Levees Broke was pretty much the last word on the national tragedy and disgrace that followed Hurricane Katrina's assault on New Orleans. Maybe not.
This is pretty much a one-woman show for Faris, and she doesn't get much help from director Fred Wolf.
Manages to be a notably funnier than average summer comedy despite being a fairly shameless rip-off of School of Rock.
[Allen's] funniest movie in years and arguably his sexiest.
Beautifully shot by Michael J. Ozier, the dominating taste in Bottle Shock is Rickman's beautiful performance as a snob -- a snob who is secretly open to being delightfully surprised.

Leaving behind the laughs for schmaltz, Hancock chickens out at the last minute, lurching toward a cop-out happy ending that gives every indication of having been reshot at the behest of test audiences. Well, at least you won't be bored.
Much of Finding Amanda doesn't stand up to close scrutiny, but at its best the still-boyish Broderick suggests his most famous character, Ferris Bueller, going through a midlife crisis.

Credit director Marcos Carnevale with beautifully pulling off this schmaltzy premise, as well as restaging the famous scene at Rome's Trevi Fountain from La Dolce Vita with his elderly lovers in place of Marcello Mastroianni and Anita Ekberg.
For an idea of the level of wit, several gags are built around the name 'Dick Banger'.
Surprisingly entertaining, Hollywood Chinese, a fast-paced survey of how the Chinese have been portrayed in American films from the silent era to the present, is packed with unexpected delights.
Fugitive Pieces, however well-meaning, is still pretty much an emotionally distanced slog.
One of the hippest, best-written and best-directed superhero movies ever -- a splendid way to kick off the summer movie season.
I love John Cusack, but I can't imagine what he was thinking as the star, producer and co-writer of the mind-boggling Iraq satire War, Inc.
A smart little bittersweet comedy.

Is there anything more boring than watching $20 million being electronically trans ferred to an offshore bank account? Maybe it's someone repeatedly barking 'You have no idea what I'm capable of!' into a cellphone.
I didn't laugh anywhere near as much at this far less fresh sequel - which is broader, more vulgar, more scattershot, more overtly political and a lot less funny than it sounds on paper.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With virtually nothing in the way of visual or physical comedy, there are more chuckles here than belly laughs, and most of them are delivered by the supporting cast.
An overwrought and patently offensive anti-abortion drama from the director of the accomplished House of Sand and Fog. Director Vadim Perelman doesn't play fair.
For anyone with an interest in racing, First Saturday is a sure bet.
Shot on ugly digital video with Troma-grade special effects, campy humor and frighteningly bad acting, Zombie Strippers should provide many laughs for stoners watching it on video.
This film is so funny it may be beside the point to complain that, as in many Apatow productions, the writing and direction are still in something of a state of arrested development.

Where in the World Is Osama bin Laden? jokes about Spurlock capturing the bounty on Osama's head, or making the world safe for his child-to-be, but it's really about the narcissistic filmmaker and his enablers the Weinsteins making a few bucks.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's little in Billy Shebar's script, the rambling direction by theater and opera helmer Chen Shi-Zheng - or Liu Ye's impassive performance as the student.
This is a feast for the eyes and a famine for the brain.

While this slow-starting update of Private Lives has plenty of laughs, the incredibly expressive Stevenson turns Julia's romantic dilemma into something genuinely moving. She makes A Previous Engagement something special.
Eerily beautiful.
On a satisfaction scale, it lands squarely between The Temple of Doom, and The Last Crusade.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Some day, there will be college courses devoted to this movie.
Full Grown Men is nicely photographed and has impressive sets; too bad there's so little going on that it seems long even at 78 minutes.
One of those Sundance "comedies" that make you contemplate slitting your wrists.

One of the 10 best American movies released so far this year, Kit Kittredge: An American Girl is the surprisingly satisfying first theatrical film inspired by a long-running series of historically themed dolls.

Would you believe the new version of the '60s spy spoof Get Smart, starring Steve Carell, isn't awful -- like almost all TV-to-movie transfers -- but instead, that it's actually pretty funny (if overlong and overproduced)?
This warped masochistic cousin to David Cronenberg's Crash - not to be confused with the Oscar winner of the same name -- is well worth seeing for Farmiga's stunning performance.
Less notable is the soap-ish plot, which leans heavily on coincidence and melodrama.

Many American sports documentaries tend to fall into a predictable inspirational rut, no matter how stunning the footage. Pepe Danquart's To the Limit from Germany looks great, but it's an altogether different animal.
Delightful music alternates with too-brief interviews with Wendo and his colleagues. On the Rumba River cries out for narration to help viewers understand the tragic context of his life.
A ruefully funny cautionary tale about cross-cultural tone-deafness.
Easily the worst movie I've seen so far this year.
How much you like this will depend upon your appreciation for repeated jokes about hummus, gays, Zohan's crotch and his fondness for older women.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stuart Gordon's gorily amusing Stuck is essentially a B-movie with a single joke, albeit a pretty good -- if admittedly sick -- one.
There's been a glut of pointless first- person documentaries lately, but newcomer Christopher Bell has a legitimate personal take in his film about Americans who use anabolic steroids.
This movie provides no good reasons to revisit Sex and the City, except to fulfill fans' desires for one more for the road and add millions to Time Warner's coffers. Be careful what you wish for.
Like its monstrous hero, The Incredible Hulk gets the job done with minimal artistry and a lot of noise.

John Leguizamo knocks it out of the park as an armored car driver in The Take, which is quite a bit better than you'd expect from a low-budget thriller that's getting a token theatrical release a month ahead of its DVD debut.
Beautifully photographed by Dean Semler, Appaloosa is the best Western since Open Range and shows there's still life in this most unfashionable of genres.
Nights in Rodanthe aims straight for the tear ducts as well, but this weepie is a dry well.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.

Chandi Chowk is fun but somewhat exhausting, with several elaborate production numbers, a bullet-proof umbrella that also serves as a parachute, a magical potato -- plus a running time just over 2 1/2 hours, which is short by Bollywood standards.
An extremely awkward cross between Ocean's Eleven and Rain Man.
Anything you need to know to avoid wasting your $12 is in the unpromising trailer.
Quote not available.

Defiance plods where it should soar, but it's still the best of this month's four (!) Holocaust movies -- if for no other reason than it confronts the common belief that European Jews didn't actively resist the Nazi onslaught.
Slight but utterly charming.

It takes a world-class storyteller and a great yarn to rivet your attention for nearly three hours. This very classy, old-school movie -- employing cutting-edge technology that will make your eyes pop -- did it for me.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sad truth is that if you laid this movie out chronologically -- and maybe if you don't -- not a whole lot of it makes any sense.
I love musicals, but I'd be hard-pressed to recommend this curiosity.
A very funny and touching movie that delivers its message of tolerance with a most agreeable light hand.
Meryl Streep is frighteningly good as Sister Aloysius, the fire-breathing principal of a 1964 Bronx parochial school in John Patrick Shanley's powerful but stagy Doubt.
This is a rare case of a movie that improves dramatically as it goes along.
Unless you've seen Robert Wise's original semi-documentary The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951), you'd never suspect the utterly generic remake was based on a seminal sci-fi classic.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fairly well-executed exploitation.
Reichardt, who directed Old Joy, doesn't so much tell a story as paint a finely detailed portrait of human suffering in this miniature marvel.
A good cast can't save The Lodger, the utterly wrongheaded fourth movie version of a 1910 novel inspired by Jack the Ripper that was most famously filmed by Alfred Hitchcock in 1926.
A dreary gay soap opera.
Despite a good cast, Explicit Ills is about as phony as it gets.
Stahl's use of space and the performances in Leave Her to Heaven...suggest he was at least the equal of the much-exalted Sirk as an artist of melodrama.
Heiskanen is a revelation as the put-upon wife, and the cinematography (some by Troell) effortlessly transports us back 100 years.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: LeGros isn't bad, but this pre-DVD road trip feels like it's four hours long.
A loose remake that's not only as Russian as vodka but also a grippingly entertaining actors' showcase.
This is a movie with the courage to examine the pressing issue of whether hot blond Aussie starlets are sleeping with government agents -- whom they meet in fender benders -- to get green cards.

Though this is the rare documentary that admirably admits recording "reality" on film actually shapes how people behave under the camera's gaze, I think Eleven Minutes is going to appeal mostly to hard-core fashionistas.
If this movie were a teenager, you'd put it on Ritalin right away.

IF Frank Langella hadn't received an Oscar nomination for "Frost/Nixon," it's pretty doubtful that an opaque oddity like Richard Ledes' The Caller would have managed even a one-week vanity booking at the Quad.
The 3-D effects are uncanny; much of the audience ducked when sea snakes lunged at it. You can't get that on your TV set. Yet.
One of those movies sponsored by an international conglomerate that lectures us about how all international conglomerates are corrupt.
At this point, Lucas is in no position to be picky about his remaining fans.
Moore steals Happy Tears by underplaying -- in what may be the warmest performance of her career.
Nominally based on a 2004 nonfiction best seller by two Sex and the City writers, the movie version of He's Just Not That Into You delivers, with far less wit, the same message as the show.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Milcho Manchevski's Shadows is visually striking but gets bogged down in supernatural clichés.
With the recession getting worse by the day, it's asking an awful lot for audiences to laugh at a romantic comedy centering on corporate layoffs.
Whatever problems Nixon might have with Nixon/Frost, Langella's magnetic performance would probably bring a smile to Tricky Dick's famously perspiration-dappled face.
This small gem has a very satisfying ending.
Most of the actors perform wonderful re-creations of the original song that give Cadillac Records entertainment value well beyond the hackneyed story lines.

Hammer, whose blunt name belies the movie's many subtle touches, has his own distinct style. He also has an enormous trust in the audience to sort out this wounded family's miseries without the assistance of narration or even a musical score.
A short and sweet anti-romantic comedy, Good Dick puts together a heav ily depressed young woman with a homeless clerk who rents her porn at a Los Angeles video store.
A fairly toothless Tinseltown expose.
Thoroughly inept in just about every aspect.
Price-Bythewood has encouraged fairly broad performances from these formidable actresses for characters who aren't terribly well developed in her script.

More of a hastily executed charcoal sketch than a portrait, Oliver Stone's W. is nonetheless an often compelling, tragicomic psychological analysis of Dubya, viewed through the prism of his relationship with an allegedly disapproving father.
Overlong, obvious and indifferently acted.
Anyone who's ever seen an After School Special knows where the family-friendly Breakfast With Scot is headed, no matter how well intentioned.
Poppy, memorably played by Sally Hawkins, is one of those individuals who sees every glass as half-full.
Body of Lies is being hailed in some quarters as a 'new' kind of war thriller. While this glitzy production may attract audiences suffering from battle fatigue, it's nothing of the sort.

Even if it weren't three years too late to parody Moore (ineptly played by Kevin Farley), Moore's ridiculous tribute to Cuban health care in Sicko is far funnier than anything in this desperately laughless farce from David Zucker.
Worth celebrating as an overdue return to form by '80s icon Jonathan Demme.
Any movie in which the hero accidentally kills a Chihuahua can't be a total loss, but How To Lose Friends & Alienate People comes pretty darned close.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The flaws of Flash of Genius are worth putting up with for Kinnear's committed performance...

A veteran London police in spector who's a devout Mus lim is intriguingly at the center of Jag Mundhra's Shoot on Sight, which starts out as a thriller inspired by that city's 2005 Tube and bus bombings but gets bogged down in a family soap opera.
This documentary-style look at a year in a French middle school is certainly ambitious and ultimately delivers after a pretty tedious first hour.
Changeling is another remarkable addition to Eastwood's directorial canon.

It's the first movie this year that demands at least two viewings to absorb its densely textured humor, which makes earlier Kaufman works such as Adaptation and Being John Malkovich look positively straightforward.
You'd have to be made of stone not to weep at the confession that caps I've Loved You So Long.
Quote not available.
Penn goes way deep and soulful in a highly ingratiating performance that's the one to beat for the Best Actor Oscar.
Never boring but often exhausting, Australia finally pulls itself together for an emotionally satisfying ending. Or six. Pass the gravy.
Rappaport does a yeoman's job in this tonally confused oddity.
An ambitious gay musical fantasy inspired by A Midsummer Night's Dream, Tom Gustafson's Were the World Mine is far better in concept than execution. The shoestring budget hurts.
Overall it's basically a crass marketing concept closer to Beverly Hills Chihuahua than a fully conceived work of art like Wall-E.
Never underestimate the value of slight but charming flicks like Anthony Bryne's How About You.
The sad thing is, there's a perfectly fine, Sam Fulle-rish, 90-minute war movie on a worthy subject trapped somewhere in the self-indulgences of Miracle at St. Anna.

If Ingmar Bergman and Wes Anderson some how collaborated on a movie together, I'd guess their sensibilities would yield something like Arnaud Desplechin's darkly hilarious, brilliantly acted A Christmas Tale.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [A] bizarre art-house equiva lent of The Bucket Lisy.

Writer-director Jared Harris (and actor and son of the late Richard Harris) claims to have spent 10 years researching this sordid milieu, yet, for all the detail, it ends up playing like an especially lurid '80s TV movie.
A by-the-numbers follow-up to the highly successful 2005 feature that was no great shakes to begin with.

Sort of a riff on The Sunshine Boys with hints of Dreamgirls, about all Malcolm D. Lee's relentlessly crass comedy has going for it are some amusing Motown-ish numbers and the chemistry between Mac and his real-life friend Samuel L. Jackson.
While sporadically funny, the sophomoric My Name Is Bruce is no Bubba Ho-Tep.
A valuable reminder that for nearly three decades, basketball was dominated by Jewish players -- and coaches who found the sport an ideal vehicle for assimilation in the United States.
A four-handkerchief documentary if there ever was one.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Four stars simply aren't enough for Danny Boyle's Slumdog Millionaire, which just may be the most entertaining movie I've ever labeled a masterpiece in these pages.
Both subjects are interviewed at length, and the filmmakers have unearthed some rare, arresting black-and-white dance footage from the '50s and '60s.
Best movie I've seen so far this year? Hands down, it's Tom McCarthy's superb The Visitor, which turns Richard Jenkins, one of the best character actors in the business, into a full-fledged star.
Usually, you have to wait for the end-of-the-year awards season to see an elaborate period piece that fails as spectacularly as "Water for Elephants."
A slight but charming DIY feature.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Nines, which in real life began as a TV project, wavers uncomfortably between satire and dime-store existentialism on the big screen.
Fails to provide any sort of genuine social context for its violence.
Christopher Walken does not actually show up in Asian drag until halfway through Balls of Fury -- not enough to salvage this mostly unfunny, extremely silly pingpong comedy.
...authentic isn't the word I'd use for this maudlin male weepie, a compendium of the worst clichés of sports and journalism movies.
