Mr. Bean's Holiday picks up steam when it finally arrives in Cannes just in time to wreak yet more havoc at the big film festival, but getting there is pretty tedious. A little of the wildly mugging Atkinson goes a long way.

Though Binoche does very solid work, she can't sell the idea of her and Law as a couple; the chemistry isn't there. Not much else rings true in Minghella's screenplay, which is full of coincidences and speeches about race and class.
Quote not available.
This new film moves along smoothly until Grandpa's most preposterous mission - which needlessly drags out the movie -- takes Jason to a severely caricatured Ecuador.
Quote not available.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's an exciting, well-directed thriller that, while providing more than enough action and gore to satisfy genre fans, also offers the political commentary that has characterized zombie movies.
I've never been a fan of Richard Gere, but he gives the performance of his career as Clifford Irving.
Nicole Kidman's character struggles to stay awake -- as will the audience.
Despite some plot holes, Delirious hits the bull's-eye with razor-sharp performances and dialogue.
An overstuffed, overlong epic with a tongue-in-cheek approach that repeatedly begs unfavorable comparisons with The Princess Bride.
Excruciatingly acted and ineptly directed.
This summer's designated Sundance crowd-pleaser, Rocket Science, is a quirkily disarming high-school comedy that calculatingly follows in the footsteps of Napoleon Dynamite, Election and Rushmore.
An extremely well-acted and well-directed remake of a 1957 oater based on a short story by the then-obscure Elmore Leonard.
The film comes off more like a drunken recollection by a war correspondent than something that might actually have happened.
...goes way over the top for the Greeks vs. Gays climax.
You can see better stuff on TV any night of the week.

This saga was the subject of Into the Wild, a short but fascinating book by Jon Krakauer that, 11 years later, has resulted in a gorgeously photographed and less intermittently fascinating 2 1/2-hour film by Sean Penn.
Not only far and away this summer's best three-peat, it's a pulse-pounding peak to Matt Damon's spy trilogy.
The Jane Austen Book Club is worth watching primarily for Blunt, the delicious scene-stealer from The Devil Wears Prada.
The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford is a gorgeous snooze.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ...overall, his [Alfredo De Villa's] latest flick is dramatically tepid.
A formidable crowd-pleaser.
[A] tasteful and gorgeously photographed coming-of-age story.
Tommy Lee Jones is at the top of his game as a grieving fa ther determined to uncover the disturbing truth behind his soldier son's death in Paul Haggis' In the Valley of Elah.
[Viggo Mortensen] lends a moral complexity to Eastern Promises that makes it much more than just a very accomplished action thriller.
A well-deserved toast to a quintessential New Yorker of the post-World War II era.
Worth watching for Foster's fiercely arresting performance.
A cut above average.
It's a stirring reminder of a time when anything seemed possible.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You know Quentin Tarantino is probably over the hill when he can be so parodied with such deadly precision in Shoot 'Em Up.
A downer of a musical biopic that leaves no cliché unturned.
[An] excruciatingly inane high-school comedy inspired by a line of sexually suggestive dolls aimed at 9-year-old girls.
Multi-segment movies tend to be notoriously uneven, and this definitely proves to be the case with The Ten.
There are many stunning special effects, including a car chase up the side of a building, as well as the sort of wild animated subtitles that turned up in Night Watch.
This astounding saga, which is told strictly in chronological order with lots of well-chosen film clips and photographs, is recounted mostly by the now elderly Pugach and Riss themselves.
What starts out as a delightful black comedy and social commentary ends up, at best, as a guilty pleasure where I had a hard time sorting out the intentional from the unintentional laughs.

Excellent performances by a good cast and a fairly authentic look at working-class struggles go only so far in Brian Jun's Steel City, which paints an industrial Minnesota municipality entirely in tones of gray and blue.

I can't claim to have followed the story line of Paprika any better than I did Pirates of the Caribbean, but this mind-blowing, adult animated adventure from Japan is half the length and maybe five times as much fun.
Abandon hope all ye seeking a coherent, much less satisfying, narrative.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Writer-director] Caleo isn't able to sell The Last Time -- not the affair and especially not the ludicrous twist ending.
Vivid work by Alec Baldwin as a brutal Gambino crime family captain isn't enough to justify the sub-Scorsese stylings of Michael Corrente's Brooklyn Rules.
Though the Wilsons are no threat to the Coens as filmmakers, The Wendell Baker Story is still a pleasingly human-scaled alternative to the big, soulless Hollywood blockbusters.

Short on insight. You'll have to look elsewhere than this love letter to the Great White Way to explain why Wicked and Avenue Q became huge hits, and why Caroline, or Change joined Taboo as a costly flop.
The beautifully photographed Disappearances is solidly old-fashioned entertainment.
Like many woeful major studio releases that run under 90 minutes, The Ex seems arbitrarily edited to squeeze in extra screenings before it's killed by word-of-mouth.
I think it's one of this year's finest and most memorable films.
Canadian filmmaker Guy Maddin pushes his love of lurid melodrama to the limit in his latest demented treat, Brand Upon the Brain!
Peter Krause, the fine actor from Six Feet Under, gives a one-note performance that seriously undermines Civic Duty
Hollywood's summer of risk-free programming continues with the fourth three-peat in six weeks, Ocean's Thirteen, the least overbearing of the franchise installments rolled out so far.
Marion Cotillard delivers a tour de force as legendary singer Édith Piaf.
A well-written and in many ways pleasing update of a character who has endured in print for 78 years.
The main joke here is that Connolly's Fido, though he never speaks, seems more alive than the rigidly conformist '50s males around him. It's not quite enough to keep Fido more than a slight comedy.
[A] sleazy, inept and worthless piece of torture porn.
A soufflé of a romantic and family comedy that stubbornly refuses to rise.
An across-the-board disaster from one of my favorite directors, Milos Forman.
A rousing alternative in a marketplace packed with noisy, special-effects-heavy sequels, Hairspray is the best and most entertaining movie adaptation of a stage musical so far this century.
Formulaic but entertaining.
Has to be seen to be believed -- a very rare case of a movie that's such an utter train wreck you can't stop watching.
movie_title: Shortcut to Happiness (The Devil and Daniel Webster) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhat resembles Paprika, another recent piece of Japanimation. But director Michael Arias, a Tokyo-based American, doesn't fuse his striking graphics to a story anywhere near as satisfying.
A xenophobic, overblown, revenge-driven action thriller that exports the Rambo mentality to the contemporary Middle East.
A fruitcake-of-a-movie dense with exposition and woefully short on payoff.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven, overlong and at times overbearing flick.
Arguably the finest 'toon in the Pixar canon.
Mostly, the flick relies on old-school stunt work rather than computer generated effects.
You Kill Me really belongs to Kingsley, whose character's deadpan reactions to his new environment are priceless. He really kills.
Posey is a delight throughout, and Zoe Cassavetes is clearly a filmmaker to watch.
[Jolie is] greatly abetted by the no-nonsense, very un-Hollywood-ish approach that British director Michael Winterbottom takes to this fact-based thriller.
Though the strain sometimes shows, Carell's skill with physical comedy is a saving grace that makes Evan Almighty at least tolerable.
Overall it delivers some genuine old-school chills -- something that was missing when Macaulay Culkin played a similar role in The Good Son.
Call the cops. Oscar nominees Ellen Page and Thomas Haden Church steal Smart People right from under the noses of its ostensible stars, Sarah Jessica Parker and Dennis Quaid.
I was struggling to stay awake.
The sort of movie you forget even as you're watching it.

While the special effects are top notch... the humans are dull, the dialogue is ridiculous, and anyone expecting a repeat of the action in 300 is going to be sorely disappointed with this bloodless PG-13 adventure.

There are zero surprises in the road comedy Bonneville, sadly including the fact that three middle-age actresses with three Oscars and nine nominations among them couldn't find anything more challenging to do.
In eschewing the use of a narrator or talking heads, Morgen leaves out too much crucial information.
Under Mark Palansky's uninspired direction, magic eludes Penelope in scene after scene.
Unsexy and not particularly good-looking.
[Rahman] Bahrani's unsentimental film is perhaps most interesting as a look at a colorful, little-known world that has recently been targeted for urban renewal.
Would be a candidate for the year's most unintentionally funny movie so far - if it weren't also the most homophobic.
Charlie Bartlett starts to get a bit preachy as it works its way toward a climax heavily influenced by Rushmore, but it's still well above average for this type of film.
A surprisingly sweet comedy showcasing a manic Jack Black.
Doug Liman's Jumper takes an intriguing premise -- a guy who can teleport himself anywhere, anytime -- and turns it into a totally ridiculous and incoherent sci-fi adventure.
Is Definitely, Maybe the best romantic comedy released so far this year? Definitely. Should you go see it? Maybe.
Disappointingly strip-mines the very fatigued comic hit-man genre to diminishing returns.
At least costume designer Ngila Dickson didn't have to work too hard on McConaughey's wardrobe.
Miley Cyrus is not U2.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Debuting director Mitchell (son of Roy) Litchtenstein creates a lot of dread but not a consistent tone.
CJ7 is heavy on slapstick and may appeal to very young viewers who won't need to bother much with the subtitles.
Anyone who has seen a chick flick knows what is going to happen next, and next, and next...

I adore Frances McDor mand, but she's seri ously miscast -- in a title role Emma Thompson could play in her sleep -- in Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day, an uneasy blend of screwball comedy and pathos set in 1939 London.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Frequently charming, beautifully drawn and far more faithful in spirit to the source material than those dreadful Ron Howard-Brian Grazer productions.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The original French title of this flick translates as Birth of Octopuses, and it's a more accurate description of the complicated relationships in this well-acted coming-of-age story, the impressive debut of filmmaker Céline Sciamma.
Roughly what Romancing the Stone would have been like as a 1970s Disney flick had CGI been available, Nim's Island is strictly for the 8-and-under crowd.
Leatherheads is far from a touchdown, but you gotta give points to any movie where a character describes its climactic game as a 'muddy snoozefest.'
Sporadically funny, micro-budgeted indie comedy.
Diverting.

Jyll Johnstone's irresistible Hats Off documents Mimi Weddell, a Manhat tanite who, at 93, has pretty much cornered the market playing elegant, very old ladies in movies, TV, commercials and print ads.

My Brother Is an Only Child is a politically charged family drama set in Italy in the 1960s and 1970s -- think The Best of Youth (director Daniele Luchetti collaborated with that epic film's writers) at a more butt-friendly running time.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The plot contortions that very slowly unfold under Michael Radford's arthritic direction in Flawless are not much...entertaining.

Yes, it's a mite pretentious and on the slow side. But debuting director Jeff Nichols has an eye for small-town America and a sensibility that he shares with fellow North Carolina School of the Arts alumnus David Gordon Greene.
The fascinating story of six college students who took Las Vegas for millions gets dealt a bad hand in 21, which turns their true-life saga into a slick, shallow and thoroughly generic caper flick.
The sort of half-baked vanity project favored by the Tribeca Film Festival, Zak Penn's The Grand features a slew of recognizable faces in a fitfully funny improvised comedy.
[A] lethargically directed comedy.
Even an ultra-feral performance by Asia Argento -- the art house Angelina Jolie -- isn't enough to suffer through Boarding Gate, a draggy and incoherent thriller by French director Oliver Assayas.
For those too young to remember, Sputnik Mania documents the fear and anxiety that gripped the United States half a century ago when the Soviet Union launched the first satellite in October 1957.
Beware any movie that ends with a cliché as dire as 'Today is the first day of the rest of your life.' What comes before that in Sleepwalking is relentlessly depressing.
Basically torture porn every bit as manipulative and reprehensible as Hostel, even if it's tricked out with intellectual pretension.
I've seen more exciting no-smoking announcements in theaters.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Go see it already.
The best movie performance so far this century? No contest. There's Daniel Day-Lewis' awe-inspiring turn as a greedy oilman in There Will Be Blood, and there is everyone else.
Beowulf can be a lot of fun to watch -- at least in the 3-D IMAX version I saw.
Spending $12 and 2 1/2 hours (30 minutes less than the Cannes cut) on something as aggressively bad as Southland Tales is not something I can recommend with a clear conscience.
Even in support of the noblest of causes, manipulation is manipulation.
Big-hearted and often quite funny if crudely made, Fat Girls cleverly subverts the clichés of high school comedies to serve an autobiographical story.
One of the year's best movies -- and surely a major Oscar contender.
Music Within never establishes a consistent tone, going from achingly sincere to borderline farcical, often in the same scene.
Cynics need not apply, but I found Bella a real heart tugger.
This flick is fast and ferocious, [Lumet's] sharpest and best since Prince of the City -- and surely one of the year's finest.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A twisty, morally ambiguous and satisfying neo-noir.
It's obviously not for all tastes, but there's going to be an appreciative audience for any musical whose opening number is 'Gratuitous Nudity.'
The script by Six Feet Under writer Nancy Oliver eschews cheap laughs for character-driven humanist comedy.
First-time filmmaker Joseph Greco draws on personal experience for this devastating yet honest portrait of an ordinary Florida family.

Expect a fast-paced, beautifully mounted and well-acted soap opera with overripe dialogue that plays fast and loose with history -- just like they did in the '30s, '40s and '50s -- and you won't come away disappointed.
Quote not available.
A genially scattershot mockumentary.
There isn't anything terribly exciting or original on offer... but there's nothing offensive either.
[Reilly] looks frail but holds the audience spellbound in Barry Poltermann and Frank Anderson's valuable record of the final performance of the autobiographical show that he toured for five years.
I've had root canals that were more enjoyable than Margot at the Wedding, Noah Baumbach's hugely pretentious, ugly and annoying follow-up to The Squid and the Whale.
This is the sort of movie that requires you not only to suspend disbelief, but to check your sanity at the ticket counter.
There's an air of extreme predictability and inevitability in the script.
In a season filled with so many feel-bad movies, don't underestimate the appeal of something as silly as Walk Hard.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A feel-good comedy about a covert US effort to fund resistance to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan? What will Hollywood think of next?
A protracted piece of schmaltz.
This is more an entertaining than a profound film.
For adults, it's like being hit over the head with a mallet every 10 seconds for 90 minutes. Two days later, I still had a headache.
[A] powerful documentary.
There are more than ample rewards for discerning adults: Some of the best dialogue in a recent movie and a gallery of unforgettable performances.
Like the maker of the similar documentary Stone Reader, De Felitta is determined to restore Paris' work to public view. Based on the many delightful samples on the soundtrack, it's an exemplary goal.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Director Joe Wright and screenwriter Christopher Hampton not only blow the Merchant-Ivory dust off the British period movie, they transform Ian McEwan's interior novel into a sweeping epic that speaks to the 21st-century soul.
He's [Christian Slater] still a capable actor, but seems to be having as much trouble finding good scripts as his Heathers co-star Winona Ryder.
Hollywood's Woman of the Year is a pregnant 16-year-old, the incredibly hip, smart-mouthed and totally endearing heroine of the wise and witty Juno.
Yes, it's in French and it's arty (in good ways) - but I promise you won't have a more viscerally emotional experience at the movies this year.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Darkly hilarious, Tamara Jenkins' The Savages captures the cruel demographic joke facing many boomers who are forced to take care of aging parents at a point when they haven't entirely figured out their own lives.
It really doesn't get much better than Frank Langella's career-capping per formance.
At two full hours it can feel as exhausting as a holiday dinner with your own family.
Like Richard Gere in [American Gigolo], Harrelson's Carter Page is as superficial as he is entertaining - at least, until he gets mixed up in a murder case.
This bittersweet comedy is a fine showcase for a pair of distinctive and appealing talents.
Anybody who thinks the Rolling Stones are old should check out the charming documentary Young@Heart, which features a group of rock performers whose average age is around 80.
Quote not available.
A Michael Mann-ish heist thriller with a pulse-pounding foot chase and some terrific stunt work offsetting its hackneyed plot and dialogue.
Recounts the true story of Chinese ballet star Li Cunxin's defection to the US in the schmaltziest TV-movie terms imaginable.
There's a charming little film struggling to get out of this nearly two-hour CGI extravaganza...
Tries to be more than a sitcom but keeps falling back on cheap laughs.
Extremely unsettling and thought- provoking.
The brain-dead male equivalent of Sex and the City 2.
Even if you buy Roberts as an introspective writer (I didn't), there's no real sense of an emotional journey here.
Cairo Time earns some indulgence for a pace that Westerners may find languid.
This very well-acted, often amusing and dirty-minded hard-R film still stands out in a sea of market-driven blandness.
These three pros take a story that could have been pure schmaltz and spin it into pure gold.
Dinner With Schmucks may actually be the funniest movie currently in the marketplace -- but that's pretty much by default.
Maudlin and unintentionally hilarious.

While it obviously isn't for all tastes, this is a big, thematically rich step forward -- mostly it's about tolerance and forgiveness -- from the empty provocation of Solondz's Storytelling and Palindromes. About time.
Child actress King is a real find; plenty of kids will be asking for a sequel.
A sublime brain-twister of a movie that plays out so intricately on so many levels simultaneously that a bathroom break comes at your own peril.
We have here a movie that's pitch-perfect one minute and awkwardly schmaltzy the next.

Winnebago Man, which appears to be notably less staged than other documentaries of this ilk, doesn't relentlessly explore all the corners of Rebney's life -- which makes him an even more fascinating subject.
Dog lovers won't want to miss My Dog Tulip. Adult dog lovers, that is.
Rockwell does a typically fine job -- he's funny, touching and appalling -- as an alcoholic mess of a former high school basketball coach who's been reduced to washing dishes in a restaurant.
Secretariat" ultimately delivers where it matters, in the home stretch.
Hot Summer Days makes a lukewarm case for global warming. It's a better argument that the production of mindless fluff is not just limited to Hollywood
The Hungry Ghosts is vanity cinema at its most tedious.
The scariest, creepiest and most elegantly filmed horror movie I've seen in years -- it positively drives a stake through the competition.
Such a stinker that the only way to improve it would be for Disney to run the negative and all of the prints through an industrial shredder.

There are few surprises in a film that finds Woody the director (he does not act here) on the autopilot he has increasingly resorted to as he continues to crank out an average of a film a year, as he has over four decades.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's the finest film in many years to open the New York Film Festival.
As a writer-director, Nelson keeps the laughs coming at a steady pace, and never condescends to his articulate redneck characters.
The ruefully funny Jack Goes Boating, which, refreshingly, takes a generous view of its flawed characters, is a must for us many Hoffman fans.
Stone shows great self-assurance and considerable comic chops in a tour-de-force that that could have seemed smarmy and/or silly in lesser hands.
The Town is an exciting and extremely well acted film.
Science fiction movies don't come much more ponderous than the beautifully filmed Never Let Me Go, which reduces the debate over genetic engineering to a mild, moist romantic soap opera.
A cheerful and proudly corny musical that's pretty hard to resist if you're in the right frame of mind.
It may not live up to that grandiose title, but this rousingly sweet little flick is certainly nothing to go out of your way to avoid.
The destruction in Max Manus is elaborately staged by co-directors Espen Sandberg and Joachim Roenning...

It smothers the already frail story of their characters' long-distance relationship with enough R-rated gross-out humor for half a dozen Judd Apatow movies -- except that virtually none of it is funny.
The Kids Are All Right might not be as edgy as Cholodenko's past work, but this more mainstream effort has lots of smarts, lots of heart and an open mind.
After 23 years and three attempts, Predators finally delivers a solid sequel to the Arnold Schwarzenegger B-movie classic.

Apprently novice filmmaker Angela Ismailos' definition of a Great Director is one who's willing to sit or walk with her while she lobs innocuous questions and gives herself lots of awed close-up reaction shots.
Robin Hood is head and shoulders above the sort of lightheaded epics Hollywood typically offers during the summer season.

This relatively short doc is more than halfway over before it gets around to addressing its stated theme: how computer trading has thinned out the crowd of sharp-elbowed traders by some 90 percent since 1997.
The extended version -- the additional footage is easy to spot because it's rather worn and a slightly different size -- provides more of the extraordinary performance by the teenage Helm.
First-time filmmaker Brooks Branch underutilizes an estimable cast...
It's about as enervating a way to waste 78 minutes as I've ever experienced.
There's so much clunky exposition in the script attributed to Justin Theroux that it seems forever before the first action sequence, which has surprisingly mediocre special effects.

Imagine Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds as a children's comedy, and you have a rough idea of the excruciatingly unfunny Furry Vengeance, which keeps slamming the audience over the head with a single joke.
It thankfully strips away the veneer of glamour that Guy Ritchie and his imitators have applied to British crime films over the last decade or so.
Scott Caan, of all people, playing a writer of romantic novels?
Did a hunky LA massage ther apist kill someone in their sleep? Perhaps the biggest problem with Allen Wolf's drowsy thriller In My Sleep is managing to stay awake long enough to find out.
Lopez, appearing in her first rom-com since Monster-in-Law five years ago, is still a likable screen presence who throws herself into the movie's slapstick sequences with unwarranted enthusiasm.
Paper Man is far from perfect, but it holds your interest as a character study because of strong performances by Daniels and Stone.
Goes over the top now and then, but overall it's a lot of nasty fun.
The Joneses is a black comedy about stealth marketing made by a filmmaker who's evidently much too close to the subject to bite the hand that feeds him.
This inspirational film, written by first-timer (and producer) W. William Winokur, is not for cynics or those resistant to cute kids (and child actors sometimes given to mugging).
This is a terminally whimsical vanity project that would probably have been a chore to sit through even in its original intended format, a 20-minute stage monologue.
While the Millers have a physical presence, they're hardly actors. In fact, it's often difficult to tell them apart, although one of them is missing a tooth and takes off his shirt a lot.
Has a certain dark charm if you can put up with very jittery camera work and editing.
A very rare contemporary romantic comedy that doesn't succumb to terminal stupidity.
Stilted dialogue, wooden acting, glacial pacing, cheesy special effects, tacky-looking sets, ugly costumes, poorly staged and edited action sequences, all shown in murky, cut-rate 3-D.
Well-acted but clumsy...
A gut-wrenching, politically neutral documentary that spends more than a year with a platoon of American GIs in a valley that's been called the most dangerous spot on Earth.
One of those movies that requires you to accept that every single time a character is presented with a choice, he or she will make the worst and most inexplicable one.
Not unusually for a Bollywood movie, Raavan combines beautiful photography, over-the-top acting, cheesy special effects and musical numbers that stretch things out well beyond the two-hour mark.
A hard-hitting exposé of a shameful episode.
Toy Story 3 may not be a masterpiece, but it still had me in tears at the end.
Basically, this is The Taming of the Shrew with an adorable-baby twist that never occurred to William Shakespeare.
Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work compellingly presents a strong woman with no shortage of anger, resentment and regrets -- but not an ounce of self-pity.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A mildly funny, stereotype-stuffed comedy about a straight-laced aspiring filmmaker who is forced to go to work for a producer of adult films.
On several levels, this film is a real-life horror story that puts most Hollywood movies to shame.

Brody and Polley's performances keep the film grounded in a semblance of reality even when it threatens to go over the top near the end, and director Natali infuses the proceedings with a consistent sense of nail-biting dread.

Prince of Persia got the go-ahead from an administration at Disney that was sent on its way last year. I wouldn't be surprised if their successors at the Mouse House wish they had a magic dagger that would allow them to go back and erase this movie.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Influenced by Jacques Tati, Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton -- as well as the British Carry On slapstick farces -- this film has long stretches without any dialogue at all.
Eisenberg never makes Sam's seduction entirely convincing, and Asch goes so far out of his way to avoid sensationalizing the material that Holy Rollers is a bit of a snooze.
Douglas' juiciest vehicle since Wonder Boys.
It couldn't have been easy making a movie with less plot, character development and dramatic credibility than an episode of a campy '80s TV series.
This long and overly genteel adaptation of Peter Cameron's 2002 novel never quite comes to a boil.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A real old-fashioned crowd-pleaser.
Down Terrace is the auspicious feature debut of Ben Wheatley, who's spent a decade directing sitcoms, Web-isodes and commercials while fruitlessly pitching scripts to Hollywood.
Well-acted and acutely observed, the sort of cerebral fare you can more typically find on HBO than in theaters these days.
After 160 years, this is a story that still grips the heart and the mind.
This silly extraterrestrial-invasion epic somehow manages the feat of making the destruction of La La Land seem tedious.
Aside from a relatively brief appearance by Joan Cusack's avatar as the kidnapped mother, there are no involving characters or situations.

More than lives up to its name with ultra-campy performances, high-glucose direction (Daniel Barnz), laughable dialogue, cheesy effects and a back-lot simulation of a Manhattan street that wouldn't pass muster on an after-school special.
An ultra-quirky animated Western with a vocal tour de force by Johnny Depp that's quite unlike anything I've ever seen.

The misleading trailers for the supremely goofy "The Adjustment Bureau" promise action-packed sci-fi. What you actually get is a love-struck Matt Damon running for the US Senate as he's stalked by fedora-wearing angels.
A dirge of a comedy...
An occasionally funny comedy with slow stretches that has directors Peter and Bobby Farrelly returning to their trademark gross-out humor.
"The Chaperone" is dreadful enough to make you wish Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson was still making family movies.

Brad Anderson's creepily effective low-budget thriller may not have a punch line worthy of your typical "Twilight Zone" episode, but it otherwise gets the job done in under an hour and a half with a good cast.
Leon is actually kind of charming as an actor, but he's completely wasted in this bomb.
Plot holes you can drive a truck through are ultimately less important for your enjoyment than how they set up the film's big set pieces.
An interminable documentary punctuated by perhaps half an hour of heavily edited 3-D performance footage.
Fortunately, Winters' legendary inventiveness as a comedian has not diminished with the years.
Though deadly serious, Christopher Smith's European-made bubonic- plague melodrama provides good value with lots of blood and guts, as well as a solid cast.
[A] delightfully silly animated flick, which doesn't wear out its welcome.
Cunningham talks freely about his passion for fashion and photography.
McCarthy has a rare ability to make familiar situations seem fresh in an era when many so-called indie films have become as predictable and formulaic as their big-budget brethren.
Too concerned with being cool to work up much in the way of political outrage, much less narrative drive.
This is a sharp-looking movie with a blue-chip cast.
I have a feeling that older audience members will, like me, be getting restless during this celebrity-voice-driven, generically plotted variation on "Madagascar."
Working on an obviously limited budget on locations in Savannah, Ga., Redford does a good job of evoking the era with the help of cinematographer Newton Thomas Siegel.
When somebody says, "The quest sucks," I was inclined to agree.
Cattrall, who gained weight for a role in which she looks every one of her 50-something years, makes "Meet Monica Velour" more involving than it sounds.
It's sort of poetic justice that the wretched "Sucker Punch" is getting kicked off four Manhattan IMAX screens after just two weeks by this charming nature documentary.
Shamelessly pandering to the elusive Christian family audience, a committee of 18 producers and seven writers has removed nearly every trace of grit from this airbrushed portrait.
"Queen To Play" is ultimately about people's capacity for emotional and intellectual growth at any age.
It might not be James Franco's tour de force in the higher-profile "127 Hours," but Oscar winner Adrien Brody makes a meal of his seriously injured character.
A lot less funny than it sounds.
A fun ride of a sci-fi thriller with terrific romantic chemistry between Jake Gyllenhaal and Michelle Monaghan.
The heavy-handed "Peep World" has a few laughs sprinkled over its abbreviated running time as it limps to a predictable conclusion.
"Sucker Punch" is what happens when a studio gives carte blanche to a filmmaker who has absolutely nothing original or even coherent to say.

Calling big-screen legal thriller "The Lincoln Lawyer" the best TV pilot I've seen in a while really isn't meant as a putdown -- the truth is, there's more good stuff on the tube these days than in theaters, especially at this time of the year.
It sounds like TV-grade schmaltz, but it isn't, thanks to expertly astringent work by Simmons...
"Cold Weather" is much less interested in providing a satisfying mystery than dwelling on the quirks of its aimless and awkward protagonist -- anyone unwilling to go along risks severe boredom.
Thanks to Portman's superb work, we feel her pain acutely.
Despite an impressive cast (excluding the excruciatingly dull O'Donoghue, a newcomer from Ireland), "The Rite" is the sort of misfire that Hollywood has long buried in January.
Without ever losing sight of the serious issues involved, Cole manages to keep things relatively light-hearted.
Beautifully shot but a soulless cash machine, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1" delivers no dramatic payoff, no resolution and not much fun.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It includes more than a few clever lines, and boasts a stellar cast, including the underutilized Diane Keaton.
Extremely well-acted, suspenseful and produced on a lavish scale, "Outside the Law" may oversimplify the complex politics, but it's a worthy companion piece to "Army of Shadows."
Like all great movies, "127 Hours" takes us on a memorable journey. Which is not easy when 90 percent of the movie takes place with a virtually immobile hero in a very cramped setting.
This animated feature is what Yogi Berra called "déjà vu all over again," its shopworn premise most recently having served the marginally better "Despicable Me" this summer.

Shange's words retain their power despite the melodramatic incidents Perry has woven to fill in the spaces between poems, his flat, TV-style direction and the highly variable performances of an all-star cast.

movie_title: The Soprano State: New Jersey's Culture Of Corruption Part One (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Both of them are so obnoxious that you're quickly rooting for the monsters to get them. Unfortunately, they're never in any real danger.
So bad it's almost (but not quite) good, Dan Ireland's Jolene is an unusually elaborate and excruciatingly long vanity production...
An eccentric little comic thriller filled with enough laughs that I was mostly willing to overlook the fact that it makes virtually no sense as a thriller.
Audiences tend to avoid Kristen Stewart's non-Twilight movies like vampires fleeing daylight. Believe me, it's their loss.
Douglas Langway's middling comedy is sort of a Sex and the City for big, hirsute gay guys and the younger cubs who fancy them...
Milks the very real problem of "organ tourism" for all the melodrama and car chases it's worth.
Charming and mouthwatering...
A solid if not-quite-classic musical version of "Rapunzel"...
Aguilera can dance like nobody's business, but her acting debut isn't going to keep Anne Hathaway awake at night.
Spectacularly misconceived, bloated and incredibly ugly...
Considerably more fun than the rather lethargic original.
[A] satisfying, well-acted drama.
The movie quickly sinks into a terminal case of the cutes and extreme predictability - amid the usual surfeit of wacky supporting characters.

It wears out its welcome well before the two-hour mark.
Spacey has a field day as the hyper-energetic Abramoff, the former producer of the Dolph Lundgren epic "Red Scorpion" who observes that "Washington is Hollywood with ugly people."
The product of an out-of-touch filmmaker that never really gets to second base.

Two-time Best Actress Oscar winner Swank needn't clear any space on her mantel for acknowledgment of her participation in this soapy redneck opus, which really belongs on Lifetime rather than in theaters.
A surprisingly unengaging and charmless fantasy from a director whose previous films ("Across the Universe," "Titus," "Frida") were, despite their other issues, never boring.

Von Donnersmarck, who brilliantly depicted government surveillance in East Berlin before the fall of the wall in his earlier German film, astonishingly can't even find a way to make Interpol's spying interesting here.
Kidman and fellow Oscar-winning Wiest could pick up Oscar nominations for this dryly un-sentimental black comedy.
Such an endearing oddity that you have to wonder exactly for whom it was made. But I'm glad they did nonetheless.
Jarecki, the wealthy co-founder of Moviefone who directed the acclaimed documentary "Capturing the Friedmans," here presents another memorable portrait of a dysfunctional family over three decades.
A sloppy vanity project ... rambling and toothless...
A delirious fever-dream of a psychosexual thriller starring Natalie Portman as a ballerina descending into madness in far and away the best performance of the year.
Despite much effort, neither Johnson nor director George Tillman Jr. can make this preposterous tale, the latest misfire from CBS Films, live up to its title.
The extremely well-acted "The Company Men" ends on a hopeful note, but Wells examines the repercussions of a layoff-based economy with devastating precision.

It's because of a superior cast that this version of Death at a Funeral is the rare comedy remake that's funnier than the original, however slightly. Personally, though, I'm not sure it was worth the effort.
Co-directors Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, who directed the gritty indie dramas Half Nelson and Sugar, go all gooey and sentimental here.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I don't think we're expected to take After.Life any more seriously than Ricci's last extended (near) nude role in the immortal Black Snake Moan. That one was more fun.

Clumsily written, mostly in English, with performances to match, the only real mystery surrounding Ghosted is how this soporific bore got made.

There are clips from more than 80 movies crammed into 100 consistently hilarious and jaw-dropping minutes, from soft- and hard-core porn to cheesy , gory horror movies to biker and car chase movies that make The Fast and the Furious look positively tame.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The beautifully crafted Adam offers no pat or easy answers to wrenching questions.
In the Loop is certainly the smartest and funniest movie inspired by the Iraq war.
Shrink starts promisingly, but Jonas Pate directs his fine cast straight into a swamp of schmaltz as every loose thread of plot gets patly resolved.
Romantic comedies are an increasingly debased genre, but few recent Hollywood products have been anywhere near as crass and contrived as The Ugly Truth.
There's something seriously wrong when you assemble actors this good -- and can't believe a single stilted word coming out of their mouths.
It's the oldest bittersweet story in the book, of course, but music-video director Marc Webb approaches his feature debut with great confidence, flair and a minimum of schmaltz.
More gut-bustingly funny than anything else out there right now.

What it lacks in laughs -- there are none -- it tries to make up for by ladling on stale clichés, such as Vardalos' two stereotypically gay assistants and a desperate younger female friend who stalks guys.

Advertised as the first Bollywood movie shot at a Hollywood studio with an appearance by a major US star, Sabbir Khan's proudly silly Kambakkht Ishq otherwise hews closely to a familiar Indian pattern.

movie_review_blurb: The fatally miscast Johnny Depp's smaller-than-life performance as the famed gangster is the central flaw in Michael Mann's disappointing, curiously uninvolving Public Enemies.
My Sister's Keeper targets tear ducts so ruthlessly, it might as well be sponsored by Kleenex.

Meryl Streep makes such a tasty and larger-than-life Julia in a nostalgically evoked late-'40s Paris that it's worth stomaching the pancake-flat sequences with her supposed early 21st-century counterpart, Julie Powell.
Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen dazzles the eye, numbs the mind and may cause deafness in some cases.
Twohy serves up a hard-to-swallow second-act twist and an unconvincing back story, but the slightly overlong A Perfect Getaway recovers with a pulse-pounding climax.
The Goods, which shows signs of considerable tinkering in the editing room, is understandably not getting a hard sell at all by its studio.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Chelsea on the Rocks rambles a bit, but it's a real slice of New York history that includes everything from Ethan Hawke recounting a hilarious story about Marilyn Monroe and Arthur Miller at the hotel to footage of the 9/11 attacks...
A remake of a film by murdered Dutch director Theo van Gogh, it fails to captivate despite -- or perhaps because of -- the frantic acting efforts of Tucci and the normally reliable Patricia Clarkson.
The Boys Are Back is not a perfect movie -- but you can't do much better than Owen, who beautifully plays against his darkly brooding persona.

A desperate, cynical -- and most likely unsuccessful -- attempt by a dying studio to stave off oblivion by jumping on the High School Musical bandwagon, exploiting one of its legacy titles in ways that dishonor the original.
The Informant! is more amusing than laugh-out-loud hilarious, but is never boring.
Fox eats and heats up screen.
It signals the arrival of Shane Acker as an audacious new talent to watch.
While Fienberg's direction is no great shakes, the film showcases its veteran cast.
Quote not available.
Taking Woodstock achieves an amazing feat: It turns the fabled music festival, a key cultural moment of the late 20th century, into an exceedingly lame, heavily clichéd, thumb-sucking bore.
At 99 minutes, World's Greatest Dad is a tad too long, and takes its sweet time to get to the point. But its twisted heart is in the right place.
Spike Lee's Passing Strange: The Movie is basically canned musical theater, but this is one Tony-winning Broadway show that's well worth preserving and seeing.
Quentin Tarantino's extremely witty revenge fantasy Inglourious Basterds may be the most fun you'll have at the movies this summer.
A witless homage to Shampoo and American Gigolo that's brain-dead on arrival.

This exquisite pastel-colored, eye-popping example of hand-drawn animation is still very Japanese, aimed most specifically at children around the world -- but with a storytelling sophistication that adults will savor.
Director Todd Graff does have a keen understanding of kids in the world of performing arts, as he shows here and in his earlier and better film Camp.

Shamelessly derivative, contrived and predictable, The Proposal is nonetheless a crowd-pleasing romantic comedy.
The new Pelham, although no classic, is a lot of fun if you're in the right mood.
While Caine is highly watchable, Is Anybody There? limns all-too-familiar and schmaltzy territory for both coming-of-age films and movies with elderly actors.
This musty yarn would have worked better as a 1940s MGM programmer.
17 Again makes the '80s comedies on which it's modeled seem positively cutting-edge by comparison.
The real mystery about The Mysteries of Pittsburgh is how writer-director Rawson Marshall Thurber could turn Michael Chabon's delightful debut novel into such a bore.
I don't want to oversell it, but Observe and Report is the sort of offbeat studio movie that should be encouraged.
The sight of William H. Macy sporting a Jew-fro as a divorced dad trying to help his nerdy son score with a prom date is among the myriad delights in the gut-bustingly funny Bart Got a Room.

A shamelessly melodramatic series of romantic, financial and political crises embroil a rundown music hall in Paris 36, a gleaming hunk of French period schmaltz expertly rendered by director Christophe Barratier.

The stars look bored out of their minds when the fourth episode of the franchise stalls between racing sequences, which is all too often in a flick where 106 minutes speed by in what feels like at least four hours.
Touching and uplifting, Goodbye Solo is a small gem.

The disjointed story is no more comprehensible than The Big Sleep. Though Alter is no Howard Hawks and Pardoe and Sanchez are no Bogie and Bacall, this movie looks great. You won't nap through The Perfect Sleep.
American Swing doesn't have a particularly well-defined point of view, but it is a succinct, entertaining and valuable record of a time that in some ways now seems as remote as the Roaring '20s.
Heavily touted as an industry breakthrough for 3-D, DreamWorks Animation's clunky and wildly unimaginative Monsters vs. Aliens really doesn't have a clue what to do with the technique.
A starless but highly effec tive Aussie noir that marks the auspicious feature debut of stuntman and music-video director Nash Edgerton.
The film is a small-scale charmer that provides a tailor-made role for Malkovich, who is always fun to watch.
The clichés are thicker than the Steam in Kyle Schickner's hackneyed dramedy.
A failed and problematic Oscar hopeful being dumped in theaters a week before the start of Hollywood's summer season.
Since it's going to make you mighty hungry anyway, I'd suggest skipping A Touch of Spice and going straight to dinner.
The Informers is a movie so seamy it makes you want to take a bath afterward. Rarely has so much sin seemed so boring.
The Woodman's return to New York after a four-year European sojourn finds him working very familiar territory much less fruitfully than in the past.
Notably thinner, less awkward and a lot less charming, Vardalos is back with My Life in Ruins, a desperate, crass and probably futile attempt at replicating the earlier movie's fluke success.

Pity the unwitting parents who take their kids to see Land of the Lost, Will Ferrell's terminally stupid, sloppy, campy and cheesy -- and thoroughly unexciting and unfunny -- experiment in 'family entertainment.'
An exquisite work of cinematic art that also happens to be the funniest, most touching, most exciting and most entertaining movie released so far this year.
A small masterpiece of poignant deadpan humor.
An absorbing study in creative tension.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Except for Santoro, the acting and the movie itself lack much of a sense of urgency. But it gets the look right on a microscopic budget, and its heart is in the right place.

The first Noel Coward play to hit the big screen in more than 40 years, Easy Virtue is a crass, heavy- handed and -- most unfor givably -- largely laugh-free adaptation of The Master's infrequently revived 1924 comic melodrama.
A Serious Man may not have the starry casts of the Coens' more recent films, but it has plenty of heart and soul. It's a movie mitzvah.
Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian seems to go on for several days and nights, though in fact it lasts just 105 minutes. I checked my watch. A lot.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An exceedingly silly historical fantasy.

Adoration, which hinges on a number of coincidences, contains some really fine performances, including a surprising one from Canadian utility player Scott Speedman as the student's rough-hewn uncle and guardian.
Hypocrisy? Your call.
Smart, epic and eye-popping.
Forget West 47th Street -- and the only Jazz in Lindsey Christian's dull indie soap opera is an aspiring funk singer by that name who lives in a diamond-shaped part of the District of Columbia.
I'm almost embarrassed to admit I found Ghosts of Girlfriends Past the season's first genuine guilty pleasure.
A super-buff Jackman gets to explore the character in more depth than previously and Liev Schreiber, as his brother, makes a dandy bad guy.
Imagine Dirty Rotten Scoundrels filtered through the increas ingly hermetically sealed sensibility of Wes Anderson, and you've got Rian Johnson's disappointing The Brothers Bloom.
Girls just wanna have fun -- and boy, do they as rough 'n' ready roller derby players -- in Whip It, Drew Barrymore's exuberant and totally winning directing debut.
It's hard to believe that the smart Lea would remain interested for six hours, much less six years, with the vapid Chéri.
An exquisitely crafted potboiler offering up two and a quarter hours of thrills, chills and Leonardo DiCaprio freaking out in a nuthouse during a hurricane.

Mostly, Formosa Betrayed seems a tedious excuse for lengthy tirades against Chiang Kai-shek delivered by the film's producer and co-writer, Will Tiao, who less than convincingly plays a Taiwanese activist.

Less funny or romantic than your average colonoscopy, this cringe-inducing bore provides dubious employment for four Oscar winners, two nominees and a raft of TV performers such as George Lopez, all of whom have been seen to better advantage elsewhere.
The film toggles between high camp and deadly earnestness, all the while threatening to drown in an ocean of not-so-special effects.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The uneasy combination of the World Trade Center, Sparks and schmaltzmeister director Lasse Hallstrom pushed me perilously close to nausea and diabetic shock, not to mention deep sleep.
The performances and what passes for dialogue -- mostly extended bickering and screaming -- are so lackluster that it's hard to care about the fate of this trio for long.

When in Rome plumbs new depths for ineptitude in acting, directing, writing and every other department.
Even a great British cast and obscenity-laden gangland dialogue aren't enough to make what amounts to an extended acting exercise into much of a movie.

Basically, if you've seen the ads, you've seen the only joke in this one-joke movie, although there are also endless groan-worthy gags about wings and teeth.

Leap Year may be the least funny Hollywood comedy to take advantage of Irish tax credits since The Honeymooners.
Waiting for Armageddon (which has nothing to do with the 1998 Michael Bay movie) demonstrates that sometimes it's far more devastating to simply point the camera at your subjects and let them talk.
Erin Dignam's episodic script, brimming with humor and honest emotion -- and the pitch-perfect direction of Udayan Prasad -- thankfully avoids manipulating the audience at every turn.
The pitch-perfect direction by Jason Reitman perfectly balances comedy and drama.
Willis basically smirks his way through the proceedings, while the gifted Morgan often seems miserable as the butt of most of the film's gags.
It's easy to see how the animation nominators fell in love with this charmer based on Celtic mythology, which is quite unlike anything I've ever seen before.
A reasonably amusing way to pass Saturday night with a significant other.
Don McKay certainly has its moments, but it never manages to maintain the consistent tone so crucial if a black comedy is going to actually be funny.
So would-be hip it hurts, Adventures of Power is barely watchable, despite the presence of such pros as Michael McKean and Jane Lynch.
It's the worst of both worlds as Disney cash cow Miley Cyrus makes the most dubious "dramatic" debut of any singer since Britney Spears.

Cusack, who self-deprecatingly mocks his iconic presence in '80s films like Say Anything, is terrific -- with an especially wonderful, demented monologue in which he explains why he and his sister are so screwed up.

movie_review_blurb: Essentially another tone-deaf update of Love, American Style.

Ultimately, The New Juarez is too passionately partisan regarding a very important and hard-to-fully-comprehend human tragedy.
Yes, the canon invoked for this film is that of the Three Stooges, but it's still not as magnificently berserk as they can be. Set your expectations carefully for this one.
This slightly better-than-average family film is all paint-by-numbers.
The film provides more of the same and nothing startlingly innovative, but what's here is good.
Arthur Newman is overwhelmed with arty ambitions and a heavy-handed acting style. Ultimately, all the weight prevents the film from taking off and soaring.
There is an enormous amount of effort put into this film which at its end just seems like noise, wind, and dust.
Fast-moving, involving, and entertaining, the tale sweeps you deep into its current and carries you swiftly along.
Pandora's Promise is a fascinating documentary about nuclear power that argues it is the true green energy. It would be hard to imagine a film more controversial than this one.
The landscape, texture, sensibility, and atmosphere of Marfa is what really makes this film so captivating and unique.
Not only have we seen this all before, but we were probably hoping to not see it again.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The film is more than a bit of a mess, with the crashes, explosions, and gunfire all dominating the action, if never quite coalescing into anything coherent.
Sure, we've all seen this story before, but that doesn't hamper this film from being enormously entertaining, with riveting performances, great beats, and poetic rhymes.
In particular, as mentioned, the dance sequences are a mess, which is the kiss of death for a film in this genre.
47 Ronin is about magic, the fantastic, a witch, and CGI monsters that adorn a muddled and confused plot.
Charming and entertaining, if overlong and a bit too melodramatic, Instructions ultimately works because of the cast.
movie_title: No se aceptan devoluciones (Instructions Not Included) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Haunting and extremely atmospheric, Mama is a horror film imbued with an unsettling and affecting power.
Rather than rising above the fray, Madea is very much the fray itself.
Obviously, I'm not even close to the intended audience for this film, but it was maddening and frustrating to watch so much ambition wasted on delivering such lame junk.
The film is mostly predictable, but throws a few curveballs and ends up being surprisingly entertaining, if not at all outstanding.
Yes, Diana is the poor little rich girl, but the opulent settings, private jets, yachts, and chauffeured cars prove peculiar and distracting affectations.
There is redemption in the chemistry between the two lead characters, their passions and complexity, as well as in the grace of the music as it is performed and how it is used.
Although at times it seems to be building emotional momentum, by the end it falls flat -- tripped by its conflicting ambitions, overload of metaphoric events, and lack of powerful catharsis.
Bad history is a meaningless criticism to lob at an animated film, but the film really has no other outstanding attributes. This one is just for the kids.
Tthe film finally falls short, an explosive beginning leading to a pedestrian end.
The most surprising thing about this movie, outside of its length, is just how unsurprising it really is, especially regarding its tired climax.
Don't suspect any surprises: It is a Christian film and demonstrates melodramatic TV strategies. Still, on its own terms it is entertaining.
Ultimately, the film is absolutely charming if a bit too predictable and glued more to sit-com narrative strategies and aesthetics than is healthy. Still, Pulling Strings works on a number of levels.
The film ends up being about much more than itself, much more than just bodybuilding or bodybuilders. Although a bit overlong, it is really a triumph of intelligent, strategic filmmaking.
Quel est le poids de l'amour, de la vengeance et de la culpabilité? À vous de le découvrir.
The Incredibles est encore un bon produit provenant de Pixar [mais] dommage que l'histoire ne soit pas toujours très inspirante et ne suscite pas l'intérêt escompté.
Schindler's List s'inscrit parmis les meilleurs films de Steven Spielberg et se veut un portrait très réussi de l'holocauste et de l'horreur qui en découle.
Tim Burton, fidèle à son talent et à sa réputation, transforme un scénario déjà bien concocté en un film des plus divertissants
À moitié réussi, à moitié raté.
Ocean's Twelve demeure un film sympathique et divertissant, mais sans plus et surtout pas au niveau du premier film.
Army of Darkness s'impose comme un film diablement amusant, un summum dans le genre et à seulement quelques échelons d'Evil Dead II
Le film est prévisible, conventionnel et on connaît les dénouements bien avant qu'ils ne surviennent.
The Experiment est un bon film, mais je comprends mal qu'il ait pu gagner des prix.
Un film délicieux que l'on écoute avec légèreté et qui fait passer un bon moment grâce à son humour, sa féerie, mais aussi dans la façon dont il nous touche.
Assez bien dans l'ensemble, mais la fascinante prémise n'est jamais vraiment exploité à sa hauteur.
Les références aux classiques de l'horreur, l'humour franchement drôle à certains moments et tout le gore réussiront peut-être à ne pas faire regretter l'achat du billet.
Du cinéma préfabriqué qui donne envie de revoir Hulk et X2.
C'est un film qui rivalise avec les plus gros blockbusters hollywoodiens. Je l'ai trouvé beaucoup plus satisfaisant que The Matrix Reloaded.
L'utilisation presque exagérée de la violence rehausse la qualité du film et l'ensemble est tellement mauvais qu'il en devient bon.
Saw n'est pas un film d'horreur des plus réussis, ni un film particulièrement brillant [mais] il dépasse aisément le niveau des Scream et compagnie.
Certains films sont davantage une démonstration d'animation qu'une histoire bien construite.
Sanglant, violent, brutal, divertissant et intelligent. À voir deux fois plutôt qu'une.
Une belle réussite, mais tout de même un peu trop exagéré par la critique pour sa valeur.
[..]sans une véritable ligne directrice, le film ne possède pas suffisamment d'attraits pour en faire une comédie réussie.
Un film qui propose à la fois une réflexion intelligente sur la chute du mur de Berlin, un divertissement amusant et un récit touchant.
Au-delà de la qualité de jeu des acteurs et des textes, les nombreuses références et les divers hommages présents dans le film en font un incontournable.
Hero est une réussite complète qui fascine les yeux et l'esprit.
Ce film est du calibre des meilleures comédies que nous offre Hollywood.
Master and Commander possède toutes les qualités qu'il est possible d'avoir dans les domaines techniques et artistiques (...) mais est terriblement ennuyant.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Aucun texte ne pourra jamais transmettre efficacement en mots la qualité de cette uvre.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Ninth Gate est un énième film sous-évalué qui mérite davantage d'attention et de reconnaissance.
...si vous avez apprécié Le Placard et Le Dîner de cons, Tais-toi! risque sans doute de vous plaire.
Un film léger qui se laisse écouter avec le sourire aux lèvres.
The Village est la première réelle déception provenant de Shyamalan.
Following est un exercice de style et d'ingéniosité qui nous rappelle [Memento] tout en ayant un cachet bien particulier.
Hulk se distingue de la masse par son caractère humain et par les thèmes qu'il aborde.
Oubliez les navets que l'on voit sur grands écrans: oubliez Battlefield Earth ou Jason X, Speed Demon est un summum de médiocrité rarement égalé.
Gothika est donc un autre film d'horreur qui semble sortir tout droit d'un programme créant des scénarios. Heureusement que l'on peut en rire.
L'intérêt envers l'orgie d'effets spéciaux baisse rapidement alors que rien d'autre dans ce film ne peut valoir le coût ou la peine d'être vu..
Les Aimants est un film inegal qui malgré ses quelques défauts apparait éminemment sympathique. [...] L'une des bonnes productions quebecoises de l'annee.
Un film divertissant et amusant qui risque de plaire au fan de Romero en attendant un nouveau film de sa série.
Le premier film d'une excellente trilogie [...] mais les deux autres volets sont davantage des incontournables.
The Great Dictator mérite amplement de faire partie des éléments clés du cinéma.
La confrontation, mais aussi l'amitié entre ces deux comédiens au sommet de leur forme, font de The Quiet American un film solide.
Cette production estivale est divertissante l'espace d'un instant si l'on ne cherche pas à en trouver les moindres défauts.
Phone Booth est un excellent suspense, mais aussi un drame psychologique qui s'aura vous divertir.
J'aurais préféré voir quelque chose de plus sombre et de plus sérieux. Dommage.
Ce film représente le summum de la carrière de Tarantino
Rappelons surtout que tout cela a déjà été fait ailleurs, et potentiellement en mieux.
Du gros, gros recyclage.
Si vous êtes prêt à suivre à votre maximum d'attention une comédie qui ne semble pas faire beaucoup de sens, vous risquez [...] de vous y retrouver.
The Amityville Horror intéressera surtout les inconditionnels de films d'horreur qui ne reculent pas devant un Halloween 8.
Il est intéressant de voir que le film s'attarde surtout à démontrer la mesquinerie de l'homme plutôt que de glorifier le christianisme.
Le plus gros problème de Crash, est de ne pas avoir réussi à dire grand chose, malgré en avoir montré beaucoup.
Primer est un film difficile à détester, mais encore plus difficile à pleinement apprécier.
Un peu de rose bonbon, ça se prend bien de temps en temps, même dans le monde du cinéma.
Une leçon de cinéma par l'un de ses plus grands artisans.
Alone in the Dark pourrait figurer dans un dictionnaire en exemple frappant de ce que signifie insipide.
Tous les fans se régaleront de ce film tout à fait réussi.
Même si Romero est très loin d'avoir tourné un classique, Land of the Dead fait plaisir à voir et n'est pas en reste de ces prédécesseurs.
[Ce film] est tout ce que l'on ne veut pas voir les Coen faire dans leur futur, mais aussi le genre de comédie romantique que l'on souhaiterait voir plus souvent.
Return of the Jedi est en bout de ligne juste assez satisfaisant [...] pour que cette trilogie se boucle comme étant marquante.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: Un exercice minimaliste satisfaisant, mais vite oublié.
C.R.A.Z.Y. est un film à ne pas manquer.
Une bonne location pour un party entre amis et pour ceux qui ne sont pas fatigués de la recette des films d'ados.
Open Range est tout simplement un bon vieux western qui fait plaisir à voir.
Conseil personnel, allez donc revoir le premier volet.
Quelques moments sont légèrement mieux et même intéressants, mais dans l'ensemble, vous allez complètement gaspiller votre argent et votre temps avec ce film.
Franchement, Jackass: The Movie se doit d'être vu même si l'idée de départ ne vous enchante guère.
Lock Stock And Two Smoking Barrels est du très bon cinema.
movie_title: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1999)

movie_review_blurb: ...[Jean-Pierre Jeunet] revient à la charge avec toujours autant d'inspiration et nous invite à passer un très beau dimanche de fiançailles.
[...] un récit fort intéressant sur la question de la sexualité dans une société puritaine..
Les fans du genre ne peuvent qu'être ravis, les sceptiques le seront encore davantage. Un drame épique d'arts martiaux réussi n'en demeure pas moins.
Un film émouvant porteur d'un message important, celui du droit de disposer de sa vie comme on l'entend.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Bien que le scénario soit plutôt conventionnel, The Limey amène une bouffée de fraicheur au genre grâce à la touche bien particulière de Soderbergh.
Loin de la pièce de théâtre filmée, Closer est une adaptation intelligente et en tout point réussie.
Un bon divertissement de masse, non exempt d'intelligence.
Inégal, mais efficace.
Mathstick Men se compare aisément à Catch Me If You Can sans atteindre la qualité de Ocean's Eleven.
The Missing est un suspense des plus ordinaires.
Narc est un film extrêmement conventionnel dans son histoire, mais brille dans sa réalisation, son atmosphère et son style.
Un film moyen dont on ne se souviendra plus dans quelques mois, un jab sans grande force qui ne laisse aucune marque.
L'humour est raffiné et subtil, le scénario est bien construit et rempli d'invraisemblances que l'on ne prend jamais au sérieux.
The most hateful presentation of a Black character (the mother) that I have seen in a movie since "Gone with the Wind".
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An outstanding documentary about a kind of farming that is disappearing everywhere, leaving in its wake in this particular instance the bonds between an elderly man and his prized ox, the "old partner" of the title.
A sizzling film noir that evokes the disillusionment of a once self-confident "tiger" economy.
A splendid grand guignol that thankfully avoids the Hallmark Card sensibility of the Twilight series.
The gangster part of the movie is riddled with cliches, but strikes gold with its depiction of immigrants on a train headed north. An excellent debut by a Japanese-American director.
Not a perfect satire by any means, but it does capture the insanity of our military using ESP as a weapon. Just one step ahead of Ronald Reagan using an astrologist.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Two movies in the inimitable PBSMasterpiece Theater style. John Keats falls in love, gets TB and dies.A movie in the inimitable PBS Masterpiece Theater style. Queen Victoria marries Prince Albert and resolve to help lift up the British workers while surro
A movie in the inimitable PBS Masterpiece Theater style. John Keats falls in love, gets TB and dies. At least there are no Exxon commercials.

Two movies for the price of one. Half is about the famous French cooking maven (and CIA agent). The other is about a blogger who launched a writing career blogging about her attempt to cook all the recipes in Child's cookbook. All it is lacking is a plot.

Caveat emptor. This is really a movie about the "me"--a starstruck adolescent from New Jersey who lands a bitpart in Welles's production of Julius Caesar, not so much about the great actor, director and leftwing mover and shaker.
Another minimalist exercise seeking verisimilitude when the real goal should be drama.
This is a flick about two women who go into the business of cleaning up crime scenes. Somebody should be hired to clean up the mess of a script for "Sunshine Cleaning".
A Romanian minimalist exercise about a cop with a conscience. I say bring back maximalism.
A movie based on a lie. Within a year of the Springbok victory promoted by Eastwood as bringing whites and blacks together, the team was up to its old racist ways.
A kind of Woody Allen comedy but without the jokes. Lots of cultural signifiers to make ivy league couples on a date feel at home, but totally lacking in substance.
A visually stunning anti-imperialist entertainment! Who could ask for more?
Totally lacking in character development. It is like seeing a love story involving toasters.
Has the anarchistic and madcap charm of an old Chuck Jones Warner Brothers movie.
Evokes "Beetlejuice" and "Pan's Labyrinth" but is much more of a children's movie and a damned good one at that.
A study of how a small town's worship of Kinder, Küche, Kirche led inexorably into the Third Reich. It is also an implicit warning about trends in the United States.
In a year that produced garbage like "The Blind Side", you have to wonder how much progress has been made in Hollywood since "Gone With the Wind".
A gloomy, self-conscious art movie version of the children's book that received the benediction of the author which should tell you something about the dubious value of the source material.
Supposedly a meditation on globalization and family ties, but to this reviewer it is much more of a French art movie version of Antique Roadshow.
Interesting that one of the best movies of the year is a filming of a play. That's a sad commentary on Hollywood but sufficient reason to see this uplifting and very witty movie.
Like "The Hurt Locker", calculated to sell tickets to tea-baggers and Moveon.org alike. Informed by the Clint Eastwood/Paul Haggis school of bad didactic screenwriting.
An odd mixture of "Marty" and "The Cabdriver", best when it focuses on the Marty side of the equation.

Like Diogenes with his lamp, director Yoav Shamir goes in search of anti-Semitism. This film goes further than any ever made in demonstrating that the Holocaust has been used cynically to justify Israeli expansionism and brutality.
Amazing that Ang Lee can make such a listless movie about arguably one of the most high energy times in recent history.
An antidote to weepy tales such as "Philadelphia" and "Brokeback Mountain". Yes, Virginia, gay people can enjoy long-term relationships.
A mindless, milling mess. Just what you would expect from somebody schooled in the Michael Bay/Jerry Bruckheimer academy of bad directing.
A totally dishonest movie and just what one might expect from director Jason Reitman who used to do TV commercials for Wal-Mart.
Movie starts off with a bang, but begins to lose interest as the main character (Ida Dalser) descends into mental illness.
More evidence, if any was necessary, that the United States is the most backward country on Earth.
A great documentary about father-son bonding in the beautiful but threatened waters off the east coast of Mexico that puts a question mark over "progress".

Despite obvious constraints from Indian censors, this movie provides a glimmer of insight into a powerful guerrilla movement sweeping the country's most impoverished regions in a real life version of Avatar.
Quite simply the finest movie that the insane wars in Iraq and Afghanistan has inspired.
Oliver Stone has made a movie that is essential viewing for both the hard left (like this reviewer) and those who only know about Hugo Chavez from CNN or Fox News (especially you!)
The greatest documentary ever made about the struggle for socialism. The real thing, I should add, rather than the epithet applied by Glenn Beck to the Democratic Party and its leader Barack Hoover.
movie_title: Le Fond de l'air est rouge (A Grin Without a Cat) (The Base of the Air Is Red) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Pointed social commentary using the vampire as a metaphor for an increasingly predatory bourgeois society.
A modern version of "Bride of Frankenstein" making the point that even monsters can feel sexual longing.
Best when it operates as yarn rather than as social commentary, even if it is filled with logical inconsistencies.

Hobbled mostly by the original material, a Dostoevsky novel, as well as an 80 minute cut imposed by the studio bosses, it is still worth seeing, especially for Kurosawa fans--this means everybody obviously.
A combination of "Open City" and "Mean Streets", as well as Kurosawa's first movie and the first one to use Toshiro Mifune.
A perfectly pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. The vitriol directed against this movie mostly has to do with the ageism and sexism of the reviewers rather than its merits.
A wistful tale about a sad sack who is counseled by an imaginary friend, a soccer superstar. Not so much "A Beautiful Mind" as it is Woody Allen's "Play it again, Sam".
A reasonably interesting mess in the spirit of Andy Warhol's Frankenstein.
Supremely moving tale about holocaust survivors as well as the decline of the Borscht Belt.
A movie with honorable intentions that is hobbled by its magical realist origins that put exposition and character development at the bottom of its concerns.
If the movie contained nothing but musical performances, it would be worth the price of admission. Beyond that, it is about as good an explanation of why Iranian youth revolved as you like to find.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Very likely the best movie ever made about mountain climbing, with some barbed commentary on life under Nazism.
A great movie sharing "The Bicycle Thief" scenario about a stolen object needed for economic survival, as well as the tableaux of a shattered axis city.
A powerful tale of a son seeking to avenge his father in a world of corporate malfeasance with Hamlet-like dimensions.
movie_title: The Warui yatsu hodo yoku nemuru (The Bad Sleep Well) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: An old-fashioned entertainment of the kind that Hollywood no longer knows how to make.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Probably the best movie ever made about the Hasidim, dispensing with "Fiddler on the Roof" sentimentality.
A much better movie than the more recent and more heralded "Mother", another movie about a killer.
Technically brilliant but heartless.
A stunning portrayal of the Third Reich cultural and political rot that got a fictionalized treatment in "Inglourious Basterds".
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Makes the case that the death of "lesser" languages is as much of an assault on civilization as the leveling of a rain forest.
Outstanding documentary on a modern prophet denouncing the crimes of Israel who is punished for telling the truth.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite glossing over the deeper social and political explanations for the rise of Berlusconi, this is a useful if not amusing introduction to a truly repellent and dangerous politician.

A masterpiece made in 1958 depicting the "lower depths" of Egyptian society making their living at Cairo's version of Grand Central Station. A beautiful and thrilling mixture of "Pagliacci" and Italian neo-realism.
movie_title: Bab el hadid (Cairo Station) (The Iron Gate) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that describes the scorched earth policy associated with free market fundamentalism, continuing with the current occupant of the White House.
Not nearly as much a detective story as it is a film representation of a teen girl's idea of heaven. A cross between a Hallmark card and the Disney channel.
Well, the best movie of 2009 is a documentary about aging heavy metal musicians making a last-ditch effort at fame and fortune.
Brilliant, compassionate and dramatically involving, this is documentary at its best.
A dreary mess directed and written by Guillermo Arriaga. Since it is Arriaga's first directing assignment, he can only blame his screenwriter for this uninvolving melodrama.
A neo-realist classic that is very likely the inspiration for "Wendy and Lucy". The two make for very interesting watching side-by-side.

Unstinting but lyrical documentary on the costs of poverty in Peru, especially on the children who scramble for coins on the streets of Lima as they ply their trades as gymnasts, jugglers, musicians and shoeshine boys.
Not the typical Chuck Norris movie, but just as rancid in its own "edgy" pretentious manner.
Superb documentary on the making of an opera and a weapon of mass destruction.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forget about "Valkyrie". This is the real story about the resistance to Hitler.

Highly entertaining documentary on a con artist who barely seems capable of distinguishing fact from fiction even she wanted to. Also a revealing commentary on the Islamophobia that made her phony book and Bush's phony war possible.

The definitive study of the contemporary art world that Eric Bogosian, one of the movie's interviewees, calls "complete bullshit". Also a poignant study of a love story compromised by unequal power and celebrity. Not to be missed!
Marred somewhat by a pat and rather unlikely conclusion, this movie does have the merit by lifting up the rock and examining liberal racism.

Nominally a slasher movie, this is very much more a study of some psychological depth about what it means to be severely disabled. With its limited budget, it achieves more than many movies seeking pat messages about society's outcasts.
Stunning portrait of an antiwar musical comedy revue that was a corrective to Bob Hope's gung-ho UFO shows.
The definitive Vietnam War documentary and arguably the greatest political documentary ever made.

Fascinating behind the scenes documentary on the struggle against Rockefeller Drug Laws, including a portrait of the immensely likable Randy Credico, the comedian who wore out his welcome on the Johnny Carson show after denouncing Reagan.
Extremely powerful story about women dealing with illegal abortion issues in Stalinist Romania, but it is not a simple propaganda movie. In fact, it is a sublime if deeply troubling work of art.
Vastly overrated movie with all the charm of two vacuum cleaners making love.
Simply the finest documentary ever made about global inequality. Puts the victims of the capitalist system in the forefront and allows them to tell their stories.
A mostly entertaining and always informative documentary on evolution versus the George W. Bush-approved "intelligent design".
movie_title: Flock of Dodos: The Evolution-Intelligent Design Circus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever you think of the interviewees (I confess to being immune to Zizek's charms), this is brilliant film-making.
Brilliant social history about one of the greatest publishers of the modern epoch, even if he is "Human, All Too Human"
A sardonic look at suburban sprawl in Calgary. With its wry surrealistic touches, this is a movie that makes you smile while it makes you think. Highly recommended

Powerful study of a landmark struggle between environmentalists and real estate developer in Austin, Texas in the early 90s. A parable for our exhausted, consumerist society that is choking itself to death.
