An almost Kafkaesque story of the daughter of two "disappeared" parents in Argentina discovering her true identity. Similar to "The Official Story" but with a key difference. The daughter is a teenager rather than a 5 year old and hence more vulnerable to

While Soderbergh and screenwriter Peter Buchman are ill-equipped to explain the Marxist motivations that drove Che Guevara to martyrdom, their film is an honest attempt to come to grips with a revolutionary despised in the mainstream media.
A documentary about the indignities suffered by undocumented Palestinian workers in Israel working on a construction site for a luxury hotel in a soulless "city of the future".
Intense portrait of a Tunisian break-dancer who is recruited into a jihadist cell for the purpose of becoming a suicide bomber. Despite the subject, this is a movie brimming with vitality.
movie_title: Making Of (Making of, le dernier film) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One of the towering masterpieces of Soviet cinema. As much of a joy it is to watch, it is sad to think that the director was effectively silenced as soon as Stalin made "Socialist Realism" mandatory.
An altogether charming study of a dysfunctional (what else!) Jewish family in Mexico City.
movie_title: Morirse esta en Hebreo (My Mexican Shivah) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Searing critique of the social decay in 1984 by Alexei Balabanov, who has an affinity with Quentin Tarentino. Worth seeing, but not as successful as his best-known movie "Brother".

More concerned with Bobby Sands's bed sores than his politics. A movie apparently inspired by Mel Gibson's "Passion". The Irish revolutionaries, whatever their flaws, deserved something more like "The Wind that Shakes the Barley".

A stunning achievement across the board. The movie fully captures the kind of middle-class existence that turned a younger generation into hippies or radicals. Powerfully written, acted and directed, this is an instant classic.

Director Ceylan uses neo-Antonioni techniques for a plot which calls much more for Billy Wilder or the Coen brothers. Cinematography can only go so far. In the final analysis, you need dialog, plot and character development for a good movie. "Three Monkey
If you want to spend two hours with a psychopath who loves nothing more than getting naked and brawling with prison guards, this is for you. I prefer vintage Kurosawa.

Classic McElwee blending together the personal and the political in his native North Carolina, to which he something of the same ambivalent relation that Faulkner, another son of the South, had to Mississippi.
Deeply powerful study of a family trying to survive repression and poverty in wartime Japan with much in common--unexpectedly--with the director's Samurai trilogy.

Not a terrible movie about a Walter Mitty dad and a creepy son who kills himself through asphyxiation while jerking off. If you like dark comedy, you will like this. At least, it is more interesting than the latest commodity from Jude Apatow.

A mumblecore bore about two heterosexual men, one living a conventional married life and the other a bohemian bachelor, who decide to make a gay porn movie on a dare. It would have been far more interesting, I'm afraid.
High-spirited documentary about the ultimate hypocrisy imaginable. Closeted politicians pushing for anti-gay legislation in the name of "family values".
Lugubrious affair involving a young man suffering from weltschmerz and the two women he loves set in Brighton Beach.
Deeply affecting antiwar documentary arriving just at the right moment with Obama planning to send 40,000 more troops to Afghanistan and just after the senseless massacre at Fort Hood.
Despite the lack of fanfare, this is a much better offering from Soderbergh than "The Informant", not to speak of its deeper critique of bourgeois society.
Simply Tarantino's best. A very intelligent script that combines war movie elements with some pointed observations about violence in movies and in society.
Superb study of the corrosive effects of fame and fortune on one of the greatest writers of the post-WWII period.
movie_title: One Fast Move or I'm Gone: Kerouac's Big Sur (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A movie finding "edgy" comedy about a man suffering from bipolar disorder? What's next? A dark comedy about cancer of the pancreas?
One might put up with the insufferable sense of superiority of the Coen brothers if this movie had some laughs.
This outstanding documentary calls for a food revolution for the very best reason. Until there is a change in the way we produce food, we face an ever-escalating cancer epidemic.
movie_title: Nos enfants nous accuseront (Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Very much worth seeing, despite being more in the Frank Capra vein than Karl Marx.

A perfect companion piece to "In Search of Mozart". A fully realized introduction to the man and his music that makes you want to listen to his entire body of work even if you think you have become jaded by one too many performances of the Moonlight Sonat
A reminder of how governmental violence and disregard for the people's will lead an unlikely man to resistance. A moral lesson for today when a new Vietnam looms in Afghanistan.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Outstanding documentary on how the powerful preyed upon the weak. Despite its understated tone, this is an incendiary argument for a fundamental change in class relations in the USA.
Like "The Cove", this is inspiring and dramatically involving documentary film at its best.

Gritty naturalist drama about Iraqi veteran suffering from post-traumatic stress. Utterly free of pat redemptive formulas and far more intelligent than "The Hurt Locker", this is the best movie I have seen in the Iraqi war genre.
Despite one-dimensional characterization of adult Muslim characters, this is a moving story about what happens to a Muslim boy who discovers a gun.
A good introduction to Mumblecore.

Don't believe the hype. This is a cliche-ridden mess which treats Iraqis like zombies or creatures from outer space. Peace activist Chris Hedges should have sued the director for allowing his words to serve as an epigraph for this sorry flick.
A complete mystery. How in the world did this lame British comedy bamboozle so many critics? It amounts to "Yes, Minister" with four letter words. You would be better off watching paint dry.
Forget about "Bruno" or "Borat". This is the real deal when it comes to exposing the phoniness of those in positions of power.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A highly revealing look at class differences stemming from a dispute between a crude 73 year old woman who bought what might be a Pollock painting and her detractors in the upper echelons of the art world.
An expose of the sham values of celebrity worship and tinseltown ambition largely unaware that the producer/director/writer and lead actor exemplifies those very values to the hilt.
Earnest and understated movie about the General's plot against Hitler. Despite Cruise's reputation for derring-do characters, this is a very human German colonel that he plays.
Essential viewing for those with an interest in Jewish popular culture and the American left. And just about everybody else as well!
Brilliant evocation of Maoist-minded workers alienated by China's bourgeois transformation.
The definitive study of factory farming in the U.S. today and an heir to the traditions of Upton Sinclair's "The Jungle". Highly recommended.

Dark comedy about the effects of outsourcing on an American call center about to lose its jobs to Mumbai. The film offers no pat solutions to a problem that faces workers everywhere, but it does challenge us to think about a system that is involved in a r
Marred by the same minimalist technique as "Three Monkeys", another film with a car accident MacGuffin and marital infidelity in the plot.
A brilliant study of slum life in Manila that is close in spirit, if not artistic accomplishment, with Bunuel's "Los Olvidados".
In the spirit of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" and "Flight of the Conchords" but much funnier.

Except for the brilliant performance of Vincent Cassel, this is deeply flawed movie. Like Refn's "Bronson", it assumes that the audience will be satisfied by unending brutality--a false assumption. But Cassel is brilliant as a creep.
A meditative look back at the mass murder of Mayan Indians in Guatemala and the role of the progressive film-maker. Not agit-prop at all despite what mainstream reviewers here say.
A documentary reminiscent of Cimino's "The Deer Hunter" but without the demonization of the "bad guys" that marred that film.
An understated but powerful treatise on migration, or the state of being in limbo between two nations, one desperate and one becoming more and more desperate.
Reveals the brutal exploitation that makes year-round tomatoes available at your local Gristede's.
In light of the recent freedom of the 3 victims of a 20th century witch trial depicted in the film, this powerful documentary becomes essential viewing.
movie_title: Paradise Lost: Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and politically inspired, this is one of the finest documentaries about the working class I have ever seen.
Ignore the negative reviews. This film is essential viewing for those trying to get a handle on the Orwellian world we are living in today.
After watching this eye-opening documentary, one almost hopes for a rebellion of the chimpanzees like the one seen in the latest installment in the Planet of the Apes franchise.

A sharp critique of human nature from the standpoint of our closest relative, the chimpanzee who comes off as much more civilized than those who maintain prisons, zoos, and fight wars against weak and defenseless nations.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: At last, a movie about the holocaust about ordinary human beings confronted with difficult choices. A superb script, terrific acting, and political relevance make this one of the more important movies of the year.
If you love Dylan Thomas (who doesn't?), then you will love this film.
A remake of a classic film that is a classic on its own terms. Miike's battleground choreography in the final 20 minutes or so is cinema at its most sublime, a ballet of cruelty second to none.

The writer-director has bitten off a bit more than she can chew but this is a must-see for anybody who loves the sound of Yiddish, as well as those interested in Jewish culture in general. The young actors, renegades from the Satmar, are superb.
A combination of erudition and inspiration so rare in documentary film. It made me want to rush out and read some Sholem Aleichem, something I never would have dreamed of in a million years. Bravo!
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its modesty of means, this is the most powerful documentary I have seen this year.
A deeply humanistic documentary about NYC's "lower depths".

Although I have become inured to Hollywood hype over the years, this is truly an incredible journey. The documentary is great for six year olds and sixty-six year old codgers like me who care about the future of the planet and an amazing creature.
As someone who has been sharply critical of ELF tactics in the past, I found myself deeply engaged with the activists featured in this remarkably intelligent and complex documentary.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite what other critics have said here, the movie allows the developers equal time. Of course, they hoist themselves on their own petards which you would expect. Anyhow, this is must-seeing for those concerned about the stranglehold of the rich on NY.

A both alarming and inspiring tale of the humble creature that has been around for 150 million years and is essential to our existence. A marvelous documentary incorporating investigative reporting and an artist's vision of nature.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is on my short list for best movie of 2011. Considering the obstacles that the director had to face, this is a stunning achievement. This is a film noir for the ages, and as auspicious a debut as the Coen Brothers' "Blood Simple".

Rejoice over this film! It is a stunning introduction to an art form developed in the Black community that has had universal influences. Without gospel, there is no rhythm-and-blues. Without rhythm-and-blues, there is no rock-and-roll.
A movie that mistakes grotesquery for wit--in other words a perfect vehicle for Steve Carell.
A wrong-headed and milling attempt at a "final conflict" tale like the Fellowship of the Ring.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly worth seeing for its elegant "old school" cels. However, the relationship between the elderly magician and the girl who tags along with him is never very moving despite all the intentions of the screenwriter and director.
Another worthy entry in a much-heralded series that amounts to a prison break story as exciting in its own way as Steve McQueen's "The Great Escape".

A totally enthralling movie that despite using well-worn themes seems totally fresh. Beautiful to behold and always witty, this is what I would have nominated as best film of 2010 had I seen it in time.
This powerful documentary debunks the "natural disaster" version of New Orleans flooding shared by George W. Bush and Barack Obama alike. Highly, highly recommended.

Recommended with qualifications, chief among them is the lack of context. What made the Japanese act so barbarically? You are left with the implicit assumption that they were practically born that way.
An astonishing work of art that has the visceral impact of Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring".

Too ironic by half, this film is hobbled most of all by principal Thierry Guetta, that I find insufferably banal. As a satire on a market-driven art world, it is fairly toothless. Why it has garnered rave reviews is the biggest puzzle of all.

Avoids the pat solutions of movies geared to children like "Free Willy" but should be seen by them nonetheless since it is a necessary introduction to the problem posed by human encroachment on marine life that can lead to their extinction.
The best film about basketball I have ever seen. It is the happy ending version of "Hoop Dreams" in many ways.
A compelling mixture of "Silence of the Lambs" and the biblical tale of god commanding Abraham to slay his son Isaac--believe it or not.
Forget about "Blind Side". This is the real deal, a stirring documentary about high school football that will move you to tears.
A fabulous achievement across the board. A typical Bollywood confection but also social commentary on a dysfunctional engineering school system that pressures huge numbers of students into suicide.
A penetrating examination of global transportation systems that make profits for Walmart while destroying the fabric of civilized life.
A perfect marriage between art and radical politics.
A much needed second look at the promise of wind energy, so often put forward with scant attention to the impact of 400 foot monstrosities on the people suffering such "progress" in their midst.
The film not only scores on the expected environmentalist level, but also as a more probing examination of the value of "civilization" as commonly understood as based on artificial light.
Not your everyday fare. A Marxist documentary assault on Tory-inspired rot in Britain. Hopefully it will inspire young American filmmakers to go after our own filthy rich.
A resolutely apolitical biopic inspired more by "Coal Miner's Daughter" than the class struggle in Brazil. Despite this, it is still worth seeing for its commitment to the cause of the 99% in Brazil.
Director Tomas Alfredson has a feel for the downscale look of London during the period that the novel depicts, but little else. Stick with the Guinness version.
A refreshingly disrespectful look at the scabrous creature who paved the way, along with fellow scoundrel Ronald Reagan, for the financial collapse we are now living under. Streep is magnificent.

Not surprisingly, the choice of the actress who played lead female character in Mike Leigh's "Secrets and Lies" betrays an affinity for Leigh in more than just the casting--and there's nothing wrong with that.
A riveting drama that puts Oliver Stone's latest Wall Street movie and the HBO "Too Big to Fail" to shame.
A fascinating documentary more about Khodorkovsky the "player" than about the social and political contradictions of post-Soviet Russia.

A convincing case is made that the government and the corporations it serves are worse than the mafia. A deeply radical film that makes you understand why young people risked pepper-spraying to build the Occupy Wall Street movement.

An amazing feat. A sharp commentary on the injustice done to Sikh people in the aftermath of 9/11 and some of the most breathtaking song-and-dance routines seen outside of a Michael Jackson or Madonna video.
Comes close to the voyeurism of Nick Broomfield's documentaries on Aileen Wuornos but is saved by Herzog's obviously deep conviction that capital punishment is evil.
Confirmation, if any was needed, that culture and civilization existed 25,000 years ago and that we have gone downhill since the introduction of private property.
A damned entertaining movie despite the fact that it stars Nicholas Cage.

Made for $17,000 and worth about seventeen cents. Mumblecore for the first half, incoherent violent imagery in the second half. Doesn't anybody making movies nowadays understand the need for compelling characters, a lesson lost on mumblecore makers.
Pretentious nonsense.
A kind of inverted version of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" with an end of the world obsession by a Joe Lunchpail type guy rather than UFO's. My pick for best movie of 2011.

Garbo was the man who inspired Graham Greene's "Our Man in Havana", a man who appeared to become a spy mostly out of a sense of opportunism than any idea. Which is not to say that he did not make history.
Not the first film ever made about a prison revolt, but one of the best I have seen in years.

The first film to tackle the all-important subject of whether the Comcast's and Time-Warner's of the world will have the power to control what we see, hear or post on the Internet. Gives the term "net neutrality" a flesh-and-blood urgency.
Brilliant film about life in a gulag in 1946 with steam locomotives playing as important and as dramatic a role as the human actors.
While the two halves of the film don't quite mesh, this is highly recommended for those who are intrigued by post-colonial tropes of the sort explored in "Even the Rain".
A tour de force that combines surrealist esthetics with political and social insights timed perfectly to coincide with Occupy Wall Street.
A sublime accomplishment that combines the social message of "El Norte" with the charm of "L'Atalante".
A fascinating study of gay men trying to assert their rights long before Stonewall as well as a good-humored slice of New Orleans life.
A terrific movie about teen magicians far more entertaining than any of the Harry Potter fiascoes.
A typical Sundance type comedy that confuses quirkiness with humor. Needless to say, it stars Paul Dano in his typically weird character role. A totally annoying film.
Put simply, this is the finest work of an African director since the death of Ousmane Sembene. A must see.
Compelling tale of ultraleftism becoming nihilistic in Japan.
Brilliant neorealist, improvisatory film using non-professionals to tell a story about a street hustler and the baby he is forced to look after.
Despite disclaimers by the directors that this is not a "political" movie, "Restrepo" is one damned good reason to get the hell out of Afghanistan NOW.

A very old-fashioned but stirring movie about family values, but not in the debased sense found on the Republican Party right. A gateway into the tastes and values of Chinese society unlike the typical Chinese film export geared to Western audiences.
Despite the obviously hostility to its main character, a ruthless FLN leader named Abdelkader, this is a serious movie for adult audiences. But certainly no competition for "Battle of Algiers".
Although the movie has an extremely retrograde viewpoint, it is a must-see for those trying to understand the hype around charter schools.
Although the movie has an extremely retrograde viewpoint, it is a must-see for those trying to understand the hype around charter schools.

A rather dispiriting attempt to graft the minimalist aesthetic of Jim Jarmusch on Palestinian suffering. A film no doubt intended for Western art houses rather than the Arab world, badly in need of courageous film-making.
A superlative introduction to the realities of Palestinian suffering and resistance.
A filthy toad of a human being whose every wart is revealed in this hard-hitting documentary.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike the current occupant of the White House, Spitzer clearly meant business when he said he wanted to clean up Wall Street. That is why he was brought down for buying sex, an act that has victimized few other politicians.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A picaresque tale of a young woman's sad passage through abuse marriages that retains the sardonic wit of the original story by E.L. Doctorow.

A "Grapes of Wrath" for our age, even better than Ford's masterpiece in some ways since it disdains melodrama and delivers a more realistic view of the human condition under poverty and homelessness. A truly great movie.

A movie that not only plays fast and loose with the facts; it also puts a rather callow and narcissistic young man in the lead role. Despite the directors' intentions, the "villain" of this movie is much more attractive than the ostensible protagonist.

While it does not really live up to the hyperbolic reviews, this is still a fascinating look at the craft of computer programming and the ostensibly boring question of intellectual property. Of course, it helps that the script is more fiction than fact.
A unstinting look at the social outcasts of Australian society made by a member of aboriginal society, its grim narrative punctuated by off-kilter humor in a minimalist style.
An homage to American western movies with an Australian aboriginal standing in for a wronged Indian "revisionist" style. Would have benefited from more dialog written for the anti-hero.
Despite the director's refusal to come to terms with Israel's role in the Sabra-Shatila massacre, this is a pacifist film that ranks with "Platoon" and other classics.

A movie that has more in common with Jean Genet than Frantz Fanon, but there's enough insights into white colonial domination of Arab peoples to make this a cut above the standard prison melodrama. Highly recommended.

A moving account of the martyrdom of Rachel Corrie directed by an Arab Jew, just one of many Israelis and Jews of other countries beginning to question a brutal system that killed this idealistic young American and countless Palestinians.
Quite simply, the definitive movie on the financial crisis and an implicit call for radical action against the two capitalist parties that are responsible for it.
Essential viewing, especially New Yorkers whose drinking water is being threatened by the same kinds of corporate greed and government collusion that allowed the BP spill.
A terrific behind the scenes look at the not too glamorous world of runway models made by an uncommonly perceptive model and her filmmaker boyfriend.

Leaving aside its merits at recreating Ginsberg's artistic evolution, it is one more laudable attempt to represent gay people as having fulfilled existences unlike the weepy "Brokeback Mountain" et al.

A compelling look at all aspects of the legendary pianist, from the well-known eccentricities to his love affair with a woman who would ultimately spurn him because of those eccentricities. The finest biography of a musician in long time.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A rough adaptation of King Lear, just as was "Ran" that Kurosawa made 30 years later. Not without its problems, but any Kurosawa is better than the Cineplex crap in your local neighborhood.
movie_title: I Live in Fear (Ikimono no kiroku) (1955)

movie_review_blurb: Bleak comedy about a virtual flophouse in Edo-period Japan based on Gorky's play. Top-flight ensemble performance.
A powerful look behind what amounted to a kangaroo court war crimes tribunal funded and prosecuted by the USA, a country with blood on its hands.

A movie whose concerns remain very much with us today unfortunately, especially in light of Republican Party saint Reagan's decision to speak in favor of "state's rights" at the Neshoba County Fair in 1980.

This flick was written by Stefan Aust, long-time editor of Der Spiegel, Germany's version of Time Magazine. Hence the lurid, superficial and reactionary tilt. The Baader-Meinhof gang was disgusting, but nearly as disgusting as the people they fought.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like "The Baader-Meinhof Complex", this is a largely pointless exercise meant to deliver the same kind of cheap thrills as "Bonnie and Clyde" or the Mesrine flicks. At least with straight-ahead gangster movies, you don't get the liberal moralizing.

Despite being ruled by the Communist Party, the China depicted in this powerful documentary evokes Karl Marx: "The bourgeoisie has torn away from the family its sentimental veil, and has reduced the family relation to a mere money relation."
Examination of Nazi inhumanity by an Israeli director on record as opposing Zionist inhumanity.

While covering the same terrain as "Restrepo", it deserves a wide audience since it will remind us of the continuing nightmare of Afghanistan that continues unabated under Republican and Democrat alike.

Now mostly forgotten, the 50 and older veterans of this experimental film movement were our generation's counterpart of the Dadaists and surrealists of the 20s and 30s resisting in their own manner a decadent capitalist system. A superb documentary.
A monumentally awful movie. Pretentious, uninformed, boring, and enough to drive one to a steady diet of Adam Sandler movies.
Riveting introduction to the Napoleon Chagnon/Yanomami controversy that erupted after the publication of Patrick Tierney's "Darkness in El Dorado".
A taut and powerful movie that might have easily been titled "Nobody is Illegal" given its courageous stance against the kind of xenophobia generated by a capitalist system in decline.

Strongly influenced by Michael Apted's "Up" series, this is a supremely apolitical film about some truly momentous events. With its "hip" triumphalism over the fall of the USSR, it seems a bit dated given the course of events over the past 3 years.
Boldly introspective but illuminating travelogue across a desolate landscape in modern-day Brazil by an existential outsider.
movie_title: I Travel Because I Have to, I Come Back Because I Love You (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some flaws, this is one of the more important films likely to be seen in 2011 since it deals with a people who are facing brutal discrimination all across Europe.
A luminous film about a six-year-old boy with a stuttering problem. Not the typical plot, but this is after all the year of "The King's Speech" winning an Oscar for best picture.

Outstanding documentary on the conflict between revolutionary artists and a state power determined to crush them in the name of "Communism". A great companion-piece to Chris Marker's "The Last Bolshevik".
With a screenplay by one of Ken Loach's long-time collaborators and a dedication to Howard Zinn, this intelligent and committed film is a rarity well worth seeing, despite some forgivable flaws.

An amazing first film by a 29 year old director/screenwriter/cameraman on location in war-torn Kashmir. Not explicitly a radical film, it has references to this beautiful country's war-related suffering in almost every frame.

A film that elevates Lee Chang-dong to the pantheon of directors who make great art out of the suffering of ordinary people: Satyajit Ray, Ousmane Sembene and Akira Kurosawa. A great work of art about the pain and aspirations of the lowly.

As with all other tendencies favoring the rise of the East as an industrial power, it would seem that movie-making is included. This is a top-notch thriller that is not to be missed and that puts Hollywood to shame.
This movie does the impossible. Make a gay neo-Nazi lead character sympathetic in a blend of "Brokeback Mountain" and "Made in Britain".
Gripping film noir from Argentina's most visionary film director.
Like the 1951 sci-fi classic "The Thing", this is a movie about monsters in the far north but in this instance the monsters are ordinary human beings transformed by cabin fever.

A film that shows how China's poor go through a Kafkaesque nightmare in a largely futile effort to get justice through Beijing's petition offices. Nominally ombudsmen, these offices largely serve to prevent justice from taking place.
Despite its dire economic circumstances, Romania is producing some of the most interesting movies in the world today, this prison story being the latest example.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Another "edgy" movie by the Coens filled with the usual comic mixture of sadism and misanthropy, this time expressed through its two lead male characters, a bushwhacker veteran and a Texas Ranger, two of America's most malignant forces.
Brilliantly written, acted and directed, this is a work that evokes the Russian novel despite being a Korean film. Treats larger questions of life and death in the serious manner that they deserve.
A by-the-numbers adaptation of a stage play that smacks of a thousand writer's workshops and that is utterly devoid of genuine feeling.
A totally cringe-inducing movie. Stay away from it unless you enjoy gawking at severely damaged personalities.
This movie was shot on a Canon SLR camera. Very impressive. Everything else about it is sheer garbage.

Ben Stiller plays the most repellent character I have ever seen in a movie and that includes "Dracula". If you are going to feature a repellent character, you have to make him or her interesting. Bela Lugosi was a huge success by comparison.

Despite its "postcolonial" reputation, this film does not allow a single African--especially the most important character--to have a single important speech. The rebel soldiers function mainly as zombies breaking down plantation doors to kill people.
Despite the claim that Wavy Gravy is some kind of holy clown, he said nothing or did nothing in this movie that is funny at all. An acquired taste, I suppose.
movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In many ways, a memorial meeting for the late, lamented and supremely talented Spalding Gray.
A stunning reminder of the redemptive power of art.
Still worth seeing despite the co-directors' inability to understand that a great lawyer will go out of his or her way to defend people being tried and convicted in places like the NY Post.
Transcending agitprop, this disturbing documentary gets to the heart of the question of civilization and its discontents.

Written by the same man who wrote the deliciously snarky "The Queen", this is a must for anybody who loves good political movies with great performances, especially from Frank Langella who is transcendent.

Despite the name of the movie, this is not the typical mindless action b-movie that Jason Statham specializes in. It is much more an exploration of British corruption, sexual and otherwise, at the highest levels of 1960s British society. Not a great movie
Charlie Kaufman's dreary, solipsistic attempt at self-therapy inflicted on an unwary audience.
Stunning indictment of racist, authoritarian and plutocratic mayor.
Powerful documentary about the American gulag system.
Another Melville masterpiece
Perceptive take on the irrationalities of capitalist car production
Austere but beautiful film about the desperately poor in Vietnam during the 1940s.
Bonedry but deeply involving film about marginal characters in Montevideo, Uruguay
Amazing story of Chinese Maoist operas
movie_title: Yang Ban Xi: The 8 ModelWorks (Yang Ban Xi, de 8 modelwerken) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliant critique of "Napa-ization" of the wine industry.
A remarkable attempt to synthesize science and spirituality
Illuminates the past while providing lessons for today's peace movement. An outstanding documentary.
How young people confronted the Nazis. An inspiration for people struggling against war, arbitrary government and ultranationalism today.
Powerful study of child labor in Bolivia, as well as the role of indigenous beliefs in sustaining the community based on the nearly exhausted silver mines.
Interesting but flawed examination of multinational corporation criminality
A powerful antiwar statement based on historical events

Film constructed of wild coincidences. A throwback to stodgy liberal melodrama of the 1960s like "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner". Says zero about the social and economic realities of LA that breed racism.
Christian propaganda delivered in mildly entertaining vehicle
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Great adaptation of prototypical feminist tale.
An involving tale of semi-redemption in small town Tajikstan.
Urban terrorism inspired by Robin Hood.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A descent into the hell of Bucharest emergency rooms
The "next Quentin Tarantino" crashes and burns
Bittersweet exploration of German-Jewish identity
Beautiful and compassionate tale of nomadic peoples that ranks with the best of Robert Flaherty's documentaries.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Reasonably effective portrayal of gay love, but with the regulation unhappy ending
The first new Woody Allen film I have been able to watch to conclusion in over a decade.
A horrible film bred from the isolation of a man at the top
Anthropomorphic study with brilliant cinematography
Sad story of misplaced trust in nature.
An earnest flop
A brilliant introduction to the music, people and culture of Turkey's great city
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A failure to communicate
Penetrating neorealist study of Angolan orphan in 1991.
Hair-raising gangster movie in the style of John Woo.
Formally elegant depiction of lives of ordinary workers involved with mammoth construction project.
Absolutely powerful indictment of imperialist greed in Sierra Leone. Reveals the hypocrisy of "humanitarian" interventions.
An anti-colonial work that resonates with the struggle in Iraq today.
Gorgeous coming of age tale featuring nonprofessional cast of Mongolian nomads.
Great masterpiece about the first working-class revolution in history.
Effervescent Turkish comedy featuring lovable car thieves.
Dramatization of a moment in the life of legendary Turkish director Yilmaz Guney.
Cinema verite look at the criminal justice system in Brazil. Distinguished by its ability to examine class society without being heavy-handed.
First-rate examination of the anomie of the Turkish educated classes.
Not as bad as The Aviator or Gangs of New York.
Debut film by one of Africa and the world's greatest directors.
Brillian dissection of the rot at the top of British high society and politics.
Absolutely riveting study of boneheaded intervention by James Carville consultants in Bolivian politics. Nearly as grotesque as Woody Allen's "Bananas".
Politics as sporting event run by wonks. Fascinating but repellent in trademark Pennebaker-Hegedus fashion.
Utterly repellent characters; totally implausible narrative. Overhyped project of the year.
A lame attempt at neorealism, hampered by an implausible plotline and warmed over existential motifs.
Wrenchingly powerful documentary on Iraq war veterans' suffering and their political awakening
Funny-man turned politico given the Pennebaker treatment.
Minimalist rendition of Bukowski masterpiece
Simply put, a masterpiece.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Probing documentary on martyred leftists, with lessons for today.
Chilling documentary on the inhumanity of food production, both to man and animal.
A postcolonial film by Africa's greatest director
Courageous effort by Laurie Poitras to tell painful truths about Iraq under occupation
Spinster women are not a very effective symbol of racism and colonialism in Haiti, are they? A better film would have targeted the U.S. Marines.
Heartpounding tale of wronged woman seeking revenge against the handsome gangster who betrayed her.
Penetrating study of the Indian mafia.
An antiwar film dedicated to South and North Korean reconciliation.
A children's film--with a difference.
Bleak but beautiful road movie about two Berber women in Algeria.
movie_title: The Daughter of Keltoum (La Fille de Keltoum) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful tale of African soldiers fighting Nazis and the racism of their French officers.
Brilliant critique of Frankenfood
Scenes of Israeli apartheid
A Brazilian "Scarface"
An outstanding documentary on a scholar-activist
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Love and alienation in the nuclear age
Fast food and the perils of commodification
Coming of age in Argentina
Moving study of a schizophrenic
Turkish minimalist tale about frustrated hopes
Suffering brought on by colonialism documented in stunning documentary
Stirring story of Maori culture
Great stuff.

Unfortunately, the film is disappointing on a number of levels. This is partly the failure of Noyce and his screenwriters to bring out the strengths of Greene's novel; it is also a function of some rather unfortunate aspects of the great writer's work...
Not only one of the finest American films of last year but one that repudiates all the attempts by conservative America to turn back the clock to a desperate and unhappy past.
In addition to political exiles like Dassin, France had been developing home-grown talent for a number of years.
Includes many images that have become part of film iconography.
A film that celebrates the Calibans of India.
movie_title: Lagaan: Once Upon a Time in India (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Its failure to present any kind of historical context ill serves the indigenous African peoples whom Endfield presumes to honor.
It ranks with Ingmar Bergman's filming of an onstage performance of Mozart's The Magic Flute.
It is very good at capturing the genuinely creepy fears that everybody has about being lost in the woods.
There is absolutely nothing in [John Sturges'] background that would suggest he would make such a contrarian film.
Worth seeing as a snapshot of American society at a peculiar juncture in its unfolding as an empire.

Raimi's direction is superb as he captures the bleak and desperate mood of men trapped in a situation which allows them to neither return to their original innocence before discovering the money, nor a successful realization of their criminal dreams.
It is one of the first films of the period to question the cold war even if on an allegorical basis.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)

movie_review_blurb: It is not to be missed.

While one would not expect a film to include the sort of psychological and political analysis of Dostoyevsky's The Possessed, its total absence leaves the viewer with an inability to understand their motivations.
The only thing surprising about Saving Private Ryan is how conventional it is. I fully expected a much more 'noir' vision of WWII along the lines of Oliver Stone's Platoon.
Woman of the Year, with its troubled and ambivalent mood, holds up much better than the flag-waving films that followed it after everybody in Hollywood became fashionably antifascist...
In many ways it is a throwback to the darker vision of a Disney past, when his films had the power to both frighten and enchant.
A masterpiece.
A powerful tale of boarding school repression based on a novel written by a Swede very much in the Stieg Larsson mold.
"Beat" Takeshi adds his own sensibility to classic pop culture icon
A subtle portrait of the Nazi education system
Powerfully realistic film about "mules"
Brutal class realities in contemporary Iran
A small jewel of a film about American Indian spirituality
A murder that helped to launch the civil rights movement
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Anti-imperialist Bollywood winner
Spielberg as Hobbesian; Wells as eugenicist
A zombie insurgency!
Powerful evocation of Great Depression
Grand Guignol comedy
Offbeat film about a cop struggling for self-respect
A masterpiece about a reluctant warrior
Loving tribute to an American original
Kazakh neorealism
Political film short on politics
Rancid politically and artistically
Hitler humanized
Brazilian "Rear Window" with a twist
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Rise and fall of punk rock pioneers
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Probing study of dysfunctional heavy metal band
Operatic neo-realist tale of downtrodden fishermen
Controversial film about art under occupation
Nazi kitsch has parallels with red state values
Pre-Production Code leftist jewel
A film long on drama, short on politics and history
An air-brushed portrait of a repulsive millionaire
The attack of the killer wallpaper
Chagall Martial Arts
Small and big lies
An exciting but reactionary film
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Portrait of the revolutionary as a young man
A masterpiece dealing with woman's liberation
Passive resistance to Nazism effectively dramatized
Muddled liberal Zionist politics. Even worse as a film.
Dystopian take on a world without children that includes pointed to current abuses in the "war on terror" and the xenophobia gripping Great Britain and other countries.
Turgid, overinflated, pseudo-philosophical, bogus radicalism from the Wachowski brothers.
Absolutely eye-popping film noir about an alienated hit-man. Not without a certain musty charm, especially the scene at the Village Gate where a "beatnik" jazz musician sings "Dressed in Black".
First-rate documentary about a screenwriter who stood up to the blacklist and serves as an example of the kind of resistance that is needed today as the government shreds the Constitution.
Searing indictment of how liberal Hollywood turned an aspiring Iraqi filmmaker into a colonized subject. A perfect metaphor for the war in Iraq.
Penetrating study of greed and feudal backwardness in Africa's last absolute monarchy.
Truly artistic documentary about 4 men who led life at the edge and came back from the brink.
Penetrating study of hardened prisoner's discovering their humane essence through training sessions in Buddhism.
Eye-opening study of how China's turbo-charged capitalism leaves something to be desired, especially for the young.
Penetrating study of how the news media allowed themselves to be used as war propagandists in the run-up to the war in Iraq.
Powerful documentary about the struggle of West Virginians against strip-mining practices that has made their water undrinkable and threatened their health all in the name of "progress".
movie_title: Burning the Future: Coal in America (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Emotionally wrenching documentary on 9/11 widows defying xenophobic expectations and devoting themselves to raising money for war widows in Afghanistan.
Magnificent documentary on Orthodox Jewish fighter who balances his faith with a brutal profession and maintains his humanity in the process.
Penetrating study of the dubious benefits of capitalist modernization in China.
Austerely beautiful coming-of-age film set in the Turkish countryside
Marvelous "revisionist" treatment of Rome versus the barbarians. Julius Caesar comes across as a predecessor to George W. Bush and hardly "civilized".
Black comedy about upper-class Koreans being humiliated and worse by countryside thugs in a kind of homage to both Mozart and "Deliverance"!
Hallmark card presentation of the onset of Alzheimer's. Totally sincere and totally unrealistic.
Extremely powerful,unsentimental and bleakly comic story of a brother and sister entering middle age, but not fully adult, coping with their father's dementia and entry into a nursing home.
Incisive study of class relationships between a pauperized would-be aristocratic woman and the maid who is increasingly ready to break free.

Based on an historical incident in which a Nazi firing squad executes 2 deserters. The twist is that the Nazis had already surrendered! The allies gave them permission to carry out the killing because the Nazis were seen as a possible ally against the new

Another "what ever happened to" type documentary. Always fascinating to see how personal flaws and the corrupt star-making machinery of the capitalist entertainment industry present obstacles to fame and fortune.

Despite making Clifford Irving into a grubby suburbanite rather than the mischievous Abby Hoffman figure he really was, the film is generally entertaining a good introduction to the greatest literary hoax of all time.
Powerful study of a young man who killed himself in search of spiritual purity.
Charming documentary on the struggle to keep Yiddish theater alive against all odds, including assimilated Jews' shame at a language associated with victimhood.
Don't believe the hype. The most unsatisfying conclusion to a film since the final episode of "The Sopranos". And that which led up to it wasn't so great either.
Vastly alluring.

Superb documentary on the mystery surrounding the "disappearance" of one of the most highly regarded jazz singers of the 1950s. The director's sleuth work reveals that the criminal is the market place itself.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cut from the same cloth as "The Pelican Brief" and "The Constant Gardener", it is much more of a psychological study than a "whodunit". Clooney is excellent in the leading role.
So-so attempt at revisiting Sleeper. Unfortunately Mike Judge is no Woody Allen, nor is Woody Allen himself nowadays.
Stupidest and most overhyped piece of garbage since "Little Miss Sunshine"
A study of the malaise of corporate culture in modern Germany with an unsatisfying ending. Up until the conclusion, it is quite rewarding.
A docudrama that is focused on Daniel Pearl's wife. While interesting in its own way, it does not begin to reflect on who Daniel Pearl really was or why he died.

Pretentious nonsense cut from the same cloth as "Crash" and "Babel". Filled to the brim with unbelievable coincidences and liberal pieties. Just the sort of thing that makes film festival panels salivate apparently.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Stunning portrait of caste oppression in South India, as well as the struggle of a young woman from the lower caste's to elevate herself through dance.
A morality tale about the sewer politics of the Republican Party since Reagan and very relevant to the 2008 elections.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Movie does not try to turn elderly speedster Burt Munro into melodrama but simply allows his astounding achievements to speak for themselves.
A combination of Alexander Medvedkin's negelected satiric masterpiece and a loving tribute to the film-maker by his life-long friend Chris Marker, who is a last Bolshevik in his own right.
Poignant coming of age movie about a ten year old boy and his father, an Auschwitz survivor.
Deeply affecting documentary about Israeli injustices toward West Bank farmers.
Outstanding documentary on the theft and destruction of European masterpieces up to and during WWII.
Searing portrait of immigrant life in Vancouver, Canada. Fully developed characters interact against a backdrop of frustrated political ideals.
Simply brilliant film-making for less than $5000. For anybody the least bit curious about China today and who has a taste for sophisticated comedy, this is not to be missed.
movie_title: Bei yazi de nanhai (Taking Father Home) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating documentary study of the lives of Afro-Brazilians who are descendants of the first successful slave revolt in the Western Hemisphere. Filled with gorgeous music and dance as well as eye-opening social commentary.

Absolutely stunning mixture of the personal story of a disillusioned Catholic priest and the sordid Christian history that drove him to cut his ties--all the while remaining deeply committed to the ethical vision of Jesus.
Second installment in Yamada's samurai trilogy. Once again the hero is unlike the super-warriors of the genre, but far more interesting.
Final installment in samurai trilogy that features a blind swordsman in an utterly distinct fashion from the Zatoichi movies--a far more vulnerable and far more believable hero.
A surprisingly relevant movie on academic freedom in light of Ward Churchill and pro-Palestinian professors being victimized today.
An intimate film about the artistic and social visions of one of Brazil's most respected singers.
movie_title: Maria Bethania: Music is Perfume (Maria Bethania: Musica e Perfume) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A wondrous trip with Africa's greatest singer as he bonds with his musical brethren in the New World.
A terrific film noir directed by the great Fred Zinnemann. Reflects growing disillusionment with American society linked to the emerging Cold War.
Gripping "road movie" featuring two remarkably well-developed 12 year old characters played consummately by two gifted child actors. Set against backdrop of infamous Tokyo subway sarin massacre cult.
Invites comparisons with "Brokeback Mountain", but this $100,000 Korean film is far better in every respect. Not to be missed.

Superb study of one of America's greatest jazz singers who lived to perform. The movie is a labor of love co-directed by her manager from the last 6 years of his life and a reminder that movies come alive when there is passion rather than money in the dri
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A movie filled with unintentional humor. Enjoyable in its cartoonish way like R. Crumb's hippies.
Totally uplifting film about a factory worker who became America's most respected topiary artist.
Documentary about a billion dollar military training center that simulates Iraqi villages in the middle of the Mohave Desert. About as much of a testimony to the folly of man as the Tower of Babel.
There are worse ways to spend an evening at a movie theater than this movie that is far better with sight gags than character development, plot or dialog.
As others have reported, this is a very inspiring film. However, it does raise troubling questions about the source of Africa's misery and how it will be ended.
movie_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Borrowing (stealing, actually) from "Star Wars", this is classic midnight movie fun. Don't miss it!
movie_title: Dünyayi kurtaran adam (The Man Who Saves the World) (Turkish Star Wars) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, funny rip-off of Texas Chainsaw Massacre that does not take itself too seriously and that is loads of fun.
First-rate "revisionist" study of great conqueror reviled by the "civilized" West. By comparison, most world's leaders are the true barbarians, especially those in Washington, DC.
A perfect jewel of a movie made by young directors who understand that social conscience is the handmaiden of all great art.
Excellent documentary about the struggle of a heavy metal band to survive in Iraq.
Totally winning documentary that can best be described as the Congolese version of "Buena Vista Social Club". A loving portrait of the reemergence of an 83 year old master musician.
Fascinating portrait of a decadent aristocrat with a flair for the beautiful.
Astonishing introduction to the Iraqi insurgents who explain why they resist occupation--a film that is a must for anybody trying to understand why the war continues to this day.
Excellent music, inspiring story of an orchestra of immigrants in Rome, who were brought together as a challenge to xenophobia.
Powerful documentary about the struggle of gay and lesbian orthodox Jews to reconcile their beliefs and their desires
Minimalist treatment of the lives of poor migrant workers in Malaysia, done with a Bressonian sensibility.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Totally appealing documentary on aspiring theatrical performers at summer camp.
Kurds feuding with Turks in the streets of Germany. Reminiscent of "Los Olvidados" or "Pixote". Grim but rewarding.
Powerful tale that unfortunately fails to provide any kind of real historical context for the oppression of Indian widows.
An uncommonly perceptive look at the counter-culture and the difficulties of preserving a sense of freedom and integrity in American society.
A throwback to the uncensored "Godzilla," a anti-American broadside with a scary monster and off-kilter humor. What more can you ask for in a movie?
Bitter recollections of Argentina's ill-fated attempt to win control of the Malvinas from Great Britain.
movie_title: Blessed by Fire (Iluminados por el fuego) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its cold war orientation, a valuable introduction to one of the last century's great composers filled with stunning images of a bygone era.
Not as good as the HBO show. Dumbed down by Larry Charles?
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Well-researched, hair-raising investigation of capitalist thievery in Iraq at the expense of the American tax-payer, the GI's and the Iraqi people.
movie_title: Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A dramatic interpretation of the Irish war of independence that is relevant to today's world. The lesson is that unless you confront the rich at home and abroad, true freedom will not be achieved.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An absolute masterpiece. Combines political commentary, human drama and great visual art into a single compelling package.
A view of Tibet that differs from Richard Gere's deification of the Dalai Lama and "Lost Horizon". Highly recommended portrait of Buddhist monk who evolved into a revolutionary.
Almost as scary as "Village of the Damned". 12 year olds who aspire to be the next James Dobson!

Sanitized version of the career and life of William Wilberforce, who thought that the uncouth behavior of slaves was a greater sin than slavery itself. Pure hagiography and an assault on the historical record.
Final installment in a trilogy about Copenhagen drug dealers. Sardonic comedy in the "Goodfellas" vein.
movie_title: Pusher III: I'm the Angel of Death (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Second in a trilogy about Copenhagen drug dealers. Sardonic comedy in the "Goodfellas" vein.
movie_title: Pusher II: With Blood On My Hands (2004)

movie_review_blurb: First in a series of 3 films about Copenhagen drug dealers. Sardonic comedy in the "Goodfellas" vein.
Life and death among the working poor. Critics hated it because it lacked entertainment value. That's more of a condemnation of them than the film.
Kafkaesque story of man who shaves trademark moustache. Afterwards everybody--wife included--insists that he has never had one!
Clash of characters in love set against a clash of civilizations.
Despite a limited understanding of why genocide occurs, a worthwhile introduction to one of the 20th century's greatest crimes.
An imaginary garden with real toads.
More interesting as historical document than as film. Helps us understand the nature of Dutch xenophobia.
Documentary about the horrors of occupying a foreign country. Especially well worth watching now.
movie_title: The Sorrow and the Pity (Le Chagrin et la Pitié) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Stirring documentary about an unlikely politician, one who puts principles above personal gain.
Highly recommended even if Al Gore is incapable of getting at the root cause of global warming.
Nifty action flick influenced by Hong Kong cinema that includes a critique of French racism against immigrant community.
Deeply affecting tale of the slaughter of Sikhs in 1984.
Deeply affecting tale of early onset of Alzheimer's. "Salaryman" undermined by loss of control and identity, especially painful for a society that revolves around such values.
Fascinating look back at the 1967 war which created the conditions that have led to suicide bombs, 9/11 and other terrorist forms of retaliation against Zionist domination.
Joins "The Fast Runner" and "The Story of the Weeping Camel" as a fascinating glimpse into the daily lives of indigenous peoples.
Although Verhoeven's plot seems far-fetched at times, it is based on actual history and casts doubt on the "Good War" mythology of films like "Saving Private Ryan".
A horror movie about the consequences of global warming. Set in the Alaskan Wildlife Natural Reserve, the oil company is far scarier than the monsters that attack the movie's main characters.
Stunning study of post-Katrina survivors trying to adapt to a racist Utah. Evokes Lost Boys of the Sudan.
A stunning documentary that combines elements of An Inconvenient Truth and Vernon, Florida.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Terrific comic re-imagining of Paddy Chayefsky's "Marty". Garlin is a complete genius.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Excellent portrait of a tragic figure, who tried to defend the interests of working people while stopping short of abolishing the system that is responsible for their suffering.
A real breakthrough for Moore. Combines his customary wit with a real respect for his characters.
Story of a devout Zulu Christian who makes a pilgrimage to Israel, only to discover that it is more like hell than heaven.
A Ken Loach masterpiece. Deals with poverty-stricken Irish Catholic's struggle to raise money for his daughter's communion dress.
A sheer masterpiece. Sustains tension throughout between disgust and affection for the most repulsive of animals.

Sensitive study of the journey taken by Primo Levi in the immediate aftermath of WWII. Mixes his own words with ordinary people whose lives have been turned upside down by the end of the USSR and Eastern European socialism. Makes subtle political points t

Besides its health care system, Canada has other charms including the rights of gays to marry, enlightened drug laws and a haven for GI's refusing to fight in Iraq. That's the case made by this entertaining documentary
Excellent introduction to the life and career of the world's greatest composer who enjoyed an uneasy relationship with his aristocratic patrons.
Superlative documentary about 28 members of the Catholic left who defied the war machine in 1971--with plenty of relevance to the contemporary struggle to end the war in Iraq.
An absolutely heart-warming film that Hollywood cannot produce nowadays. Fortunately there is Bollywood! Don't miss this movie of the year.
A pastoral romance based on an earlier version of Lawrence's novel that is softer and can stand on its own terms, despite lacking the class distinctions that would distinguish the final version.
A North Korean version of films like "Hoop Dreams". Humanizes a people who are considered outside of humanity in the West.
Profile of the last American GI defector in North Korea. Fascinating!
A documentary that rues the fact that the US was not able to impose its will on the Iraqi people, but never questions the right to do so.
Superb documentary on gypsy musicians in the spirit of "Buena Vista Social Club"
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful drama about a legendary rock musician's battle with schizophrenia and a chance at a new life.

Alain Resnais deals with the impact of the war in Algeria on a French veteran. Although the surrealist touches seem dated, the issues of war and torture are not--especially in light of the current war in Iraq.
movie_title: Muriel ou Le Temps d'un Retour (The Time of Return) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: Surrealist curiosity directed by Robbe-Grillet. Has the effect overall of a Ridley Scott Chanel commercial. Will certainly hold one's attention even if the plot is incomprehensible.
Chabrol film based on true life incident, the investigation of crooked executives at Elf Aquitaine, the French version of Enron. Isabelle Huppert is terrific starring as chief magistrate.
Chabrol film about a teenage prostitute who kills her parents, based on real-life story. Mostly interesting for its atmosphere and for Huppert's acting.
French version of upscale cop shows like NYPD Blue or The Wire.
Pretentious, murky and pointless study about a serial killer/puppeteer and two women who follow him around the French countryside.
Terrific documentary on the animal rights movement that allows all sides in the debate to make their points.
A German film strongly influenced by the Dardenne brothers. Using nonprofessionals in a naturalistic setting, it tells about the consequences of "careless love".
A documentary about the penalties paid for hyper-growth in China. Highly recommended.
Sharp appraisal of fetus fetishists.
movie_title: Unborn in the USA: Inside the War on Abortion (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Put succinctly, this is the greatest film ever made dealing with the connection between art and radical politics.
First they came for the dolphins, then they came for the honeybees; now they come for the songbirds. Unless we stand up for all of them, we are next.

Although the film might serve as a portrait of Iran's two conflicting social groups as reflected in the Green movement/Ahmadinejad clashes, it is much more about moral contradictions that any society has to face. A masterpiece.
A brilliant take onthe hypergentrification that made funky old Chelsea the hq of buildings that now have individual swimming pools in apartments like a Scrooge McDuck comic book from the 50s.
Astonishingly perceptive take on what it means to be a victim of capitalist progress. An amazingly political film from a director who has not made such a film in the past. Not to be missed.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A vastly entertaining documentary about the underground drag racing scene in Cuba that is also about as informative a take on the social and economic reforms being pushed by Raul Castro as you can find anywhere.
A philosopher best known for the "banality of evil" comment about Eichmann who deserves to be understood in her full depth. This film helps flesh her out.
movie_title: Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An amiable enough movie although it has about as much to do with the real Chet Baker as "Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Killer" has to do with our 16th President.
A joyous mix of social history and musicology.
Another demonstration of Farhadi's ability to diagnose his country's ills through the microcosm of the family drama.

Despite being in the now popular Israeli hand-wringing genre, one that doesn't envision ending the Zionist system that makes IDF soldiers et al feel soul-sick, this is worth seeing for its honesty and germaneness to current Israeli horrors.
Whoever could have dreamed that economics could be so much fun? I guess that goes with the territory when it is explained by people of the left in a film in the Monty Python tradition.
Want to have a vicarious experience on how great it was to be a 60s rebel? This is the film to see.
Beautiful music and a good introduction to the complexity of Malian/Tuareg politics.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from a certain reductionism with respect to the jihadists but then again that is to be expected in an epoch when Islam is a dirty word almost universally. Could have been better but still worth seeing.

Tightly coiled drama of swimming instructor falsely accused of molesting a boy. Thematically related to "The Hunt" but more in common with the theater than the typical film. All in all, a gripping tale.
movie_title: The Virus of Fear (El virus de la por) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the title, not at all a "fan" tribute to a group that like so many others in the mad 1960s imploded through a combination of state repression and its own ineptitude
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: More educational than all the seminars you can take at place at NYU or UCLA over a decade put together.
A subtly political film about the hopes and frustrations of ordinary Chinese citizens that is as dramatic in its own odd way as a kung-fu costume drama.
A film about a climb more daredevilish than Philippe Petit's tightrope walk. Brilliantly filmed by the climbers who are as good at cinema as in climbing up the face of a mountain.
Fascinating in a voyeuristic way. A demonstration beyond doubt that celebrity is as life-threatening as the bite of a Black Mamba.
Like "Boyhood", this film tracks a character for 14 years. Unlike "Boyhood", it is actually compelling cinema.
Quickly paced and surprisingly entertaining, this is a film for anybody who cares about the abuse of political power by the superrich. In other words, everybody but the one percent.
Like "Key Largo", this is in effect a staged play with an ensemble cast taking refuge from a storm but Quentin Tarantino is no Maxwell Anderson.
Much more of a survival film than a revenge one--and a spectacular one at that. Like "All is Lost", another in this genre, there's not much dialog. None is needed.

Todd Haynes is a director born to make Highsmith's novel about lesbian love ending happily. A masterpiece that is even a better adaptation than Hitchcock's "Strangers on a Train", another Highsmith novel.

Like most documentaries about the Mexican drug wars, this has nothing to say about the social and political context. It is meant for visceral entertainment and as such reflects the aesthetic of Kathryn Bigelow--the executive producer.

With a number of flaws, especially any explanation of the backgrounds of the adults who produced the musical or what the musical was about, it is redeemed by the human interest of Hong Kong's "troubled" teens.
A painterly historical drama that is emotionally sterile. Grab it if you are more interested in cinematic composition than story.
A plot similar to "Dog Day Afternoon" with the comic sensibility of Nathaniel West. What's not to like?

Simply the best film Spielberg has made in decades. Avoids the sentimentality of most--perhaps because of the inclusion of the Coen brothers in the screenwriting team. Their best work in a decade as well for that matter.
Marred by its failure to make up its mind whether to tell a tale of victimology or resistance, it is redeemed by its performances and general panache.
Totally brilliant. Like an episode of "The Walking Dead" directed by Akira Kurosawa or Sam Peckinpah.
More in common with the French New Wave than Italian neorealism, this is a film that both celebrates and sheds tears over gansta life. It is the French version of "New Jack City" in some ways.
Mesmerizing documentary on an artist who is both modern and very old-fashioned in his painterly approach.

Steve Hoover took considerable risks in making a film about a pastor who takes his Christianity seriously. If we had more directors and pastors like these two, the world would be in a lot better shape.
In the 60s the left used to refer to the cops as an occupying army. This fine documentary shows how reality has caught up with the rhetoric.
Ken Loach at his very best. It might be subtitled "Why Jeremy Corbyn became Labour leader". Succeeds as social commentary and as the story of an individual.
Pay no attention to the "rottens". This is an outstanding film by the Dardennes about the difficulties of living a moral life under capitalism.
A model of scientific insight, story-telling and cinematic panache that reminds us that the future of life under capitalism is guarded at best.

Although in many ways an unrealizable project, Menachem Daum's attempt at reconciliation with Palestinians is a reminder that Jewish ethics is not necessarily a contradiction in terms when it comes to Israel.
A reminder of how documentary filmmakers are using the videocamera in the same way that earlier generation of revolutionaries used the printing press. BRAVO!
movie_title: Southwest of Salem: The Story of the San Antonio Four (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pay no attention to the "rottens". This is vintage Oliver Stone and powerful story-telling about a true American hero.
A close call with a gargantuan catastrophe and a risk that still exists as long as nuclear weapons exist.

A fascinating examination of the role of radical artist in bourgeois society that prioritizes the drama of an individual rather than the social drama of a crackdown that anticipated Pinochet. Despite that, it is great filmmaking.
A poignant tale of a mass exodus that will certainly relate to today's tragedy, even if some shallow film critics can't make that connection.
A film that explains the Arab Spring better than any documentary. My pick for the best foreign film of 2016 for now. I doubt that anything will surpass it.
movie_title: As I Open My Eyes (À peine j'ouvre les yeux) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While rescuing Jews has been the subject of a number of fictional films, it takes a documentary to do justice to the decency of Waitstill and Martha Sharp.
movie_title: Defying the Nazis: The Sharps' War (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While "inspiring" is a hackneyed term in film reviews, in this case it really applies.
Does for the attack on public universities what Charles Ferguson's "Inside Job" did for (or against) Wall Street chicanery in 2010. An exemplary film.
A black comedy of the sort that Quentin Tarantino made before he burned out. "Pulp Fiction" with a Norwegian accent.
A quiet and subdued family drama about the struggle of Algerian immigrants to make a life in France today, a film that is ever so timely in light of the Islamophobia gripping the country.

Evocative of "Hoop Dreams" but much more about the hopes of becoming rich rather than escaping poverty. Good story-telling and very perceptive about the corporatization of high school basketball programs.

This is the definitive documentary on the big business of amateur sports covering NCAA exploitation, the risks of CTE and the general slave-like conditions of the gladiators who generate obscene profits for places like USC.
Absorbing documentary on the erosion of abortion rights that leads to interrogation of how this could happen with a White House verbally committed to such rights.
A documentary that is far more frighteningly dystopian than any Mad Max movie because it is real.
A selection from 24 films by an outstanding cameraperson and human being. With all due respect to Shelly, it is documentarians who are "the unacknowledged legislators of the world".

Werner Herzog is always in search of the obsessed oddball, either a German-American inspired to become a pilot after seeing allied bombers destroying his village or now computer engineers. There is only one Werner Herzog, god bless him.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The definitive look at the nuclear power industry focused on a plant that conceivably lead to a disaster greater than Fukushima..
A remarkably intelligent case for the humane treatment of farm animals only marred by the inclusion of Whole Foods CEO who exploits prison labor for products in his grocery stores.
A wonderful mash-up of "Easy Rider" and John Hughes teen comedies done in neo-New Wave style and completely irresistible.

Brilliant film-making combined with historical accuracy. Pay no attention to the "Rotten" reviews here. As someone who has written 25 articles on the Civil War, I consider this the final word on racism's vicious legacy and how good men fought it.
Powerful melodrama that combines "Thelma and Louise" with Bollywood conventions.
Sick of art as commodity, with sharks in formaldehyde tanks? This is the film for you. (Ignore the Village Voice review since this worthless newspaper is part of the problem, not the solution.)

A powerful look at the psychological and mortal consequences of the Vietnam war on two GI's from privileged families that benefits from the testimony of uniquely self-aware and articulate men and women.
Much better on human drama than social history with some unfortunate anti-Communist cliches. Above all, a powerful cinematic undertaking by a young director/screenwriter.
Surprise-surprise. Young boys and girls become Islamic fundamentalists in order to get a meal and a roof over their head. The answer is not Predator drones but ending inequality.
An enthralling tale adapted to the screen by a director whose work mostly deals with contemporary issues--a testament to Hardy's continuing appeal.
A reminder that films can reach the level of art on rare occasions. This is a tour de force of script, performance and cinematography that will stay with you for years.
Marred by a refusal to deal with politics (possibly a function of the novel it is based on), it is a moving story about the toll that the Cultural Revolution exacted on a family.
Given the racist hatred toward Latino immigrants, this is a film that will help increase much needed solidarity as well as deliver a powerful dramatic tale that succeeds in cinematic terms.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Gibney has a really great ability to consider the contradictions that made up Steve Jobs, a thorough scumbag who had an artist's flair for technology.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The critics screwed up on this. It is a much better film than its rating here. Take that from someone who worked in IT for 44 years and who knows the difference between "fresh" and "rotten".
A bold work of art featuring a domestic servant that leaves films such as "The Butler" in the dust.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful examination by a gay Muslim about the conflict between sexual identity and spirituality, reminiscent in many ways of "Trembling before G-D", the documentary about Jews similarly conflicted

In the new "scramble for Africa", the Africans are losers once again. The hypocrisy of Christian missionaries and UN officials are exposed by allowing them to hoist themselves on their own petards. A brilliant documentary for the ages.
A fascinating study of how Black culture influenced if not made possible an art form commonly understood as distinctly European. And all the while illustrated by great music!
movie_title: Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful first-hand testimony from British miners on how their defeat led inevitably to the rise of the one percent. From Thatcher to Reagan, we are still paying the price.
A brilliant combination of pop music history and geopolitical analysis. It arrives on VOD platforms (IMovie, Amazon, etc.) on August 4, 2015--not to be missed.
movie_title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock And Roll (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A very fine screenplay based on a novel written by a neuroscience researcher with a PhD from Harvard who obviously knew the territory, including the life-style of its mandarin lead character toppled by Alzheimers.
While nominally a cops and robber film, it often seems inspired by Buster Keaton and Hitchcock's "The Trouble with Harry". A brilliant and hilarious genre-bending delight.
Powerful drama serving to illustrate the Kafkaesque and repressive nature of the Indian judicial system. The film might have easily been called "Kangaroo Court".
A fine piece of investigative reporting about the incestuous relationship between companies like Monsanto and the government agencies that supposedly are for protecting society rather than profits.
A little too reluctant to take a stand against chemicals but worth seeing for its empathy for its main character who is forced to carry out a crime that puts her in league with Monsanto.
In what amounts to pantomime, the actors convey more psychologically and reveal more about their characters than 99 percent of the films coming out of Hollywood today. Bravo!
Like "Catch 22" or "Mash", an absurdist comedy about the tragedy inflicted on Palestinian people when a tiny dairy farm became a "security risk".
Faster and louder than the original but lacking in the character development and wit. If you enjoy a dinosaur making a meal out of men in 3D ad infinitum ad nauseam, be my guest.
David Gulipil is Australia's gift to great film as always--in the latest he is also co-author of the screenplay that renders white injustice vividly, evoking Ferguson, Missouri.
A precipitous decline from "Beyond Thunderdome".
Probing examination of the art, life and activism of a seminal figure in the American environmentalist movement.
Beguiling tale of three young Palestinian women with a love for fast cars trying to hone their skills under conditions of occupation and insecurity.
Amazing story about the militarization of the police that connects white bread Utah with Black Lives Matter. Documentary filmmaking at its best.
If design is a fine art (YSL was the subject of a Met show), then this is a designer's "Lust for Life".
Covers some of the same ground as "Gaslandia" but is remarkable for its coverage of how ordinary citizens are resisting fracking.
movie_title: Groundswell Rising, Protecting Our Children's Air and Water (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film demonstrates how a scientific understanding of global warming is an imperative to take action in order to save ourselves as well as the sea creatures the director loves so much.
Dispenses with the romanticized version of the mafia in American films and depicts the reality most Italians know: pointless violence and greed that eats away at society.
Film defies conventional expectations about biblical notions of retribution, even as it initially prepares you to accept them. A truly complex work of art.
A drama about guilt and responsibility set against the backdrop of male domination in Iranian society that even affects the secular and well-educated milieu depicted in this gripping drama.

The hostility directed to this immensely powerful film by RT critics is probably a function of writing for the commercial press that prefers Adam Sandler junk. For those with a heart, this is not to be missed.
