A curious mixture of Thomas Mann's "Magic Mountain" and Fellini. Despite its grim topic, the so-called "mortality zone' as Tom Brokaw put it, it is a drily comic masterwork.
The voice of the underdog finally finds a cinematic voice in corrupt, class-divided Russia.
A very modest film having much in common with the after-school Disney TV shows about kids and geared to kids. If you have kids that play chess, they'll enjoy this.
While it is short on analysis, it is excellent as entertainment and of some use for your friends or relatives who still think that capitalism is a viable system.

Like the USA, Romania is haunted by the slavery of the 19th century. The Roma, like the Africans, were less than human in the eyes of those above them, even when they too were seen as dirt by the ruling classes.
As film, it is not up to the standards of "Orlando", another film dealing with sexual ambiguity in early Europe but the story it tells is of such interest that it demands to be seen.
A thrilling action drama, not about CIA agents or Mafia gangsters, but about bird lovers putting their lives on the line to prevent poachers from "emptying the skies".
A chilling exploration of the toxic underpinnings of the word "fragrance" that appears on detergents and colognes alike.
A brilliant dissection of high technology deployed on behalf of barbaric goals.
A film that shows the social costs of the war on drugs, a campaign that is as futile as the war on terror with three compelling main subjects.

Four heroic photojournalists are the subjects of a film that shows both the daily realities of Afghanistan and its endurance under the Taliban that banned not only advocacy photos but wedding photos as well.
Very fine documentary in the spirit of Studs Terkel's "Working".
Superb dissection of class and race contradictions in a society that is falling apart at the seams.
Both topically and dramatically, this is a film that matters more than most when immigration has reached an explosive status with people fleeing misery being blamed for the Paris terrorist attack.
Although somewhat limited by the cinéma vérité framework, this is a fascinating study of two men on the opposite of the barricades searching for a common ground.
Moore is as engaging as ever but the film's message is nonsense. It is more likely that France will become more like the USA than the other way around. That is how capitalism works, after all.
How Pakistan's master musicians created a hybrid of their own style and tunes like "Take Five", which turns out to be joined at the hip to their own traditions.
Frederick Wiseman, now 85, has made a politically engaged film about people confronting the gentrification that is robbing NY of its soul. Great work by our greatest documentary filmmaker.
Ignore the "rotten" reviews here, at least if you are looking for superlative filmmaking combined with a timely message about how the rich and the reactionary combined to silence free speech.
A superb introduction to the career of the father of African cinema as well as a commentary on the problems of postcolonial Africa.
An offbeat experimental film that mixes Spalding Gray type monologue, California history and film history. It starts off on a languid note but grows on you.
A reminder of how documentaries are becoming the sole repository of authentic human drama in an era of escapist dreck.
A penetrating look at how offshore tax havens in places like the Cayman Islands operate as a key neoliberal institution.
A stunning combination of art and politics. My pick for best documentary of 2015 and probably of the past decade.
movie_title: The Pearl Button (El botón de nácar) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A prophetic call for action against capitalist waste of natural resources, as well as some stunningly beautiful vistas above and below the ocean. It took six years to make the film and it shows.
As long as you accept that this film is fiction and that its view of Shirley Clarke and Carl Lee is hateful, it is still worth seeing for its performances and bold if repellent POV.
There have been documentaries in the past about FBI entrapment but none featuring an entrapper and entrapped. An amazing breakthrough and chilling drama.
Looking for a film in which the drama rests on fighting over whether the original Macintosh will say hello over the machine's speaker? Then this is for you.
Gets the street fighting and the voices of the participants right but little else. Ukraine still needs a documentary that includes scholarly experts as well as footage of fighting on the barricades.
movie_title: Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Oddly enough, a plot similar to "Mad Max: Fury Road" but a million times more interesting--and by a first-time director, no less.
Despite the modesty of means, the accomplishment is Olympian. Great as film and even greater as political protest.
The finest movie ever made about the game of chess as well as a deeply perceptive take on the brutal conditions indigenous peoples face in New Zealand.
Stick to the HBO documentary. The film is accurate to the historical events but ironically the documentary has more drama than the fictional treatment.
A "Salt of the Earth" for 2015 with a bagel shop instead of a zinc mine serving as the terrain of struggle. "The Hand that Feeds" could not be better--a masterpiece.
Everything you ever wanted to know about the fastest growing spectator sport with fighters who despite the violence of their craft are smart, articulate and likable. Highly recommended.
Finally a film about slavery by an American director that is the artistic and political peer to Gillo Pontecorvo's "Burn".
Ms. Wells is 10 times funnier and smarter than Louis CK. Her film is a reminder of what a crime sexism is. It not only harms women, it prevents the real cream from rising to the surface.

Comparable to "Manhattan" in its use of black-and-white and the bad character of the men who made the films, "I Love You, Daddy" is an inferior film. But then again, so everything Allen made after "Manhattan".
The film both makes a compelling case for abolishing football as well as explaining why it was so beloved by the players whose brains it was destroying. First-rate.
A story similar to "The Shining" but much scarier because it is true.
A film so necessary when Muslims and other non-Ayran peoples are being demonized by white supremacists like Donald Trump for the crime of trying to flee war and economic disaster.
A typically mind-boggling tour de force from Miike that echoes both "True Grit" and "The Wolfman".
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and thought-provoking documentary about Jane Goodall despite questionable attempts to link chimpanzee violence to the warfare of organized capitalist society.
Deeply involving story of 3 Hasidic Jews who break away from a sect that provided both support and frustration. My choice for best documentary of 2017.
A ponderous film that contains the Michael Bay esthetic beneath a thin veneer of faux feminism.

Consistent with the latest generation of these Boulle-based films that started in 2011, it examines the question of who is bestial. Man or ape? It answers the question with an intelligence not often found in Hollywood blockbusters.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A vivid portrait of the archetypical New York hoarder as well as a glimpse into Brooklyn's insular orthodox community, all the more remarkable given the gentile identity of the directors.

Unlike "Psycho" or "Shutter Island", a realistic and moving depiction of the life of a schizophrenic. It not only succeeds as drama but as a social statement badly needed to educate a public so used to stigmatizing those who are ill.

Not just a story of survival, it is a statement about the values of a family that were not only considered anathema to the Nazis but to the alt-right of today. In many ways, this is the most powerful anti-fascist film you will see this or any other year.

Convincing evidence that the Koch brothers should be put in prison for the rest of their sorry lives. What is the difference between putting arsenic in someone's food or toxins in their water? Not much, actually.
Penetrating and complex study of the relationship between trophy hunters, the game they pursue, and a pact with the devil that might protect Africa's endangered species.
Existential drama about a one-time radical now settled into a middle-class life-style being summoned to carry out a selfless task that might destroy everything he treasures, including his life.
movie_title: The Long Night of Francisco Sanctis (La larga noche de Francisco Sanctis) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Worth watching as a compilation of the great singer's songs but even more worth watching as social history from the heyday of the civil rights movement to Black Power to the end of apartheid.
This loving tribute to a saintly Austin recording studio owner is also a searing examination of the dubious benefits of streaming services like Spotify.
A fantastically entertaining movie even if you--unlike me--never had the pleasure (and frustration) of using a manual typewriter.
Sensitive study of the activists in Ferguson who helped launch an urgently needed new civil rights movement, especially with a racist President determined to permit cops to kill with impunity.
Brilliant synthesis of film noir and political analysis of the fetid core of Egyptian bourgeois society.
A timely reminder that the South Korean state could act as brutally as the demonized regime to the North.
Starts out like "Super Size Me" and then turns into an investigation of Russian use of PED's and a much more interesting film.

In 25 years of reviewing documentaries, this is the most powerful work on labor exploitation I have ever seen. It brings Marxist theory to life with a remarkable compassion. Brilliant in all respects.
A powerful documentary that reveals how much Iditarod and Michael Vick have in common.
A stunning achievement in every sense. The film stands on its own as family drama but beyond that is a profoundly sensitive look at an orthodox society that is facing challenges from within.

A portrait of a young man who never expected to serve life in prison for a first-time drug offense and whose true-life escape from a Turkish prison was dramatized effectively by Oliver Stone but with a needless demonization of the Turks.
movie_title: Midnight Return: The Story of Billy Hayes and Turkey (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Compelling story of how a Soviet satellite stood up for its national dignity during the depths of the Cold War but without anti-Communist cliches.
The urgency of this problem requires people to become informed about the issues, starting with seeing the film either at the IFC or on Netflix.
Mesmerizing tale of a professional strongman as well as a fascinating examination of the powers of the mind as well as the body.

A timely reminder that as the city of Raqqa is being bombed mercilessly by the USA, it was never reconciled to ISIS rule. Ordinary Syrians were confronted by fascists in beards and fascists in neckties. Down with fascism.
Kaurismaki continues to make the case for immigrants using his characteristically deadpan humor. Superb.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Outstanding both as neo-film noir and as penetrating examination of class relations in Egypt that help explain the continuation of capitalist oligarchic rule.
A celebration of the life of the most important film critic of the past 50 years, a man of the people as well as a film connoisseur.

Like fellow German Werner Herzog, Fatih Akin is as adept in documentary film as narrative. Also, like Herzog, he a humanist. This film pits the salt of the earth against a bureaucratic environmental nightmare in a small town where his ancestors lived.
movie_title: Garbage in the Garden of Eden (Müll im Garten Eden) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The young director of this documentary did not allow her politics to color her altogether stunning portrait of a Serb who volunteered his lethal skills for the problematic Donetsk Republic.
If you are a political person concerned about economic inequality and ecological ruin, this film is a must. Forget about the bumbling critics who panned this film. They deserve Adam Sandler.
movie_title: The Young Karl Marx (Le jeune Karl Marx) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliant use of animation to put the spotlight on Iran's social contradictions using film noir conventions adroitly. Not to be missed.
This is a brilliant combination of ethnomusicology and history enhanced by superlative performances.
movie_title: Gurumbe. Afro-Andalusian Memories (Gurumbé. Canciones de tu memoria neg (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A critical look at Palm Springs. Beneath the glitz is a cautionary tale about environmental despoliation and genocide against native peoples.

The latest in a series of documentaries taking up the cause of Chinese workers that incorporates the socialist outlook that the state has abandoned even as it continues to pay lip-service to Karl Marx.
An elegiac look back at 1968 when students challenged the status quo across the planet and a reminder of how much we have lost since the return to bourgeois normalcy.
movie_title: In the Intense Now (No Intenso Agora) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Deeply informed documentary that puts Pussy Riot into the context of the Russian avant-garde that is rooted in "Actionism".
In a period where nuclear holocaust is threatened over North Korea, a nuanced film such as this is essential.
Rick Alverson's breakthrough film about a bitter, aging stand-up comedian who is a character that Nathaniel West might have conceived.
A searing study of an aging hipster who encapsulates the misanthropy popular culture's notion of what it means to be funny.
Deep insights into what Marx called "the opiate of the people" from America's most interesting indie director.
Debut film of America's most interesting indie filmmaker that zeroes in on the dashed hopes of an Irish immigrant.
Arguably the most politically engaged artist of the post-WWII period, Beuys is well-served by this documentary.

Rotten much more for the politics than for the narrative skill. I'd advise waiting for it to show up on HBO, especially if you understand civil war in terms of social conflict rather than as a Hatfield-McCoy feud.
A neo-realist tale with a soupcon of magical realism that is totally irresistible.
A beautiful and inspiring film that shows how the struggle against patriarchy is taking place everywhere.
Forget about Russian interference. The real culprit was a reclusive rightwing billionaire named Robert Mercer who is to Donald Trump that Howard Hughes was to Nixon.
Brilliant satire on the art world focused on the pretentious, Whitney Museum milieu in Sweden. A morality tale mixed with sketches that put SNL to shame.
Noah Baumbach's spleen is directed at the second-rate pretending that they are first-rate. This is called "punching down" and in line with America's degraded values.
Noah Baumbach's spleen is directed at the second-rate pretending that they are first-rate. This is called "punching down" and in line with America's degraded values.
A film ignorant of Indian history and filled with laughably improbable reconciliations.
A ponderous policier that posits white saviors of native peoples for the umpteenth time. Except for the landscape photography, utterly forgettable.
Surprisingly willing to confront the incestuous ties between the Washington Post's executives and the national security state.
Film has an urgent mission given the rise of the neo-Nazi AfD in Germany. It is also dramatically compelling and deserving of a much higher rating here.
Except for the make-up job on Oldman, not much to write home about--least of all the idea that Churchill was defending "Western Civilization" against the brutes. Tell that to the Indians and Kenyans.
Artistically disjointed and historically unfactual, just the latest in a series of vastly overrated Christopher Nolan films.
A penetrating study of the dry rot at the heart of capitalist society. Haneke at his best.
Another work of genius from one of America's outstanding directors and social critics.

Succeeds both as entertainment, musicology and American Indian history. It shows that no matter how hard white America tried to force Indians to be "white", they maintained their traditions even expressing them as rock-and-roll.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating insights into the real possibility of living without war in a society committed to equality. Not a utopia--just Costa Rica.

When a year in prison cost more than a year in an Ivy League college, something is deeply wrong--and even wronger when it is spent on a 13 year old juvenile offender. This documentary puts a spotlight on the pathology of those who made such a system.
Sick of those BP ads that claim everything has returned to normal? This is the film for you.
A reminder that Istanbul can be a place of great warmth and solidarity even extended to street cats.
Should be seen by all Americans as part of the necessary process of understanding Syrian refugees and why a tyranny forced millions to seek asylum.
An object lesson in avoiding stereotypes. A tattooed biker in southern Missouri looks like a Trump voter but is far more enlightened on immigrant rights than most.
Fascinating oral history about Costa Rican social history from a nonagenarian still sharp as a tack and very engaging.
Ignore the "Rottens", at least if you are a politically aware person eager to see how people of conscience dared to throw a monkey-wrench in the Nazi machine.

Vince Giordano is a national treasure dedicated to performances of classic jazz but never musty. Indeed, you feel like you have visited the 1920s in a time machine watching the Nighthawks perform. The film does his work justice.
movie_title: Vince Giordano: There's a Future in the Past (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating tale of an autodidact who died at the age of 32 leaving behind a body of work that ranks among the 20th century's most valuable.
Great story and powerful performances in a film that dramatizes a neglected aspect of the Civil Rights movement.
This is the kind of film Michael Moore has a reputation for making but does not deserve. If his latest depicted France as a liberal utopia, this one shows the grim reality--but with humor.
Four young men with Asperger's discover that comedy is the best cure for what ails them.
A bittersweet documentary about a man who lived to drive subway trains and buses under false identity, the kind of work real employees regard as oppressive.
Both a breezy entertainment and a profound statement on the pursuit of the Bitch Goddess success in American capitalists society.
Mostly of interest for chess enthusiasts, it is a fascinating study of someone as gifted as Bobby Fischer but not burdened by madness.
As much a documentary on Kurosawa, the film is a reminder of how much we have lost since the golden age of cinema was replaced by the bottom-line barbarianism of the Hollywood studios.
This film benefits from a screenplay written by David Hare, arguably Britain's finest living playwright, who eschewed holocaust film cliches.
It is the definitive film critique of pesticides that benefits from a wide array of scientific experts and activists including Weir himself who has credentials as both.
Poignant study of a Jewish writer in exile that evokes the period we are living through now.
Octopuses from outer space can't begin to compete with Klaatu or ET.

Filled with implausible incidents meant to buttress the premise that Obama was an outside to both Blacks and whites and generally devoid of any deep psychological or political insights, it is worth watching on Netflix just for laughs.
By far the most effective treatment in either documentary or narrative film of the war crimes that will be linked with Barack Obama for decades to come.
Useful survey of the left media but the notion of I.F. Stone having something in common with millionaire blue-dog Democrat Michael Moore is patently absurd.
movie_title: All Governments Lie: Truth, Deception, and the Spirit of I.F. Stone (2016)

movie_review_blurb: More like Charles Bukowski than Henry David Thoreau, the eponymous farmer featured in this brilliant film is a reminder that documentaries are often far better than narrative films in character development.

Whether your interest in Babel is purely literary or political or like mine a combination of both, this is a must-see film. It will make you want to read his great works for the first time or once again like me. A superb production.
The first film since John Huston's "Roots of Heaven" that makes you want to support sainthood for the activists trying to end elephant poaching.
A stunning achievement that despite its understandable inability to ground its critique in the capitalist system that is the root of all our problems, this film is both timely and insightful.
A reminder that volcanoes can be just as deadly as grizzly bears and just as much of an inspiration for arguably the world's greatest septuagenarian director.

An outstanding film both artistically and politically. I only wish that there were parts 3 and 4. Unique for its being made by a victim of the US made by a native of the country . Not to be missed by serious political people. My pick for best doc of 2016.
An update of "Lord of the Flies" taking place in a post-apocalyptic Detroit rather than a Pacific island. A much better example of this genre than the Mad Max franchise.
A gripping mystery story based on cultural clashes between a Dutch couple and the only family left in a farming village in Spain's beautiful but impoverished Galicia region.
Terrific story of two men and the revolutionary period they lived in made all the more powerful by their defiance of society's norms as septuagenarians.
More interesting as a portrait of James Baldwin than it is of the men he planned to write about but compelling nonetheless.
Courageous filmmaking at its best.
Despite a questionable revision of the Leskov novella upon which the film is based, a most compelling work that prioritizes mis-en-scene over dialog.
By far the best documentary on Syria to date. It deserves the widest audience given the urgent need for solidarity with a people who have been killed or displaced for demanding freedom.
movie_title: Hell on Earth: The Fall of Syria and the Rise of ISIS (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I have over 1000 reviews on Rotten Tomatoes and this is the first one that uses that overused word "inspirational". A great work for a period when the government views the film's subjects as superfluous.
This film is an unqualified masterpiece and my pick for best foreign language film of 2017. It is a throwback to the naturalist fiction of Chekhov and Zola but in cinematic terms. Bravo!
Penetrating examination of how an avant-garde artist true to the vision of the early days of the USSR collided with the reactionary "Socialist Realism" diktats of Poland's Stalinist bureaucracy.
The documentary hearkens back to Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life". I prefer the documentary.
Deeply affecting portrait of two White Helmet first responders who struggle to save the lives of victims of Russian and Baathist terror.

Does not quite get to the social contradictions of New York that have turned it into a theme park for hedge fund magnates, but it does serve to show how big capital was fought by Jane Jacobs in the early 60s.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Confused thematically but cinematically impressive. A study of obsession evocative of Herzog's "Aguirre, Wrath of God" but based on British rather than Spanish colonialism.
An absolutely devastating critique of corporate corruption in post-Communist Bulgaria. Brilliant script and performances single this film out for one of the best of 2017.
"Entertainment" oriented critics obviously were not entertained by this. If you are a thoughtful person trying to get a handle on the barbarism of the 20th century, this is a good place to start.
Despite the light-hearted and guffaw-inspiring nature of most of the film, it is also a deadly serious look at repression in Egypt and how it might crop up here in the USA as well.
A worthy addition to the genre that includes "Vernon, Florida" and "Pleasures and Plagues of the Salton Sea".
Quite simply, the greatest film about a jazz musician ever. Do not miss this story of a career cut short by a "Frankie and Johnny" tragedy.
No film in this genre comes close to "Tanna" in terms of story-telling expertise, acting by non-professionals, cinematography, music and political insight.
Nominally about whether jokes about the holocaust can be funny, it is much more an insightful look into the nature of comedy itself.
A documentary about the clash between romantic illusions in the Zionist dream of the early 50s and the ugly reality of today's Israel embodied in a family drama. Raw and realistic.
With one settler asserting that Israel is entitled to all the land between the Nile and the Euphrates, this documentary should serve as a wake-up call especially with Trump in the White House.

Yes, the film is flawed but it is still one of the most important films to see this year for its first-time look at one of the 20th century's greatest injustices that sheds light on Ukraine's current travails.

Despite its Bollywood conventions, this is not an escapist film but one that deals with a social problem facing India and the entire world: corporate environmental despoliation and the cancer epidemic
A dubious film based on a dubious novel.
The visceral excitement of "Wages of Fear" combines with a sharp critique of "Good War" mythology. Brilliant filmmaking with a moral edge.

Could an anti-Semite renounce decades of ideological zealotry and become an observant Jew after discovering that his grandmother was an Auschwitz survivor? Maybe or maybe not. The film allows you to make your own conclusion.
Did the retreat of the 60s radicalization ultimately lead to Mayer Vishner's suicide? Depression was also a factor as this deeply moving film indicates.
A briskly entertaining film about a woman who "makes it" as an entrepreneur, even if the film fosters Horatio Alger type illusions in a period of deep capitalist decline.
Despite a tendency to veer toward something out of the McDonalds PR department, a briskly entertaining look at Ray Kroc's sleazy business practices.
You'll learn more about the art of filmmaking in this documentary than from any course in the UCLA or NYU film school.
A film that makes you want to stand up and cheer at the ending, much more than the routinely "inspirational" films shown in Multiplexes.
A fascinating deconstruction of ethnographic films that still remains faithful to the genre it belongs to.
Extremely droll comedy about France's (if not the world's) most controversial novelist, who turns in a great job playing himself.
A tale that serves to subvert the romanticized version of gay life in Morocco found in Paul Bowles or William S. Burroughs.
Staggeringly beautiful movie with almost no story, a representative "New Argentine Film"
A pastiche of every horror movie you've ever seen but one that is enlivened by the screenplay written by the twin brothers who wrote the superlative 2006 remake of "House of Wax".
The latest in a string of anti-corporate dystopian films that has the evil CEO's overthrown by a superhero rather than the workers. What would Karl Marx say, I wonder?
A documentary that examines the contradictions of staging an elaborate "subversive" art festival that relies on donations from hedge fund operators. Commerce once again trumps art.
If you haven't made up your mind that big pharma is a criminal enterprise, this documentary should close the deal.
Pure film poetry woven from the daily woes and joy of a most unpoetic people.
movie_title: The Machine Which Makes Everything Disappear (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping documentary about a snitch responsible for two young men being entrapped by the FBI. In a period where federal agencies are breaking crimes left and right, a most topical offering.
The title can refer to the children whose tragic death the film is based on but more subtly on the dependency of Mounir, a North African, on his adoptive father and that of the wife on Mounir.
Works equally as social history as a survey of standup comedians of the Borscht Belt. Will be enjoyed by everybody but particularly by those who spent time in the Catskills.
A sizzling crime melodrama seemingly inspired by "The French Connection". The best Hong Kong movie I have seen in years even remarkably filmed in China.

Ignore the bad reviews from my jaded colleagues. This is not only a compelling story that goes to the heart of the immigration debate, it is a lovely work of art in the grand Italian neorealist tradition.
Orson Welles's "F for Fake" was obvious the inspiration for this film. It would have been better if the script was up Welles's more modest productions. But very few films are today unfortunately.

The film is very much in the vein of "Mad Men", laughing at the silly clothes and life-style of a past generation. Foolishly, I went expecting it to be an exploration of how computers became so good at chess.
A cynically exploitative film made in the name of human rights, which it has about as much to do with as the Punked show on MTV.

Much better than the other reviews reflect. A feel-good entertainment that sheds light on the misunderstood but heroic Sikh peoples. Now available on Netflix streaming, see for yourself and don't rely on the critics.
Exhilarating entertainment that is a great introduction to both Bollywood and the saga of the heroic Sikh people.
Unblinking study of the Oxycontin epidemic in West Virginia. Essential viewing for those who care about the transformation of the USA into a 3rd world country.

This film makes you understand why a whistle-blower like Edward Snowden emerged. The incestuous relationship between the Facebooks of the world and the NSA will certainly lead to a Stasi-like police state unless an aroused population takes action.
Soft-core Zionist propaganda in the vein of "Waltz for Bashir" or "The Gatekeepers".
Wistful look at core institution of the Black community featuring the sweet and slightly off-kilter proprietor of a Harlem funeral parlor.
More Oliver Stone than Dostoyevsky. A go for the jugular attack on Khazakstan's business/gangster ruling class.

Powerful existential drama about the tension between morality and the imperatives of warfare against the century's most immoral regime. A sign of the continuing health of Russian film after the devastating blow of Yeltsin's privatization.

Children's book author, antiwar agitator and pornographer for the carriage trade, Tomi Ungerer is one of the more interesting artists of the past half-century. Be thankful that this documentary captures his essence.
movie_title: Far Out Isn't Far Enough: The Tomi Ungerer Story (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Riveting biopic about the first target of the Israel lobby.
Gripping documentary about a young man who risked a stiff prison sentence for doing something to stop global warming, a crisis that could lead to the deaths of 100 million people.

Wang Bing is the cinematic bard of the Chinese working class and peasantry. The film is must viewing for those who want to understand the grim realities behind China's highly touted "economic miracle". In other words, their 99 percent.
Does for the world of magic what "The Wrestler" did for another profession based on illusion. Much better than "The Prestige" even though with a more modest provenance.
Not only is this movie funnier than "Shawn of the Dead", its obvious inspiration, it is proof that Cuba is not a totalitarian dungeon.
Not quite as good as "Take Shelter" but still an intriguing story with a strong performance by Matthew McConaughey.

Reminiscent in some ways of the Damien Nichols story but more about a father-daughter relationship. It also shows what a gifted conceptual artist can do, making the Whitney Biennial look like a bit of a joke.
Maudlin claptrap
This aptly titled documentary draws upon the sharp memory and deep insights of a rueful nonagenarian. It might be of most interest to political people. If that describes you, DO NOT MISS IT.
Lifetime Channel movie with paternalistic liberalism bordering on Paula Deen malignity.
Can't make it up whether it is John Le Carre or Robert Ludlum. It ends up as quite a mess.

A joyless, misanthropic 105 minutes worth of "comedy" that rates as Coen brothers at their worst. How one can take such a marvelous period and turn it into a voyage into hell is an imponderable mystery to this critic.
Brazilian film noir that evokes Jim Thompson and Patricia HIghsmith. If you are into tales of obsession and murder (who isn't?), you'll love this well-written and directed debut feature.
movie_title: A Wolf at the Door (O Lobo atrás da Porta) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Produced by ML King Jr. biographer Taylor Branch who makes the case that college athletes are like indentured servants.
movie_title: Schooled: The Price of College Sports (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Although it would have benefited from some expert testimony, the film does capture the Mexican equivalent of gangsta rap.
Braat's choices remain a mystery throughout, something that adds to the appeal of this unusual documentary.
Why preserving the Martin guitar is as important in the long run as saving the spotted owl or the snail darter.
A reminder that this zombie flick was as much a product of its time as "Easy Rider" or "The Graduate".

I wish I could rate this as "frotten" since Wiseman's filmmaking is as adept as ever, even though the politics of the film is hostile to the student movement. I guess that being lionized as a director helps dull the edges.
Visually stunning and featuring the always engaging Inuits, the film hones in on the threats to the animals they rely on for survival but all of humanity. No man is an island...
A perceptive look at how the "Ode to Joy" served as an anthem for liberation struggles, something Beethoven clearly intended as a partisan of the French Revolution.
movie_title: Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven's Final Symphony (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Not only a passionate defense of the right of a people to live according to their own culture but a dazzling look at one of Africa's most elegant tribes.
The interplay between Ginsberg and Carr characters in the first half of the film is supremely entertaining; the crime melodrama that follows much less so.

Despite the obvious enthusiasm of the screenwriter, the director, and the actors for Kerouac's novel, they get it wrong. Probably nobody can get it right, since the power is in the words, not the story.
Competent adaptation of Jack Kerouac's swan song. Those expecting a groovy good time should look elsewhere since this is a movie about a nervous breakdown.
Way too long but interesting as a lecture on film. For insights into Marxism, look elsewhere.
A reminder that the first instance of the "Arab Spring" might have occurred in Iran. A reminder that the thirst for human rights and political freedom is universal.
If John Reed had been armed with a digital camera rather than a typewriter, I doubt that he could have surpassed this masterpiece. My pick for best documentary of 2013.
A subtle trashing of Wikileaks by someone echoing the outlook of the NYT and the Guardian--anxious to make a buck off of the leaks but anxious to preserve the status quo.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A throwback to red scare movies of the 1950s with Julian Assange portrayed as the fanatical intellectual bent on destroying bourgeois society and the lives of those naive enough to follow him. Utter trash.
Seemingly inspired by "Taxi Driver" with its security guard stand-in for Travis Bickle wasting Wall Street brokers who are arguably worse than the pimps in "Taxi Driver".
Like "Gravity", a film about survival that opens to great acclaim--in this case well-deserved.
Much less than meets the eye. A victim once again of the professional critic's blurb machinery.
Cooper and Hemingway remain fascinating even if their machismo evokes a distant and depressing past.
movie_title: Cooper and Hemingway: The True Gen (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Colonialism is alive and well in Uganda. How the evangelicals use their superior wealth and power to force their sexual politics on a weaker nation.
Zhangke is a throwback to the golden age of cinema, evoking Ray, Kurosawa and Sembene. Like them, he embodies the national idiom while addressing the universal human condition.
A reminder that ecology is not just about clean air and water but the right of urban dwellers to enjoy the spiritual and esthetic benefits of liberated rivers.
Sets the standard for films about the ills of chemical farming and the need for organic alternatives. Not only is it educational in the deepest sense of the word but artistically captivating.
Deeply compassionate and artistically realized study of the Cambodian poor by a Cambodian. Remarkable testimony to the power of committed film-making.
The director stated she did not intend to make a political film. It shows.
A good first film but not quite deserving of the hype. The best parts have nothing to do with Oscar Grant's murder but the quotidian tale of survival by a young man with the best of intentions.
Tis the season of misanthropic condescension. First "Inside Lleywn Davis" and now this hateful mess.
Very informative documentary even if it allows the filthy Steve Ells of Chipotle's a platform.
The Way We Never Were (The Weather Underground never took part in armed robberies.)
Forget about your local Cineplex. This is genuine summer entertainment.
Absolutely mind-expanding look at the borderlines/tension between analog and digital in the movie world with an amazing who's who of directors involved with the transition.
Brilliant dissection of class divisions in contemporary Brazil. The condo-dwelling rich both rely on and fear the subservient. Karl Marx mixed with Ionesco.
A film in the spirit of Michael Moore's "Capitalism, a Love Story" but more attractive through its nod to the Occupy Movement rather than re-electing Obama, today's Herbert Hoover.
movie_title: Brother, Can You Spare a Dollar (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thank god that Woo left Hollywood. This is the masterpiece he was destined to make.
Far more thrilling use of an ancient weapon than anything ever seen from Sherwood Forest.
movie_title: War of the Arrows (Arrow, The Ultimate Weapon) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Both a thrilling swordplay epic as well as an intimate chamber drama about clashing filial loyalties.
Supremely entertaining documentary about the salt of the earth versus Satan.
Far more dramatic than Dragon Tattoo since it involves a real Swede against real vicious corporate pigs. The truth, of course, is always more interesting than fiction.
A worthy remake of the 1962 classic at just the right time, given the authoritarianism that led to the Fukushima disaster.
A documentary about the refusal of one woman to cater to the prejudices of Ukrainian society and an inspiration to all of us in a badly decomposing civilization.
movie_title: Family Portrait In Black And White (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Modernization is a double-edged sword as this superb documentary illustrates.
A useful reminder that China's efforts to "catch up" with the West includes a descent into savagery.
A work of enormous humanity and a reminder that anthropology textbooks are often more a study of the author's savagery than those under his microscope.
An absolutely breathtaking and politically committed chronicle of the events that continue to shake the Middle East. Documentary film-making at its pinnacle.
A model of clarity about a topic of burning urgency, namely the threat that mega-dams poses to farmers and ranchers in Chile, and the planet overall.

Delivers the goods on the incestuous relationship between the most powerful breast cancer advocacy group and the corporations that sustain it through the ill-gained profits made from spewing out carcinogens.
Rightwing idiocy. The UN has its problems but this ex-investment banker has no idea how to solve them.
A truly powerful statement on the horrors of occupation and the heart of the resistance to it.

Stunning example of the redemptive power of art. Despite his considerable disabilities, the subject of this documentary understands what goes into a powerful film. Raw, honest, and engaging, it is the definitive account of what "madness" is about.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Russian New Wave cinema at its best.
Racist and reactionary tripe whose closest relative is "Gone with the Wind".
Very topical indeed, insofar as it diagnoses the threat to the planet posed by predatory financial corporations in its insatiable desire to turn rainforests into capital.
A delicious combination of Sex and the City and a Modern Language Association convention.
Shocked at the negative reviews here. This is by far the best documentary on the beats.
Far more like Hemingway than Edward Abbey with a message that appears comfortable with species extinction than the publicity would allow you to believe. But Dafoe--as usual--makes it worthwhile.
Well, it's better than "Melancholia" but strictly for Abel Ferrara fans like me.

Despite its tendency to blame India and China more than the wealthy Western nations for the Copenhagen climate change fiasco, the documentary is a solid examination of the truly catastrophic implications of uncontrolled greenhouse gases.
A courageous statement by one of Iran's greatest directors and a powerful indictment of a state that would send him to prison for six years for simply telling the truth. A masterpiece.

A powerful documentary on the demise of the auto industry without Michael Moore's mawkish Capraesque pieties about how Barack Obama will institute a new New Deal and return the working class to its gloried past.

As an object lesson in the reactionary possibilities of a nationalist revolution, this documentary is most instructive. It is also a reminder that people of different ethnic and religious backgrounds can live together.
movie_title: Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City - 1900-1922 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Gimlet-eyed view of a legendary pioneer of "free form" radio as well as a probing examination of the Balkanization of the left.
Deeply moving although simply made documentary about 32 Iraqi orphans looked after by a man who symbolizes the sad nation's best hopes.
A great story about a great man and a reminder of why NYC remains one of the world's thriving metropolises. Hint: it makes it possible for someone like the film's subject to make a life for himself.
movie_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Both social history and a cry for social justice, this is the best documentary on society's lower depths since "Dark Days".
movie_title: Lost Angels: Skid Row Is My Home (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A landmark documentary on gay people that will become a classic like "Before Stonewall" or "The Celluloid Closet". At once a great family drama and detective story.
An all out assault on NY real estate developers and their nonstop drive to turn one of the world's great cities into a Tower of Mammon.

Next time NY won't be so lucky. A really big storm might kill thousands and leave us under water for months. This film shows us what forces are operating to make that more likely and what must be done to overcome them--starting with the Kochs.

Funny to see the rotten reviews of this film as if it were supposed to be entertaining as a romantic comedy. We are in deep shit, brothers and sisters, and this movie gives you and idea of how good people are trying to pull us out of it.
This brilliant coming-of-age story should demonstrate that Americans should be hacking Chinese computers to steal intellectual property and not the other way around--especially Hollywood.
A loving tribute to a man who taught my generation to worship art rather than mammon.
A strikingly accomplished film about worthless people.
Self-serving baloney reminiscent of Errol Morris's Robert McNamara documentary
The latest installment in an auteur's thematic: the outsider who rejects bourgeois civilization's empty pleasures. Siberia has never looked so beautiful.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Politically powerful neorealist treatment on Senegalese "boat people" done with a poet's touch.

Critics expecting something along the lines of Spielberg's dreadful "Lincoln" were bound to be disappointed but if you are looking for something more like Woody Allen (but funnier) you will love this.
A paternalistic Lincoln who freed the slaves? Bad movie and worse politics...
A passionate and even radical case for racial justice coming from Ken Burns, all the remarkably so given his "feel good" aesthetic so resonant of Steven Spielberg's narrative films.
Brilliant debut film about a landmark case on miscegenation, reminiscent in many ways of the struggle for gay marriage today.

Like last year's adaptation of Shakespeare's "Coriolanus", a film very much limited by the source material--Victor Pelevin's cult novel--that reminds me of why I try to stay away from people who want to talk about their acid trips.
Despite its length and deliberate pacing, this is a film that is cathartic like no other film I have seen in a long time. An eloquent but non-propagandistic plea for gay rights.
A film that allows Israeli military judges to hang themselves on their own petards, men who might have sent a shiver down the spine of the Nazi architects of the Nuremberg Laws.
If Black America is an internal colony, then Detroit is its epicenter. Hence, the more than coincidental ties between this powerful documentary and Pontecorvo's masterpiece.

A raw and pulsating take on the brute facts of repression in Guatemala that lives on after the dictatorship of the 1980s was dismantled from the point of view of a young artist--both the main character and the identity of the director.

An understated but effective study of the problems faced by an "illegal" returning to his village in Mexico and an implicit argument against the brutality of North American nativism, under both Bush and Obama.

Both a scholarly and entertaining look at the good people who brought the "one percent" to its feet through what amounted to the electronic version of sit-in's at segregated lunch counters in the 1960s.
movie_title: We Are Legion: The Story of the Hacktivists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Like Harvey Pekar and Spalding Gray, Ross McElwee makes art out of the often sad and desperate moments of his life. And like them, he is damned good at it.
So Obama is bringing socialism to America by 2016? That would explain why Bain Capital is making bigger donations to him than to its founder Mitt Romney.
A marriage made in hell between bad politics and bad art.
A powerful, timely and brilliant examination of the new economic apartheid that has beset South Africa and the inspiring struggle against it.
Although owing a bit too much to a Travel Channel episode, this is a valuable look at a country undergoing important and necessary changes.
movie_title: They Call It Myanmar: Lifting The Curtain (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A timely exploration of the damage done to people in spectator sports just one step above what took place in the coliseums of another Empire in its decline.
Searing, Guernica-like evocation of the brutal war against Palestinian civilians by a rogue state.
More Jean-Claude Van Damme than Woody Guthrie or John Steinbeck. And not very good Van Damme at that.
A scientific/philosophical/religious meditation on Time. That's something you don't see in a movie theater routinely, all the more compelling since it is visually rewarding as well.
The film towers over all the Hollywood animated films about ogres, monsters, and archfiends like Mount Everest over an ants' nest. Japanese animation at its pinnacle.
movie_title: Okami kodomo no ame to yuki (The Wolf Children Ame and Yuki) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If it is a question of the survival of the pelican and outfits like BP, I'll go with the pelican. A lyrical and forceful plea for a most photogenic and charismatic creature.
More interesting for its insights into East German society than as film art. Worth it for those trying to make sense of an end to the "End of History" nonsense defended by Francis Fukuyama.
Leaving aside the flaws as film (underdeveloped characters, etc.), it is worse as a message. Deriding agriculture and hyping space exploration is even more fascist than "The Dark Knight Rises".
A brilliant mixture of Godard and Italian neorealism conveying a message drawn from Franz Fanon's writings. If that means anything to you, do not miss this film.
Whatever motivation Matt VanDyke had for fighting in Libya, his example is far more laudable than what American fighting men do in the name of "defending democracy".
Confirmation that for 90 percent of human history greed and violence were unknown.
movie_title: The Hadza: Last Of The First (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This documentary shows how Great Depression-like conditions have changed consciousness in a Pennsylvania town that in the past would have inspired a Norman Rockwell painting.
Don't bother with this baloney. Watch a good Korean movie like "I Saw the Devil" to see how a revenge movie is done right.
Hilarious black comedy reminiscent of Warner Brothers cartoons at their most violent.
Fascinating documentary about the Russian hockey team that reflected Communism at its best and worst.

Despite his reputation as an action film star, Renner plays a character whose enemies are the Washington Post and a cowardly management at his own paper. The drama is over the struggle to get out the truth, a permanent part of our culture.
A documentary about the love of baseball in a region of India that is a cauldron of resistance to colonialism. What's not to like?
Despite an unfortunate MTV aesthetic, this documentary puts a spotlight on government harassment of young men and women with nothing else on their mind except defending freedom.
A decidedly noncommercial film about the courage of a newspaperman who was a real contrast to the inside-the-beltway hacks of today, anxious to justify every war that comes along.
Poses important philosophical questions through essentially a two character staged play. Not exactly historically accurate but a serious and thoughtful film not to be missed.
A gimlet-eyed look at "free" Romania where the market dictates how people live--often just one step of the poorhouse--rather than the secret police.
If you've ever played chess, you'll appreciate the dedication that the film's blind protagonist devote to the only sport that sharpens the brain rather than destroys it.
The reference to Dante might be obvious even if the USA is no paradise for the undocumented workers crossing the border.
movie_title: Purgatorio: A Journey Into the Heart of the Border (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A likable film more in the spirit of "Footloose" than agitprop. A reminder of the powerful solidarity that was possible in an era far removed from our own ugly, profit-driven world.
The best work that the Dardennes have done, a study of the Hobson's Choices facing workers in a period of wanton ruling class greed.
Altina Schinasi was like Peggy Guggenheim-a member of the Jewish haut bourgeoisie who opted for a bohemian life in the arts. Jewish cultural history of a key but neglected figure.
Although the LSD no-hitter was likely never to have happened, there are enough wild stories about a 60s wild man to keep you captivated.
Fascinating account of the moral and scientific failings of New York's famous cancer hospital and research center, where I worked in the 1980s.
A modern twist on the King Lear tragedy. Captures the rhythms of farm life as much as any documentary, depicting a way of life fast disappearing.
Very stylish Sicilian mafia movie. One part Antonioni and one part Calvin Klein commercial.
Brutally realistic prison melodrama without pat answers.
Quite simply, the greatest documentary about musicians I have ever seen. Informed historically and sociologically, it is also the ultimate hootenanny.

The swan song in an illustrious career. With its reference to Thomas Mann's "Magic Mountain", this is obviously a film geared to adults. But bring the kids since they will be enchanted by the airplanes, just as I was.
A quite exciting spectacle based on a racist version of indigenous history, one in which the genocidal conquistadors are the New World's liberators.
Death Metal comes to war-torn Angola, an expression of the good side of globalization.
Only for those addicted to video games and the Transformer series. The original was bright, funny and inventive. The sequel not so.
So an audience needs to be persuaded that Ahmadinejad and his goons are evil? Talk about breaking down an open door, not to speak of Obama's crackdown on our own investigative reporters.
Reminiscent of Michael Moore's search for Roger Smith, arguably a more toxic figure than Shorty Guzman
movie_title: Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Strictly for Refn fans, especially those like me trying to figure out where he went astray.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Cronenberg's films are always interesting to look at even when hobbled by a so-so script. Interesting that the screenwriter lets the studio brass off the hook, which indicates a certain tameness.
Totally unbalanced film. The North Vietnamese army becomes the symbol of invading barbarians when as Walt Kelly put it, "We have met the enemy, and he is us."
Brilliant stroke to have a nebbish carrying out a one-man vendetta against a gang of bad guys rather than a Charles Bronson retread.
Mostly for those who have the superior taste and intelligence to be Mads Mikkelsen fans.
In an age of incestuous ties between the Pentagon and Hollywood that produces films like "American Sniper", thank god for the Estonians who remind us of what a horror war is.
A film that despite its obvious religious overtones is much more about the hell of relationships based on commodities rather than sin.
Deeply pessimistic but cinematically radiant take on the futility of existence.
Both a powerful statement for animal rights as well as a metaphorical commentary on the rise of racism in Hungary today.
A brilliant and idealistic soul sacrificed at the altar of Barack Obama's war on intellectual and political transparency.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Very informative documentary about the corporatization of the academy, drawing from experts as well as boneheaded libertarians like Peter Thiel who hoists himself on his own petard.
A film that wisely allows the audience to understand the character's motivations rather than having them telegraphed. An art film in the best sense of the word.

A film in which a dying lake becomes a symbol of India's environmental crisis as well as of Kashmiri hopes for freedom. But it is not so much a political film as a deeply realized drama about the human condition.

A stunning achievement and an interesting comparison to Spielberg's "Lincoln", a film that gave short shrift to Black self-emancipation, something that attests to the need for Black directors like Ava DuVernay.
A film of monumental stupidity. If the Rand Corporation served as a consultant, no wonder American imperialism is messing up everywhere.
Canny cinema verite representation of the Euromaidan struggle, one that allows Ukrainians to be put into the foreground rather than geopolitical abstractions.
Thrilling reminder that people are ready to die for their ideals in a period of history when corruption and brutality run rampant, starting with the White House.
A work that rivals great literary masterpieces of years past, especially Chekhov's plays but with the added visual dimension of someone who has a painterly eye. Superlative filmmaking.
An utter failure to understand Brown's legacy as well as a misbegotten use of flashbacks like a time-machine gone haywire.
If you are interested, even slightly, in what distinguished Alan Turing, this is not the film for you. It has about as much to do with his contributions to automation as does a Judd Apatow movie.
If you are interested, even slightly, in what distinguished Stephen Hawking, this is not the film for you. It has about as much to do with his theoretical breakthroughs as does a Judd Apatow movie.
A match made in heaven between avant-garde jazz and avant-garde cinema.
A reminder that character is the heart of drama, even in a documentary made on a shoestring.
Worth watching even if it fails to deal with the paper's troubled relationship to the power elite that effectively makes it our Pravda.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The real scandal at the NYT is not Jayson Blair's plagiarism but the paper of record's incestuous relationship to the military-industrial complex.
movie_title: A Fragile Trust: Plagiarism, Power And Jayson Blair At The New York Times (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Astonishing work of art that both expresses and transcends the 'anime' genre. Made by a 79 year old director, it is a film for the ages.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A great satire against monarchic pretensions by artists reared in the 1930s agitprop tradition.
Carries on in the grand Bob Clampett Warner Brothers "Porky in Wackyland" tradition. Surrealism for the six year old and the sixty year old.
Quite simply the greatest film every made about the art of photography.
Don't pay attention to the NY Times review. They didn't care for Occupy Wall Street either--the action itself, not any film.
An extraordinary summer blockbuster that reprises the fatal encounter of European colonizers with Native Americans and George Orwell's "Animal Farm".
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Reminiscent of the struggle between the Charlie Sheen and Tom Berenger characters in "Platoon" but even more powerful since it shuns sensationalism and sticks to the brutal story of how the American military became a death squad.

Gets past the Joe Six-Pack, NASCAR fan stereotypes and shows you how ordinary working class people work and play. Given the deepening class divisions in the USA, a film that illuminates how people survive psychologically.
Totally thrilling documentary about a topic that might have been distinctly unthrilling. Great work from its physicist producer and director.
A view of India that is a corrective to the "economic miracle" mythology promoted in the corporate media presented in powerful neorealist terms.

A powerful tale of two young people relying on the kindness of a disenchanted professor to escape the vendetta of a backward Turkish village. Based on a novel by one of Turkey's greatest progressive minds.
A road movie through liberated Kurdish territory in northern Iraq. The personality of the wonderful Kurdish people shines through.
Brilliant comedy about a serious question: forced marriage and physical abuse of women in Kurdish society. Director Rosebiani edifies while he entertains. A must-see.
A zombie movie in which the normal people are to be feared. Modest in scope, but very effective.

Ignore the one obviously Zionist "rotten" below. This is a terrific documentary about the resistance to a vulgar and soulless gentrification of a beautiful and historic old city. The story of Zionist brutality in a microcosm.
Despite its "The Defiant Ones" liberal Zionist pieties, there's solid drama and performances.
A dream-like collage of the Palestinian experience focused on its artist lead character. An art movie in the best sense of the term.
Has all the electricity of a Jason Bourne movie but the truth of the Palestinian people suffering under a brutal occupation. Not to be missed.
A thought experiment about who gets picked to survive a nuclear Armageddon. Intelligent dialog about utilitarian ethical choices.
A charming mash-up of a Guy Ritchie style crime caper movie and Italian neorealism about the Paraguayan poor.
A profoundly important subject--the "repressed memories" witch-hunts--dramatized superbly with a top-notch cast. Deserves not only best foreign picture of the year award, but best picture period.
The artistic achievements and personal torments of one of Latin America's greatest vocal artists and the conscience of her continent.
movie_title: Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Battle scenes have about as much realism as "Kill Bill". Politics are vintage Chuck Norris/Sylvester Stallone.

X-Files style horror movie based on MK-Ultra drug experiments. Ted Levine as a Hunter Thompson character is superb. On a budget, the film is a lot scarier than most of the more expensive "apparition" type movies showing up at the Cineplex.
Marred by unlikely coincidences that rob the film of realist foundations, it is still worth watching for its confrontation with Germany's barbaric past.
A neorealist jewel about a country unlucky enough to enjoy being "liberated" from socialism.
Stunning mixture of understated social criticism and minimalism a la Kurismaki.
Casting Christian Bale as a Bronx Jew makes as much sense as casting Woody Allen as a Baptist minister from Alabama, not that casting Woody Allen in Bale's role would have saved this mess of a film.
The director of this film plagiarized "Goodfellas" but did a poor job. Not half as interesting as the original.
As a long-time leftist, I expected something like "Norma Rae". It was much more Harry Potter or Twilight.

While the film leaves out the civil rights movement that played a role in making Branch Rickey's mind up that segregated baseball was done, it is still first-rate. Family entertainment of the best kind.
A great story as well as the greatest pairing of a male nonbeliever an a female believer since "The African Queen".
Overlong, self-indulgent garbage with a portrayal of a "house Negro" that is a grotesque distortion of a sad reality.

Two hours of torture and degradation were done much better in "Saw" or "Hostel". This is not a Major Statement about slavery but one about a visual artist's preoccupation with pain--just like his misbegotten "Hunger".
A kindred spirit to "Offside" and "Persepolis", this film is ten times more inspiring than "Breakaway", another tale of an underdog and a bicycle. A must-see.
Not just deserving of an Oscar for best foreign film of 2013 (Iran's official nominee) but best picture--period.
A documentary that evokes Robert Bresson and a welcome sign that Polish cinema might be going through some kind of renaissance. Pure poetry using the humblest of human material.
A film that despite its modest means tells a stirring tale about sports and politics. Starring Kevin Sheppard, a completely winning personality and basketball player.

A documentary about the Turk-Greek population exchange of the 1920s that impacts both the mind, the heart and the eye. A stunning treatment of a theme that has universal meaning: how the nation-state can turn toxic.
movie_title: From Both Sides Of The Aegean: Expulsion And Exchange Of Populations, Tukey-greece 1922-1924 (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hauntingly beautiful film about two lost souls seeking redemption in the ruggedly beautiful mountains of the Black Sea region in Turkey. Art film at its best.
A loving tribute by an Arab director to Egypt's "rootless cosmopolitans".
More than meets the eye. It is not just about the need to legalize a harmless weed but also about the divisions in the pro-legalization community on how to do it right.
movie_title: Evergreen: The Road to Legalization in Washington (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In a way, it makes as much sense to review this like any other movie as it does to review a mass demonstration or a strike. If you understand the film's political importance, you understand the need to see it and recommend it widely.
Like Ishmael, the sole survivor of the encounter with Moby Dick, the German banker who is the film's only subject tells a tale of another great disaster.
A home invasion movie that is more Godard than grindhouse, and a brilliant one at that.
An idiotic film about ecoterrorism without bothering to engage with ecology. Ms. Reichardt should stick to the kind of mumblecore she adopted early on unless she bothers to do her homework.
Silly critics expected "Braveheart" when it was more like Ingmar Bergman's "Virgin Spring". Ignore the shallow minds; this is a serious art film worthy of your attention if you have an IQ over 80.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Magical realism without the magic. Wonderment comes from rural people (and goats, chicken, and cattle) being themselves--caught in the moment by a director with an affinity for ordinary people.
Much better than the first in the series. In fact, it was better as action and better as social commentary. If like me you go with few expectations, you will be delighted.
Nothing can top the original. This one is geared to the teenaged audience brought up on video games. Instead of a meditation on nuclear perils, it is "Transformers" type junk.
Probably the only good thing to come out of the Palestinian dispossession is a long list of great films, and this is one of the greatest among them.
A film that demonstrates that there is hope for independent filmmaking in the USA. A humanist masterpiece that eschews market gimmicks like mumblecore or "edgy" sexual perversions.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A visually stunning, superbly acted film with an intelligent and timely screenplay about the right of the human being to make the ultimate decision: ending one's life.

A taut thriller about honor killings that is marred by plot improbables. Saved by Paddy Considine's customary fine performance as well as a strong lead character, a young woman fighting against patriarchal chains.

The finest documentary about an artist I have ever seen. Folkes is an original and every minute spent in his company will remind you why true geniuses have a hard time in an art world more commodified than McDonalds fast food.
Not without its problems, but anything done by Atom Egoyan is worth seeing.

A film compromised to some extent by its emphasizing of human melodrama rather than social and political issues that figure in the novel it is based on. But it still a gripping story about people caught up in a civil war sadly typical of Africa today.
A loving tribute to a leftie and a comedian that Lenny Bruce counted as one of his major influences.
Ignore the jaded Village Voice critic. This is a compelling story about the key question of our age: the right of indigenous peoples to live in peace and freedom.
Worth seeing but marred by its refusal to ask tough questions.

With blood on his hands rather than a glass of Pinot Noir, Church brilliantly plays the same kind of likeable loser he played in "Sideways". This is a brilliant deconstruction of the criminal on the lam genre and a must-see.
A refreshing account of what it means to be a young musician more committed to an artistic vision than "making it".
Cinematically and philosophically daring, this is a reworking of the flood story that speaks to 21st century realities and that will make you think hard about "the Creator's" capriciousness.
A travelogue focused on various bodies of water (lakes, rivers, oceans, and underground aquifers) threatened by capitalist development.
Even if you've never made a leaflet or used a bullhorn, this stirring documentary will make you understand and appreciate what it means to be a revolutionary.
movie_title: American Revolutionary: The Evolution Of Grace Lee Boggs (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Although marred by a weak script and an obtrusive film score, this film is saved by its theme, namely the Palmer Raids of 1919 that was a precursor to the abuse of democratic rights happening right now.
A narrative film from Venezuela that leads one to conclude that racism and homophobia remain in a country that is moving in radical new directions.
The perfect answer to those disgusting BP commercials about how the Gulf Coast "is back" and the equally disgusting full-page NYT ads screaming about how BP is being extorted by lawyers.
movie_title: Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen Of Pointe A La Hache (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A typically witless comedy from Wes Anderson that has about as much to do with Stefan Zweig as it does with WWII and Nazism, the disasters that led to Zweig's suicide in 1942. A total travesty.
Don't pay attention to the "rotten" reviews. This film is a real homage to Stefan Zweig, as opposed to Wes Anderson's witless "Grand Budapest Hotel".

Not an advocacy film in the conventional sense but one that deals with the ethical and spiritual paradoxes of Italy's version of the Terri Schiavo controversy. Brilliant filmmaking as always from Bellocchio.
Nauseating claptrap that allows a war criminal to waste 103 minutes of our time and over $10 of our hard-earned money in self-justification. Errol Morris should be ashamed of himself.
It had all the infectiousness and emoji-big smiles you need from three hours of live musical entertainment.
The formula of the show is well set: uncanny impressions, relentless passive aggression and a surprising amount of pathos, this time all soused in vino tinto.
Classy and solidly watchable in an HBO kind of way, it nevertheless offered a few bizarre turns.

Pharmacy Road is a tasteless send-up, and that's fine -- but it shows a really astounding lack of taste to make a spoof about a rather lovely historic event killed by doping, then to invite the main murderer to dance on the grave.
It was a full portrait of the artist, if not of the man.
It's hopefully not too backhanded a compliment to say that it really made me want to read the book.
The transformation, when it comes, is sensational, and all the more agonising because it is never absolute
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhere amid the cacophony, a human drama emerges that is sensitive, expertly orchestrated,
